Unlike the situation which prevailed before the board of the General Motors Corporation proposed a two-for-one split-up of the common stock on June 5, Wall Street was expecting the similar split recommended yesterday by directors of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company. General Motors' action...

From the rail of the outbound transport Gen. S.D. Sturgis a knot of tired world-travelers yesterday watched the Statue of Liberty shrink in the distance. Headed for a displaced persons camp in Germany, they blunted their disappointment with guesses of how soon they might return to the United States.

NONVEINUK, Alaska, June 21 --The outlet of Nonveinuk seems to be a concentration point for large rainbows and mackinaws. Although both feed heavily on the sockeye fingerlings that are moving through, the rainbows respond readily to wet flies and streamers.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 21--The number of juvenile delinquents committed by the courts to New York's state institutions has risen 40 per cent in the last six months, Deputy Commissioner Raymond W. Houston of the state Department of Social Welfare reported today.
CAIRO, June 21--The Arab states pledged themselves today to maintain peace and not to use for aggressive purposes arms obtained from the Western Big Three or other powers.
Macy's and Local 1-S, independent, representing the department store's employes, have agreed to a two-year contract extension, the union and management announced yesterday.
Directors of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company of Youngstown, Ohio, yesterday raised the dividend on the common stock and recommended a two-for-one split-up of the shares.
WOODSTOCK, N.Y., June 21-- Charles Rosen, landscape and stilllife painter, died in Kingston Hospital today. His age was 72.

The Institute of Life Insurance will open a campaign next week that is designed to help protect the buying power of savings, with the curring slogan, "Remember, It's Your Money." The campaign originally was planned for the fall but is considered of particular timeliness now.
BALBOA, C.Z., June 21--Gov. Francis K. Newcomer left by plane today to attend Congressional hearings on reorganization and incorporation of the Panama Canal.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 21-- Jane Powell is expected to take over the role in Metro-GoldwynMayer's "Royal Wedding" from which Judy Garland withdrew. Miss Garland was suspended from salary by the studio last week-end.

JERUSALEM, June 21--An opposition motion for a full-dress debate on the New Jerusalem plan, which the Israeli Government submitted to the United Nations, was defeated today in the Knesset (Parliament) by 47 votes to 27.

LONDON, June 21--Running counter to the Labor Government's policy of relaxing economic controls, the annual conference of the National Federation of Building Workers voted unanimously today for the "nationalization of the building industry as a general policy."

A ban on advertising which exploits the misconduct of film personalities was adopted yesterday by the Motion Picture Association of America. The action, which was unanimously voted by the board of directors, followed in the wake of criticism by public officials, members ...

WASHINGTON, June 21--The authorities will be sought in vain to determine what there is about Ohio that produces so many non-conformists who have successfully practiced politics, a trade where regularity is generally acknowledged to be the most reliable rule for self-preservation.
John L. Turnbull of 399 Park Avenue, vice president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 55.
The Singer Manufacturing Company reported yesterday a slight improvement in earnings for 1949 with a net of $15,453,850 after taxes and all charges. In 1948 the company earned $15,169,778.

Four men went to the workhouse for thirty days each and two others received six-month suspended sentences yesterday in Special Sessions on their pleas of guilty to fraudulent impersonations in connection with civil service examinations.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 21 --John Nicholas Brown's year-old yawl Bolero, longest by a few inches of all the record fleet of fifty-four yachts in the race of 635 miles from Newport, R.I., was first to arrive and cross the finish line at St. David's Head this afternoon.
Community teamwork is needed to conquer tuberculosis, the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association declared yesterday.

Eighty-five food writers tucked away enough information last evening--not to mention corn, clams, chicken and lobster--to enable them to answer a summerful of reader questions on how to conduct a clambake.

PARIS, June 21--The French Foreign Ministry said today that France would propose to the United States and Britain that they declare that the state of war with Germany ended June 5, 1945, the date when the Allied commanders formally imposed the terms of surrender on Germany and assumed joint control of that country.

Because of numerous complaints by food distributors over variations in the size of premium coupons, a uniform size will be adopted soon. Food manufacturers have agreed that coupons should be of uniform thickness and approximately the size of United States currency. This will facilitate handling at all trade levels, they explained.

PARIS, June 21--Jean Monnet, principal author of the Schuman plan, announced today that the French had modified their proposal so that the decisions of the "high authority" to be created would be subject to parliamentary as well as judiciary review.

The defeat in the Australian Senate yesterday of the Government's bill outlawing communism emphasizes an important problem that all democracies face today. A similar measure in South Africa has proved one of the most contentious measures faced by a Parliament that has been noted for its disputes.

WASHINGTON, June 21-- Charges that the Federal Tariff Commission has been "lax, remiss and inattentive" in failing to determine whether Canadian newsprint mills have been guilty of monopolistic practices were contained in a letter sent to President Truman tonight by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York.

HONG KONG, June 21--Nationalist planes strafed two British merchantmen and one small coasting vessel opposite Formosa today as the survivors of yesterday's two sinkings, by what appeared to be mines, reached Shanghai.

A zoning amendment requiring that in the future garage or parking space in varying degrees must be provided with nearly all types of housing construction was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission at City Hall.

IN the late and eloquently lamented Nineteen Twenties Vina Delmar wrote "Bad Girl," a novel that shocked and delighted so many people that it set the Literary Guild on the highroad to prosperity. The trend-trundlers said it was A Great Sociological Document; the Boston carabinieri said it was wicked; the "Oxford Companion to American Literature" thought the ...

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Cecilia Leary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick John Leary of 320 Park Avenue, to Noel Raphael Ryan, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Matthew W. Ryan, took place yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

LONDON, June 21--The stock market here took on a brighter appearance today and modest rises were recorded in most sections. The election of S. Ralph Lazrus as chairman and Oscar M. Lazrus as president of Benrus Watch Company was announced yesterday. Benjamin Lazrus was also elected treasurer and Julian Lazrus was re-elected secretary.

CHICAGO, June 21--Corn continued to show the way in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, although closing trades were somewhat irregular, with corn 5/8 to 1 7/8 cents higher, while oats, which have been showing strength of late, finished 3/8 to 5/8 cent lower.

BILBAO, Spain, June 21--Generalissimo Francisco Franco completed a four-day round of official inspections, visits and dinners here tonight with what must be put down in the political accounts as a triumph for him.
How shall home cooks present fish this summer, when the fresh variety is at its annual peak in supply and meat at its annual peak in price?

For no very good reason, George D. Widener's Sungari, winner of the filly division of the National Stallion Stakes in her last previous start, was only the fourth choice in the $12,800 Astoria Stakes at...
The new Federal Maritime Board is being organized on a long-range and permanent basis under circumstances that augur well for the future of the country's shipping.

Twenty local civic associations, organized as the Midtown Expressway Committee, announced yesterday that they would finance a private study of a mid-Manhattan underpass linking the East and West Sides of Manhattan Island.

WASHINGTON, June 21--Representative Frank Buchanan, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said today he would ask the House Lobby Investigating Committee, of which he is chairman, to summon Irenee and Lammot du Pont to testify on their connection with the National Economic Council.

All segments of the rayon textile industry will meet next month to formulate a promotion program for their product, it was learned yesterday. Yarn producers, weavers, converters and finishers have indicated agreement on the need for an over-all plan of strategy to ...

BERLIN, June 21 (AP)--Deputy Premier Walter Ulbricht of the Soviet-dominated East German regime announced in Prague today that his Government would renounce all claims for 2,000,000 Germans to live in the Sudetenland.
Besides honoring President Truman, members of the Press Photographers Association of New York "shot" one another and their wives last night.

WASHINGTON, June 21--The House of Representatives and Senate gave final approval today to a bill providing a straight extension of Federal rent control to Dec. 31, with an additional six months of regulation for communities asking it.
ALBANY, June 21--The State Education Department announced today the names of 1,654 high school pupils who won university scholarships as a result of a special scholarship examination last March.

PITTSBURGH, June 21 (AP)--A Federal grand jury today returned indictments against a manufacturer of gas refrigerators, and twelve other persons, firms and corporations, charging them with violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP)--Billy Pierce pitched the White Sox to a 3-1 victory over the Red Sox today, yielding seven hits. It was his fifth triumph.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)-- Over the strong protests of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, the Senate today approved a bill toning down a penalty provision in the Hatch "clean politics" act.
GENEVA, June 21 (UP)--Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, predicted today that the United States would never suffer another major depression.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 21--Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, Foreign Minister of Pakistan, and Nasrollah Entezam, Iranian representative to the United Nations, have entered the race for President of the General Assembly next September.

Why go to school if school will beat a path to your wheel chair? That's what 13-year-old Sandra Faye Helton asked yesterday when classmates and teachers from her Montville, N.J., school flocked into New York's Hospital for Special Surgery to present a diploma from the eighth grade.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)-- New York State pleaded with the Federal Power Commission today for authority to harness the hydroelectric resources of the St. Lawrence River. Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer opposed the proposal, asking that it be turned down--as recommended previously by a commission examiner.
Hunter College granted 1,113 degrees to the largest graduating class in its eighty-year history last night at the ninety-eighth semiannual commencement exercises.

An expedition to Africa in search of seeds yielding precious chemicals that can be converted into cortisone, the hormone offering dramatic relief from rheumatoid arthritis and other crippling ills, has returned after a six-month survey.

CHICAGO, June 21--The country's 300 Class I railroads tonight were confronted with strike threats served within a few hours by three unions. If carried out, the strikes would paralyze the rail transportation systems and imperil the national economy.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 5 --The Soviet Union has under way in Central America a long-range program for penetrating interAmerican defenses in the strategic Panama Canal region and shattering continental unity.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 21-- Miss Evelyn Odom of Wheatley Hills and Mrs. Percy Uris of Inwood defeated the strong team of Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century and Mrs. J.B. Balding of The Creek, 2 and 1, in the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's four-ball best-ball tournament over the Sunningdale course today.

Officials of the Rockville Centre Bus Corporation cited decreases in revenue and passengers yesterday as reasons for seeking an increase in fares and a reduction of service. The service covers Rockville Centre, and the adjacent areas of Hempstead, Lynbrook, Valley Stream and Long Beach.

Service on the Long Island Rail Road's Port Washington branch will be reduced somewhat when summer schedules go into effect on Sunday. Non-rush-hour trains will leave Pennsylvania Station for Port Washington, and Port Washington ...

WASHINGTON, June 21--Senate investigators will close on Sunday night their two-month examination of eighty-one confidential State Department loyalty files and will return them at once to the Administration.

DETROIT, June 21--A jurisdictional strike that has closed the Canton, Ohio, forge plant of the Ford Motor Company threatens to shut down Ford operations throughout the country, company officials said today.

DETROIT, June 21 (AP)--The Senators hit hard and often behind Sandalio Consuegra's five-hit pitching as they downed the Tigers, 12--4, today for their second straight victory over the American League leaders.

An interim fare of 8 cents, effective July 1, on the lines of nine private bus companies now charging 7 cents was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate at an executive session in Mayor O'Dwyer's office at City Hall.

MADISON, Wis., June 21-- Spokesmen for six farm programs defended them against criticisms from a panel of experts here today in a symposium arranged by the National Creameries Association to clarify "unprecedented dissension" on farm programs.

WASHINGTON, June 21--The National Labor Relations Board refused today to assert jurisdiction in a construction-industry case on the ground that the contractors' business had "a very remote and insubstantial effect on commerce." The board divided 4 to 1.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 21--Gov. Frank J. Lausche, Ohio's politically independent Democratic Governor, today was chosen chairman of the annual Governor's Conference, which also expressed its gratitude to Secretary of State Dean Acheson for his discussion of foreign affairs.
LONDON, June 21 (AP)--Two ranking American women players lost in upsets in the Lodon lawn tennis championships today but three United States netmen moved up another round.

UPPER BROOKVILLE, L.I., June 21--In the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, Miss Lucetta Gilbert Crisp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Van Devanter Crisp of Hillandale and 33 East Seventieth Street, New York, was married ...

King Paul and Queen Frederica of Greece have expressed a desire to visit the United States and preparations for their trip already may be under way, it was said here yesterday by Dr. Athanasios G. Politis, newly appointed Greek Ambassador to Washington.
Store salespeople are too independent, and cannot forget the big commissions they made in the '40s, according to B. Earl Puckett, president of the Allied Stores Corporation, department store chain.

David S. Meister has sold the two-Story building at 83 South Main Street in Freeport, L.I., containing three stores, two apart ments and an office, to the Standard Realty Corporation. The building occupies a plot 50 by 168 feet in the block between Merrick Road and Sunrise Highway.

James Amarante's stubborn attitude before Brooklyn's racketinvestigating grand jury became more pronounced when the District Attorney's office sought to link him with the activities of the brother of Joe Adonis, big-time gambler.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 21.-- The controversial problem of Lutheran unity took precedence over all other issues here today as the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod opened its triennial national convention at Concordia College.

WASHINGTON, June 21--The House approved and sent to the Senate today the final draft of a bill to make an additional $2,000,000,000 available to the Commodity Credit Corporation for supporting farm prices. The vote was 235 to 81.

CLIMAX, N.Y., June 21--To most folks a cave is just a hole in the ground, but to a speleologist a cave is a magnificent subterranean temple in which the mysteries of nature may be worshiped and is one of the very finest places to spend a pleasant summer afternoon, lying flat on your back in a puddle of water far underground.

W. Paul Jones, president of Servel, Inc., of Evansville, Ind., announced here yesterday that his company's first national sales drive in marketing a single-unit heater and air conditioner will start July 1. At a luncheon at the Biltmore Hotel, attended by more than 170 ...

WASHINGTON, June 21--The Senate deleted today from its bill to extend the Selective Service system for another three years a proposal that inductees and new enlistees be permitted to signify that they would only serve in military units with men of their own race. The vote was 42 to 29.

The shift of thirteen hearing examiners from the Immigration and Naturalization Service to a semiindependent status in the same capacities by the Civil Service Commission was in effect challenged yesterday by a lawyer at a deportation hearing.

Fifty members of the Park Association of New York and their guests took their interest in developing the city's natural recreational facilities to Staten Island yesterday. There they made a forty-mile tour of Richmond's parks, parkways and playgrounds, with time off for visits to points of historical interest.

DENVER, June 21 (AP)--Led by Miss Betty MacKinnon of Dallas, Tex., the amateurs roared back in the women's Western Open golf tournament today, eliminated the defending champion and took five of the eight quarter-final spots.

WASHINGTON, June 21--St. Alban's Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Nancy Louise Misson, daughter of Rear Admiral clinton Alonzo Misson, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Misson, to George Randolph Cooper Jr., son of Rear Admiral Cooper, U.S.N., now stationed in Paris, and Mrs. Cooper of Paris, and Charles Town, W. Va.
The cotton futures market closed 22 to 43 points net higher with a moderate volume of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The United Nations will tomorrow lose one of its most brilliant and effective servants when Sir Alexander Cadogan, Britain's representative to the Security Council, sails for home. That great venture in world cooperation is in a parlous state, and if Sir Alexander has any regrets today it ...

LONDON, June 21--Britain recognized Communist China primarily to protect her own interests there, but, incidentally the action put her in a position to assist the United States as well. In many little ways Britain has been able to help the United States, which has no diplomatic representation there.
One of the better Broadway money makers, "Mister Roberts," will lay off for four weeks this summer to afford its star, Henry Fonda, a well-earned rest.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21-- Ira Godin didn't need them, but Harvard got him ten runs in the second inning, and the righthander followed through by limiting Yale to three hits as the Crimson beat the Elis, 17--3, at Soldiers Field today.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 21--A stock colony of germ-free animals for scientific research was begun today at dedication ceremonies for a new germ-free laboratory in the Laboratories of Bacteriology at the University of Notre Dame.

Kirby Higbe's quiet campaign for a chance as a Giant starting pitcher came to fruition yesterday at the Polo Grounds, with results that were harrowing. In a weak moment Manager Leo Durocher consented to try the experiment against, of all people, the Cardinals.

Mayor O'Dwyer disclosed yesterday that plans were under way for a series of softball games between the City Councils of New York and Chicago. They would be played for charity on a home-and-home basis.

Just when Manager Barney Shotton had thought that his pitching worries were a thing of the past, poor hurling again bobbed up to plague the Dodgers yesterday. Don Newcombe tottered in the ninth and Jack Banta and Bud Pocbielan failed miserably in relief, with the result that the Brooks, ...

All efforts to effect their immediate admission to this country as immigrants having failed, the little company of 106 men, women and children who have already crossed two continents and an ocean in their search for a haven resumed their travels yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 21--Spokesmen for larger home furnishings and department stores today indicate that buying at the Summer Home Furnishings Market here by these outlets has been exceptionally light. Purchasing, it was said, has up to now reversed glowing pre-...
AUSTIN, Tex., June 21 (AP)-- Two upsets trimmed the number of seeded singles players to five in the National Collegiate A.A. tennis tournament today. Rain canceled the second round of doubles.

WASHINGTON, June 21--The House Committee on Un-American Activities voted today to speed up court tests of how far a witness might go in refusing to answer questions without being in contempt of Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 21--The Air Force moved closer today to ward realization of the seventygroup size that more than one student of air power and national security has called the minimum "safe" peacetime strength.
Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, told twenty internes yesterday that he would recommend the dismissal of any docotr on the city payroll who "is an active Communist."
CLEVELAND, June 21--The Yankees ran head-on today into the second superb pitching performance of the trip and lost by 5--1 to the Indians.
The Pennsylvania General State Authority borrowed yesterday $65,000,000 on revenue-secured bonds maturing serially from 1953 to 1977 at an interest cost of 1.8414237 per cent.

The organization and state of training of United States Army units in this country have been improved and strengthened considerably in the last year, though few if any units are ready for instant action.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 21-- Long-hitting Melvin (Chick) Harbert, a finalist in the 1947 tourney, today shared honors at the end of the initial eighteen-hole qualifying round of the National Professional Golfers Association championship at the Scioto Country Club with Marty Furgol, who registers from Albuquerque, N.M.

The steady decline of the last week on the stock market came to a halt yesterday and in a complete reversal of trend, prices rose 1 to 2 points. The gain of 1.10 points in the composite rate erased the losses of the two previous sessions and put the list back to last Friday's closing level.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Astor, the attraction is "The Lawless," a social drama produced by William H. Pine and William C. Thomas for Paramount. Macdonald Carey, Gail Russell, Lalo Rios, a newcomer to the screen; John Sands, Lee Patrick and John Hoyt ...
WASHINGTON, June 21--A woman educator just back from Europe reported today that $250,000 spent on aid to women scholars in formerly occupied countries had brought rich results.

A comprehensive plan for rapid transit improvement in Queens, including a link with the proposed Second Avenue subway and purchase by the city of the Rockaway Beach branch of the Long Island Rail Road, was submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)-- Paul Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, told Senators today that roughly one-third of the European recovery spending is pouring into the tills of American small business.
TOKYO, June 21 (AP)--Mrs. Etsu Sugimoto, author of "A Daughter of the Samurai," died last night in her residence here at the age of 76.

A permanent exhibit of prosthetic and sensory aids will be opened to the public tomorrow on the third floor of the Veterans Administration quarters at 252 Seventh Avenue. The exhibit includes devices currently in use, others that have been outmoded and some still in an experimental stage.

MANILA, June 20--Past abuses of authority by regular and irregular pacification forces have complicated the problem of Hukbalahap suppression in Central Luzon. Today, anti-Huk fighters with a new policy of seeking public goodwill are having to combat fears and aversions among the people created by the harsh, ill-controlled methods formerly employed.

"The Shoemaker and the Elves," the Park Department's marionette show, will appear in Brooklyn today at 3:30 P.M. at Lincoln Terrace Park and tomorrow at the Howard Avenue (Pacific and Dean Streets) playground. Two performances will be held on Saturday at McCarren Park at 11 A.M. and 2:30 P.M. For future schedules call RE 4-1000.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 22 (AP) --John Foster Dulles, adviser to the United States State Department, conferred with Gen. Douglas MacArthur today on Communistmenaced Asia and predicted "positive action" by the United States to preserve peace in the Far East.

WASHINGTON, June 21--The United States, in a sharply worded note delivered today to the Rumanian Foreign Office, announced its intention to recall Capt. Herschel Hutsinpiller, Assistant Military Attache in Bucharest.

NEW LONDON, June 21--The Harvard varsity crew that will row Yale Friday for the eighty-fifth time over the four-mile downstream course on the Thames will be the same eight that Tom Bolles has sent out for every race of the season.

NEW LONDON, June 21--The Harvard varsity crew that will row Yale Friday for the eighty-fifth time over the four-mile downstream course on the Thames will be the same eight that Tom Bolles has sent out for every race of the season.
Leaders of civic, industrial, labor and professional groups in New York pledged their cooperation yesterday to the city's celebration of Oct. 24 as "United Nations Day."

A rounded picture of Czechoslovakia under Communist domination such as has just been sent us by Dana Adams Schmidt, our former correspondent in Prague, makes sad reading. Americans will always have a soft spot for Czechoslovakia; its roots stem back to the days of Thomas Masaryk in the United States.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 21 --An almost perfect halo of light, almost as large as the apparent size of the planet Jupiter and surrounding a fuzzy central object of about the same brightness, has been found by Arthur Hoag of Harvard Observatory in the constellation Serpens.

The American War Blinded Veterans, Inc., a new organization established to provide for the personal needs of sightless men and women formerly in the services, will open its first public appeal for funds today.

Miss Roberdeau Callery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Callery of 133 East Sixty-fourth Street, and Yarmouth, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Arthur Brooks Du Bois, son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Du Bois of 1215 Park Avenue, and Woods Hole, Mass., in the Members' Reception Room of the Colony Club.
Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange were firm and active yesterday.

The New Jersey Department of Conservation and Economic Development, Bureau of Navigation, called attention yesterday to regulations which small boat operators on the state's tidal inland waters must observe during the summer boating season.

WASHINGTON, June 21--The last obstacle to the sale of the strike-bound transportation system of Atlanta, Ga., was reported cleared today when the Securities and Exchange Commission advised the Georgia Power Company that the commission's approval was not required to make the sale effective.

LONDON, June 21 (AP)--The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Geoffrey Fisher, defended his leftwing Dean tonight as a man who "holds profoundly and sincerely the precise same Christian faith as you and I hold."

CHICAGO, June 21--Familiarity breeds acceptance rather than contempt when it comes to radical innovations in furniture design, according to George Nelson, a designer who is himself identified with this kind of furniture.

The earlier a college student decides on a vocational goal, the better chance he has of attaining it, according to a follow-up employment survey conducted among graduates at the City College School of Business and Civic Administration.

The Federal Public Housing Administration contracted yesterday to assist the New York City Housing authority in financing $99,464,000 of additional public housing and to pay up to $4,475,880 a year in subsidies to keep rents in these projects within the reach of low-income families.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP)-- Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, today demanded an investigation of "very serious questions" involved in the conduct of Federal Communications Commission hearings on the license renewal application of Station KMPC, Los Angeles.
James A. Goldsmith Sr. of 1 East Eighty-eighth Street, president of Hess, Goldsmith Co., Inc., textile manufacturers, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 77.

BUDAPEST, June 21--The Hungarian Roman Catholic Bishops have decided to ask the Government to open negotiations for a church-state agreement following the Communist regime's stepping up of its campaign against the church.

Television Station WPIX announced yesterday that it was making its facilities available this evening to four civic leaders who took exception to Mayor O'Dwyer's initial video show last Thursday. They will be heard for fifteen minutes, starting at 8 P.M., and their program will bear the title of "From the Other Side of the Mayor's Desk."

Financial requirements of the merger of Sunray Oil Corporation and Barnsdall Oil Company were consummated marketwise yesterday afternoon by the sale of $9,468,000 of common stock of Sunray Oil by an underwriting syndicate headed by Eastman, Dillon Co.

Nine months ago the House of Representatives expressed its conviction in no uncertain terms that the Social Security Act of 1935 was inadequate to meet present-day needs. The three-story building at 113121 Clara Street, Brooklyn, accom modating twenty-three families, has been sold by Lee Itzkowitz to Minnie Kaplan. The building, on a plot 85 by 110 feet, was constructed in 1939. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $54,500.

WASHINGTON, June 21--Miss Ann Distler, daughter of Mrs. Walter G. Distler of Washington and Spring Lake, N.J., was married to William F. Brown 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Brown of Montclair, N.J., and Spring Lake, in St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral, here, at noon today.

Labor was urged yesterday by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, to build in the South if it is to protect its political future and obtain the enactment of more social legislation.

PARIS, June 21--Maurice Petsche, Finance Minister, told the Finance Committee of the National Assembly today that France had reached the position of having a sound economy but that business was nearly stagnant.

Deposits in mutual savings banks of the United States continued to mount in May, the gain of $67,000,000 sending total deposits to $19,807,000,000. The rise was 14 per cent more than the $58,000,000 increase in May, 1949. Deposits have risen $1,004,000,000, or 5.3 per cent in the last twelve months.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 2,875,000 barrels, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute issued yesterday. At the week-end they were 116,374,000 barrels, compared with 119,249,000 a week earlier and 116,403,000 a year ago.

Reaction in Queens yesterday to the proposals announced by the Board of Transportation Wednesday for improving transit service in that borough was, generally, that the plan was good as far as it went, but was inadequate.

The Reds may be a dead last in the National League, but if this be true the Dodgers are convinced the world is upside down. For those singular Cincinnatians, to the keen dismay of a ladies' day turnout of 19,152 at Ebbets Field yesterday, sent Burt Shotton's Brooks sprawling for the second successive afternoon.

A 75 per cent dividend in common stock, payable on July 12, has been authorized by directors of Lily-Tulip Cup Corporation, Henry Nias, chairman of the board, and Walter J. Bergman, president, announced yesterday.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., June 22-- Playing spectacular golf in her first tournament appearance of the season, 17-year-old Miss Barbara Bruning, White Plains High senior and host club ace, led the individual field of sixty-one in the annual women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Associations' intercounty championship today.

Six hundred dejected college men and women, Europe-bound from as far away as California and the Northwest, found themselves stranded in New York yesterday when the Coast Guard pronounced their chartered ship unsafe and halted its sailing scheduled for 4 P. M.

Young American conductors, composers and arrangers will be featured in a series of summer radio concerts to be introduced by Paul Whiteman over the American Broadcasting Company Tuesday evening from 8 to 8:30 o'clock.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 22-- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Baltusrol and Mrs. A.J. Bryant of Rockland won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's four-ball best-ball tournament over the Sunningdale course today.

The marriage of Miss Patricia Jan Riker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Riker of New York, to Stanley Marvan Jordan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Jordan of Jersey City, took place last night in the main ballroom of the Pierre. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Ira Eisenstein. Later there were a reception and dinner.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was strong again yesterday, and closing prices were 1 to 24 points net higher than on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, June 22--President Truman emphatically reiterated today his opposition to expanding the Air Force to seventy groups from its present size of forty-eight.

WASHINGTON, June 22--Wayne Coy, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, suggested today that Continental Press Service, of Cleveland, could be prosecuted under the anti-trust laws for alleged monopolistic practices in its distribution of "flash" racing news to selected clients around the country.

LOS ANGELES, June 22--Such color tones as orangy red, persimmon, bittersweet, tomato and crushed strawberry added interest to the combined "Harvest of Fashions" showing held here this week by the Affiliated Fashionists of California. Also recurrent are blue grape, bright navy, light, dusty blues and soft beiges.

BUFFALO, June 22--Joe McCarthy, 63, ailing manager of the Red Sox, came home tonight to take a rest.
TRENTON, June 22--A move to freeze out bookmakers in New Jersey was announced today by Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons.

The coat and suit industry now offers junior management opportunities as important as can be found in any field of business, according to Samuel Deitsch, president of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit Skirt Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, June 22--Plans for formation of a new soft coal operators' association to bargain with John L. Lewis United Mine Workers have been retarded by the reluctance of some leading operators to join. The plans have been in preparation for many months.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., June 22--The sprawling one-story plant of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York, Inc., at Sunrise Highway and Merrick Road here, was destroyed today in a spectacular fire in which fifteen persons were reported hurt.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 22 --The oldest of all intercollegiate sports events, the Harvard-Yale rowing regatta, will be held here late tomorrow afternoon for the eighty-fifth time since 1852, with the Crimson varsity favored to get home first over the four-mile downstream course on the Thames.

BREMEN, Germany, June 22 (AP)--Leopold Ziegenbein, retired North German Lloyd Company captain, died yesterday in near-by Nordholz at the age of 75.
Serious difficulties in Soviet efforts to increase petroleum, natural rubber, and newsprint production are revealed in Soviet newspapers received in this country.
WASHINGTON, June 22--The conflict between the Taft-Hartley Law and hiring customs in the construction industry is snarling progress on a $100,000,000 atomic project at Arco, Idaho.

LONDON, June 22--Britain's national wage restraint policy, which Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced in February, 1948, is about to undergo its first major revision. A new policy of approving moderate wage increases on the basis of the merit of each case will be submitted next week to the General Council of the Trades Union Congress.

The eleven Communist leaders asked the United States Court of Appeals yesterday to reverse their conviction because, they said, rulings by Federal Judge Harold R. Medina had made a fair trial impossible.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 22 (AP)-- A thrilling story of a battle with the sea in which a man was swept overboard was told today by John Nicholas Brown, skipper and owner of the yawl Bolero, first to finish the 635-mile Newport-to-Bermuda race.

WASHINGTON, June 22--Edward H. Miller, a prominent lawyer and legal partner of Clark M. Clifford, former special counsel for President Truman, died at his home here today. He was 43 years old. Recently, he had suffered a heart attack.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP)-- Four home runs and a triple play carried rookie Bob Miller to his sixth pitching victory without defeat today as the Phillies downed the Pirates, 7--4. As a result, Philadelphia rose from third to second place, just ahead of the Cardinals.

BILL DEWITT, the president of the St. Louis Browns, has just made the ominous threat that unless the fans give the club more support at the gate "we may have to move." It's enough to make a man's blood run cold, the most horrifying prospect that could be imagined.
Five of Massachusetts' municipal housing authorities announced yesterday that they would seek bids June 29 on issues of temporary loan notes, totaling $10,249,000, to finance state-aided projects.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., June 22--Girl Guide from India, Eclaireuse (Scout) from France, Padvindster (Pathfinder) from Holland, Danish and Canadian blondes, Japanese and Korean brunettes---- they sat together today on the grass of an American Girl Scout camp, in the deep quiet an hour from the city.

CLARK LAKE, Alaska, June 22 --Priest Rock Creek may not be the greatest grayling stream in the world, but it is impossible to imagine any body of water with more of these fish or one providing more interesting fishing.

One of the chief port problems under study by Mayor O'Dwyer's Joint Committee on Port Industry is the elimination of unnecessary handling of perishable foods moving in tremendous volume into the city every day.

JERSEY CITY, June 22--Municipal employes, during the last two years of the administration controlled by the Hague Democratic machine, paid "collectors" in their departments "campaign contributions" on the basis of 3 per cent of their annual salaries.

Thirteen years ago this month Generalissimo Francisco Franco's forces, then in rebellion against the elected Government of Spain, took the Basque industrial city of Bilbao. Many Spaniards were fighting on Franco's side,

CHICAGO, June 22--Business booked during the first three days of the summer home furnishings market here by the Pullman Couch Company was 10 to 15 per cent less than in the corresponding period of last year's market. This was revealed today by Lawrence K. Schnadig, president.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 22 -- Rabbi Judah L. Maimon, Minister for Religious Affairs, angrily walked out of a Cabinet meeting yesterday and tendered his resignation.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)-- The Navy has been given a goahead to build a flush-deck aircraft carrier similar to the one Defense Secretary Louis Johnson halted on the ways last year.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 22-- The Rev. Dr. John William Behnken of Oak Park, Ill., was elected to his sixth three-year term today as president of the Lutheran

ALLENTOWN, Pa., June 22-- Immediate education of the public on future road requirements and periodic realignment of regulatory signs to conform with changing traffic volume were emphasized today as basic remedies for highway congestion.
The 1950 population of Staten Island has been tentatively set at 191,015.

When and if the Senate confirms the President's appointment of Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming as Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation the shipping industry can count on an enthusiastic supporter of a strong and wellrounded American merchant marine.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 22-- Sam Snead, who as defending champion did not have to qualify, nevertheless, led the field through the thirty-six-hole elimination process that was completed today in the National Professional Golfers' championship over the Scioto Country Club course.

TOKYO, June 22--A modified peace treaty or an agreement whereby a system would be established here similar to that in Germany where the Military Government by the Allies has been removed but Western defense forces remain may be offered Japan by the Western powers.

WASHINGTON, June 22--Two Senate committees that have considered jointly a second year of military assistance to nations resisting communism declared today that the day of neutrality, anywhere in the world, had passed.

The bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation said yesterday that the city's failure to permit a 10-cent fare on its lines would mean a 30 per cent curtailment in service in the Bronx and the accompanying dismissal of 300 to 500 employes.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 22--The United States made public today a detailed outline for the operation of an eleven-nation disarmament authority first proposed more than a month ago.
Plans for the merger of Birmingham Electric Company with Alabama Power Company were announced here yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 22 -- Guy G. Gabrielson, Republican national chairman, declared tonight that the Republicans had an excellent chance of gaining control of the next Congress at the November election.
The regulation barring over-size trucks from the garment sector in daytime was all but killed yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer.

PARIS, June 22--After meeting a heavy defeat by a vote of 352 to 195, Premier Georges Bidault asked the National Assembly today for a vote of confidence next Saturday against the Assembly's wish to exceed the available credits in raising the pay of civil servants.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22-- "About Mrs. Leslie," a new novel by Vina Delmar, has been purchased for the screen by Paramount as a prospective George Stevens production, the studio announced today. Stevens also will direct the film version of the novel, which is described as a dramatic love story about a worldly woman.

Everyone has been under the impression that Elia Kazan is to direct Tennessee Williams' next play, "The Rose Tattoo," for Cheryl Crawford. He might, but as of yesterday Mr. Kazan was quite vague about it. At first he declined to specify any reason for the uncertainty.

The splashiest piece of music at last night's Stadium concert was the Rachmaninoff "Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini," but the best --and also best played--was Mozart's Piano Concerto in A major (K. 414).
A group of upstaters flew to New York yesterday and voiced harsh words for Dr. Wallace E. Howell, the city's rainmaker.

DETROIT, June 22--The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., called a strike today, effective Monday morning, against a major supplier of the Chrysler Corporation and continued its efforts to halt a jurisdictional strike that threatened a shutdown of the Ford Motor Company.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 22 --Argyll, 57-foot yawl belonging to W.T. Moore of Oyster Bay, L. I., became the winner of the 635mile blue-water race from Newport to this harbor tonight, when time allowances of all the smaller yachts that hadn't finished expired.

Police Inspector Nicholas A. Pisarra, former commander of Brooklyn's Nineteenth Division, has been ordered to reappear on Monday before the special grand jury investigating organized gambling in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)-- Three Hollywood writers and producers went on trial in Federal Court today on charges of contempt of Congress for having refused to say whether they were Communists.

LONDON, June 22--Continued buoyancy of British Government securities again radiated cheerfulness to most sections of the stock market here today. Most of the industrial leaders went ahead while interest in the gold mining issues kept prices on the upgrade.

In its first change of ownership since 1906, the eight-family house with two stores on lot 27 by 72 feet at 1608 Third Avenue, near Ninetieth Street, was sold by Madeline Scheyer, Elsie Bongo and Frank, Harry and Philip Brauneis to an investing client of Hardy, Brauneis Naumann, Inc., brokers.

The Board of Estimate's "unanimous" decision to hold private bus lines in New York City to an 8-cent fare after July 1, while charging a 10-cent fare on city-owned lines, contradicts logic and contravenes justice to private enterprise.
WASHINGTON, June 22--President Truman argued for strict party regularity today in calling for the election of "real Democrats" in the Congressional election in November.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 22-- United Nations officials are planning the creation of a new department to take charge of the organization's entire program of technical assistance to underdeveloped areas.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 6 --The Soviet Union's challenge to continental unity in the Western Hemisphere through its so-called people's national liberation front policy, which has won a foothold in Guatemala, is being pressed today in at least four other LatinAmerican republics. In others the groundwork for the policy is being laid.
CHICAGO, June 22--The nation's railroads, already threatened with walkouts by three unions, today faced another strike call.

WASHINGTON, June 22--Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, announced today plans for an investigation of complaints that there had been "huge expenditures of money" in more than a half dozen primary and convention contests for Senate seats.

CHICAGO, June 22--Favorable weather for harvesting winter wheat and for promoting rapid growth of the new corn and oats crops resulted in bearish sentiment prevailing on the Board of Trade today and grain markets worked lower, closing around the inside prices.
Legislation supporting and stimulating the merchant marine has received no aid from the executive branch of the Government, a group of shipping operators charged yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 22-- In the Battell Chapel of Yale University here this afternoon, Miss Joan Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Soutter Campbell of New Haven and Fishers Island, N.Y., was married to Sidney Lovett, son of the Rev. and Mrs. A. Sidney Lovett of New Haven, and Holderness, N.H.

With the summer school vacation at hand, Water Commissioner Stephen J. Carney warned yesterday against the "vicious water waste" caused by the hot weather practice of turning on hydrants to provide "showers" for children.

Eight public school teachers who refused to tell whether they were members of the Communist party pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of insubordination and conduct unbecoming teachers and won adjournment of their departmental trial to Sept. 18.

In appreciation of their out standing service in standardization, the American Standards Association awarded certificates yesterday to ten men of the New York area.

A suggestion that this country "accept, free of duty, up to, say, 5 per cent of the physical production of any industry in the United States, to the extent that proves practicable," was advanced yesterday by Lewis H. Brown, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Johns-Manville Corporation.
Construction of a $1,000,000 Science Building on the Riverdale campus of Manhattan College will begin this fall, Brother Bonaventure Thomas, president, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 22--Major shifts of command for general officers of the Army and a series of recommended promotions were announced today by President Truman.
Marketers will find a wide assortment of fresh fruit this weekend. Retail prices on a number of varieties associated with summer are at the lowest level this year.

HARWELL, England, June 22-- Sir John Cockcroft, director of Britain's atomic energy research establishment here, envisaged today the possibility that means of propelling ships and operating power plants with atomic energy would be developed in eight years.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 22--Dr. Max Radin, Emeritus Professor of Law at the University of California and a nationally-known scholar and writer, died here today in Peralta Hospital after becoming ill Monday night of an inoperable blood clot. His age was 70.
It was Stunts, the 5-year-old gelding owned and trained by George Herbert (Pete) Bostwick, all the way on the head-end in the nine-furlong race that topped the program at Aqueduct yesterday.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., June 22--Jane Cowl, one of the outstanding figures of the contemporary American stage, died this morning at Santa Monica Hospital, where she underwent an operation for cancer a fortnight ago. Her age was 65.

If the "relationship of the free people is to be on a sound basis, it must be on a business basis," Paul G. Hoffman said yesterday. The head of the Economic Cooperation Administration asserted that Western Europe can go a long way toward achieving this if, between now and 1953, it can "earn a billion dollars more and spend a billion dollars less."

Net profit of the Masonite Corporation for the nine months ended with May increased to $4,794,200 from $2,752,042 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year. The profit for the latest period is equivalent to $7.10 a share on the 675,276 common shares, compared with $4.29 a common share for the earlier period, the report showed Yesterday.
BERLIN, June 22 (AP)--Communists tonight rigged the East German Republic's first election to capture 70 per cent of the Parliamentary seats regardless of the voting next Oct. 15.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 22-- Twenty-four hours after being sworn in as Minister of Labor, Rupee to Puga Fisher took off today in the President's plane for the strike-bound copper region north of Antofagasta. He was accompanied by four Deputies, one Senator and a technical expert.
Another motoring season is here, one that will last until the frost and the early snows of autumn.

Business borrowings from New York banks continued their upward trend last week, registering, an increase of $49,000,000 in the third successive weekly advance. Normally, the seasonal upturn does not begin until about the end of July.

WASHINGTON, June 22--John S. Service, a State Department career officer, conceded today that in 1945 he might well have given to Philip J. Jaffe confidential military information that could then have been "technically considered secret."
LONDON, June 22 (AP)--Playing true to form, the four members of the United States Wightman Cup team moved into the women's semifinals of the London tennis championships today.

ATHENS, June 22--Dr. Henry F. Grady, retiring United States Ambassador to Greece, said today that "the essential difference between Greece's victory and China's defeat is that the Greeks were willing to fight and die."

WASHINGTON, June 22--The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives formally approved the 1950 tax bill today, 17 to 8, and leaders prepared to call it up in the House next Tuesday. Passage without any changes on Thursday was slated.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis has approved awards totaling $1,441,721 for research and professional education in poliomyelitis.

Directors of the Chrysler Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of $1.75 a share on the common stock, an increase of 25 cents a share over the payments made in each of the three preceding quarters. The latest dividend will be paid on Sept. 12 to shareholders of record on Aug. 14.

LEE, Mass., June 22--Dr. Joseph F. Wickham, Professor Emeritus of English at Brooklyn College, died at his home here today. His age was 68. He retired last fall from active teaching after a career of forty-two years at Townsend Harris Hall, the College of the City of New York and Brooklyn College.

LONDON, June 22--Orders on hand indicate that there is "no reason for pessimism over the future of the Clyde shipbuilding industry," Charles Murdoch, chairman of the Scottish Board of Industry, said in Edinburgh today.

WASHINGTON, June 22--The spiked-shoe clan assembled here today, 500 strong, for the last big track and field rendezvous of the 1950 campaign in this country, the National A.A.U. junior and senior championships. Competition will start tomorrow at the University of Maryland Stadium in near-by College Park, Md.

The American Stores Company last week transacted the largest volume of sales for any nonholiday week in its history, William Park president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday. He added that the total was exceeded only by the sales for the Christmas week of 1949.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. William Watson Caswell of Havana, Cuba, of the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Lee, to David Malcolm Brush, son of Mr. and Mrs. Graham M. Brush of this city and Warren, Conn. The wedding has been planned for October.

They turned Yankee Stadium into a tanbark arena, planted three rings on the lush green infield, and the result was a three-hour show by Cole Brothers Circus that left 12,000 patrons, mostly small fry, hoarse from shouting and whistling.

WASHINGTON, June 23--Average primary market prices rose 0.3 per cent in the week ended June 20, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 157.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.6 per cent above four weeks ago and 2.3 per cent above the comparable week of 1949.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 23--On both sides of the Andes it is now apparent that President Truman faces more than a casual decision on the question of whether he will come to Chile in November in response to President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla's invitation.

WASHINGTON, June 23(AP)-- Contempt proceedings against Steve Nelson, a Communist organizer, were voted today by the House Un-American Activities Committee because he had refused last year to answer questions dealing with atomic espionage.
FRANKFORT, Germany, June 23--The International Authority for the Ruhr has postponed indefinitely a debate and decision on the German practice of double pricing for the coal mined in the Ruhr.

CHICAGO, June 23--A fifth unit of railroad employes, the Railroad Yardmasters of America, A.F.L., today raised the possibility of a strike, which could take place on or after July 15. It denounced as "disgraceful" the June 15 recommendations of the Presidential fact-finding board in its case.

Back-to-back seventh-inning homers by Don Mueller and Hank Thompson, the former with a mate aboard, provided the winning margin as the Giants downed the Reds, 5-2, at the Polo Grounds last night.
The rebound by the stock market was carried into the third day yesterday. Prices, however, encountered some difficulty in holding the new gain because of realizing.
A removal hearing for David Greenglass, 28-year-old war veteran charged with feeding atomic secrets to a Soviet spy ring, was adjourned yesterday until July 13.

The orders of finish in the varsity and freshman races at last Saturday's Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on the Ohio River at Marietta, Ohio, were revised yesterday after an examination of official motion pictures by a special reviewing committee.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23-- Samuel S. Fels, Philadelphia industrialist and philanthropist, died this afternoon in Temple University Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 90.

Thirty-one years ago Dr. Dorothea M. Toile, who had just completed her internship, became a resident physician at Willard Parker Hospital for Communicable Diseases at the foot of East Fifteenth Street. A week later she contracted diphtheria and spent her next two weeks at the hospital in bed.
KANSAS CITY, June 23--A group of Baptists having the Christmas spirit even in June took their minister to court today on the ground that he is "anti-Santa Claus."

Peyton Boswell Jr., editor and publisher of Art Digest, a semimonthly publication, and author of three books on American painting and painters, died yesterday morning at his home, 88 Coolidge Street, Malverne, L.I. His age was 46.
ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP)--Declaring he was "physically exhausted," Joe McCarthy retired from baseball for the second time today.
WASHINGTON, June 23--Two Canadian clergymen today leveled charges of monopoly against the newsprint industry in their native land.

Edgar B. Landis of Riverdale and the University of Pennsylvania Club, trust officer of the Chemical Bank Trust Company, died yesterday of a heart ailment at White Plains (N.Y.) Hospital. His age was 58.

BOSTON, June 23 (AP)--With homers accounting for all of their runs, the decisive one being Earl Torgeson's two-run drive into the right field bullpen with one out in the ninth, the Braves defeated the Cardinals, 4--3, tonight before a crowd of 30,720, the largest the Wigwam has housed this season.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 23--The Egyptian Ministry of Social Affairs, in its official announcement today of the Government's decision to provide an old-age and total ...
WASHINGTON, June 23--The House Republican Policy Committee took a "hands-off" attitude today toward the new tax bill. This leaves party members free to vote as they choose on passage next Thursday.
The machinery for bringing about the city's purchase of all the Bronx bus lines of the Third Avenue Transit System was put in motion yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer.

Despite rumors to the contrary, "Anna and the King of Siam" will be the next offering of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, the latter indicated yesterday from his country home in Pennsylvania.

CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP)-- Large Luke Easter clouted two homers and drove in six runs tonight to lead the Indians to a 13to-4 victory over the Senators. Bob Lemon got credit for Cleveland's ninth victory in 11 games of its current home stand.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, June 23--Coinciding with the announcement of strong police measures to preserve order next Monday--"Protest Day"--Parliament received today a report on a series of riots by Negroes in the Johannesburg area during the last eight months.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 23-- Trygve Lie said today that he stood by his statement last December that he would not be a candidate for re-election as Secretary General of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, June 23--James V. Bennett, director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, urged the Senate Crime Investigating Committee today to make a study of the means by which gang leaders in the country recruit their forces and enforce order in their mobs.
More than a million roses appeared in the cut flower market in New York in the last week. These were grown in greenhouses, although roses are blooming outdoors all over the country.

A vacant plot on the westerly side of Forty-eighth Street, 250 feet south of Thirty-second Avenue and north of Northern Boulevard, in Woodside, Queens, has been sold by John Cogliati to Leonard Spear, who plans to improve it with a onestory industrial building.

The Pirates brought their renowned home run slugger, Ralph Kiner, to Ebbets Field last night, but in the course of the next three hours it was the Dodgers who showed the ill-starred Corsairs, as well as a cheering crowd of 25,519 suectators, exactly how it's done.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 23-- The Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod's Bureau of Information Regarding Secret Societies gravely warned the church's triennial convention today against what it described as the "lodge evil."

DENVER, June 23--Miss Peggy Kirk, amateur from Findlay, Ohio, and Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrtkson Zaharias, powerful pro from Chicago, today gained the final in the twentyfirst women's western open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP)-- Weekly earnings of the 11,800,000 production workers in manufacturing plants continued upward during May to another all-time high of $57.50, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Miss Suzanne Bunker, daughter of Mrs. Harvey William Bell of Ghent, N.Y., and the late George Haring Bunker, was married to David Luke Hopkins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hopkins of Baltimore, yesterday afternoon in All Angels Protestant Episcopal Church here.

The illuminating analysis of the dissident Hukbalahap movement in the Philippines in current dispatches to this newspaper by Tillman Durdin should help to put this threat to Philippine public order in better perspective in this country.

MORRISTOWN, Tenn., June 23 (U.P.)--The state charged three Congress of Industrial Organizations members today with deadly assault against a non-striker at the American Enka rayon plant and the union accused authorities of abandoning "due legal process."
Formation of a new company to offer mechanized agricultural services on a fee basis to farmers in the South American Republic of Ecuador was announced yesterday by Nelson A. Rockefeller.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 7--United States business interests are enjoying a honeymoon today everywhere in Central America except Guatemala.

ALBANY, June 23--The State Banking Department announced today that the W.W.W.U. Local 65 Credit Union, 13 Astor Place, had received approval for a certificate of change of name to Distributive Workers Union Credit Union.
BERLIN, June 23--Walter Ulbricht, Deputy Premier of East Germany, signed away tonight the claims of the Sudeten Germans to live in Czechoslovakia.

David H. Dubrowsky, former Russian Red Cross director in this country, who had more lately testified at official hearings against the Soviets, died yesterday in his home at Roxbury, Conn., at the age of 61.
The autobiography of Anzia Yezierska, author of "Hungry Hearts," is planned for September publication by Scribner.

It has been traditional for years in a number of American heavy industries, where freight costs represent an important part of the total cost of the product to the consumer, to employ the "basing point" system of prices.

CANTON, Ohio, June 23--The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., staged a back-to-work movement at the Ford Motor Company plant late today that appeared to have ended a four-day jurisdictional strike and removed fear of a nation-wide shutdown of all Ford plants.

WASHINGTON, June 23--A Republican member of a Senate investigating subcommittee declared today that for him no verdict would be possible as matters stood on one of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's basic charges of communism in the State Department.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 23-- The Mayor and City Council of Englewood, opposed to public housing yet anxious to provide low cost housing and slum clearance, today announced a plan whereby they believe both objectives are possible through private enterprise.

DETROIT, June 23--With 51,400 perfervid fans yelling wildly and with torn paper descending on the neat terrain of Briggs Stadium, Hoot Evers hit a two-run homer off Joe Page inside the park to give the Tigers a 10-9 victory tonight and go two games ahead of the Bombers in first place.

Advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities during May totalled 220,211,436 lines, a gain of 4.5 per cent over the like month of last year, according to an analysis of Media Records.

In time-honored paternal fashion, the United States Government yesterday moved to the rescue of 550 college students in a jam. It offered the military transport General C.C. Ballou to the National Student Association to take its stranded tourist group to Europe.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP)--The power-laden Red Sox were not to be denied under their new leadership tonight, slamming four Brownie pitchers for 15 hits and a 12-9 triumph in a game that saw the lead change hands five times. Dick Kokos hit the only home run of the game.

TRENTON, June 23--This city would like to have Thomas Rossiter's painting of George Washington's welcome to Trenton on his trip to his inauguration in New York as the new nation's first President.

Arturo Toscanini was voted the favorite radio conductor for the seventh consecutive year by 700 music critics of the United States and Canada. The announcement was made yesterday by Musical America magazine, which conducts the annual poll.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29-- A revolutionary electronic machine that makes possible automatic control of anesthesia during an operation and maintains "smooth anesthiesia" at any desired depth was described here today at the annual meeting of the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, June 29--The House of Representatives passed the 1950 tax bill today by the topheavy vote of 375 to 14. The measure now goes to the Senate for a fate that is uncertain.

George R. Sommers has been appointed general sales manager of the Sylvania radio tube and television picture tube divisions. He succeeds C. W. Shaw, who has been made assistant to the vice president in charge of sales.

LONDON, June 29--The Far Eastern situation continued to grip the attention of British Ministers today. The Cabinet held a three-hour session in the morning to study the latest news from Korea and to dispose of other matters.

WASHINGTON, June 29--The Senate passed and sent to the House today a compromise bill to authorize an Air Force of seventy groups and an Army 837,000 strong. The version passed today had been agreed upon by a conference committee.

License: Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey has placed Michael Todd's "Peep Show," a lavish burlesque spectacle, under surveillance.
BELFAST, Ireland, June 29-- The largest tanker ever built here, the 28,000-ton Verena, was launched today by Harland Wolff for the Anglo-Saxon Petroleum Company.

WASHINGTON, June 29--A further reduction of $208,000,000 in Marshall Plan funds for countries resisting communism was voted tentatively today by the Senate Appropriations Committee, members disclosed.

CHICAGO, June 30--Revenue and wage losses were counted in the millions of dollars today in the six-day-old strike of the Switchmen's Union of North America, A.F.L., against five railroads of the Midwest and West.

The big noise yesterday was caused, by 900,000 boys and girls dropping their textbooks and screaming farewell to their teachers as the city's public schools ended academic routine for the start of a ten-week-vacation period.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the largest since April and the heaviest of any June in seventeen years, or since 1933. The turnover for the first half of 1950 amounted to 251,889,199 shares, the greatest number for the period since 1936.

Charles V. Schelke has been appointed a vice president of the International General Electric Company, Inc., W.R. Herod, president, disclosed yesterday. Effective on Sept. 1, Mr. Schelke will be in charge of the Department of Affiliated and Associated Companies.

WASHINGTON, June 30--The House of Representatives today sustained President Truman's Reorganization Plan No. 24 transferring the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Department of Commerce, over Republican opposition.

The stock market abruptly changed its course yesterday and in average-wise terms made its best advance in three weeks. Despite a new selling assault during the lunch period when the White House disclosed that American ground troops had been ordered into the Korean fighting, standard stocks managed to show gains of 1 to 3 points.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., June 30--President Truman tonight denounced Communist-dominated countries for regimenting their youth with the aim of sacrificing their lives, if necessary, in the cause of Red imperialism.
The year's worst traffic congestion was expected to develop today as a record number of automobiles take to the roads for the long week-end occasioned by the falling of a major holiday on a Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, June 30--In its drive against alleged monopoly, the Federal Government started civil anti-trust lawsuits against powerful segments of the automobile parts and outdoor advertising industries today. Attorney General J. Howard McGrath made the announcement here.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP)-- The Athletics moved out of the American League basement tonight by taking both games of a double-header from the Senators, 17--6 and 4--2. Eddie Joost's eighth-inning homer with Ferris Fain aboard, broke a 2-2 tie to give Alex Kellner his fifth victory in the nightcap.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 30--Norway has offered to decorate and furnish the Security Council chamber in the permanent East River capital of the United Nations and will probably get a go-ahead.

"The Pulitzer Prize Playhouse," which would offer televised dramatizations of both old and new works of Pulitzer prize winners, reportedly is about set for sponsorship in the fall, with a portion of the proceeds going to the Columbia University School of Journalism.

BOSTON, June 30--The Yankees and Red Sox knocked each other silly in a day-and-night baseball extravaganza today to the bewilderment of a combined total of 49,509 onlookers. When it was all over neither side had gained so much as an inch on the other.

A three-hour cram course in sociology was given yesterday afternoon along the steamy streets of the lower East Side. The students were fifteen teenagers from Long Island who have volunteered to serve as counselors this summer at a Long Beach day camp for slum youngsters.

ALBANY, June 30 (AP)--New York's new social insurance for workers swings into full operation tomorrow. About 6,000,000 workers will be assured of financial protection in event of sickness or disability not connected with their jobs, Officials estimated, however, that only about 3,000,000 actually would have to contribute to the system.

Consolidated net sales of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company rose more than $67,000,000 in the fiscal year ended Feb. 28, 1950, but earnings declined more than $5,200,000 from the total of the preceding fiscal year, the company reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 1--The first United States ground troops flew in to South Korea today in an attempt to stem a Communist armored drive threatening to overrun all resistance before the refugee capital of Taejon.

WASHINGTON, June 30--The Eighty-first Congress drew together in unity today in support of President Truman's order putting United States ground forces and uninhibited American air power into the struggle for the life of Southern Korea.

Fare increases ranging from one to three cents became effective one minute after last midnight on all surface transit lines, public and private, except those of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, on which the 12-cent fare remained unchanged.

Frequent stops at the kinds of places children enjoy--parks, lighthouses, airports, picnic lunches, a chance to get out now and then and relax with a game of "catch," will help keep youngsters contented and amused on long motor trips, according to Mildred Dorr, child development specialist.

Narrowing profit margins on shoes have led to reports of impending price advances, reflecting stronger leather and hide markets, it was reported here yesterday. The General Shoe Corporation already has informed customers of a possible increase of 10 to 15 cents a pair on Aug. 1.

New York City puts into effect today the first fare change on municipal transit since the 5-cent fare tradition was broken on July 1, 1948. It also raises the pay of transit employes and makes other improvements in working conditions, at an annual cost of more than $13,000,000.
BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP)--The house that built Babe Ruth and turned many an orphan and tough boy into good, solid Americans passes out of existence today, St. Mary's Industrial School is closing.

WASHINGTON, June 30--President Truman, before leaving today to address the Boy Scout Jamboree at Valley Forge, Pa., sent to the Capitol two messages withholding approval from bills passed by Congress.

Jacob J. Siegal has purchased the three garden-type apartment houses at 8715-45 Little Neck Parkway and 8724-48 256th Street in Bellrose, L.I., from a syndicate represented by Lawrence Gerber, attorney.

Much of the comment on the struggle that is taking place in Korea has concentrated, quite naturally, on the world-wide implications of the clash. It is viewed, and correctly, as an acid test of the survival capacity of the United Nations. It is held up as a turning point in the foreign, and particularly Far Eastern, policy of the United States.

PARIS, Saturday, July 1--Acclaimed in the National Assembly for his support of United States action in Korea, Henri Queuille obtained today endorsement as Premier of France by a vote of 363 to 208. He needed 311 for a majority.

An item that the New York Public Library has been trying to find for five years, a copy of the cover page of the first issue of Yank, which was printed on June 17, 1942 and ordered destroyed because of a "boner," was brought to the library yesterday to be microfilmed.

BOSTON, June 30--New England, first region in the country to complete its 1950 preliminary census figures, reported today a sixstate population of 9,305,766. Paul G. Carney, area supervisor, said this represented an increase of 868,476 since 1940.
LONDON, June 30 (AP)--England's 1-0 loss to the United States in the World Cup soccer tournament in Brazil brought tears to the eyes of British sports writers today.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 30--A large majority of United Nations delegates consulted here gave their informal approval this afternoon to President Truman's decision to send ground troops to Korea and bomb military targets in Northern Korea.
BERLIN, Saturday, July 1 (U.P.) --The Russians cut off electricity and water to West Berlin at midnight in a repeat performance of a move used in their 1948-49 blockade of the former German capital.
The City of San Francisco, Calif., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Aug. 7 on bond issues amounting to $20,560,000.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., June 30-- The body of Charles P. Hammond, 41-year-old vice president in charge of advertising and promotion of the National Broadcasting Company in New York, was found today in his car atop a hill a mile from his home on Old Farm Road here. The police said he had died of carbon monoxide poisoning.

Temperatures in June were slightly above normal and precipitation and humidity were less than customary, Weather Bureau statistics showed yesterday. For the first month this year, there was more sunshine than usual.
