LAKE SUCCESS, June 30--The list of countries supporting United Nations action in Korea grew tonight to thirty-three and the official cablegram office here decided to stay on the job on a twentyfour hour basis to handle the communiques from capitals all over the world.
FRANKFORT, Germany, June 30--Russian control officers in the soviet zone quickly snuffed out this week a series of resolutions calling on the Soviet Union to join the war in Korea.

TAIPEL, Formosa, June 30 (AP) --Nationalist China offered the United Nations assistance "within its power" for South Korea today and called for concerted action by all United Nations members to keep the peace in Korea and elsewhere.

The 1,500 G.I. students at the Meat Cutters School of Manhattan were assured yesterday that their vocational training would not be halted by the stoppage of tuition payments by the Veterans Administration.
Murano, 6-year-old horse from the Argentine, made his New York debut yesterday and proceeded to a two-length victory at Aqueduct. He was the 19-to-20 favorite in a field of five.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 1 (UP)-- The Seoul radio broadcast today an announcement heard in Tokyo today that the Communist captors had laid down a series of strict occupation rules for the city. They called for oaths of cooperation, a blackout and a curfew and the severe punishment of violators.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 30-- Walter Geist; president of AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company, announced today the signing of a five-year labor-management contract with Local 248 of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30-- Jennifer Jones will play the title role in the new screen version of Theodore Dreiser's novel, "Sister Carrie," with Sir Laurence Olivier at Paramount, the studio announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 30--The place to see a pageant of New York from July 8 through Dec. 17 will be Corcoran Art Gallery in this city.
Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union, will leave New York today on a globe-girdling tour to study the conditions of human liberty in such...

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP)-- John D.M. Hamilton, court-appointed attorney for Harry Gold, the Philadelphia chemist indicted on a charge of delivering atomic secrets to Russia, said today he had advised his client to plead guilty.
Union and management representatives met for three hours yesterday in an unsuccessful attempt to settle the eighteen-dayold strike of the Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., against The World-Telegram and Sun.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., June 30--The marriage of Miss Sally Christie Rutherfurd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Rutherfurd of Laurel Hollow and New York, to Thomas Chambers Wayne Roberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Roberts of Princeton, N.J., took place here this afternoon in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church.

The response of the whole of Latin America to the crisis over Korea is one of the most gratifying features of this remarkable week. The latest highlight is the good news from Buenos Aires that Argentina has at last ratified the Inter-American Treaty of Reciprocal Assistance drawn up at the Rio de Janeiro conference in 1947.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP)-- Frank Pace Jr., Secretary of the Army, said tonight that if Russia thrust "a truly major war" upon the United States it would be "a full-scale ground war."
WASHINGTON, June 30--The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations stated today in a 116-page report that world grain stocks were not high in view of unsettled conditions.

Former Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander, wartime chief of the city's civilian defense organization, was named yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer to serve as his special adviser and consultant in civilian defense matters.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in June totaled $121,134,000, compared with $183,834,000 in May and $76,996,000 in June, 1949. The total last month was the largest for any June since 1947, when $159,686,000 was redeemed.

LONDON, June 30--Early dullness on the stock markets here today was partly dispelled by modest rally, particularly in British Government securities, that resulted on balance in higher closing prices than yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30--A new technique for saving sight and relieving pain in victims of the serious eye disease, glaucoma, was described here today at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Medical Association. Glaucoma is marked by intense internal pressure which eventually results in blindness if not relieved.
Twenty-two veterans occupying a temporary project in Leonia, N.J., acquired the status of "squatters" yesterday with the expiration of six-month eviction notices.

CHICAGO, June 30--The grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today being under pressure at the start only to rally sharply later on the news from Korea and the rapid absorption of tenders on July contracts.
WASHINGTON, June 30--Employment in the United States is now at the highest level since the record month of July, 1948, the Bureau of the Census disclosed today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 30--Commencement exercises were held here tonight for 275 of the 1,000 bank officers from all parts of the nation who had completed the two-week session of the graduate school of banking at Rutgers University.

ALBANY, June 30--The final step in the integration of all the gas and electric utilities of the former Niagara Hudson Power Corporation was taken today when the Public Service Commission approved the merger of the Niagara Falls Power Company into the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation.

Activity at the New York Furniture Exchange yesterday was described as heavier than normal by manufacturers' representatives. They said few quantity orders were received but added that the aggregate of small orders written throughout the building was more than satisfactory.

RYE, N.Y., June 30--Donald McNeill of Bellerose, L.I., national indoor titleholder, and Ricardo Balbiers of Chile gained the semi-final round of the Eastern clay court tennis championship today at the Westchester Country Club.
MADRID, June 30--The hopes of advantage for Spain in international politics rather than the fears of a world war seem to be Spain's chief thought in the present critical situation in Korea.

Sibby Sisti's grand slam, pinchhit home run in the ninth inning beat the Giant's, 8--4, for the Braves last night. It was a sad denouement for the 24,137 spectators at the Polo Grounds who had watched the home team fight back into contention after Boston had surged to a 3-0 lead in the first inning.

Events in Korea are still running a logical and even inevitable course. One must take the order to use United States ground troops in support of the South Koreans in that light. We are basically committed, along with other United Nations members, to the defense of Southern Korea.

Corporate bonds included in the legal list now total more than $19,000,000,000, representing an increase of $2,300,000,000 in the year ended today. The new list of securities considered by the Banking Department to be eligible for purchase by savings banks in this state, was issued yesterday by William A. Lyon, Superintendent of Banks.

Conn Cohalan, an attorney and son of the late Supreme Court Justice Daniel F. Cohalan, died yesterday at his home at 529 West 238th Street, the Bronx of head injuries suffered in a fall on the stoop. He was 47 years old.

Water Department records compiled yesterday showed that on this week's "Wet Thursday," the second since water holidays were temporarily suspended two weeks ago, consumption in the city totaled 999,000,000 gallons.

ALBANY, June 30--In St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Julie Manetrie Refiner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Refiner of Loudonville, was married to Spotswood Page Nelson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson of McDonough, Md.
BUENOS AIRES June 30-- President Juan D. Peron placed an Argentine flag before the principal altar in the Basilica of Our Lady of Buenos Aires yesterday.

Five scenes in Michael Todd's recently opened musical offering, "Peep Show," will be modified in accordance with the wishes of License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey, who attended the show's opening night performance on Wednesday and objected to the "bumps and grinds" therein.

Ellen M. Daily and her family sold the three-story dwelling at 155 West Eighty-seventh Street to an investing client of David Neuwirth, attorney, who plans to convert it into apartments. The house was sold for $18,000, subject to a...

A new handbag can give as much lift to an outfit and the disposition as a new hat. Summer wardrobe pick-ups for this purpose are being offered in a range of unusual bags for both sport and dress occasions. These are interesting for their many new shapes as well as the materials.
WASHINGTON, June 30--The American Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., voted in convention early today to take the lead in promoting publication of one or more union-sponsored daily newspapers.

Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg, passing on provisions of the new state rent law yesterday, directed that a widow who had been evicted "as a result of trick and chicanery" must have her apartment restored to her.

LONDON, June 30--Robert Crail, who rose from junior clerk to general manager of the Cunard Steamship Company, retired today after fifty-one years of service with the company. He will be succeeded by Frank H. Dawson, who joined the steamship line in 1912.

WASHINGTON, June 30--The role of local police forces throughout the United States in a war or other national emergency was emphasized today by two speakers at graduation exercises of the National Academy of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

White flowers formed a garden background yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church for the marriage of Miss Mary Lathrop Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Stelle Brown of 133 East Eightieth Street and, Tranquillity Farm, Ashville, Me., to Maxwell Evarts...
ALBANY, June 30--The State Banking Department announced today that approval had been given to a change of location of the Nyack Savings and Loan Association from 20 to 21 North Broadway, Nyack.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 30 (AP) --A husky 20-year-old circus roustatbout, by his own words a killer and arsonist since the age of 6, has confessed to touching off the blaze that took 168 lives as it swept through the Ringling Brothers circus six years ago, authorities claimed today.
Henry Hesterberg, former Borough President of Brooklyn, who was a member of the New York Board of Water Supply, died yesterday morning in the Midwood Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 68 years old.

Investment bankers say the Columbia Gas System, Inc., may be in the market with a new debt offering for $90,000,000. This jibes with information obtained from a spokesman for the utility who said that no "final" decision has been reached as to this financing.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP)--Opening a home stand, the Cardinals broke out of their batting slump and mauled the Pirates, 9--4, before 12,631 spectators tonight. The triumph moved St. Louis into second and place. Three percentage points behind the leading Phils. Stan Musial slammed a three-run homer in the eighth.

CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP)--The Reds scooted to a four-run margin in the first inning and then threw back three Cubs' rallies to win, 8--5, tonight. Phil Cavarretta and Hank Sauer hit successive home runs with none on for Chicago in the fourth.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., June 30 --Touched off by bursting aerial bombs, a colorful flag-raising ceremony at this historical shrine today marked the official opening of the week-long, second National Boy Scout Jamboree.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 30-- Cariocas halted today as dancers gazed skyward admiring the giant Pan American World Airways stratocruiser carrying two score American publishers that landed at Galeao Airport at 1:20 P.M.

A complete new line of high capacity "robot-eye" controls for smoke prevention on the largest sizes of public utility and industrial boilers is now being put on the market. W.H. Holby, chief engineer of the General Power Plant Corporation, 381 Fourth Avenue,...

WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 30-- New Jersey will form a small, mobile guard of experienced officers and men if its National Guard should be called to Federal service, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of that state said here today.
Yesterday, 10-year-old Mickey De Bovis passed the first trial in his ambition to become center fielder for the New York Giants.
ACCOMAC, Va., June 30 (AP)-- The cargo door of an airliner winging over coastal Virginia flew open early today and a flier-passenger was swept to his death in the sea, a mile and a half below.
The cotton futures market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday closed steady, 4 to 22 points net higher.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30--The Dodgers blew another one tonight, this time when it hurt most. Before 31,555 cash customers in Shibe Park, who became slightly hysterical when the Phils scored four runs in the eighth, the Brooks were beaten, 8--5, and fell half a length behind Eddie Sawyer's young men, who thus attained first place.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 (AP)--Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor, two of Australia's young Davis Cup hopefuls, scored the biggest upset of the All-England lawn tennis championships today when they eliminated the topseeded American doubles team of Gardnar Mulloy and Bill Talbert, 8--6, 8--6, 8--10, 10--8.
The first United States troops to enter the fighting in Korea are going into what American military men have called "the toughest fighting terrain this side of the jungles of New Guinea."
A plan to clear up traffic snarls in congested business districts "at no cost except a few gallons of paint" has been submitted by a city engineer not directly concerned with the knotty problem.

A new retirement program at Columbia University made yesterday a day of figurative good-byes around the Morningside Heights campus as eleven professors received emeritus status and three top administrators left their posts to return to teaching.

Bankers Trust Company is considering the acquisition of the banking business of Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The latter institution, with deposits of nearly $60,000,000 at the end of last year, has a head office at 176 Broadway, and nine branches, five in the banking division.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 1-- Dr. George Woolsey, a retired surgeon, formerly of New York, died in his home here today after an illness of a month. His age was 89.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, June 24--Medical scientists have started here this hemisphere's first attempt at mass eradication of a disease by "one-shot" injections of penicillin.

AT the beginning of this century, the woman doctor occupied an ambiguous position. She was admitted freely to medical school, but was denied, in all except a few hospitals for women and children, the interneship necessary to complete her training.

THE third American Dance Festival at New London, which is to be given under the auspices of Connecticut College, has changed its format a bit this year, introducing four guest soloists in addition to the two resident companies, and scheduling...

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 1-- The marriage of Miss. Katherine Chandler Carr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bruce Carr Jr., to Richard Doane Grinnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Grinnell of Charlottesville, Va., took place here this morning in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.
Retail trade here made a good showing last week, with summer merchandise in good demand. Department store sales were estimated at about 6 per cent over the comparative week of last year.

The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Cecil C. Hine of 178 Bennett Avenue have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Margaret Adelaide, to William Francis Hurley 3d of Coronado, Calif., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William F. Hurley.
LONDON. NOW comes the suggestion, from an exalted level, that television should be rationed. Headmasters, prel ates, police and parents are worried about the effect of TV on children.

Savings and loan associations have moved into the strongest competitive position in their entire history. Based on President Truman's signing of the Savings and Loan Bill last week, the advance is being hailed by industry leaders as the most significant in two decades.

Opposing a bid by the Pan Atlantic Steamship Corporation to extend service to the ports of Galveston and Houston, the Newtex Steamship Line and the Seatrain Line will press the issue to the Supreme Court if necessary.

Reverse the stirrups, turn out the mounts to pasture; the cavalry has gone. The crepe is on the pommel, the mourning bow upon the sword hilt; the cavalry has gone.

THE experts probably could supply many reasons for the recent resurgence of the Cleveland Indians into pennant contention. Not the least of them, though, is Albert (Flip) Rosen, a hustling young man who thinks life is simply wonderful because he's being paid to do what he loves best, playing baseball. Please don't breathe a word of this to Messrs. Ellis Ryan, Hank Greenberg or Lou Boudreau, but he'd do it for free, it necessary.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Bartlett Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Amagansett, L.I., of the engagement of Mrs. Bartlett's daughter, Miss Barbara Winslow Tuttle, to Edward James May, son of Herbert A. May and the late Mrs. Sara Davidson May of Pittsburgh. The wedding will take place in the autumn.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)--A State Department spokesman denounced as "phony Communist propaganda" today a reported Russian protest against what Moscow called United States dumping of potato bugs in East Germany.
CHICAGO, July 2--Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, prominent American Zionist leader, today attributed confusion in the Zionist movement to a "lack of dynamics of action."

TOKYO, Monday, July 3--Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters has asked correspondents to refrain from identifying military units in the Korean military operations, and reporting the whereabouts of headquarters or the movements of troops, "proposed or in progress."

The rain had been drumming hard all through the day and suddenly out of the warm drizzle and mist of the night came the fireflies with their magic lanterns sparking cheerily in the gloom. These were the season's first arrivals.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 2 (AP)-- Two research achievements that may foreshadow more medical wonders through use of the now precious pituitary gland hormones were reported today by Dr. C.H. Li, discoverer of ACTH.

Two Cardinals presided at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. They were Cardinal Spellman and Manuel Cardinal Arteaga y Betancourt, Archbishop of Havana, Cuba, who is on a Holy Year pilgrimage to Rome.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 2--The Czechoslovak Communist party announced plans today to weed out undesirable members in its greatest purge since it took power in this country in February, 1948.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2--A home run beat the Dodgers in the first game with the Phils today and another homer saved them in the second game that was ended by the Sunday curfew in an 8-8 tie after ten innings. The umpires announced this game would be replayed in its entirety.

PARIS, July 2--Reports from Paris that concentrate on the headline news--the provisional solution of the Government crisis, the reaction to developments in Korea, the needling questions the Schuman plan delegations bring back from conferences with their governments--give a false idea of what the French capital feels and looks like.

Eagle Scout Byron Lay, who lives in Arizona "fourteen blocks from Mexico," took a boat ride around Manhattan Thursday with other Jamboree-bound Boy Scouts. Moving up the East River, the 15-year-old visitor looked with...

Six new films, including an importation from Russia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow: Today--"Crisis," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama starring Cary Grant and Jose Ferrer, at the Capitol. Richard Brools, who wrote the screen play from a story by Georges Tabori, also directed, and Arthur Freed produced.

Dr. Morris Kellogg Smith, chief of surgical service of the Halloran Veterans Administration Hospital, Staten Island, died late Saturday night at the home of his brother, Dr. T.A. Smith of Short Hills, N.J. His age was 64.

PARIS, July 2--Sharp fluctuations on the gold market were the outstanding feature of the week on the Paris Bourse. The French louis, the twenty-franc gold piece, which at the end of the previous week was selling for 3,030 francs,...

Petite and vivacious, Adele Simpson seems to carry the energy of a jet-propelled engine in her small frame. One marvels at a woman of her type, who creates four fashion collections a year, runs a town and a country house has time for her two children and her husband, and withal has time and energy for the minutest detail.

The three-story garden apartment building occupying a plot 198 by 205 feet and housing fifty-one families at 2 Greenridge Avenue White Plains, N.Y., was sold by Harry Lachman Sons to an investing client of Dreyer Traub for cash over mortgages amounting to $222,000. Robert E. Hill Inc., was the broker in the sale of the building, which was erected in 1939.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 2 (AP) --The 239-foot excursion steamer State of Pennsylvania grounded in the harbor here early this morning. No serious damage was done to the steel hull.
Twelve hundred Americans of Czechoslovak origin participated yesterday afternoon in a mass gymnastic spectacle as part of the twelfth quadrennial Sokol Slet.

ST. LOUIS, July 2--In a surprise move, the New York City Teachers Union, Local 555, United Public Workers, has withdrawn from the National Education Association. It withdrew in protest against a proposed ban on Communist teachers in the public schools.

ALBANY, July 2--The Public Service Commission warned in its annual report today that if the operating costs of public utilities continue to soar, "no act of this commission can preserve either the regulated company or the public from serious injury."

Giving expression to the gathering wrath of the civilized world against the Soviet-sponsored breach of international peace and security in Korea, thirty-nine members of the United Nations and one prospective member, Italy, have now lined up in support of...
Cotton prices last week in the domestic market worked higher, with day-to-day changes mostly small. During a few of the sessions, however, prices registered rather broad swings at times.
After a period of post-war readjustment, in which many of its activities were sharply curtailed, the United Seamen's Service is now considering plans for expanded peacetime operations.

NEW CITY, N.Y., July 2--Four out of ten amateur gardeners, especially commuters, have lost their wartime interest in raising vegetables. This was shown by a south Hudson valley survey made by William J. Clark, Rockland County Agricultural Agent of the United States Department of Agriculture.

North Koreans were reported to have thrown more armor across the Han River and to have outflanked Suwon and its airfield. Australian and United States planes hit invasion bases, one an airfield 145 miles inside North Korea. [1:8; map P.2.]

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lloyd of 178 East Seventy-second Street and Oyster Bay, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Herbert Lloyd, to Peter deLancey Wallace, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Campbell Wallace of 21 East Eightyseventh Street.

First-class accommodations to Europe are now available in all vessels of the Cunard fleet, commencing with the July 13 departure of the Mauretania, according to Vincent A. Demo, general passenger manager of the line.

MATUNUCK BEACH, R.I., July 2 (UP)--A powerful Canadian truck driver, spurted by news of his daughter's birth, won the $1,000 swim from Matunuck Beach to Block Island today. Tom Park, 26, of Hamilton, Ont., swam only twelve miles of the fifteen mile course before judges ordered the race halted because of pea soup fog. His time was 7 hours 9 minutes.

A lamp is an important decorative object that should give importance and drama to a room, in the opinion of Paavo Tynell, Finnish lighting designer, whose latest creations were shown last week at Finland House, 41 East Fiftieth Street.
Exiled leaders of Eastern Europe will speak to their countrymen behind the Iron Curtain tomorrow and thereafter in a new radio program.
Loans and discounts of the nation's 9,611 state-chartered bank on Dec. 31, 1949, totaled $25,694,031,000, according to an annual study of state banks.

The world's ten "most boring classics" have been selected by hundreds of the nation's amateur and professional literary critics. The idea was broached by Columbia University Press' "The Pleasures of Publishing."

OMAHA, Neb., July 2 (AP)--Jim English, formerly of Omaha, staged a record-smashing golf show today. The 24-year-old former Nebraska amateur champion, who has lived at Red Oak, Iowa, since last fall, routed Jack Vickers of Wichita, Kan., 11 and 10, in the final of the Trans-Mississippi tournament.

Out-of-town buyers last week completed their buying for fall. They asked for the merchandise to be shipped as quickly as possible for early promotion, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Zip-in coats were requested for delivery especially early.

CHICAGO, July 2--Grain markets moved up rapidly on the board of trade last week with all deliveries of wheat and soybeans except July and all deliveries of corn selling at new high prices for the season to date.
PARIS, July 2--Working swiftly through the day, Premier Henri Queuille announced tonight a new French Cabinet, without the Socialists, which will be based on the Center and the Right.

BOSTON, July 2--Determined to bludgeon their way back into the American League flag race at all costs, the Yankees today flattened the Red Sox, 15 to 9, in the series finale to split the four-game set. But that wasn't the Bombers' major story of the day.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 2 per cent in June compared with the same month last year, according to a month-end survey made by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

"America, like Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, is suffering from a dual personality," the Rev. Dr. Charles B. Foelsch, pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street, said in his morning sermon yesterday.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 2--Long experience in the air, skillful handling of a sailplane and a thorough knowledge of meteorology are -credited to the winner of the first event in the Northeastern States Soaring Contest being conducted here, the "soaring capital of the world."

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 2--Five hundred forty students from fifty-seven colleges and universities from Maine to Texas are here for six weeks of specialized training in the communications field at a Reserve Officers Training Corps encampment in the Camp Wood area of the Signal Corps Center.

CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP)--Bob Feller pitched his 200th major league victory today as the Indians won the second game of a doubleheader with Detroit, 5--3. The Tigers won the first game, 8--5, for their only triumph in a fourgame series.
MOSCOW, July 2 (AP)--Soviet newspapers continued their campaign for non-intervention in Korea today with new and harder-hitting epithets directed against the United States.
More than half of the 790,164 gross tonnage of deep-sea shipping now being built according to specifications of the American Bureau of Shipping is being made in foreign shipyards.
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., July 2 (AP)--Church call echoing across the valley brought a temporary calm to jamboree city today but 47,000 Boy Scouts could not remain quiet too long.

One of the immediate results of the Communist invasion of South Korea was a quick and drastic revision of the Far Eastern policy of the United States. The Administration declared that there had been no "reversal," but there was certainly a change to a completely different direction. Action was substituted for inaction, decision for indecision, moving for waiting.

The program started here last week by the Better Business Bureau of New York City to combat deception in the advertising and selling of television sets is expected soon to be taken up by local bureaus in at least two other large television centers, Philadelphia and Chicago.

This is about the time of year when wives in large numbers begin to leave their husbands-- without, one hastens to add, creating a buzz in social circles, although the disturbance within the homes being deserted by helpmeets may prove to be prodigious.

TOKYO, Monday, July 3 (AP)-- Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, commanding the Twenty-fourth Infantry Division, has been named commander of all United States forces in Korea, called U.S.A.I.K. (United States Army in Korea). The announcement of his appointment was made by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters.

More than any other group, Protestants have a great obligation to preach and maintain the double ideal of supremacy of God and recognition of the rights and dignity of the people, the Rev. Dr. F. Howard Callahan, pastor of the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-Sixth Street, said yesterday in his morning sermon.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 (AP)--George Munger batted in the Cardinals' first run, then scored the winning tally as St. Louis edged the Pirates, 2 to 1, today. Ralph Kiner hit his nineteenth homer in the eighth with the bases empty for the lone Pittsburgh run.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 2-- Ray Billows, a Walker Cup Player, survived the jinx that sometimes is associated with the winning of the medal by capturing a nineteenhole match from Neal Fulkerson of Cherry Valley in the second round of the Ekwanok Country Club invitation golf tourney for the Robert Todd Lincoln Cup today.

Leading engineers have recommended a long-range program of industrial water conservation that includes greatly expanded uses of salt water in manufacturing plants as a major remedy for current fresh-water shortages. These plans point toward the industrial advantages of tide-water factory sites that may increase greatly the importance of Eastern states.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)--A proposal to fight communism with a free flow of ideas on an ambitious scale will get public support this week from Gen. Dwight Eisenhower, Secretary of State Dean G. Acheson and many other prominent figures.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 2-- Movements on the Zurich stock exchange last week showed that President Truman's promptness in sending American armed forces into action in South Korea averted a panic in Europe and re-established confidence.
The immutable military law of supply and demand has commenced to exercise a dominating influence over the Korean fighting. The "battle of the build-up" has succeeded the "battle of the blitzkrieg."

A veteran of almost fifty years at sea and senior captain of the American Export Lines fleet, Capt. W.W. Kuhne was named yesterday as master of the new 26,000ton luxury liner Independence, now nearing completion at Quincy, Mass.

Picking up where he left off in the film version of "Life With Father," William Powell last night made his debut in a new transcribed radio series (9:30 P.M. on N.B.C.) which promised to be one of the more rewarding attractions of the summer. Under the title of "My Mother's Husband" he portrayed...

WASHINGTON, July 2--The United States has asked the Chinese Nationalist Government to confer with Gen. Douglas MacArthur before reaching a final decision on dispatching 33,000 seasoned troops from Formosa to South Korea.

VIENNA, July 2--A survey of the Communist "peace" campaign as recently conducted in the Soviet satellite countries of Eastern Europe and now to begin in Russia indicates that the Kremlin, paraphrasing Clausewitz, believes that peace is war continued by other means.

New efforts of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., to increase vacation and tourist business for the city through use of advertising techniques is be ing developed with the hope that results will lead to an organized full-scale campaign, an official of the organization disclosed last week.

The Government of the Republic of China received today a communication from the Secretary General of the United Nations requesting it, in accordance with the resolution adopted by the Security Council on June 27, 1950, to furnish such assistance...

Four privately owned pleasure craft went aground in New York waters yesterday, three of them within an hour. Police launches and Coast Guard picket boats went to their assistance quickly, and no one was hurt.

LOWELL, Mass., July 2--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Chester Morrill Runels of Lowell and Marshfield, of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne, to Robert Meeks Eggleston, son of Mrs. Jere Dudley Eggleston of Pelham, N.Y., and Pine Orchard, Conn., and the late Mr. Eggleston. The wedding has been planned for September.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 (Reuters)--Four countries--Brazil, Spain, Sweden and Uruguay--today won berths in next week's play-offs for the world soccer championship.
TROON, Scotland, July 2 (AP)-- Jimmy McHale, a Californian transplanted to Philadelphia, looks like the American long shot most likely to lift the British Open crown from South African Bobby Locke.

NO spots is writer ever should be so gullible as to pay attention to publicity releases from Hollywood which are meant to snatch a few lines in the sports pages. They always should be treated with considerable suspicion. But one arrived the other day and it was difficult to resist it because it sent the imagination racing down memory lane.

The American paper and pulp industry, source of important munitions materials as well as a large volume of containers and other products for military use during World War II, is prepared for reorganization of production to meet limited or full war emergencies virtually overnight, a key official said yesterday.

Although the crisis in the Far East in the final week of June pretty much overshadowed other developments, the business upswing last month probably made a new high, according to the National City Bank of New York in its monthly letter.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 2--The Government of Israel came out tonight in full support of the United Nations measures seeking to end the war in Korea.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP)--Bob Cain walked Roy Sievers with the bases full in the eleventh inning to give the Browns a 4-3 victory over the White Sox in the second game of a double-header today. Chicago. won the opener, 5--2.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 2-- Edgar L. Raymond Jr., at the helm of his 32-foot jib-headed ketch, Chanteyman, today won the twentieth annual Riverside-Stratford Shoals race and brought the Commodore Pierce Trophy to the Riverside Yacht Club.

RYE, N.Y., July 2--In the steadiest volume of breeze since the championship summer series of sail racing started out on Long Isand Sound in May, 126 craft spread canvas today in the regatta of the American Yacht Club. It was a creep-up over the season's top number by two.

B-29 Superforts of the Twentieth Air Force ranged far northward yesterday to strike the airfield at Yonpo on the east coast of Northern Korea. Returning pilots described the raid as excellent and stated that the entire target area was covered by smoke following the strike.

An annual memorial service for 12,000 patriots who died on British prison ships in Wallabout Bay in the Revolutionary War was held yesterday at the Emmanuel Baptist Church, Lafayette Avenue and St. James Place, Brooklyn.
Industrial pension plans may gum up the recruiting of manpower for war factories if an emergency makes it necessary to call hundreds of thousands of workers to new jobs.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 2--Miss Gloria Nora Forman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Forman, was married to S. Martin Billett, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Louis Billett, this morning in the garden of the home here of the bride's parents.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP)--The starting line-up of sixteen players selected by 3,167,326 baseball fans for the seventeenth annual major league All Star game in Chicago July 11 was announced today.
CHICAGO, July 2--A study by the University of Chicago discloses that 1,580 courses in race relations are being offered by 293 colleges and universities throughout the country.

LONDON, July 2--Under the open opera-commissioning plan in connection with the Festival of Britain, Arts Council judges have recommended to the council that four operas out of sixty for which required preliminary scores were submitted shall be commissioned to be completed.

The word censorship is abhorrent to General MacArthur, as it is to all believers in freedom of the news and a true democratic society. To anyone who has ever summered in Italy, the new Mercurio Restaurant, 106 West Fifty-second Street, brings back memories of similar establishments in Rome, Milan or Florence. Each table, covered with a red-checked cloth, has the tiny vase of flowers and the cool green bottle of mineral water that become a part of the table setting with the first warm day in Italy.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 2-- Representative John Davis Lodge of Westport, the Republican nominee for Governor in Connecticut, has used the weight of his position to bring about a reorganization of the Republican party leadership in the state.
DETROIT, July 2--Eliel Saarinen, world famous architect and city planner, died last night at his home in suburban Bloomfield Hills. He was 76 years old.

PITTSBURGH, July 2--If it were possible, steel demand was even more hectic last week as the result of the international situation. Most consumers had been trying to get as much steel as they could. They were meeting with no more success than they did weeks ago.
PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP)-- The Yonkers (N.Y.) Canoe Club took the annual Peoples Regatta over a half-mile course on the Schuylkill River today, scoring 39 points.

LONDON, July 2--How to end the state of war with Germany in spite of the fact that no peace treaty has been concluded will be the main question before the conference of the United States, British and French representatives that begins at the Foreign Office tomorrow.

CUZCO, Peru, June 29--The earthquake of May 21 that took at least ninety lives and left more than 10,000 persons homeless here also tore the adobe covering from a great Inca wall hidden since the colonial era.
WASHINGTON, July 2--Sales of television receivers to dealers in areas able to get good reception are estimated at 369,000 for April.

TOKYO, Monday, July 3--Four North Korean columns, at least two of them led by tanks, struck southward and southeastward today from Seoul, captured South Korean capital, toward United States infantry moving up swiftly to meet them.

A collision with a collier sank the 2,054-ton sand dredge Sandcraft in the Narrows yesterday before dawn. All thirty-four members of the sandsucker's crew were rescued. Some were fished out of the water after drifting seaward for a half hour on a strong ebb tide.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2-- Ray Milland will go to England late this summer to star in "Full Circle," a photoplay by Phillip McDonald, under a deal arranged by Coronado Productions, the David E. Rose Anglo-American company. Jacques Tourneur will direct the film and Joan Harrison will produce it.

GENEVA, July 2 (Reuters)-- The death was announced here today of Emile Jaques-Dalcroze, Swiss composer, who first linked music rhythm and gymnastics and invented the art of eurhythmics. He was 84 years old.

New York State's workmen's compensation law provides compensation only for disabilities and deaths that are the result of accidental injuries incurred on the job. Last year the law was temporarily expanded to include non-occupational disabilities and sickness.

GREENS FARMS, Conn., July 2--The engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Triplett Harrison of Greens Farms and 1 East End Avenue, New York, of their daughter, Gertrude Floyd-Jones, to Hamilton Winslow, son of Mrs. John Winslow of Montclair, N.J., and the late Mr. Winslow.

What has been happening to children in families on relief? What is being done to meet the needs of physically handicapped children? To what extent have the schools adopted an approach to child behavior that is concerned with finding the causes of problem behavior rather than considering it a matter of discipline?

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)-- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, declared today that "American boys are dying in Korea" because "a group of untouchables in the State Department sabotaged" the aid program that Congress had voted for Korea.
WASHINGTON, July 2--The Senate Commerce Committee today unveiled a bulky report designed "to show the pattern of race news distribution which is reaching the bookies" over the nation.
RYE, N.Y., July 2--Richard Savitt of East Orange, N.J., scored his most notable conquest today at the Westchester Country Club.

CHICAGO, July 2--Arthur J. Glover president of the striking Switchmen's Union of North America, A.F.L., flatly rejected today the request of John Thad Scott Jr., chairman of the National (Railway) Mediation Board, that the union call off its strike against five Western railroads.
WASHINGTON, July 2--The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period June 24 to 30 are given in the appended tabulation:

TAMPERS Finland, July 2 (UP) --Bob Richards of the Illinois A.C. set a new European pole vault record today when he cleared the bar at 14 feet 10 inches in a meet against Finnish athletes at Pyynikki Arena.

GONAIVES, Haiti, June 23-- Two voodoo chiefs demonstrated in a hut here tonight the ancient rituals of their religion. The demonstration indicated the extent of the problems voodoo poses for modern medicine's campaign to "eradicate" the widespread disease of yaws in Haiti.
MANILA, July 2--Government preparations for an emergency stemming from fright over the Korean situation are taking a political turn here.

NINETEEN years ago a scholarly biography was published in England by a young historian of 32, named Arthur Bryant. It was "King Charles II,"* and it made Mr. Bryant famous. Since then he has written nineteen other distinguished books, written and produced a series of historical pageants and, since 1936, written a weekly article for The Illustrated London News. WASHINGTON, July 2 (U.P.)-- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, said today he would like more relief for small business than the House-approved Tax Bill provides and smaller tax increases for larger corporations.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)-- Mortgage debts of individuals continued to increase at a near-record rate in the first quarter of 1950, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
National security from the standpoint of the merchant marine will be submitted to an intensive re-examination and appraisal this week.

LONDON, July 2--It is a long time since the City received such a shock as was experienced last week from the Communist invasion of South Korea. Coming like a bolt from the blue when the stock market was steadily gaining confidence, its effect was dramatic.
MADRID, July 2--Generalissimo Francisco Franco was reported still confined to his room today after a week of suffering from an unspecified intestinal ailment.

DETROIT, July 2 (AP)--Dr. Cary Middlecoff, the touring dentist from Ormond Beach, Fla., led an all-out assault on par today as he posted a 133 to take a one-stroke lead at the midway point of the Motor City Open golf tournament.

Uppermost in Helen Hayes' mind are the problems of young performers. Rather than discuss the subject from an academic standpoint, she is doing something about it. To that end, Miss Hayes is negotiating for the rights to put on a revival of Sir James M. Barrie's fantasy, "Mary Rose," next winter, she said yesterday.

Baseball is a game in which a club must make the most of its openings, and because the Giants failed to do so in the nightcap they dropped both ends of yesterday's double-header with the Braves at the Polo Grounds.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (U.P)-- Fearful that the Korean crisis might explode into World War III, Congress may forget economy and give the Defense Department all the funds it requested this year.

Charles Masterson and Jack Geller, rated seventh and eighth respectively, were the only seeded players on hand yesterday as play continued in the New York State tennis championships at the Seminole Tennis Club at Forest Hills and both came through with straight-set victories.

We believe the City Planning Commission has taken a step in the right direction in adopting a zoning amendment that would require that garage or parking space be provided with housing construction of the future. In its last meeting the Board of Estimate put off this proposal for further study, but it deserves consideration soon.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2-- "New patterns in women" to meet the demands of the future were called for tonight by Dr.K. Frances Scott of Northampton, Mass., at the opening session of the biennial convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.
LIMA, Peru, July 2--While soldiers with fixed bayonets guarded some polling places, Peru's first national election in five years was held today in an atmosphere of lethargy.
Heavy traffic clogged highways in and out of the metropolitan area yesterday, the second day of the four-day Fourth of July week-end.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)-- Representative Ivor D. Fenton, Republican of Pennsylvania, appealed today to Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson to halt the use of oil for heating national defense establishments.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed somewhat irregular yesterday, 3 points lower to 32 points higher, with the March contract stronger than other months.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 3--The North Korean Government sent a bitter protest to the United Nations today, accusing the United States of "bare-faced aggression" and serving notice that Communist forces would press forward "their holy war" against South Korea.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)-- Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois said today he would like to know "what has happened to the business judgment of Boston bankers."

The Atlantic passenger fleet is receiving reinforcements for the exceptionally heavy Holy Year travel season from nine reconverted liners, converted troopers and freighters all but two of which are operating under the flag they flew before the war.

MONTREAL, July 3 (Canadian Press)--Leon Keyserling, chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, said here tonight that the United States' rate of economic growth should enable a 25 per cent increase in the nation's general standard of living within ten years.

CINCINNATI, July 3 (AP)--The Reds, who had taken a long-term lease on last place in the National League, finally dug themselves out today by beating the Pirates, 8 to 5, despite two home runs bY Ralph Kiner. The Cincinnati triumph dropped Pittsburgh into the cellar.

I have the honor to request you to bring to the notice of all members of the United Nations the declaration made by me on the instructions of the Government of the Korean People's Democratic Republic on 1 July, 1950.

The hide futures market on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday belatedly joined the general upswing in commodity market prices due to developments in Korea. Prices advanced 52 to 65 points, setting new highs for all active contracts as trading expanded to 3,760,000 pounds.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 3--Even though the poor weather here today "had the birds walking" on near-by Harris Hill, the sailplane pilots competing in the Northeastern States Soaring Contest refused to be grounded.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 3-- Herman Barron of Fenway dominated the one-day Westchester P.G.A. best-ball tournament today over the hilly Mount Kisco Country Club course. Paired with two of his home club members, Saul Lantzis and Alvin Sheerr, Barron won first and second places on cards of 10 and 9 under par, 30, 32--62, and 30, 33--63, respectively.
LEWISBORO, N.Y., July 3-- This 224-year-old town in the northeast corner of Westchester County at the Connecticut border is getting ready to dedicate its first Town Hall.
After a successful tryout earlier in the year, Menasha Skulnik, the wan tragi-comic who skips about stage, opened in his own comedy series last night on N.B.C. Television (8 P.M.).

MINEOLA, L.I., July 3--A classified file of 400,000 individual marks of laundries and cleaners will be placed in the custody of the policeman succeeding the late Acting Captain Adam Yulch as head of the laundry mark bureau in the Nassau County Police Department.

BARCELONA, Spain, July 3-- Seventy-two United States students have cancelled their reservations for a summer course in Spanish culture organized by the University of Barcelona and the course has been dropped. Persons connected with the course say the cancellations were made "for political reasons" because of pressure put on the students.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The people of Puerto Rico received today an opportunity to assume a wider degree of self-rule than ever before as President Truman signed a bill offering them a constitutional government.
WASHINGTON, July 3--Joe DiMaggio made his debut as a first baseman today and it may be reported without fear of contradiction that the Clipper acquitted himself exceptionally well.

Steel warehouse executives here are discounting possibilities of imposition of emergency federal price controls and allocations at this time, spokesmen said yesterday in a canvass of leading companies.
With one day remaining of the four-day holiday week-end, traffic fatalities in the nation rose sharply yesterday to 336, an increase of ninety-six in twenty-four hours.
Although it is a prevalent illusion, the best fishing is not to be had in faraway places.

An apartment house site of about six acres on Pelham Road at the foot of North Avenue in New Rochelle, N.Y., has been purchased by Alfred Kaskell, president of the Carol Management Corporation from the City of New Rochelle. Maxwell R. Feinberg was the broker.

The Puget Sound Power and Light Company agreed yesterday to sell its extensive properties in Seattle, Wash., to the City of Seattle for $25,850,000. The utility originally asked $45,000,000 and the city offered about $23,000,000.

More than 1,000 friends, former colleagues and public officials attended a funeral service yesterday afternoon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, for Dr. Albert A. Berg, philanthropist and, former presi

WASHINGTON, July 3--The Federal Government closed its fiscal year 1950 with a deficit of $3,122,000,000, which was $2,411,000,000 less than was forecast by President Truman in his budget message in January, the United States Treasury announced today.

Borough President Maurice A. FitzGerald of Queens has asked the Board of Estimate to deny tax exemption to the proposed $18,568,148 housing project planned by the Clearview Housing Company, Inc., on an 88-acre site near Francis Lewis Boulevard and Seventeenth Avenue, south of Whitestone.
EASTON, Pa., July 3--Dr. William Mackey Smith, head of the Department of Mathematics at Lafayette College, died today in Easton Hospital. He was 69 years old.

TRENTON, July 3--Federal District Judge Philip Forman weighed today a request of a small New Jersey electric lamp manufacturer to intervene in the Government's anti-monopoly action against the General Electric Company and seven associated concerns.
In line with the cooperative campaign to increase retail grocery sales, the National-American Wholesale Grocers Association made available yesterday a check list of fifty operational aids.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 4--A communique issued by Gen. Douglas MacArthur today indicated that the advance by North Korean troops in South Korea had slowed down.

TAEJON, Korea, July 3 (AP)-- The Foreign Minister of invaded South Korea today thanked the United Nations and the United States for support, and said this might be "the hour of recession of the tide of communism."

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)-- Twenty-one Republican members of the House of Representatives today endorsed as "a brilliaint document" a statement of principles by a group of party members who called themselves "the Republican Advance."

It was a little difficult yesterday to keep from throwing caution overboard and predicting that the reservoirs and lakes in the immediate environs of New York City were on the threshold of the biggest season for black bass in years.

A plot of 15,000 square feet with a frontage of eighty-eight feet on Kissena Boulevard between Seventy-first Avenue and 156th Street in Flushing, Queens, has been sold by John Benthin to a client of the Connaughton Agency, broker in the transaction.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 4--The Soviet Government accused the United States Government today of "gradually pushing the country step by step into an open war" through "direct acts of aggression" in Korea.

The sand dredge Sandcraft came within ten feet of bumping an anchored tanker before it collided with and was sunk by the collier Melrose in the Narrows, a Coast Guard board of inquiry was told yesterday.

MANILA, July 2--The Philippine republic of today is a brash and turbulent new democracy that is trying hard to consolidate its status as an independent nation after 350 years of Spanish and American rule.
PARIS, July 3--The Schuman plan for merging the coal and steel production of Western Europe ran into its first serious snags today.
HONG KONG, July 3--A usually reliable source reported here today that American oil companies had been told to stop sending petroleum products to Communist China.

Mary Donados is only 10 years old, but she has her summer plans all made. Her home is at 404 West Fifty-eighth Street, and that's only two blocks and a tree-shaded path from the August Heckscher Playground in southern Central Park, which is Mary's summer headquarters.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 4-- American troops went into action against North Korean forces yesterday for the first time, General MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

Senator Morse of Oregon called upon the President yesterday to take whatever steps may be necessary to end the railway switchmen's strike, because, said he, "we are at war." The union and the railroads, he declared, "owe it to the American people to get together and negotiate a settlement."

CHICAGO, July 3--The situation in the nine-day switchmen's strike against five Midwestern and Western railroads remained stalemated today, but mediation continued in the attempt to avert the possibility of a strike by trainmen and conductors before July 15.
A comprehensive plan to develop the tourist industry in Venezuela to increase its dollar-producing power is under consideration there.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The Senate Finance Committee, ruling out delay in considering the Houseapproved tax bill, decided today to start hearings on Wednesday with a view to getting the measure to the floor by July 20.

PARIS, July 3--Premier Henri Queuille will bring his Cabinet before the French National Assembly tomorrow with the parties still confused and undecided on how to take the new Government combination. The Socialists, having been left on the outside, were especially uncertain and were still debating whether to oppose the Government or abstain.

Once more France has a shaky Government in a critical time. In forming a Right-Center Cabinet without the Socialists, Henri Queuille, the new Premier, probably did the only practical thing. There could not be a strong Government in the circumstances.

Just over a year ago the National Committee for a Free Europe was formed by a group of public-spirited private American citizens, who wished to do something concrete about preserving the breath of liberty and democracy among the Communist-controlled peoples behind the Iron Curtain.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 3 (UP)--The Alaska Air Command said tonight that "something" which appeared to be a guided missile had passed over this strategic United States defense outpost Saturday night and officers were investigating reports that a similar object had been seen this morning.

NEWARK, July 3--Supplies from six New Jersey plants of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company were shut off today by pickets representing the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, A.F L. The strike was called yesterday at the Newark plant by Local 177 and at the Paterson plant by Local 129.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 3 (AP)--A reorganization plan for the bankrupt Florida East Coast Railway should include a provision for its capitalization at $45,000,000, the St. Joe Paper Company suggests in a revised plan submitted to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 3--President Truman held a secret conference with national leaders this afternoon to consider calling a special joint session of Congress to deal with the Korean war. Afterward it was reported that he had decided not to take this action at present.

WADING RIVER, L.I., July 3-- Mrs. Lawrence Eisenhauer is spending the holiday week-end here at Boy Scout Camp Wauwepex, seeing at first hand the things she hears about all year from her husband and children.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 3-- Oklahoma's primary campaign ended tonight with the experts divided on the number of persons who will interrupt their Fourth of July holiday to vote tomorrow.

Another blow was directed yesterday at the stock market, but a come-back in the afternoon permitted extreme losses of 4 points to be whittled considerably. Selling in the forenoon was directed mainly against the key issues and these also proved the spearheads for the afternoon recovery. The decline

The steel industry's operating rate will fall below capacity this week for the first time in twelve weeks. With holiday shutdowns today lowering the steel production rate 8.6 points to 92.6 per cent of ingot capacity, the industry's run of record production will end.

Exactly what was expected to happen did happen in the 55th Gazelle Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. It was figured by almost all concerned--owners, trainers, players and mere objective observers in the crowd of 30,763--that the Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt entry of Next Move and Bed o' Roses would finish in that order in the $20,000 added event.

A UNITED STATES POSITION South Korea Front, July 3 (AP)-- Mustang planes bearing Australian markings staged a furious machine-gun and rocket attack near this United States position today, slightly, wounding one American sergeant.
WASHINGTON, July 3--The Joint Chiefs of Staff today ordered a force of Marines, probably a division, as well as Marine air units to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's command in the Korea fighting.

The Soviet Union has made significant progress in reducing the work time required to buy consumers' necessaries over the past two and a half years, according to fixed state store prices reported to the Office of Foreign Labor Conditions of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3--"Not the analytical ability of men but the intuition of women" was acclaimed tonight by William S. Rosecrans, vice president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, as the greatest safeguard the country possessed for resisting propaganda.

GENEVA, July 3--The eleventh session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council opened here today in a sombre atmosphere. Delegates of fifteen nations representing the non-Communist world opened discussions of the heavy agenda with one ear cocked to get the latest news of Korean fighting. ing.

LONDON, July 3--Prime Minister Clement Attlee gave the House of Commons an appreciative review today of moves in many parts of the British Empire in support of the United Nations Security Council's decision to aid Southern Korea.
"I'LL make a deal with you, Rube," said Connie Mack craftily. "If you'll also pitch the second game of the double-header, you can have a couple of days off to go fishing."
All witnesses agreed that a bridge-jumping took place at 4:45 P.M. yesterday somewhere along the lower East River but the identities of the jumper and the bridge were still mysteries last night.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 3-- The Race Relations Department of Fisk University has completed the first of several rank-and-file studies it is making of minoritygroup practices prevailing in the United Packinghouse Workers of America, C.I.O.
Political exiles from Czechoslovakia and Rumania began recording radio programs at the WMCA studios yesterday in the Radio Free Europe series.

CHICAGO, July 3--Heavy evening-up operations and profit-taking for the July 4 holiday resulted in an irregular close on the Board of Trade today after an early bulge had carried all deliveries of grain and soybeans to new seasonal highs except for July wheat and oats.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The headquarters of three of America's chief women's organizations are now being taken over by three personalities in some ways new to the national scene, but in many ways typical of the women they represent. The new leaders are:

Frederic Balazs came to this country in 1940 with the clothes he was wearing, a violin and twenty-one cents. Tonight he will step to the podium at Lewisohn Stadium in white tie and tails, with a few dollars in his pocket and a baton in his hand.

The Federal Housing Administration will offer on July 12 a total of $42,219,000 of temporary-loan notes. Of the eleven public-housing agencies included, the three largest are Baltimore, $13,495,000 of notes due on Dec. 1, 1950, Boston, $14,977,000 due on Dec. 1, 1950, and New York, $9,467,000 due on Feb. 9, 1951.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 3-- Pierce (Bud) Russell of Troy, who has previously triumphed twice in the Ekwanok Country Club invitation golf tourney for the Robert Todd Lincoln Cup, gained the final once more this afternoon when he vanquished Joe McBride, the metropolitan amateur champion, 2 and 1, by rallying to win the last three holes.

CAIRO, July 3--United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery expressed to Egyptian Foreign Minister Mohamed Saleh el Din today his Government's regret that Egypt was not supporting the United Nations Security Council in the Korean aid resolution.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 3-- Warren Noble, automotive engineer and inventor, died last night in the Brunswick Home here after a long illness. Mr. Noble, who was 65 years old, lived at the Garden City Hotel.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 (AP)--Rain and bad weather held up play for four and a half hours at the All-England lawn tennis tournament today before four players finally squeezed in one hour's play.

There was a marked pick-up in interest in the New York State tennis championship at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills yesterday with the arrival on the scene of the headliners, occupied over the week-end at the Westchester Country Club.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP)--The Braves beat the Phillies, 3 to 1, today to make the National League's first division a very congested place just one day short of the traditional midway point in the season.
Seventy-five American artists issued a statement yesterday strongly defending the Metropolitan Museum of Art against charges that it was hostile to advanced art.

A code of ethical standards for clinical and consulting psychologists is being completed and will be presented to the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association in September, the official organization of the nation's psychologists.

DETROIT, July 3 (AP)--Lanky Fred Haas Jr. of Claremont, Calif., set a new course record of 64-- eight under par--at Red Run Counry Club today to go into a three-way tie for the lead at the three-quarter mark of the 72-hole $15,000 motor city golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)--The Army added five names to its Korean casualty list today for an officially reported total of sixteen missing from one air crash.

Alexander Borovsky, Russian pianist, made his Lewisohn Stadium debut last night with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony in a concert directed by Alexander Smallens that got the third week of the season off to a very pleasant start.

BALTIMORE, July 3--William F. Cochran, churchman and philanthropist, who devoted his life and a large part of his fortune to various welfare and reform movements, died last night at his suburban home near here. He was 74 years old.

North Korean forces crossed the Han River east of Seoul in the vicinity of Kwangjang on July 2 and advanced south and southwest toward Suwon in two small parallel columns eight and twelve miles east of Seoul.
The events occurring in Korea arose on June 26 as a result of a provocative attack of the troops of the South Korean authorities on border areas of the Korean People's Democratic Republic.
Samson Raphaelson's drama, "Hilda Crane," which was scheduled for production here this fall under the sponsorship of the Theatre Guild, will not be presented under Guild auspices.

LONDON, July 3--A meatless week-end for Londoners was followed today by the danger of a stoppage in the delivery of other rations as the ten-day-old strike at the Smithfield Market spread from the meat to other departments this morning.

The Navy's Philippine Mars alighted gently on Rockaway Inlet yesterday afternoon with ninetytwo midshipmen from the Naval Academy on a routine training cruise. They had left Jacksonville, Fla., five and a half hours before.

TORONTO, Ont., July 3-- Church leaders from six nations gathered here tonight on the campus of Emmanuel College to participate in the first of a series of twelve conferences designed to guide the future policy of Protestant and Orthodox bodies throughout the world.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 3--One of the most unusual exchanges of population in history is under consideration.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 3 --A 150-year-old windmill is being moved along the ocean beach in the Hamptons these days.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The merger and consolidation of five gas companies, all of Oil City, Pa., was authorized by the Securities and Exchange Commission today. The companies involved are the United Natural Fuel Gas Company, the Ridgeway Natural Gas Company, St. Mary's Natural Gas Company, Smethport Natural Gas Company and the Mercer County Gas Company.

ST. LOUIS, July 3--The National Education Association, in a "Report on the Enemy," was told today that a highly organized and well financed attack on public education was now under way in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 3--Masterful diplomacy by the State Department played an important, possibly an indispensable, part in persuading Prime Minister Nehru and the Government of India to endorse the second resolution of the United Nations that urged its members to use "armed force" to repel aggression in South Korea.
CUZCO, Peru, June 30--Great as was the destruction caused by the earthquake of May 21 here, the population has borne up remarkably well.

Fourth of July was a day for community celebration till the automobile broke up the crowd and hurried each family away for its own private partying. The gathering used to be big; so was the menu and, apparently, the appetites.

DAMARISCOTTA MILLS, Me., July 3--The marriage of Miss Harriet Barton Scovil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lorne Scovil of Samhar Lodge, New Harbor, and Basking Ridge, N.J., to Howard Rockwell Townsend of New Canaan, Conn., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Howard Rockwell Townsend of Oyster Bay, L.I., took place here this afternoon in the rectory of St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.
LOS ANGELES, July 3--Coordinated ensembles for various occasions, from sports and play to cocktail and informal evening wear dominated the fall showings of the Los Angeles market.

TOKYO, July 3--The Japanese Government is planning to offer "peaceful cooperation" with the United Nations international police action that sent United States troops and United States, British and Australian air and naval units to Korea to halt the Communist invasion of the South Korean Republic.

The utility industry in this state --and that embraces gas, electric transit and communications companies--reacted with mild alarm, some resentment and the usual reluctance when asked to comment on the 1949 report of the Public Service Commission that became available to most of them, yesterday.

Praise for the defenders of the Republic in past wars will be mingled with prayers for the safety of its youth battling to preserve human freedom in Korea as the nation today marks the 174th anniversary of Independence Day.

WASHINGTON, July 3--Through a loan described by Senators as a fantastic transaction, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has put the Government indirectly into the gambling business, according to testimony today before a Senate subcommittee investigating lending policies of the Federal agency.
United States forces--air, sea and land--were converging on Korea yesterday, but the North Korean Communist Army, firmly established across the Han River, was still probing to the South.
Eleven innings, nearly every one a pulse-stopper, were needed by the Giants and Dodgers to reach a decision under the hot sun at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3-- "Montserrat," the Lillian Hellman play of last fall which Anatole Litvak bought for the screen in December, has been acquired for Twentieth Century-Fox from Litvak.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 3 (AP)--John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, said today the occupation authorities now were Willing to reconsider the Bonn Government's request for West German central police force.

Mill prices of upper grade Canadian hardwoods are now so high that some American distributors are considering a thirty-day withdrawal from the Canadian market. This was made known yesterday by E.R. Plunkett, president of Plunkett-Webster, Inc., one of the largest wholesalers in the Northeast.
CHICAGO, July 3--Vice President Alben W. Barkley, upholding United States action in Korea, declared here today that "a free world can no longer retreat."
The first work relief program in this city since the depression of the Thirties will start tomorrow.

TROON, Scotland, July 3 (AP)-- Flory Van Donck, a six-foot Belgian who has been winning British tournament purses for two years, shot around Troon's sand dunes today in a record 65 to lead first round qualifiers in the British Open golf championship.
Importers of steel, watching both domestic and foreign markets closely, are now giving greater leeway to forward commitments, it was reported here yesterday.
Unions are planning to use the same tactic that proved successful in establishing pensions in the basic industries to break down employer resistance to a guaranteed annual wage.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 3--Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek urged today that the United Nations charge Russia with having instigated the war in Korea, and order her to end it.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 4--Paul A. Schweizer was named tonight winner of the four-day Northeastern States Flying Contest at Harris Hill here.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 4-- Lobstermen in the Narragansett Bay area say they are having the poorest season in the history of the industry.

Donald McNeill, Ricardo Balbiers of Chile and Bernard Schreiber moved into the quarter-final round of the New York State tennis championship yesterday on the clay courts of the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.
James H. (Jimmy) Doolittle former commanding general of the war-time Eighth Air Force and leader of the famous Tokyo raid was named yesterday as the out standing aviator of the last ten years.

WASHINGTON, July 4--Leland Burnette Morris, veteran State Department figure and first United States Ambassador to Iran, died here on Sunday in George Washington University Hospital. He was 64 years old.

The Bayside National Bank, Bayside, Queens, reported deposits of $18,746,019 and assets of $20,488,942 on June 30, 1950, compared, respectively, with $16,818,934 and $18,418,163 on Dec. 31, 1949. The fourth anniversary next Monday of the death of Sidney Hillman, founder and first president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O., will find construction workers almost finished with the two-year task of building the $1,000,000 Sidney Hillman Health Center at 14 East Sixteenth Street.

The Jonkoping football club of Sweden ended a successful North American tour by defeating a picked eleven representing the German-American Soccer League, 4 to 2, at Throggs Neck Stadium in the Bronx, yesterday. Of ten games played, the tourists won six, lost three and tied one.

WASHINGTON, July 4--Forgetting such eccentricities as converting Joe DiMaggio into a first baseman, the Yankees today concentrated on the more serious business of bowling over second-division entries. But once again Casey Stengel's Bombers found that...
SAN FRANCISCO, July 4-- Business activity in California and other Western States maintained a steady upward trend through the early months of 1950, independent surveys showed today.

WASHINGTON, July 4--The Air Force issued today a general call for critically needed specialists in radar work and the whole field of electronics. It asked for voluntary return to active duty of reservists having the required skills.

WATERTOWN N.Y., July 4-- Members of the Fiftieth Armored Division, National Guard, and the Seventy-eighth Infantry Division Organised Reserve Corps, both New Jersey groups, with their attached units, did not pause in their training today to mark Independence Day.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 5-- United States troops went into action tody on a South Korean warfront aflame with a Communist offensive that flanked the SeoulInchon-Suwon triangle.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)-- Two veteran officers, who won decorations in the Pacific campaigns of World War II, will lead the Marines in the Korean theatre.
MANILA, Wednesday, July 5 (AP) --A Filipino publisher wrote today that he had talked with Luis Taruc, head of the Communist-led Hukbalahaps, and published pictures to prove it.

Nearly $250,000 has been allocated by the Research Corporation in the form of eighty-three grants in aid of research to colleges, universities and scientific institutions in twenty-four states and the District of Columbia.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 (AP)--The chances of an all-American men's final in the all-England lawn tennis championships vanished on the center court at Wimbledon today. But on the No. 1 court the United States made certain that it would have one man in the last two for the fifth straight year.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 4 --Continued reports of the growing remilitarization of East Germany have not altered the Western Allies' view that the West German Government requires neither an army nor an army-type police force, despite the example set by the Communist invasion in Korea.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 4--Mediation procedures, which have been suggested repeatedly during the past several days to help end the Korean war, were generally ruled out today at the United Nations. The view firmly held in most quarters here is that talks are useless until the Communist troops withdraw behind the Thirty-eighth Parallel to their pre-attack positions.
