BOSTON, July 4 (AP)--The Red Sox-Athletics double-header was washed out by heavy showers today after two innings of the first game.
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., July 4-- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared tonight that the United States' decision to intervene against the "outrageous invasion" of South Korea was "inescapable."
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP)-- John B. (Jack) Kelly Jr. scored a pair of victories on the Schuylkill River today to lead the Vesper Boat Club to victory in the annual Peoples Regatta.
ROGERS, Ark., July 4 (UP)--If the Korean war and the atomic bomb have made you jittery, an Arkansas man thinks he has the answer to your problem--for a price.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 4 (AP) --Sungari led all the way in the $10,000-added Colleen Stakes at Monmouth Park today, and was three lengths in front of Brazen Brat at the finish. Top Level was third.
Harbor police reported late yesterday afternoon that they had not yet found any trace of a man who fell or jumped from a Staten Island ferryboat at 3:45 A.M., at the height of a severe thunderstorm.

LONDON, July 4--Most sections of the stock market made some progress today toward recovery from yesterday's sharp falls. British Government securities and South African gold mining shares in particular regained a considerable part of their losses.

PARIS, July 4--Little-known details of the American Revolution figured in a singular court action here today as the Marquis of Bausset-Roquefort sought to establish his title to vast New York State holdings he said had been acquired by an ancestor in the last years of the eighteenth century.

STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP)-- King Ranch's Middleground lost some ground in his quest for 3-year-old honors today when he could do no better than third to Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' Post Card and Rokeby Stables' County Delight in the $22,500 added Leonard Richards Stakes, closing day feature at Delaware Park.
BROOKLINE, Mass., July 4-- Charles E. Stewart, a mechanical engineer, who supervised the motorization of the Boston Fire Department, died today at his home here. His age was 70.
ISTANBUL, July 4--A congress of the People's party, defeated in the May election, ended last night in Ankara with the re-election of Gen. Ismet Inonu as the organization's president.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4-- Transamerica Corporation and the Bank of America, now involved in litigation with the Federal Reserve Board over transfer of twenty-two branch banks, prepared today to argue their case before the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4-- Coming out of the West, as did a young man named Lochinvar, a dry squall today hit the racing fleet in the annual regatta of the Larehmont Yacht Club.
PAGELAND, S.C., July 4--A stock car in an Independence Day race hurtled into a knot of spectators at the Pageland Beach Track infield today, killing two persons and injuring at least twelve.

CAIRO, July 4--Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador, called on the Egyptian Foreign Minister again today in a further effort to change Egypt's decision to abstain from supporting the United Nations resolution for aid to Southern Korea. He had called on the same mission yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, July 4-- Eight Southern California counties have 52 per cent more residents than they had ten years ago, preliminary census figures disclosed today.

An end to the period of skyrocketing coffee prices is predicted by W.F. Williamson, executive vice president of the National Coffee Association. Most of the pressures that created the unprecedented coffee price inflation have disappeared, he explained.

HENLEF-ON-THAMES, England, July 4 (AP)--American crews from three colleges and two prep schools present the greatest mass challenge to British rowing honors in the 111-year history of the Royal Henley regatta, which opens tomorrow.

Twenty-one Republican members of the House of Representatives have endorsed a statement of principles drafted over the week-end by a group of rankand-filers who call themselves "The Republican Advance." The statement favors a strongly international foreign policy and a progressive program of domestic legislation.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP)-- Representative Walter E. Brehm, Republican of Ohio, said today that so far as he was concerned the "Republican Advance" movement launched in Philadelphia last week was not intended to repudiate the party's Congressional leadership.

WASHINGTON, July 4--Plans were being pushed with a sense of urgency at the State Department today in the Government's effort to enlarge and strengthen the link between the United Nations and the many-nation command of Gen. Douglas MacArthur in Korea.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (U.P.)-- The Railway Mediation Board today called on striking Great Lakes dock workers in Ohio to return to their jobs while a Presidential emergency board investigates their dispute.

DETROIT, July 4 (AP)--Most auto assembly lines extended the week-end shutdown from last Friday night through to Wednesday morning, so July production gets away to a slow start. The month's output will fall considerably below the record of more than 855,000 vehicles the factories rolled out in June.
LONDON, July 4 (Reuters)-- The three-day match between the West Indies cricket team and Hampshire was drawn at Southampton today.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)-- The invasion of South Korea by Northern Communists has made the development of strong democratic trade unions in Asia more important than ever, the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions said today.

Mike Monroney, 48 years old, a six-term member of the House of Representatives, held a small but increasing lead late tonight over Senator Elmer Thomas. 73-year-old farm and silver bloc spokesman, who sought a fifth term in Oklahoma's Fourth of July primary election.

The United States Treasury has just closed its books on the fiscal year 19491950. The fiscal result is more encouraging--or perhaps one should say less disheartening--than that for which the country had prepared itself on the basis of the President's revised estimates of last January.

Large manufacturers will probably avoid the effects of President Truman's veto of recent basing point price legislation by expanding branch plants, purchasing agents in this district disclosed last week.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 4 (AP)-- The United States escort carrier Sicily, its decks loaded with warplanes, sailed from here today for an undisclosed destination.

TOKYO, July 4--The Japanese Cabinet adopted today a basic policy of peaceful collaboration with the United Nations policing operations and the United States forces resisting the Communist invasion of the South Korean Republic.

Rules issued by the city for collection of the new sewer rental charge showed yesterday how the Water Department proposed to raise $15,000,000 annually by this device to remove pollution from surrounding waters.

CHICAGO, July 4--Business prospects for the immediate future in general are still bright, James E. Walsh of Oscar Mayer Co., president of the Chicago Association of Credit Men, reports in a survey of accounts receivable just completed.

The Giants split a twin bill with the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds yesterday before 49,316 fans, the season's largest National League crowd.

Dr. Charles Frederick Bolduan of Northport, L.I., a leading public health official in this city for many years, died yesterday after a brief illness at Bellevue Hospital. His age was 77.

Hoyt, who as First Deputy Police Commissioner became known as the father of modern traffic control in New York, died of a heart attack Monday night while visiting friends in New Rochelle, N.Y. FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 4 (U.P.)--The Alaska Air Command announced today that a flaming object that flashed across the sky over Fairbanks Saturday night was a meteor.

RENO, Nev., July 4 (AP)--Charles W. Mapes Jr. today described as "ridiculous" Senatorial protests over a Government loan to his hotel here.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP)-- The way it has been treated and mistreated, it is a wonder there remains a copy of the Declaration of Independence. The historic document, now scarred by the years and hardly legible, is under glass at the Library of Congress. But it had a hard time getting there.

WASHINGTON, July 4--The Securities and Exchange Commission reported a new high record of $69,000,000,000 of net working capital of corporations, exclusive of banks and insurance companies, at the end of March. The previous high level had been $1,300,000,000 less at the end of 1949.

CONWAY, Mass., July 4--Within a few hours after seeing their 92-year-old town hall destroyed by fire today, citizens of this western Massachusetts hill town regathered to dedicate a new swimming pool that had been all but pumped dry in a battle with the flames.
SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., July 4 (AP)--Efforts to quench a forest fire with man-made rain apparently failed today.

The crew of a Harbor Police launch rescued four teenage boys in trouble in the Hudson River last night after a holiday outing in a rowboat. The small craft was caught in strong river currents.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 4-- Banco Brazil ceased issuing dollar remittances for commercial bills beginning in May and the ban still continues. The decision was taken suddenly without issuance of any formal statement. Market analysts blame the falling off in Brazilian exports in recent months.

LONDON, July 4 (Reuters)--Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Eachequer, told Parliament today it would remain British Government policy to get as much of Britain's requirements from Canada as she could afford to pay for in dollars.

Comdr. Ernest J. Leonard, a retired Naval officer who had served on active duty for nearly forty years, died Monday evening at his home, 3207 Avenue J, Brooklyn. He was a veteran of both World Wars.
RYE, N.Y., July 4--Favorites in the women's Eastern clay courts tennis championships advanced today at the Westchester Country Club as seven of the eight quarter final berths were filled.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 4 --The famous volcano island of Krakatao, which almost blew itself out of existence in 1883 with the mightiest natural explosion ever heard by man, erupted again last night. Showers of cinders and stones flew 2,000 feet.
NEW ORLEANS, July 4 (AP)-- Oliver George Lucas, 60 years old, chairman of the board of directors of the National Bank of Commerce here, shot himself to death today.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 4 (U.P.)-- Two men were killed and four persons injured in a holiday collision on the heavily traveled White Horse Pike at near-by Cologne today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 4 (UP)-- Top Puerto Rican officials in Independence Day exercises today hailed the law just signed by President Truman enabling the island to write its own constitution as a great victory for the people, opening a new relationship with the United States.
ABO, Finland, July 5 (AP)--B. Johansson of Finland outsprinted John Twomey by a yard to win the 1,500-meter run in 3:50, fastest time of the year in this country.

The twenty-fourth annual general meeting of Marks and Spencer, Ltd., was held on June 29 at 82, Bakerstreet, London, W. England. Sir Simon Marks, D.Sc. (chairman and joint managing director), presided.

Record demand, together with increased labor and materials cost, is spurring an upward price trend in virtually all grades of paper except newsprint, trade sources said yesterday. The trend, it was noted, also reflects high general business activity.

The Chase National Bank's statement of condition as of June 30, published today, shows increases in deposits, loans and total resources over comparable figures issued three months ago and at the end of June last year.

Export prices of Brazilian cotton continues to hold about 6 cents a pound above comparable grades of American cotton. At the end of April, the Brazilian staple was selling slightly below American cotton, but since then the Brazilian staple has forged steadily ahead.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)-- The Federal Power Commission authorized today a 50-year license to Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, Syracuse, N.Y., for construction and operation of a $5,600,000 power plant on the Sacandaga River in Saratoga County, N. Y.
A series of articles modeled on the Federalist Papers was published yesterday by Harper Bros. under the title of "The New Federalist."

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 5 (AP)--Two American boats today cruised to victory in the opening heats of the four-day Royal Henley regatta and headed toward a meeting on Friday in an all-Connecticut quarter-final.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 5-- Chinese Nationalist leaders, saying their opinions are based upon intelligence reports, believe Russian expectations in Korea have not been fulfilled thus far.

The Jamaica race track, where Empire City's ten-day meeting opened yesterday, has some new topsoil on it. Maybe it was imported from Golden Gate Fields, the California speedway. Three new special coupes were introduced yesterday by the Lincoln-Mercury Division of the Ford Motor Company.
A shipping industry "task force" organized to spur remedial maritime legislation and press the Government on a large scale ship repair program opened its campaign in Washington yesterday.

A thunderstorm brought temporary relief last night to heatweary New Yorkers, but the accompanying flash floods and lightning caused considerable damage throughout the city. The storm lasted from 8:30 to 10 P.M.

Rising costs of wool goods have compelled women's garment manufacturers to increase prices on fall coats, it was learned yesterday. Medium range categories will show a price, rise of approximately $3 a garment compared with opening prices for fall, as a result of added cost factors in coating fabrics. These have gone up from 10 to 30 cents a yard.

The less said about yesterday's ball game at the Stadium, where the Yankees routed the Athletics, 12--8, the better. Even Tommy Byrne, credited with his ninth conquest, though removed in the sixth frame, was willing to forget everything. It was that horrendous a contest.

WASHINGTON, July 5--President Truman's Point Four program for providing technical aid to underdeveloped countries of the world was reported authoritatively today to have been cut, tentatively at least, to less than one-fourth of what he had recommended.

SCHEVENINGEN, ' the Netherlands, July 5--An overpowering revelation of Mahler's Second symphony was presented to an enraptured capacity audience tonight by Leonard Bernstein, in his first appearance of the Netherlands Festival, with the Flague Residence Orchestra.

Lodewick Vroom, one-time president of the Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers and former general manager for the late Charles Frohman and Henry and Gilbert Miller enterprises, died Tuesday night at Doctors Hospital of a coronary thrombosis. He was 66 years old.

Ezzard Charles, National Boxing Association heavyweight champion, inactive because of a bruised heart muscle since his knockout of Pat Valentino in San Francisco on Oct. 14, 1949, received a clean bill of health from the New York State Athletic Commission's Medical Advisory Board late yesterday afternoon.

The bullet that killed Bernard L. Doyle in the Polo Grounds on Tuesday as he sat in an upper tier of the grandstands was a 45-caliber missle, apparently discharged from an automatic pistol, an autopsy revealed Yesterday.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit modified its opinion of June 2 yesterday and affirmed a Federal District Court order of Feb. 10 approving the plan of consolidation of the Long Island Lighting Company with its two subsidiaries.

The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation in the fiscal year ended last April achieved the second largest sales in its eighty-year history, but earnings were slightly less than the previous year.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 5 (AP)--Budge Patty and never-saydie Frank Sedgman won the men's singles semi-finals in the All-England Lawn Tennis tournament today before a wildly clapping center court crowd of more than 15,000.

While admitting that the collier Melrose had the right of way, the second mate of the ill-fated sand dredge Sandcraft, Oscar A. Sandstrom, expressed the belief yesterday that the early Sunday morning collision of the two vessels in the Narrows could have been averted if the former had "stopped her engines."

TOKYO, Thursday, July 6United States troops, fighting their first major engagement in the Korean war, successfully stood off the initial attacks of massive tankled North Korean forces plugging south along the road from captured Suwon.

ST. LOUIS, July 5--Despite progress in recent years to improve school conditions, 10,000,000 children living in rural areas are getting a sutstandard education, a rural school authority asserted here today.

Deposits of Guaranty Trust Company of New York rose $145,583,275 during the second quarter ended June 30. According to the bank's statement of condition published today, total deposits at the end of June were $2,335,396,908, against $2,189,813,632 on March 31, and $2,301,105,242 on June 30 last year.

A fantastic plot to steal $3,000,000 from the Cuban Treasury last January and replace it with counterfeit United States currency, was described yesterday to a judge and jury in the Federal District Court.

The Police Athletic League opened sixty-four play streets and six additional playgrounds yesterday to start a nine-week program of outdoor activities for the thousands of youngsters in congested areas of the city. Five playgrounds were already in operation.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 5 (AP)-- Star's Pride won the $10,000 Historic-Dickerson Cup today in two straight heats at Historic track to establish himself the favorite for the Hambletonian trotting classic Aug. 9.

TORONTO, July 5--World Protestantism heard a grave warning here today against associating itself with the so-called Stockholm appeal for the outlawing of atomic weapons on the ground that the appeal was being used by Communist groups to further their own ends.

For four months a large ship, similar to a passenger carrier and yet suggestive also of a tanker or general cargo carrier, has been haunting the North River, causing much curiosity and speculation among ferryboat commuters.

WASHINGTON, July 5--Senator Wayne L. Morse, Republican of Oregon, said in the Senate today that there was no legal obligation on railroads and railroad unions to accept the findings of an emergency board.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 5 (AP)--The thirty-one-foot cutter Amantha V was towed into Harwichport with no one aboard tonight, leaving to conjecture the whereabouts of a New York man who ckartered the craft.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 5-- Mrs. Frank Maloney of the Meadow Brook Club, aided by an eightstroke handicap, captured first prize in the Women's Long Island Golf Association annual point-par tournament with 38 points at the Huntington Country Club course today.

BETHEL, Me., July 5-An experiment in human relations is under way at the National Training Laboratory in Group Development here. Some the country's leaders in group activities have journeyed to Gould Academy, in the foothills of the White Mountains, to gain more awareness of the problems of group behavior.

LACEYVILLE, Pa., July 5-- Miss Marian Elizabeth Carnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Evans Carnell, was married to Harry Judson Rosengrant, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Harry Wilbor Rosengrant of Veroria, N.J., in the Skinners Eddy Methodist Church here today.

Only modest demand was necessary yesterday to give the stock market a limited recovery. Business and industrial reports remained highly favorable, but the Korean situation kept trading, on a reduced scale. Some of the standard issues managed to register gains in excess of a point, while the composite rate advanced 0.89 point.
WASHINGTON, July 5--The Truman Administration gave its qualified support to the Houseapproved tax bill today as the Senate Finance Committee opened hearings on the measure.

NEEDHAM, Mass., July 5-- Henry I. Harriman, Boston public utility executive and financier, died last, night after a long illness. His age was 77. Although he maintained a home in Newton, Mess., Mr. Harriman had been staying here with his daughter, Mrs. Eunice Alberta Milliken.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active, and final prices were 6 to 25 points net higher than Monday's close.

LONDON, July 5--Further improvement in British Government securities took the limelight in the stock markets here today. Elsewhere the opening of the new bookkeeping account was characterized by quiet steadiness after a dull start.
S. N. Behrman's comedy, "The Second Man," may be brought to Broadway by Jean Dalrymple this fall after it completes a series of bookings at summer theatres.
RYE, N.Y., July 5--The women's Eastern clay court tennis championship continued without upset today as the semi-final brackets were filled at Westchester Country Club.

A light rain which turned into a downpour shortly after 8:30 o'clock last night forced cancellation of the first of two scheduled night games at Ebbets Field between the Braves and Dodgers.

BOSTON, July 5--Admiral Louis E. Denfeld, relieved as Chief of Naval Operations last year in a dispute over the armed forces unification program, announced tonight his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor of Massachusetts.
The National League will attempt to break the Americans' All-Star monopoly next Tuesday without the help of St. Louis Cardinal pitchers.

George M. Bersch has been appointed a new member of the board of directors of L. Bamberger Co., Newark, N.J., store of the R.H. Macy Co., Inc., chain group. Jack I. Straus, president of Macy, also announced yesterday a realignment of the supervisory responsibilities in the Bamberger merchandising organization.
Thirty-one officers and enlisted men in this district answered yesterday the Air Force appeal for reservists with training in electronics and radar work to volunteer for active duty.
Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation started work yesterday on the last gap in a $2,000,000 forty-mile natural gas pipeline --a 2,600-foot link under the Hudson River.
Police Inspector Nicholas A. Pisarra was ordered yesterday to appear in Kings County Court tomorrow for a judicial and medical examination on his mental state.

James J. Moran, First Deputy Fire Commissioner since Feb. 15, 1946, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer as a Commissioner of the Board of Water Supply. The $15,000-a-year post carries life tenure.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5-- World tensions led the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs in biennial convention here today to direct a study of economic, political and social factors disturbing to peace and of methods proposed for strengthening peace.

MANILA, July 2--Students of current Philippine affairs nearly a11 agree that the new Republic's gravest problem today is one of leadership and administrative effectiveness. Corruption in the government is an integral part of this problem.
The joint industrial preparedness for national defense in Great Britain, Canada and the United States has been moved a big step forward by agreement upon unfication of standards on bolts and nuts.

Tulare County, Calif., has awarded to the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and associates, $1,420,000 of Porterville Union High School District bonds, due Aug. 1, 1951 through 1966. The bonds were sold at a bid of 100.101 for 2s and 1 s, a net interest cost of 1,903 per cent.

Hide futures continued to advance on the Commodity Exchange yesterday following the belated sharp upturn in prices in that commodity earlier in the week. The market opened at slightly better levels than Monday and the upward trend was maintained throughout the day's trading. Closing prices were 45 to 52 points higher, with all active futures deliveries establishing new price peaks.

PARIS, July 5--Delegates of six western European nations came to grips today for the first time with the problems of laying the foundation for the federal unity of Europe.

COMPARATIVELY unnoticed in the flood of week-end sports news was the quite remarkable feat of Bob Mathias winning the Na tional A.A.U. decathlon championship for the third straight year. By way of giving it an extra flourish, this aging veteran of the all-around competition broke the world record.

The city's new work relief program started quietly yesterday morning. Plans that had been in the making for several months were set in motion on schedule at 8:30 A.M. at the Municipal Shelter at 432 East Twenty-fifth Street. And through a long day little trouble developed.

Arguments against the proposed Narrows Bridge on the ground that it could easily be bombed and the port bottled up have been strengthened by recent harbor collisions, in the opinion of Representative Donald L. O'Toole, Democrat, of Brooklyn.

BERLIN, July 5--Behind the "self-administration" allegedly granted in increasing measure to East German officials, Soviet control over the 17,000,000 Germans in that territory is tightening visibly.

WASHINGTON, July 5-Four high present and past leaders of the United States appealed to Congress today for a greatly amplified American "propaganda of truth" about Korea and about this country's purposes every where.

Informed of widespread use of lawn and garden sprinklers far beyond the 8 P.M.-11 P.M. daily authorized hours, Water Commissioner Stephen J. Carney warned yesterday that action would be taken against violators.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP)--Manager Casey Stengel of the New York Yankees will have nine members of his team available for action when he directs the American Leaguers in the seventeenth annual All-Star game at Chicago's Comiskey Park next Tuesday afternoon.

VANCOUVER, B. C., July 6-- The marriage of Miss Patricia Aldyen Austin Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin C. Taylor of Vancouver, to William Francis Buckley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Buckley of Sharon, Conn., and Camden, S.C., took place here at noon today in St, Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.

LONDON, Friday, July 7--Russia charged today the American blockade of Korea was a "new act of aggression" and warned she would hold the United States responsible for any damage to... Soviet interests as a result of the blockade.

PARIS, July 6--Guy Mollet, secretary of the French Socialist party, failed today to get all the party groups of the nation together on a program to lead to a Premier and Cabinet, but he continued to deal with the parties separately until he declared that progress had been made.

WASHINGTON, July 6--President Truman disclosed today that he had no intention of appointing Sumner T. Pike to the chairmanship of the Atomic Energy Commission but he said he would give no assurance to this effect to the Senate. He denounced the opposition to Mr. Pike's nominations as foolishness and Republican politics.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)-- Cotton state members of Congress plan a conference with officials of the Commodity Credit Corporation Monday to learn details of the 1950 cottonseed price-support program.

The Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, Inc., processors of cottonseed oil products, earned $3,247,415 more in the nine months ended on June 3 than in the previous year's period, although sales were down $24,417,963.
Pitching with only two days' rest Preacher Roe racked up his lenth triumph as, the Dodgers flatened the Braves and Warren Spahn, 8--3, last night, before an Ebbets Field crowd of 20,019.

WASHINGTON, July 6--A $200,000,000 ring of American radio stations to encircle the Soviet Union and satellite countries and to outdo the Soviet wireless propaganda voice was recommended today by Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff.

The executive committee of the New York County Republican Committee yesterday countered Tammany's designation of Assemblyman Harold A. Stevens, a Negro, for nomination for judge of the Court of General Sessions by naming Lassen Walsh, a Negro, for Justice of the City Court.
ALBANY, July 6--Following is the text of Governor Dewey's statement here today on Korea:

WASHINGTON, July 6--Stung by early American reverses on Korean battlefronts, members of the Senate Armed Services Committee decided today to call for "all the facts," with key military men serving as the key witnesses.

ST. LOUIS, July 6--With Only one delegate voicing disapproval, the National Education Association virtually completed today its drive to bar Communist or subversive teachers from membership. Communists within the country's largest and most influential school organization would be ousted:
A U.S. NAVAL BASE, in Japan, July 6 (AP)--Seagoing officers here say they need more ships and men to cut off North Korean seaborne supplies.

Despite some faulty base-running, the Yankees whipped the Athletics yesterday, rallying for a 5-4 victory at the Stadium. Rookie Ed Ford, the Long Island City lefthander, made his initial major lague start, tired in the seventh aftar a commendable early showing, and Tom Ferrick, his replacement, was credited with the deci sion.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 6--The engagement has been announced of Miss Jane Wise Manning, daughter of Mrs. James Forrest Manning Jr, and the late Mr. Manning, to Charles Adcock DeVinne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles DeWitt DeVinne of Orienta Point, Mamaroneck, The wedding will take place in the autumn.
The death of a tow-headed lad from West Virginia, the first G.I. to die in the new war in Korea, was reported from the Far East yesterday.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 6 (AP)--Coast Guard search crews swept the ocean waters off Stone Horse Lightship tonight in a quest for Frederick Parker Humphreys, 59 years old, of Bantam, Conn., whose chartered yacht was found empty and adrift at the entrance of Nantucket Sound yesterday.

BETHEL, Me., July 6--Representatives of groups that often have conflicting interests, like labor and management; the Army, the Navy and the Air Corps, and local, state and Federal welfare departments, sat at the same table today and talked over common problems in the field of human relations.

Because of the drastic cut in acreage ordered by the Department of Agriculture, there is considerable interest in the trade over the official report to be issued on Monday on acreage planted to cotton this year.

The trustees of the Long Island Rail Road were authorized yesterday by Federal Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Brooklyn to apply to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to abandon service on parts of the road's Rockaway branches.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 6--With forty-four of the fifty-nine members of the United Nations now supporting the use of military force for the defense of South Korea, there is no longer any doubt of the world-wide approval of the action taken by the Security Council, under the leadership of the United States, June 25 and 27.

There were no hot-tempered truck drivers, dented fenders, honking of horns or disgruntled pedestrians yesterday in New York's men's clothing center--the area between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas from Fourteenth to Twenty-third Streets.
The appearance this morning in Kings County Court of Police Inspector Nicholas A. Pisarra for a preliminary examination on his mental condition has been postponed until tomorrow at 10 A.M.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 6--Chou En-lai, Foreign Minister of the People's Republic of China, served notice on the United Nations today that "despite any military steps of obstruction taken by the United States Government, the Chinese people are irrevocably determined to liberate Taiwan [Formosa] without fail."

CHICAGO, July 6--Citing "the threat of direct Government action," the Switchmen's Union of North America, A.F.L., tonight called off its twelve-day strike against four Midwestern and Western railroads, but continued it against a fifth, the 8,000-mile Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad Company.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP)--The R.F.C. pleaded with the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals today for an early hearing of its appeal in the complex Lustron Corporation bankruptcy.

Expenditures for national advertising in newspapers by the top 100 advertisers using the medium totaled $223,924,290 in 1949, according to a report issued yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, Inc.
PARIS, Friday, July 7--Final agreement on the financial terms of the European payments union was reached early today by the European Marshall Plan Council and United States officials.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet but steady, and closed 5 points higher to 5 points lower.
The Title Guarantee and Trust Company plans to dispose of its banking business by sale of its "banking premises and facilities" to the Bankers Trust Company "at appraised values."
The Jersey City jurisdictional fight for loading work on Piers D and F, which was believed settled almost a year ago, has flared up anew and work on the two docks has been halted.

The price of the top grade of steelmaking scrap metal declined $2 a ton at Pittsburgh yesterday when a district consumer reentered the market, which had been rather inactive for the last three weeks. The sale of a small tonnage was made at $40 a ton.
Produce counters are heaped this week-end with bountiful supplies of vegetables and fruits from nearby farms, many high in quality and relatively reasonable in price.

Herman T. Stichman, State Commissioner of Housing, and his deputy, John T. Haugaard Jr., who said they were dog lovers themselves, insisted yesterday that the rights of children to safe, unmolested and clean play were greater than the right of dog owners to keep pets in veterans emergency housing projects.
SANTA FE, N.M., July 6 (AP)-- A Federal grand jury today indicted David Greenglass, 28 years old, on a charge of conspiring to give atomic secrets to Russia.

Looking forward to fall or for immediate attention, the fashion story on coiffures is one of longer hair vrith bath interest. The gamine "little boy" cut, with its bare cropped shingle, is gone. Nor will there be a return to the flowing manes oP a few years back.

WASHINGTON, July 6--A union lawyer repudiated the testimony of one of his own witnesses today in a secondary-boycott case that grew out of a dispute between the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York and the Interborough News Company a year ago.

Representatives of major New York City agencies handling tickets for non-scheduled airlines mapped yesterday a policy of cooperation with the carriers designed to eliminate under-cutting, "rate chiseling" and illegal package ticket sales.
WASHINGTON, July 6--Dr. Edward K. Barsky, Howard Fast, the novelist, and nine other members of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee have now been scattered through six Federal prisons.

ALBANY, July 6--Governor Dewey called upon the Truman Administration today to admit publicly that Communist aggression has been winning the "cold war" for five years and to institute forthwith an "all-out program" to enable the United States to "match and then outstrip Soviet production of arms."

Felix Brunner of 900 West End Avenue, stamp dealer and philatelist, with offices at 505 Fifth Avenue, died on Wednesday of a heart ailment in Royal Oaks Convalescent Home, Madison, N.J. His age was 57.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6--The existence of a subtle program to confuse American thinking about relations between this country and the United Nations, "to the ultimate detriment of both," was charged tonight by Byron Price, Assistant Secretary-General of the United Nations.

MANILA, July 2--The Department of Defense estimates that Philippine Government forces have disposed of roughly 1,000 armed Hukbalahaps in the last three months. Most of these Communistled Hukbalahaps have been killed, some have been captured and only a few have surrendered.

Some 23,000 people clambered into Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear the annual all-Gershwin concert, and officials declared that it was a record for the summer concerts there.
Airline navigators from eight countries, including the United States, adopted a four-point program yesterday to promote safe and efficient flying on commercial airlines.

With American troops battling in Korea to halt a new aggressor--condemned as such by more than two-thirds of the United Nations--the Security Council meets at Lake Success today to perform an urgent duty.
BERLIN, July 6--A Prospective deficit of 655,000,000 Deutsche marks [approximately $156,000,000] was indicated today when the West Berlin budget was presented to the City Assembly.

WASHINGTON, July 6--All shipments of oil and of materials with any possible war potential have been cut off from the Far East in moves by the United States Government to prevent essential supplies from falling into the hands of North Korean sympathizers.
President Truman's Point Four program for providing technical aid to underdeveloped countries ought to appeal to anybody with an economical drop of blood in his veins. In contrast

WIMBLEDON, England, July 6 (AP)--Miss Louise Brough and Mrs. Margaret du Pont won the allAmerican women's singles semifinals at Wimbledon today but most of the capacity crowd couldn't have cared less.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 6 (AP)-- Attorneys General of six of the eight states comprising the Ohio River Valley Sanitary Compact decided today to enlist nearly the entire nation in an effort to preserve the Compact and similar ones throughout the nation.

SCARBOROUGH ON HUDSON, N.Y., July 7--Led by Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock, the Long Island team of fifteen won the Golf Illustrated Trophy over the Sleepy Hollow Country Club course today.

Intensification of fighting on the Korean front was reflected on commodity markets here yesterday. Prices of natural crude rubber advanced steeply in the futures market on the Commodity Exchange, following the pattern set in the London market and in the primary rubber market at Singapore.

Summer is the time the fishing contest reaches full flower. While those sponsored by various coastwise resorts for any and all species draw most entries, the pursuit of tuna under formal tournament conditions engenders more concentrated attention.
LOS ANGELES, July 6--the longest continuous run in theatrical history began its eighteenth year tonight as a local production of the melodrama, "The Drunkard," clicked off its 6,350th performance.
Americans in Europe are taking the Korean fighting in stride and there is no appreciable demand for return passage home, according to Harold White, president of Thomas Cook Son, travel agents.

Anyone who has ever turned over and gone right back to sleep after the first loud burst of the alarm probably would react quite differently on hearing "Oh, What a Beautiful Morning" and "I Love You Truly" peal forth.

WASHINGTON, July 6--The use of high-frequency sounds and the reflecting microscope for studying tumors and cancer cells are among new research techniques underwritten by cancer grants of $1,160,816 announced today by the Public Health Service of the Federal Security Agency.

VIENNA, July 6--A call to pro-Cominform Communists in Greece and Yugoslavia to sabotage what he calls the "Athens-Belgrade Axis" by attacking its railway communications has been issued by Nicolas Zachariades, secretary general of the Greek Communist party.
WASHINGTON, July 6--Business spokesmen called on Congress today for outright repeal of wartime excise taxes, regardless of the Korean situation.

NEW DELHI, India, July 6-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's action, in accepting the United Nations Security Council's resolution condemning the aggression of North Korea and in imposing counter-measures, was a highly courageous decision in the context of the delicate state of Indian public opinion, in the view of diplomats and other observers here.

WASHINGTON, July 6--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, accused Secretary of State Dean Acheson today of having "sabotaged and vetoed" a Congressional attempt to fortify South Korea against the Communist invasion.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 6 (AP)--The Royal Henley Regatta produced a little bit of everything today, including a last-second victory by a never-saydie Harvard crew.

WASHINGTON, July 6--President Truman declared today that the Korean war situation would work out all right and he said he saw no present need to mobilize the organized Reserves and the National Guard or to ask Congress for additional defense funds.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 6--Dr. Asaf Fyzee, Indian Ambassador to Egypt, has appealed here for support for South Korea and recognition of the Chinese Communist Government. He said India very much hoped that "Egypt would accept our view."

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 6--A junior player did his bit for golf history today when 19year-old Billy Edwards of Hempstead, L.I., scored a 65 to win the qualifying medal in the Metropolitan Junior Championship over the Upper Montclair Country Club course.

The police prepared yesterday to extend their area of search for the person who fired the 45 caliber bullet that killed Bernard Lawrence Doyle as he sat in the Polo Grounds awaiting the opening of a Fourth of July double-header between the New York Giants and the Brooklyn Dodgers.
Sharp rate reductions for ocean freight to continental ports have been announced by two eastbound trans-Atlantic freight conferences.

ORADELL, N.J., July 6--Percy Keese Fitzhugh, author of more than 100 juvenile books, died here yesterday in his home, 283 Maple Avenue, after a long illness. His age was 73. He often used the pseudonym Hugh Lloyd.

AREQUIPA, Peru, July 6--The Arequipa uprising of June 13 and 14, which took at least thirty lives, was based on purely domestic political circumstances, which have not been altered fundamentally by the fact that the Government has regained control.

WASHINGTON, July 6--Dr. Earl J. McGrath, United States Commissioner of Education, today announced the creation of the Commissioner's Council of Education, to be composed of twentyfive leaders of the profession.
Continuing their upward trend for the fifth successive week, loans to business made by banks in this area advanced $10,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday.
The Girl Scouts can do a great deal to counteract the "bad name" youth organizations have earned since Nazi days, Mrs. Paul Rittenhouse, national executive director, declared yesterday.

Testifying in Spanish in Federal District Court yesterday a Cuban Secret Service inspector said he found $18,000 in counterfeit United States currency on two men he arrested in Havana.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 6--United States forces fighting in Korea may hoist the blue and white banner of the United Nations tomorrow or Saturday.

The City of New York yesterday awarded $70,000,000 of tax anticipation notes to twenty-six banks and trust companies. Dated July 7, the notes bear interest of 1 1/8 per cent. Of the total, $30,000,000 will mature on Oct. 19 and $40,000,000 on Oct. 24.

WASHINGTON, July 6--The preliminary report of a Minneapolis-St. Paul pilot study in family clothing inventories, issued today by the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics, disclosed a great popularity of informal clothing.
ST. LOUIS, July 6 (AP)--One inning--the first--was all the Cardinals needed to beat the Reds tonight. St. Louis pounded in ten runs in that frame to start toward a 13-to-1 decision.

Prize-winning work by high school art students throughout the country and from Alaska and Hawaii, selected in the 1950 Annual Scholastic Magazines National Exhibition and competition, will be shown in New York for three weeks, beginning Monday.

William O'Brien of Jersey City, a lookout on the collier Melrose, which was in collision early Sunday morning in the Narrows with the sand dredge Sandcraft, testified yesterday that the latter "came out like a car from a side street," just before the crash.

Advertising in the seven major New York City newspapers for the first half of 1950 totaled 77,660,4; lines, a gain of 6.45 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 6--The decision of the Switchmen's Union, A. F. L., to end a strike on four of five Western railroads followed by a few hours today President Truman's threat to take action to restore traffic.

Early negotiation of a new tax covenant and commercial treaty was urges yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council as a vital step in expanding the commercial relations of Australia and the United States.
There's a possibility that the international military jumping phase of the National Horse Show next fall will be bigger than any in the last twenty-five years.

WASHINGTON, July 6--The State Department ridiculed today Soviet claims of "potato bug warfare" by the United States Government and charged that the insect "saboteur" had been invented to explain an anticipated crop failure in Eastern Germany and the satellite countries.
LONDON, July 6 (AP)--Field Marshal Lord Chetwode, a veteran of sixty-one years in the British Army, died today of injuries suffered in a fall from a bus last week. His age was 80.

MONICA, Ill, July 6--Two high-speed Santa Fe Railway streamliners, streaking eastward side by side, bumped midsections in a freakish collision today that brought death to nine persons and injuries to about seventy-five.

CHICAGO, July 6--More than seventy programs are being developed by the Munitions Board to perfect War mobilization of industry and to coordinate production schedules to conform with military requirements if the need arises, Hubert E. Howard, board chairman, said in a progress report in Commerce Magazine today.

CHICAGO, July 6--Grain markets closed irregular on the Board of Trade with trading much slower than of late. July soybeans were under pressure from liquidating longs in the late trading and finished 8 to 8 cents lower with the new crop months unchanged to cent higher.

The isolated unit of less than one battalion, supported by one battery of field artillery, which was at Osan yesterday, was attacked by the best Red division, supported by forty tanks, which were extremely skillfully maneuvered.

Plans for the erection of the threestory business building were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by Francis J. Kleban, builder, of a plot containing 5,800 square feet at 247 Broadway, southwest corner of Murray...
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)--The Atomic Energy Commission has informed Senators that atomic weapons production is in better shape today than ever before.
WASHINGTON, July 6--Army spokesmen disclosed today that Gen. Douglas MacArthur was shaping a main line of resistance south of Suwon in South Korea and that a stabilized situation was building up.
Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's valet has a racing stable. So has his blacksmith. It was the blacksmith's turn to win a purse at Jamaica yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 6-- Miners, dockworkers and factory hands in several parts of Belgium struck work for fifteen to thirty minutes this morning to demonstrate their opposition to the eventual return of King Leopold from exile.
WASHINGTON, July 6--The White House was urged today to increase substantially the production of synthetic rubber in the face of the Communist threat to natural rubber sources in the Far East.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 6-- Paul W. McQuillen has made known the engagement of his daughter, Patricia Dorothy, to Charles H. Watts 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Watts of Bronxville, and Center Ossipee, N.H.
The RCA-Victor division of Radio Corporation of America yesterday introduced its new line of eighteen television receivers featuring prices $40 to $200 lower than the line it replaces.

TOKYO, Friday, July 7--Thrust back by a massive onslaught of North Korean tank columns, the scanty United States troops in Korea were forming a new defense line today south of Pyongtaek along the road running south to the temporary capital of Taejon, according to late reports here.
PHILADELPHIA, July 6--Sheldon Jones went into a nose dive today and carried the Giants down to defeat at the hands of Eddie Sawyer's Phillies, 9 to 6.
Twenty-two boys and girls from Western Europe spent their first day in New York yesterday and pronounced it "fantastic."

Because of the prevailing shortage of graduate nurses, a shortage that is aggravated by their usual summer journeys to camp jobs and vacations, an increasing number of wards and private rooms in New York voluntary hospitals are being closed, or are unable to open as planned.

A two-year wage agreement reached by employers and union leaders in the trucking industry here was voted upon last night at a closed meeting of Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, but the outcome left some doubt as to the sentiments of the rank and file union members.

The sportswear industry may kill itself off unless manufacturers can achieve rapid production shifts and timing based on consumer demand, Ralph D. Schneider, president of Broadstreet's, Inc., men's wear chain, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 6--Virgil W. Peterson told the Senate Crime Investigating Committee today that organized crime in the United States was controlled by an alliance in which the principal partners were the Frank Costello ring in New York and the syndicate in Chicago that fell heir to the underworld empire of Al Capone.
HONG KONG, July 6--Gunfire broke out today in two places along Hong Kong's frontier with Communist China where not a shot had been fired in anger since the Communist armies arrived last October.

The stock market made further progress yesterday on the recovery trail, with the average price returned to the mid-position of last Friday. It was a laborious comeback, however, as trading remained fairly passive.

WASHINGTON, July 6--The Interstate Commerce Commission today heard argument in a proceeding in which one of its examiners has recommended that the I.C.C. close the present 8 per cent gap between interstate and intrastate commutation fares in New York by raising fares within the state.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 6--The cut of $25,000,000 reportedly made by the Senate Appropriations Committee in the $35,000,000 authorzed by Congress for President Truman's Point Four program created alarm today among several delegations here.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP)--A Senate Appropriations subcommittee approved today a bill earmarkin $947,970,000 for the atomic energy program after erasing a provision that opponents said might have put Russia ahead in the hydrogen bomb race.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 6 --After examining charges that The Yonkers Daily Times had used its telephones to aid and abet illegal betting on horse races, Supreme Court Justice J. Gordon Flannery denied today an application by the paper for a peremptory writ of mandamus compelling the New York Telephone Company to restore service.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 7 (AP)--Budge Patty, one-time international playboy who says he's a changed man, won the coveted men's singles title today in the All-England tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 7--Immediate appropriation of $2,000,000,000 more than the $1,222,500,000 thus far approved for military assistance this year to countries resisting communism was urged upon Congress today by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts.

LONDON, July 7--The British Government, which has asked the Soviet Union to use its influence to help end the Korean war, is growing more disturbed by the Soviet Government's new internal propaganda line on Korea than by its bellicose statements for purely foreign consumption.

OSLO, Norway, July 7 (AP)-- Touring athletes from the United States today again dominated the international track and field meet with Scandinavian foes.

OIL CITY, Pa., July 7 (AP)--The Cities Service Oil Company of Pennsylvania today sold its Titusville, Pa., refinery and its oil wells and pipelines in Pennsylvania and Ohio to the Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation of Oil City.

WASHINGTON, July 7--Average primary market prices advanced 1.2 per cent in the week ended on July 3, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 159 per cent of the 1926 average, 1 per cent above four weeks ago and 3.9 per cent above the comparable week in 1949.

The youth of the entire world without regard to nationality, color, social status or political differences, will be welcome at the 1952 Olympic Games in Hensinki, said Erik von Frenckell, president of the Finnish Olympic Committee, at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

TROON, Scotland, July 7 (AP)-- Bobby Locke, walking as if the Troop fairways were carpeted with eggs, shot a fourth-round 68 today to win the British open golf title for the second straight year and lowered a scoring mark that had stood since 1932.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 7 --John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, said today he did not believe the Russians would attack in Germany, but he advocated a larger Western military force in Western Europe.
Steamship operators, brokers and agencies throughout the nation were asked yesterday to inform the Government immediately on the availability of dry cargo tonnage for July and August.

Dr. Angelica Balabanoff, 71year-old Socialist leader returning from a trip to Italy where she had gone to fight communism, was detained at Ellis Island after her arrival here at 4 P.M. yesterday on the Vulcania.

NEW DELHI, India, July 7-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that India was "of the opinion that the admission of the People's Government of China into the United Nations Security Council and the return of the U.S.S.R. are necessary conditions to enable the Security Council to discharge...

A former Protestant church at 67 East Eighty-ninth Street, used in succession by two congregations, will be blessed at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow as the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in a newly created parish.

ALBANY, July 7--The State Banking Department announced today that the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, 13 William St., had received approval to change the location of its branch office temporarily from 1242 to 1243 Second Ave., Manhattan.

When opportunity knocked at Ebbets Field last night the Dodgers found the door had been jammed by Eddie Sawyer's mischievous Whiz Kids, so the Brooks went down to a 7-2 defeat and the Phils moved into a first-place tie with the Cardinals.
FREEHOLD, N.J., July 7-- Philip H. Harrison of Colts Neck Road, a major distributor of electrical appliances, died early today at his home after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 7--The Senate Crime Investigating Committee received today a confidential list of some eighty companies, engaged in legitimate business, in which gangsters and racketeers were believed to have substantial ownership interests.

Richard Savitt of East Orange, N.J., and Seymour Greenberg of Chicago gained the two remaining semi-final brackets in the New York State tennis championship yesterday at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, July 7--President Truman today authorized the Army, Navy and Air Force to discard their "peacetime" manpower quotas and to build their forces, using Selective Service if necessary, to the limits needed to cope with the Korean situation.

WASHINGTON, July 7--Imports in May gained sharply compared with April, figures released today by the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce disclosed. The trend was an encouraging sign to Administration officials who have been seeking to bring about a closer balance in our foreign trade.

Riders who make 29,000,000 crossings of the bay a year on Staten Island ferries will soon be able to drink orange juice and munch on frankfurters while they view the passing harbor scenes between Whitehall Street and Saint George.

Eclipse Sleep Products, Inc., will increase prices on all its non-fairtrade bedding items between 4 and 5 per cent, effective July 25. This was made known yesterday by Irving Weisglass, president of the company, which is one of the largest bedding manufacturers in the city.

Newest thing in iced tea: a teablackberry julep. This was one of half a dozen iced tea beverages sampled yesterday by food writers attending a luncheon at the Red Coach Grill, 7 East Fifty-eighth Street. The host was the Tea Bureau.

James Eugene McCarthy Jr. of 100 Seventy-ninth Street, Brooklyn, a pilot in the New York Harbor service, who guided many large liners from Sandy Hook up the Bay, died yesterday in St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn, after a month's illness. His age was 43.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 8--Gen. Douglas MacArthur, in a letter today to Premier Shigeru Yoshida, directed that the Japanese National Police and the sea-going Coast Guard be more than doubled to insure that the internal security of Japan "continue unchallenged by lawless minorities."

Summer, more than any other time of year, finds the displays in city florist shops reflecting the flowers blooming in gardens around the country. No other season finds cut flowers so abundant and, as a consequence, priced so reasonably.

Expenditures under the Marshall Plan reached a total of a little over $9.5 billion on Friday, June 30, according to an announcement made this week by the Economic Cooperation Administration. This is the kind of folding money which we used to associate only with large-scale wars.

Unless the international situation takes a change for the better, the nation's vital industries will continue in a period of "watchful waiting," Washington observers of Federal agencies involved in the regulation of industry said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 7--A proposed report accusing Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of failure and bad faith in his campaign to find Communists in the State Depart-- ment is being studied by the Democratic members of the Senate subcommittee that investigated his charges.
CINCINNATI, July 7 (AP)-- Commissioner A.B. Chandler ruled today that the National League must have Hank Sauer's big home run bat in the starting line-up in the All-Star baseball game next Tuesday.
TRENTON, July 7-Rigid regulations for out-of-state milk distributors who wish to do business in New Jersey were announced today by the State Department of Health.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 7--The Security Council today authorized the United States to establish a unified command for the United Nations Armed Forces defending Southern Korea, paving the way for the appointment of Gen. Douglas MacArthur as Commander-inChief and the use of the United Nations flag.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 7--Billy Edwards of Hempstead, L.I., whose record 65 led the qualifiers, moved through two match play rounds of the Metropolitan Junior Golf championship at the Upper Montclair Country Club today.

ON THE KOREAN FRONT, Saturday, July 8 (UP)--Fresh, battle-bound United States troops waved confidently today at bitter, retreating Americans and South Koreans they passed on the long, muddy road to war.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP)-- Francis J. Russell, director of the State Department's Office of Public Affairs, said tonight that Russia would "never cease its efforts until it has secured domination over all the world's population."

A 14-year-old boy confessed yesterday afternoon to the police that he had fired a .45-caliber pistol last Tuesday from the rooftop of his home at the time a man in the near-by Polo Grounds was killed by a bullet of that caliber.
Dallas, Tex., will offer on July 25, $17,220,000 of various-purpose obligations. Details concerning the date and maturity of the twentyyear serials will be announced later.

Romulo described the United States as the Filipinos' best friend and said economic collaboration with the United States would remain for an indefinite period the cornerstone of the commercial policy of the Philippines.

Howard Korman, recently account executive with the Biow Company, and previously vice president in charge of merchandising with McCann-Erickson, Inc., has been named director of creative planning of Cappel, MacDonald Co., Dayton Ohio, national sales incentive organization.

Frederick Brown has sold the four-story store and residence building at 50 East Fifty--third Street to a syndicate represented by Edward L. Lane, broker. The property, on a lot 16 by 100 feet, was one of fourteen buildings which Mr. Brown acquired from the Columbia Broadcasting System.
WASHINGTON, July 7--In the light of new international developments, talk of adjournment or recess of Congress by Aug. 1 was silenced today.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 8-- North Korean tank-led columns pushed slowly forward again today against the United States defense line temporarily stabilized roughly ten miles back from the advanced positions that the Americans evacuated Thursday under pressure of superior Communist forces equipped with heavy armor.

WASHINGTON, July 7--Bernard M. Baruch urged the establishment today, in the propaganda conflict with the Soviet Union now deeply engaging the United States, of a powerful new Federal organism to direct this and all forms of psychological warfare.

The United Specialties Company reported yesterday, for the nine months ended on May 31, net profit of $325,930 after taxes and all charges.

NEWARK, July 7 (AP)--Three railroads obtained approval today to increase South Jersey commuter fares to out-of-state points but a similar rise for service within New Jersey was denied them.
ST. LOUIS, July 7 (AP)--The St. Louis Browns beat Chicago, 4--3, in ten innings tonight after the White Sox had won the first game of a twilight-night double-header, 5--2.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 7 --Pending the signing of a final order, the New York Telephone Company chose today to permit The Yonkers Daily Times to continue with temporary service on six of its twelve telephone lines. Yesterday Supreme Court Justice J. Gordon Flannery ruled that the lines had been used for gambling purposes and that all could be disconnected.

WASHINGTON, July 7--Representatives of "economy brand" cigarette manufacturers, renewing their fight for a tax cut, accused the Treasury today of deliberately making a "false" report to Congress on the revenue losses that would result.

The first annual convention of the International Airline Navigators Council (I.A.N.C.) ended yesterday with the election of permanent officers and a statement of policy by John D. Nicholas, the new chairman.

Harry B. Chambers, chairman of the Bronx County Democratic Committee, authorized yesterday the filing of a suit in the Supreme Court seeking to have the name of Bernard G. Walpin stricken from the Democratic party's rolls.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 7-- W. Malcolm Brady, a member of the board of directors of the Burlington. Mills Corporation, died here today in his home on Fox Run Lane. His age was 53.

PARIS, July 7--The European payments union, the major objective of the Economic Cooperation Administration for this year as a step toward European integration, became a reality today when the seventeen national governments represented in the Marshall Plan Council unanimously accepted it.
HAVANA, Cuba, July 7 (AP)-- The opening match in the CubaMexico Davis Cup tennis play was suspended today because of rain and darkness, with the score tied at two sets apiece.

NEWARK, N.J., July 7 (AP)-- War jitters have sent sales of tires soaring in some sections of New Jersey, but sugar sales mostly have remained steady, a survey showed today. Dealers in both commodities said supplies were plentiful, and there was more where they came from.

DETROIT, July 7 (AP)--Lefthander Teddy Gray of the Detroit Tigers set the hard-hitting Cleveland Indians down with four hits tonight as he posted a 5-to-2 decision for his tenth triumph of the season.

PITTSBURGH, July 7--Business in the Pittsburgh district last week rose to the highest levels recorded since January, 1949, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 7--The United Nations sent Gen. Douglas MacArthur the flag of the world organiation tonight and its hopes for peace in Korea.

Mayor O'Dwyer greeted James C. Dunn, United States Ambassador to Italy, Prince Marcantonio Pacelli, president of Linee Aeree Italiane, and Carlo Diani, president of the Boys Republic of Italy, at City Hall, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set the stage for a fresh start toward reorgnization of Standard Gas and Electric Company, a major utility holding company.

The use of Japanese-flag vessels, by agreement, on runs from Japan to Burma, Indonesia and Korea may have important consequences in the Korean crisis, the American Merchant Marine Institute said yesterday.
TRENTON, July 7--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll completed his action on several hundred measures today for return to the special session of the Legislature convening tomorrow.

PARAMUS, N.J., July 7--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mason of the home club, playing alternate shots, won the Jane Brooks Robbins Memorial husband-and-wife trophy with a.6-over-par 37, 40--77 over the Ridgewood Country Club east and center nines today.

ALBANY, July 7--The State Department of Education, for the second time in a little over a year, refused today to overrule the action of the New York City Boards of Superintendents and Education in barring the weekly magazine The Nation from public school libraries.

ST. LOUIS, July 7--After a spirited debate, the National Education Association overwhelmingly approved today a resolution favoring Federal aid for public schools only. The organization also adopted an amendment to the bylaws that would outlaws Communists from membership.
WASHINGTON, July 7--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 1, 1950, totaled 783,357 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The full membership of Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, numbering 8,000, will get an opportunity to vote on the two-year wage agreement reached with employers by its wage scale committee.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP)--Connie Ryan stole home on Johnny Vander Meer today to score the run that gave the Reds a 5-4 victory in eleven innings over the Cubs. Vander Meer, who entered the game in the tenth inning, lost his fourth decision without yielding a hit.
Governor Dewey criticized the Federal Government yesterday for failure to provide a national uniform civil defense plan against the possibility of enemy attack.
Some 5,000 shrubs that were on a site acquired by the city for a new school in Bellerose, Queens, have been disposed of to city departments and private buyers.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 7--John Guy Gilpatric, widely known writer of sea stories, and his wife were found shot to death in their home here today in an apparent murder-suicide pact.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP)-- The Senators snapped their Bob Hooper jinx tonight by shelling the Athletics' rookie for sixteen hits in seven innings to defeat Philadelphia, 7 to 5. One of the hits off Hooper, who had beaten Washington three straight times, was Ed Stewart's third homer.

JERSEY CITY, July 7--The American Export Lines' Piers D and F here were closed for the second day today as the dispute between Joseph Ryan, International president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., and officers of its Local 1247 continued.

WASHINGTON, July 7--Britain has turned down an informal United States request that she sharply curtail the shipment of oil and other strategic materials to the Far East, the State Department announced today.

Jake La Motta, the Bronx battier who will defend his world middleweight championship against Tiberio Mitri of Trieste at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, submitted to a physical examination at the headquarters of the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday.

The slump in bituminous coal sales which has existed since the coal strike has definitely ended. Now big soft coal users are starting to cover on future requirements up to 60 per cent of next year's needs. The remainder of their purchases will be filled in on spot purchases, executives stated here yesterday.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, Eng., July 7 (AP)--Two American crews rowed within sight of the glittering booty in the tradition-steeped Royal Henley regatta today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 7-- Twenty-two European boys and girls who are guests of Youth Incorporated on a visit to this country, arrived here this afternoon and immediately indulged in the old Southern custom of walking barefooted in the countryside.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 7--An independent American oil combine, now operating in the Western United States and Mexico, has been invited to visit Israel for the purpose of establishing a large refinery and to explore natural oil possibilities. The offer includes "off shore" drilling in addition to the Negeb and other potential areas.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7--The complex process of producing official census figures has started in a sprawling brick factory here.

NASHVILLE, July 7--The integration of minority groups in the United States Army has improved rapidly since the end of the war, Brig. Gen. Arthur G. Trudeau, deputy commandant of the Army War College, declared today.

Legislation to create a Board of Hospitals that would function as the top policy-making body of the Department of Hospitals was introduced in the City Council yesterday at the request of Mayor O'Dwyer. It was referred to the General Welfare Committee, which will hold a public hearing on it at 11 A.M., July 18.

BOSTON, July 7--The pitching wizardry that carried Larry Jansen through seven successive victories deserted him tonight and the slender Oregonian, along with his Giants, crashed to defeat at the hands of the Braves before 26,178 fans. The score was 8 to 2.

Blanche Yurka, who has been absent from the Broadway stage for three-and-a-half years, will be a co-star in the Festival Theatre's presentation of August Strindberg's "Crimes and Crimes," beginning Sept. 4 at the Fulton Theatre.
Robert Ross Wason, former president of the National Association of Manufacturers, died yesterday of a hear attack in his office at 405 Lexington Avenue. He was 62 years old.

A two-hour session at the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, 341 Ninth Avenue, failed yesterday to produce any area of agreement in the strike of the American Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., against The World-Telegram and Sun.

Miss Felicia Schiff Warburg, daughter of Mrs. J.S. Warburg of 875 Park Avenue, and Paul Felix Warburg of London, was married to Robert William Sarnoff, son of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. David Sarnoff of New York, yesterday afternoon in the Baroque Room of the Plaza.

C.B.S. television had a rugged night of it last evening. It visited the Stork Club, warmed up the usual new mystery series and permitted amateur song writers to get before the cameras. It's probably a wiser network this morning.

PATUXENT, Md., July 7 (AP)-- A test pilot bailed out of a burning Navy jet fighter plane and landed unhurt in Chesapeake Bay today. He was rescued from the water by a Navy helicopter.

TAIPEI, Formosa, July 7--In a move described as self-protection the Chinese Nationalist Government has resumed the search and seizure of vessels flying either the Chinese Nationalist or the Chinese Communist flag.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 (AP)--The last-place Pirates exploded for six runs in the first inning tonight, then went on to defeat the Cardinals, 9-1, and snap a seven-game St. Louis winning streak. Vernon Law, 20-year-old rookie righthander, went the distance for Pittsburgh to register his first Major League victory against two defeats.

LONDON, July 7--The stock markets were undecided today and business was at a minimum. Only noteworthy features were a small improvement in British Government securities and a general advance in copper shares. Foreign bonds remained dull, with German and Japanese issues lower.

An industry-wide footwear committee to advise Government agencies in the event that emergency regulations are planned was announced yesterday by Mark A. Edison, president of the National Association of Shoe Chain Stores.

LONDON, July 7--Strongarm stuff in a Soho night club accompanied by some pleasant little tunes and dances is the formula for Noel Coward's "Ace of Clubs," which opened tonight at the Cambridge Theatre before an enthusiastic audience.

ALBANY, July 8--Substantial progress has been made in the last year in building to relieve congestion in the state's mental institutions, the resident population of which increased by 3,377 to 102,216, Dr. Newton Bigelow, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, reported today.

ALTHOUGH restrictions on watering gardens have been somewhat relaxed in New York City, no one can pre dict whether it will be necessary to tighten them again before the summer is over. Home owners in other areas face a similar dilemma.

A group of officers of the Girl Scouts of America sailed yesterday on the Queen Mary. They will represent their organization at the biennial conference of the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts in Oxford, England, this month.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 8-- President Truman and "white supremacy" have been made the main issues of the South Carolina Democratic primary election campaign. These are strange "issues" on which the individual voter is asked to make his choice because nobody takes the other side: All the candidates for major office are against Mr. Truman and for white supremacy.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 8-- Permits for the construction of 468 new housing units, valued at a total of $2,423,800, were issued in the first six months of this year as the city's building pace topped that for the same period of 1949, Building Superintendent Walter F. Fromm reports.

SOBERED, like everyone else, by the Korean crisis, motion picture industry leaders took stock last week of some two dozen war films, films about the aftermath of the recent war, or films dealing with the armed services, all in various stages of preparation or production, to determine how they might fit into the uncertain future scene.

Willie Turnesa, of the Knollwood Country Club, White Plains, one of the nation's greatest amateurs, continues to reign as the top golfer here. This was indicated yesterday as the Metropolitan Golf Association issued its handcap list for 1950.

Hillas of Dellwood Park, Madison, took place here this afternoon in St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Ronald H. Rowland performed the ceremony.

MANILA, July 2--A special seslion of the Philippine Congress is expected to meet this month with the express purpose of approving higher taxation. The objective will be to help eliminate the heavy deficit that appears in the figures for the 1950-51 budget.

Ladewig, vice president of the international division of the Bristol-Myers Company.

HOW many ballets come into being with any basic expectation that they may remain in repertory? Too often, due to a chronic lack of cash or consideration, a ballet finds itself in mid-process of creation almost in spite of itself, on the spur of some moment, out of a complex of fortuitous circumstances.

ALBANY, July 8--Governor Dewey approved today a program to enable New York State to throw its full industrial potential into war production in the event of any emergency arising out of the current Korean crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 8--William M. Boyle Jr., chairman of the Democratic National Committee, summoned all party leaders today to the fight for a Federal Fair Employment Practice Act.

ONE of the most important programs of the present season of the Stadium Concerts is scheduled for to morrow evening--the memorial program of works by the late Kurt Weill. The forty-seventh annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Aasociation championship will start tomorrow morning over the Sleepy Hollow Country Club course in Scarborough. Police Inspector Nicholas A. Pisarra was directed yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz to "voluntarily appear before the grand jury" investigating rackets in Brooklyn. BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 9-- The commodore of the New York Athletic Club's yachting department, Carl Schuster, an advertising man, was found early today to be this year's winner of the traditional 106-mile predicted log power cruiser race to Block Island.

CHICAGO, July 9--Service was being resumed rapidly today on the 8,000-mile lines of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad Company.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP)-- Administration Democrats suddenly changed their tune today and predicted that the Senate would confirm President. Truman's renomination of Sumner T. Pike to the Atomic Energy Commission.

CHICAGO, July 9--Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced today the development of an electronic pressure gauge that accurately measures the most perfect vacuums scientists have been able to achieve.

WASHINGTON, July 9--Statements that Jean Sibelius, the great Finnish composer, has received no American royalties for performances of his works in the United States have been brought to the attention of officials here, but so far the situation is dim and hazy.
