Hostesses who have extra guests dropping in these days for a cooling drink on the terrace or a few games of canasta may ease their entertaining problems with the aid of a portable serving cart, now available in stores in a wide range of prices and styles.

The Walsh-Healey Act of 1936 could raise considerably legal minimum wages set by the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1949, in so far as public contracts are concerned, according to Herbert R. Northrup, labor economist of the National Industrial Conference Board.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 10--The thirteenth exhibit of the National Housewares Manufacturers Associatian opened in Convention Hall here today with early indications that buying would be strong as retailers and wholesalers took steps to meet effects of the Korean crisis.

GENEVA, July 10--Stern warnings that the under-developed countries must help themselves if they want help from others were given in the United Nations Economic and Social Council today by speakers of several countries and persuasions.

NEWARK, July 10--An application by Jersey City to set aside the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad's 5-cent fare increase has been denied by a three-member Federal statutory court, it was announced here today in the court of Senior Federal District Court Judge Guy L. Fake.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture reported today that 19,032,000 acres of cotton were in cultivation on July 1. This was 31.3 per cent less than the 27,719,000 acres of a year ago.
BOZEMAN, Mont., July 10--A new philosophy may be found today among farmers and ranchers in the Northern Great Plains.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 10-- Censorship of the press returned to the American scene here today in uncertain and apparently contradictory manifestations.
Contemporary furniture, though simple and uncluttered in design, may be dressed up in many ways without distracting from its clean lines. One way is by using exotic, richly grained woods.

Dr. Angelica Balabanoff, a Russian Communist leader in Lenin's day who has been an active antiCommunist for more than twenty years, was released yesterday from Ellis Island after three days' detention.
WASHINGTON, July 10--Republican demands for a greater manifestation of bipartisanship and a stronger sense of Congressional participation in the conduct of the Korean war arose today.

CHICAGO, July 10--A panel of musical instrument industry leaders predicted today that sales of virtually all types of instruments this year would reach record levels, that prices would be higher on most of them and that production facilities of many makers would operate at capacity.
WASHINGTON, July 10--The legal see-saw that has brought contention over the non-Communist affidavit section of the TaftHartley Act was tilted in favor of the National Labor Relations Board today.
Enlistments in the armed forces spurted al over the United States yesterday, the first ful day of recruiting since President Truman on Friday authorized use of the draft.

WASHINGTON, July 10--Soviet Russia was not represented at the Cairo Conference in November-December, 1943, where, in association with Great Britain and Nationalist China, the United States took the step--momentous, as it proved--of specifically guaranteeing the post-war independence of Korea "in due course."
WASHINGTON, July 10--The Senate voted today, 55 to 24, to confirm the nomination of Sumner T. Pike of Maine to a new term of four years as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 10--It's a long swim from Nova Scotia or New Brunswick to Montauk Point, yet every week during the summer season some 12,000 lobsters make the 340-mile trip--in the wet well of the lobster smack Lynn.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 10--Prompted by the success of the Refugee party in the SchleswigHolstein state elections yesterday, the West German Government set out this morning on a reinvigorated program of refugee aid.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10-- Lester Cowan, independent film producer and promoter, has concluded a deal to produce a comedy feature, "The Customer Is Always Right," in New York in September utilizing a three-dimensional process developed by the Polaroid Company.

The first exhibition in New York of prizewinning art by high school students in the national Scholastic Magazines Art Awards contest was opened yesterday by John J. Bennett, Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions, acting for Mayor O'Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)-- Congress got a suggestion from New York business men today that the $1,010,000,000 excise tax slashing bill be put aside until the world impact of the Korean war was clarified.

"So Young, So Bad," the drama produced by the Danziger brothers here starring. Paul Henried and Catherine McLeod, originally scheduled to open at the Criterion on Saturday, will open there at a later date, it was reported yesterday by a spokesman for the management.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 10 --Westchester's plans for a new $4,930,000 trunk sewer and disposal plant system in New Rochelle and vicinity were endorsed by that city, Larchmont and Mamaroneck this afternoon at a public hearing of the Board of Supervisors. Speakers hailed the project as a long-overdue step toward elimination of Long Island Sound pollution.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 10--Glenn H. McCarthy, Houston oil man, announced today that he had borrowed $5,000,000 from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, using his oil field near New Ulm, Tex., as security.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 10--Arrangements have been completed by the Rutgers University Press and the Abraham Lincoln Association of Springfield, Ill., for the press' publication in 1952 of the collected writings of Abraham Lincoln. The twelve-volume set will contain approximately 50 per cent more material than that in all previous collections combined, and will be titled "The Writings of Abraham Lincoln."
WASHINGTON, July 10--The Defense Department called on the Selective Service System this afternoon to draft 20,000 men for the Army as soon as possible.
WASHINGTON, July 10--The Chiefs of Staff of the Army and Air Force took off from here tonight on a suddenly arranged flight to Japan to consult with Gen. Douglas MacArthur on the Korean fighting.

Average interest rates charged on business loans by New York City banks moved upward slightly between March and June this year. Data based on reports from twelve New York City banks, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, showed, however, that the rates remained approximately at or below those charged in June 1949.

WASHINGTON, July 10--In a new move designed to force civil rights legislation to the Senate floor for a vote, Administration leaders set out today to stop a Southern Democrat filibuster before it started.

AT THE KOREAN FRONT, July 10--A United States officer said today that he had found the bodies of seven American soldiers Monday afternoon lying alongside a road, their hands tied behind their backs, and shot through the face.
Two Coast Guard cutters, normally on North Atlantic weather patrol duty, took part in emergency medical assistance action yesterday at widely separated points in mid-ocean.

LONDON, July 10--Britain will send to Moscow soon a reply to the request of Andrei A. Gromyko, Deputy Foreign Minister, for "elucidation" of the London Government's original appeal to the Soviet Union to use its influence to help end the Korean war.

Rains that approached a tropical intensity yesterday drenched the metropolitan area, bringing benefits to some communities and troubles to others. The storm was general throughout the Middle Atlantic region.

Hyphasis of the Belair Stud sailed to victory in the Last Coin Handicap, feature race on the card at Jamaica yesterday. With Bobby Bernhardt doing the riding, Hyphasis registered by almost two lengths over the Sanford Stud Farm's Round View.

The Whitehouse, fifteen-story apartment building accommodating ninety families at 262 Central Park West, has been purchased by Whitehouse Realty Associates, headed by Walter Hirshon, from Sisbrothers, Inc., of which Norbert Natanson is president. Sale was for cash above a first mortgage of about $1,950,000 held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)-- Honeymooning Willie Pep put his marriage ahead of a scheduled 10round boxing bout tonight and thereby drew a suspension from the National Boxing Association. The fight was canceled.

No decisive action took place between North and South Korean ground units since the last communique. The South Koreans' capital division in the vicinity of Chinchon was pushed back about five miles in action which more or less straightened the line at this point.

Increased car orders here and throughout the state since the start of the Korean campaign were reported yesterday by the Automobile Merchants Association of New York and the New York State Automobile Dealers. As a consequence, further delays in deliveries were forecast, many dealers already being behind in fulfilling their commitments.

CHICAGO, July 10--Seventeen years ago a World's Fair was held in this bustling Midwestern village. It had educational exhibits of vast intellectual scope and it also had fan dancers who were not quite as intellectual in their appeal. But it also had a baseball game, and that was one thing which remained to posterity.

Against a newspaper backdrop of fashion headlines, an exciting show of Coro jewelry and Glentex scarves was held yesterday for the New York and visiting out-of-town fashion editors at the Pierre Hotel. It was presented by Ann R. Silver Associates.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10-- L. M. Giannini, president of the Bank of America, Sam Husbands, president of Transamerica, Inc., and both institutions were adjudged in civil contempt by the United States Court of Appeals here today.

Operations of steel mills this week are scheduled at 96 per cent of ingot capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The return to the preholiday record high level of output has been delayed because of vacations at several plants.

MOFFETT FIELD, Calif., July 10--Aeronautical science today unveiled a new type of wind tunnel which is expected to aid in development of guided missiles capable of reaching fifteen times the speed of sound. That would be about 11,000 miles an hour at sea level.

A check on how the bass season has been progressing on some of the watershed lakes after a week of operation provided conclusive proof that the fishermen are holding up fine. There were indications, however, that the bass have tired of the fishermen.
The Department of Defense has requested the Advertising Council to aid the Armed Forces in increasing voluntary enlistments, it was disclosed yesterday by Theodore S. Repplier, council president.

The relaxation of water restrictions for swimming pools, wading pools, street and playground showers and the limited use of garden hoses and sprinklers, originally scheduled to end on July 15, was extended yesterday to Aug. 15.

Uneasiness over the Korean campaign was evident in merchandise markets here yesterday. The reports were apparently disturbing enough to alter buying plans of a number of store representatives looking for fall and winter goods.

The special meeting of stockholders of the General Motors Corporation to vote on the stock split-up proposed by directors a month ago has been scheduled for Sept. 27. The board decided yesterday that the record date for the special meeting would be taken as of the close of business Aug. 14.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 10 (AP) --George D. Widener's Marabout, a light gray son of Mahmoud, led all the way today to win the featured Billy Kelly Purse at Monmouth Park in 1:12 2-5 for the six furlongs.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 10 (AP) --Dick Attlesey of Southern California cracked the world record for the 110-meter high hurdles tonight with a time of 13.5 seconds.

Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, announced last night that he had asked the help of President Truman for his favorite project of clearing the slums of Chinatown and setting up a "China Village" neighborhood community there.

CHICAGO, July 10--In an acrimonious atmosphere that permeated both camps, the National and American Leagues arranged their battle lines tonight for the seventeenth annual All-Star game which will be played tomorrow afternoon at Comiskey Park, scene of the first midsummer classic in 1933.

BOGOTA, Columbia, July 10 (AP) --Colombia's official earthquake toll reached 270 in dead today, and Red Cross 'reports said 40,000 persons had been left homeless in a rich coffee growing region 230 miles northeast of here.

John L. Smith, chairman of the board of Charles Pfizer Co., Inc., manufacturing chemists, and vice president, treasurer and a director of the Brooklyn Dodgers baseball team, of which he was a one-fourth owner, died yesterday in his home at 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, after a five-month illness.

The first structure in New York since the days of frame houses that will be built with no masonry showing on its facade is soon to be erected as an annex to the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. The land on which this architectural innovation will rise is occupied now by a sandstone building, formerly a residence, the demolition of which will begin on Friday.

The season when green and yellow squash are most plentiful has begun with the arrival of the first sizable shipments from the Hudson Valley and New Jersey. Both varieties of this summery vegetable will continue to be plentiful during the warm weather, a reporter of the United States Department of Agriculture predicted yesterday. As supplies increase, the cost may go lower than the current average of 15 cents a pound.
The executive committee of the Kings County Republican Committee yesterday endorsed Nicholas H. Pinto, a member of the State Commission Against Discrimination, for the nomination for Surrogatte.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 10--Billy Timpson of the Rockaway Hunting Club teamed superbly with Gil Cavanaugh, Vic Chezzi's youthful assistant golf professional at Inwood, to score 32, 34-66, six strokes below par, to win the weekly Long Island P.G.A, amateur-pro best-ball tournament at Wheatley Hills today.
When Postmaster General Donaldson announced economy curtailments in the postal services last May many of us thought that the public would not be seriously inconvenienced.

Designs for two parks near the east end of Forty-second Street, part of the over-all plan for making that area conform to the general layout of the adjacent home for the United Nations, were approved yesterday by the city's Art Commission.
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was heavy yesterday and prices closed up 200 to 280 points, net.

The eight public school teachers who were suspended recently for refusing to say whether they were members of the Communist party will receive separate departmental trials on charges of insubordination and conduct unbecoming teachers.
PARIS, July 10--Premier-designate Ren Pleven's chances of reconstructing a strong French Cabinet coalition were considered to depend tonight on whether the Socialists agreed to join the Cabinet.

Negotiations are under way between the Shubert office and John Charles Thomas for a production on Broadway this fall of the venerable operetta, "Blossom Time," with the noted concert and opera baritone as its star.

J. Osgood Nichols, an attorney associated with the old Manhattan Railway Company and later the Interborough Rapid Transit for more than twenty-five years, died Sunday evening in New York Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 81.

WASHINGTON, July 10--After two and a half years of litigation the National Labor Relations Board has directed its general Counsel, Robert N. Denham, to seek enforcement of its orders against the International Typographical Union, A.F.L.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 10 --The Arab League is in grave difficulties. The question of its attitude toward aggression in Korea has revealed the lack of a common viewpoint among the Arab states on an issue that has no connection with Israel.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., July 10--The women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fortyseventh annual championship got under way over the hilly and rugged Sleepy Hollow Country Club course today in some of the worst weather in the history of the event.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 10--Dr. T.F. Tsiang of China told the United Nations Little Assembly today that he planned to ask for a special meeting of the fiftythree-nation organ to take up his Government's charge that Russia
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared yesterday that the world was now working "under the dark clouds of a threat of war" and blamed a wide lack of knowledge of world affairs for the "state of tension."

Citing "the threat of direct government action," Arthur J. Glover, president of the striking Switchmen's Union, ended the walkout on four large Western railroads last Thursday, but announced that switchmen on the fifth road, the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific, would not return to their jobs.

WASHINGTON, July 10--A large measure of criticism of the Federal Government's growing role in housing emanates, ironically, from within the Government's own ranks. The general basis for this criticism is the belief that Congress, in yielding to numerous pressures, has saddled the administrative offices with reckless policies which, if continued, will inevitably lead to credit socialization.
Mayor O'Dwyer appointed Arthur W. Wallander, former Police Commissioner, to the post of City Director of Civilian Defense yesterday, and said he expected "pretty prompt" action on the city, program.

Plans for the fifteen-story store and office building to be erected at the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-first Street were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Emery Roth Sons, architects. The cost was put at $2,165,836.
Hampered by a six-hour driving rainstorm, which cut attendance below expectations, the local summer furniture market got off to a slow start in the New York Furniture Exchange yesterday.

Re-checking yesterday by the New York Athletic Club's committee handling the Block Island regatta indicates that the bizarre sailing cruiser race whose fleet floated eastward on Long Island Sound, propelled mainly by tides and currents in a contest that had no wind, was won by W.T. Snaith's Figaro, a 32-foot Alden cutter.

The National Battery Company is advising stockholders of a proposal to change the name of the company to Gould-National Batteries, Inc. At the same time the company yesterday released its report for the fiscal year ended with last April.

WASHINGTON, July 10--Edward Weinfeld of New York was nominated by President Truman today to be a Federal judge in New York's Southern District. If confirmed by the Senate, he would succeed Judge Simon H. Rifkind, who resigned May 24.
LONDON, July 10--The Soviet Government, which has blocked an Austrian state treaty for three years on one pretext after another, forced a further two-month postponement today.

Post Office trucks reclaimed 6,038 sacks of mail from two strike-bound Jersey City piers yesterday and transferred them to two vessels that are to sail today from Pier 84, North River, for Mediterranean ports. Both ships, the Expeditor and the Exbrook of the American Export Lines, had been scheduled originally to sail from Jersey City.
PEARL HARBOR, July 10 (UP) The Essex-class carrier Philippine Sea, the backbone of Task Force Yoke, sailed into Pearl Harbor today, escorted by the destroyers Knox and Hollister.

Contrary movements ran through the major world security and commodity exchanges yesterday, although some showed a pick-up even before General MacArthur's more reassuring report on the Korean fighting. Brussels and Amsterdam stock exchanges firmed and Paris resisted selling. Initial hesitancy in London was replaced by better conditions.
Meat and bread prices went up in the city yesterday.

Textile houses in the Worth Street primary market yesterday withdrew prices on both gray and finished goods for a new computation of costs following the cotton price rise of 2 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange.

TOKYO, July 10--Top Japanese Government officials discussed today with occupation authorities the creation of national police reserve of 75,000 men to maintain internal order as United States troops are drawn from Japan for combat in Korea.
The population of the metropolitan area was reduced yesterday by 2,702,554.

Future contracts for delivery of hides were in strong demand on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Prices advanced 110 to 132 points as the volume of trading expanded sharply to 7,520,000 pounds, the highest in several months. Yesterday's rise marked the fifth consecutive trading day in which new high prices for the life of contracts were recorded in all active deliveries.
WASHINGTON, July 10--A tugboat engineer today gave a Congressional subcommittee his views on the newsprint shortage and what could be done about it.

LONDON, July 10--From the sophisticated audience of London balletomanes, accustomed to the polished perfection of the famous Sadler's Wells troupe, the New York City Ballet Company received an enthusiastic reception tonight when it opened a month's engagement at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10-- The Bank of America has filed suit in the Los Angeles Superior Court to attach the assets of the Nasser Brothers, northern California theatre operators and owners of the General Service Studios here, to insure recovery of $829,528 in unpaid film loans which the Nassers guaranteed in 1948 and 1949.

"Your Hit Parade," one of the old stand-bys of radio, took the television plunge last night on N.B.C. (9:30) and, for the moment, decision must be reserved-- rather firmly reserved, as a matter of fact.

TORONTO, July 10--Bishop Eivind Berggrav of Oslo, Primate of the Lutheran Church of Norway, was unanimously elected a president of the World Council of Churches today by that body's ninety-member policy-making central committee, meeting here in annual session on the campus of Emmanuel College.

New York City will supply 1,203 men for the Army as its part in the nation-wide call for 20,000 men, local Selective Service officials reported last night. They said it would take about sixty days for the men to be inducted.

WASHINGTON, July 10--The American Electric Securities Corporation. New York investment company, applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to purchase 7,000 shares of its own participating preferred stock at $2 a share. The purchase would be made from the Office of Alien Property, Department of Justice.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 11 (AP) --The Soviet Union charged today that the United Nations Security Council's decision to place all United Nations forces in Korea under the leadership of the United States was unlawful and "represents direct support to armed aggression against the Korean people."

James Amarante received another chance yesterday to purge himself of contempt. But the 38year-old "free lance" house painter again failed to impress the Kings County District Attorney's office with his answers on his connection with an alleged policy bank headquarters in Brooklyn.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 10-- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, who canceled a projected European tour last month because of the Korean crisis, hopes to leave within a week or ten days for a short vacation in Norway, usually well-informed sources said today.

COLUMBIA, S. C., July 10-- Radio loudspeakers broadcast three solid hours of political oratory tonight as candidates carried their final vote appeals over a South Carolina network of more than twenty-five stations in preparation for tomorrow's Democratic primary in which an estimated 400,000 persons will vote.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 10-- The international situation and the fear here that the war in Korea will continue for some time and spread will induce Brazil to ease up its import licenses for American goods, especially semimanufactured products and some raw materials for domestic manufactures.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 10 (AP)--The Czechoslovak Government charged today that American military planes had been flying over Czechoslovakia. It said there might be "consequences" if the flights continued.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 10 (AP) --Nationalist China's top diplomat in the United States said tonight that free nations should throw off their prejudices and unite in the common struggle to check Communist domination of the world.

"All the world's a stage" and every woman on it an actress. This is the thought behind the varied and stimulating collection on which Mr. John raised the curtain yesterday morning in his whiteand-gold-decorated salon at 53 East Fifty-seventh Street. The hats he offers for the end of 1950 and the beginning of 1951 were created so that women may dramatize themselves a la Mr. John.

In his original announcement about military aid to Korea on June 27, President Truman said: "I have similarly directed acceleration in the furnishing of military assistance to the forces of France and the associated states in Indo-China and the dispatch of a military mission to provide close working relations with those forces."

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 11-Seesaw, indecisive fighting was in progress today on the Korean front as Americans, for the first time using tanks, backed by a concentration of bombing, rocketfiring and strafing planes flying in clearing weather, were attempting to hold back a mechanized North Korean attack north of the Kum River on the road to the temporary Republican capital of Taejon.
It is good that among the gardener's attributes is a store of patience upon which he may draw as needed, for this sea son he has had to tap this reservoir until its level now is low.
Traffic lights hung over Manhattan streets to supplement the present eye-level lights will be needed in the new progressive signal plan, Lloyd B. Reid, Commissioner of Traffic, said yesterday.

Appointment of Gen. Lucius D. Clay to head New York State's Civil Defense Commission is a good indication that its work is going to be taken seriously. At the last session of the Legislature the structure of a civilian defense organization was established with passage of a measure setting up the nine-man commission of which General Clay has now been named chairman.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP)--The major leagues today formally agreed to relax their March 1 deadline for the start of spring training, and heard an alarming report on the effects of television and radio on minor league attendance.
WASHINGTON, July 10--President Truman's second bid to give departmental status to the Federal Security Agency was rejected, 249 to 71, by the House today.

Esther Rothstein has sold the six-story forty-three-family apartment house at 1460 College Avenue, the Bronx, to the Martel Realty Company. Mrs. A. Inselstein was the broker and the attorneys were Abraham P. Insel for the buyer and Bernard L. Seligman for the seller. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

ALBANY, July 10--Gen. Lucius D. Clay was appointed by Governor Dewey today as chairman of the State Civilian Defense Commission with broad powers to meet the emergency of possible atomic warfare for New York's 15,000,000 people.

Every morning since June 26 this newspaper has published maps of the fighting in Korea, with black arrows representing the invading Red troops and white arrows representing the defenders. A week ago this morning the black arrows were still north of Suwon and east of the Kimpo airfield.

The men's clothing industry will be ready for any Government demands upon it as a result of the Korean situation, Isidore Grossman, chairman of the convention committee of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A., said at a meeting yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CHICAGO, July 10--Traffic on the Illinois Waterway soared to a record 12,895,114 tons in 1949 although mine shutdowns caused a reduction of more than a 1,000,000 tons in coal shipments below 1948, Col. J. P. Campbell, Chicago district engineer, said today.
Last night started out like any other night for Patrolman William Jennings of Mounted Squadron 1, Troop B, and his big 20-year-old gelding, Otis.
BREWSTER, N.Y., July 10 (AP) --An estranged wife seeking divorce evidence was shot to death early today as she knocked on the door of a cabin occupied by her husband and a woman friend.

Robert Fulton, popularly but erroneously known as the "inventor" of the steamboat, is the subject of an exhibition that opened yesterday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Fortysecond Street.

Monday's heavy rains flooded the tributaries of the Catskill and Croton reservoirs and added 893,000,000 gallons to the city's water storage. The gain reversed a downward trend during which daily losses have been as high as 700,000,000 gallons.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 12-- American forces at the front in South Korea have their backs to what until recently was the area of the most intense guerrilla activity in that rugged country.

Organization of civilian defense moved ahead rapidly yesterday when Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman of the State Civilian Defense Commission, opened offices in Manhattan, and Mayor O'Dwyer rallied his city administration behind the state program.

BOSTON, July 11--Revolutionary methods for the collection and preservation of blood, together with new apparatus and techniques that make possible for the first time the isolation of many new components that promise to serve as veritable "elixirs of life," were demonstrated here today at the laboratories of the Harvard Medical School.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11-- George Gard (Buddy) De Sylva, retired song writer and film producer, died today at the Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital of a heart ailment from which he had suffered for five years. His age was 54.

The Jersey City jurisdictional dispute within the ranks of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., continued its spread yesterday with the result that two Holland-America Line vessels, the Veendam and Diemerdyk, were not worked by Hoboken longshoremen.

CHICAGO, July 11--The millennium has arrived. It's the dawn of a new era. The National League won an All-Star game from the American League. Honest injun. It said so on the scoreboard. The numbers read, 4 to 3, late this scorching afternoon at Comiskey Park as the first overtime fray in All-Star history went fourteen dramatic innings before Red Schoendienst, a rather obscure member of the cast, ended it.
Six thousand or more New York young men will be called by their draft boards for examination, beginning next week, to assure filling the city's initial quota of 1,203 recruits.

The four-story building containing four stores and ten apartments at 851 East 169th Street, northeast corner of Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Bertha Q. Middendorf to the Gregmal Realty Corporation. George A. Bowman, Inc., was the...
CHICAGO, July 11--Burt Shotton gave the answer today to one of the most abusive demonstrations a major league baseball manager. ever experienced.
Reaction in the liquor industry to international developments spread yesterday to increased demands for Scotch and other foreign distilled products.

It is as true in legislation as in most other fields of endeavor that efforts to please everyone too frequently end in pleasing no one. We are witnessing an illustration of this in the case of the tax bill, which passed in the house ten days ago by a vote of 375-14, but which has run into very heavy going in the Senate Finance Committee.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 11 --Foreign Minister Mohammed Saleh el Din Bey, in a statement to the press today, said Egypt hoped Communist aggression would be checked everywhere. He said Egypt would not recognize the Communist Government in China, indicating Egypt considered it had come to power by aggressive means.
LONDON, July 11--Winston Churchill, Conservative leader, declared in the House of Commons today that War Secretary John Strachey was "unfit" to hold the post of Secretary in the British Government.
WASHINGTON, July 11--The tax bill approved by the House of Representatives lost its place of top priority in the Senate today, and there were indications that it might not be called up at all.
The United Nations received late yesterday afternoon the first twenty-five of the 500 official United Nations flags it had ordered in a hurry for combat units in Korea.

In a move for new business, Buchanan Co., Inc., has increased its staff and added four new directors, John Hertz Jr., board chairman, announced yesterday. CHICAGO, July 11--The armed services' nurse corps have not started a special recruiting campaign as a result of the Korean fighting, but officials of the American Nurses Association said today that its members were "geared to emergency at all times."

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, July 11--The vital ministries and official agencies of the Korean Republican Government continue to function. Virtually the entire Cabinet and fourteen-man committee of the National Assembly are working in this capital to deal with the problems of caring for refugees from Communist-captured areas, the organization of communications lines and the national security behind the combat front.
The New York City Housing Authority will open bids on $9,467,000 of its temporary-loan notes today at its offices at 63 Park Row. The notes will be dated July 28 and will mature on Feb. 9, 1951.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 11--Speaking before educators here for a three-day conference and inspection of the summer training camp of the Reserve Officers Training Corps, Maj. Gen. Kirke B. Lawton today emphasized the need for more college-trained officers for the modern American Army.

The opinion of the International Court of Justice that South-West Africa, is still under an international mandate and that the Union of South Africa has no competence to change its status without the consent of the United Nations is momentous. This is a real assertion of authority and an...
Radar helped but did not wholly overcome the rain and fog that beset New York flying and shipping from late Monday night until mid-morning yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 11--At least two separate economy movements were being organized today as the Senate opened debate on the Omnibus Appropriations Bill, which carries $34,688,308,672 for operation of the Government in the current fiscal year.
LONDON, July 11--The four British Parliamentary members of the unofficial International Committee for the Study of European Questions announced their resignation today.

Althought the Korean war has brought about some anticipation of needs by both consumers and industrialists, panic buying is not likely to develop, according to C.F. Hughes, Business News Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Speaking at a meeting of the Millinery Mer-...

ELMSFORD, N.Y., July 11-- The marriage of Miss Maxine Emily Hillman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hillman of 1150 Park Avenue, New York, to Jay Kay Lazrus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar N. Lazrus, also of New York, took place this evening at the Fairview Country Club. The Rev. Ira Eisenstein performed the ceremony.

Machinery set up to operate the state rent control law when it became effective on May 1 is now functioning smoothly, State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick said yesterday. He added that applications from both landlords and tenants for relief were being disposed of with a minimum of delay.

WASHINGTON, July 11--Maj. Gen. Glen E. Edgerton, director of the Office of the Commission on Renovating the White House, today reported the work now 25 per cent complete, and still a month ahead of schedule.
The first voluntary insurance plan for dental care in the nation was approved yesterday by the First District Dental Society, whose members practice in Manhattan and the Bronx.

The tall, skinny man with the bald head, gold-rimmed spectacles, and peppery manner sat down to file a claim for old age benefits for his wife. Her birth certificate, he told the interviewer, had been destroyed in a fire many years ago.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 11 (Reuters)--The International Court of Justice, highest legal authority in the world, today ruled that South Africa could not modify the international status of the mandated territory of SouthWest Africa without United Nations consent.

Retail prices of lamps are headed for a decline following completion of a long-range cost-reduction project by the National Lamp and Shade Institute, which represents producers all over the country. This was asserted yesterday by Benjamin H. Hyman, president of the New York Lamp and Shade Manufacturers Association.

The open seasons and other regulations for the hunting of waterfowl will not be issued until about Aug. 26 this year, a month later than usual. Meanwhile, tentative dates and bag limits for doves, rails and gallinules in all states and for scoter, eider and old-squaw ducks in the northeastern states have just been made public in Washington.
ROME, July 11--Msgr. Patrick J. Byrne of Washington, D.C., 62year-old Bishop and Apostolic Delegate to Korea, has been missing since the Communist invasion of South Korea.
William F. Spaulding has been appointed assistant to the president of William Skinner Sons. He formerly was division sales manager and coordinator of production with the Verney Corporation.

Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company's two new debenture issues aggregating $35,000,000 are being marketed today. Out of the proceeds the company will prepay $10,000,000 of promisory notes due May 1, 1951 and $3,000,000 due Aug. 11, 1950, while the balance will provide part of the cost of new facilities to be added to the company's natural gas pipe line system this year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 11 --Henry Payson, the home club champion, and Jack Marcato of the Winged Foot carried off honors today in the first member-guest best-ball tournament over Fenway Golf Club course. The last duo to finish, Payson and Marcato, carded a paid of 33s for a 66.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,997, against 498 last week and 2,441 in the similar week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,222 arrivals yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11-- Lauren Bacall, whose stormy, sixyear career at Warner Brothers has been regularly punctuated by salary suspensions because of disagreements with the management over the suitability of her vehicles, has obtained a release from her...

Mayor O'Dwyer urged Congress yesterday to restore to the amended Social Security Act provisions for public assistance to Puerto Rico that were approved by the House of Representatives but deleted by the Senate.
PARIS, July 11--The Western world must prepare for war with Russia, Gen. Charles de Gaulle said today.

Theatre-in-the-round, conceived in the hinterlands and dedicated to the proposition that there should be a minimum of artificial barrier between performers and audience, is a thriving stage device these days.

DETROIT, July 11--Delayed in his trip from his home in Los Angeles, Herman Steiner, United States chess champion, had to resort to rapid play against Major J. B. Holt of Sarasota, Fla., in order to avoid a possible forfeiture of his first-round game in the annual open tournament for the Sturgis Trophy in the Detroit Edison Company's huge auditorium today.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 11 (AP)--In a move to promote business for the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway, Assemblyman Wilson C. Van Duzer today demanded a state police crackdown on what he said was the overloading of trucks.

BOSTON, July 11--The nation's home owners are being lured into buying "gew-gaws and nooks" at the expense of safe minimum standards of area and livability, Robert Woods Kennedy, Boston architect, asserted today at the forty-first annual meeting of the American Home Economics Association.

JERUSALEM, July 11--Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion today invited the Knesset (Parliament) to choose a new Government if the members wished to reverse the policy of deporting infiltrators entering Israel from the neighboring Arab states.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange staged another advance yesterday, and closing prices were 2 to 70 points net higher.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 12-- United States forces have fallen back behind the Kum River, the broad stream that is the last natural barrier before the temporary Korean Republican capital of Taejon, and invading North Korean tank columns are probing at strategic crossings over the broad stream, now swollen by recent rains.

Yesterday's humidity produced a rush for soft drinks at the thirdfloor canteen in the Veterans Administration Building at 252 Seventh Avenue. Frank A. Kelly, the blind canteen manager, figured it as a "peakey" day, with 1,500 drinks served.

LONDON, July 11--Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, reported to the House of Commons today that Britain would soon cease her discriminatory trade practices against other members of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation as a result of the agreement to establish a European Payments Union reached in Paris four days ago.

TORONTO, July 11--The Central Committee of the World Council of Churches was requested here today to declare its opposition to all infringements of religious liberly, whether committed by churches, government or "other agencies."

LAKE SUCCESS, July 11--Gen. Douglas MacArthur, commander of United Nations forces defending South Korea, has requested Secretary General Trygve Lie to send 400 United Nations flags for the use of his command.

WASHINGTON, July 11--The American people were warned today to be prepared for a long, bloody and difficult operation in Korea and to accept the possibility of yet more Soviet-inspired military action in other parts of the world.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 11-H.L. Keenleyside, chief of the United Nations technical assistance mission to Bolivia, discuss today with President Mamerto Urriolagoitia plans to implement the mission's report, which will in effect be a thorough audit of Bolivia's public administration and economy.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 12-- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today that documentary evidence had been received here of the murder of four United States prisoners by North Korean Communist troops.
LOS ANGELES, July 11--Nearly 10,000 Marines are sailing from Long Beach and San Diego for war in Korea.
There is no shortage of shipping for military-naval purposes and there have been no delays in moving personnel and equipment to the Korean war zone for lack of tonnage.

ROME, July 11--In the past few days Italy has reaffirmed her stand on international issues. The three day parliamentary debate which ended tonight with a long exposition of foreign policy by Foreign Minister Sforza and a fiery defiance of the Communists by Premier de Gasperi was as fervid in spots as the weather which is said to ton the record.
WASHINGTON, July 11--Francis Biddle, national chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, declared today his organization was "proud to be a part of what might be called the 'liberal lobby'."

Dr. Angelica Balabanoff, 71year-old Socialist leader who was released on Monday from Ellis Island after a three-day detention, said yesterday she was unable to explain why her re-entry into the United States had been held up by immigration authorities.

LONDON, July 11--The Soviet Government is now watching for an auspicious moment to begin diplomatic bargaining with the Western powers for the termination of the Korean war, in the view of certain expert circles here.

Thomas J. Curran, New York Secretary of State and chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, charged last night that the national leadership in Washington had courted the political favor of the Communists.

The Senate has confirmed the President's nomination of Summer T. Pike of Maine as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission. Democratic members voted almost solidly in favor of this action. The Republican members were divided; but the fact that nearly as many Republican votes were cast for Mr. Pike as were cast against him...
The demand for natural crude rubber for future delivery broadened on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday and prices advanced sharply in the near-by deliveries.

WASHINGTON, July 11--Organized labor today pledged its full cooperation in any future emergency but asked for representation in the policy, planning and operational divisions that may be created to deal with the crisis.

ALBANY, July 11--The Court of Appeals upheld today the constitutionality of all but one section of the State Rent Control Law. It held that landlords were entitled to collect back rent increases authorized by the Federal Housing Expediter which accrued prior to May 1, 1950, the effective date of the state statute.

EMPORIA, Kan., July 11--Herbert Hoover said tonight that American hopes of a lasting peace lay "in a new direction of national policies," including reorganization of the United Nations to confine communism.

A dramatic series produced in London by the British Broadcasting Corporation had its local premiere last night at 9:30 on the city's station, WNYC, its first presentation being a dramatization of the ill-fated campaign of Bonnie Prince Charlie to invade England.
The head of the Census Bureau in Washington has offered to come to town next week to search for some missing persons.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 11 (AP) --F. Eugene Dixon Jr.'s Honey's Gal reveled in the sloppy going at Monmouth Park today and registered a four-length victory over Brookfield Farms' Imacomin in the six-furlongs headliner.

Summer picnics are lots of fun for the whole family, especially when the food served can be toted to the beach or park in proper style. Picnic hampers that are veritable refrigerators are available now to make this possible.

TOKYO, July 11--Premier Shigeru Yoshida today warned Japan's opposition parties against inviting misunderstanding of world opinion by insisting that the nation remain neutral following the outbreak of the Korean war and United States and United Nations action to halt the North Korean invasion.

Promotion by Japan of betterquality and higher-priced goods in the United States was listed yesterday as a major aim of that country's future trade policy at the formal opening of the Japanese Overseas Agency office in this city.

CHICAGO, July 11--Two big rail unions, the Railroad Trainmen and the Conductors, with a membership of 250,000, announced tonight they would make a new try to avert a strike that they at a legally free to start on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 11--President Truman urged a bipartisan group of Senate leaders today to reverse the action of their Appropriations Committee by restoring a $15,000,000 cut in funds to be devoted to technical assistance to foreign countries under the Point Four program.

Meat hardly seems a politic subject for discussion now after Monday's price rise above the already forbidding levels. But the new service of the Northwestern Meat Corporation, offered to householders with freezers or extra-sized freezing compartments, has as much of a convenience as a cost angle.
A canvass of food prices yesterday disclosed no appreciable change from Monday when certain cuts of meat went up 1 to 6 cents a pound and bread a cent a loaf.

Bankers Trust Company has been appointed sole agent of General Telephone Corporation to issue and transfer warrants to purchase common stock and to accept subscriptions upon exercise of such warrant for the subscription period July 7 through July 19, 1950.

The Berks County Trust Company, Reading, Pa., reported as of June 30, total deposits of $72,894,230 and total assets of $80,106,080, compared, respectively, with $67,126,369 and $74,108,714 on Dec. 31, 1949. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $9,865,770...

NEW DELHI, India, July 11-- A special session of the Indian Parliament has been called to discuss the Korean conflict and the international situation. The session will open July 31 and last two weeks.

Bitter fighting in Korea, with small United States units holding, delaying and retreating, was again reported from the Far East yesterday as the Communist invaders drove toward the important Kum River defense line.
IN SOUTH KOREA, July 11 (UP) --United States troops were staggered today by a licking from crack, welt-equipped North Korean soldiers wearing red stars over their hearts.
WASHINGTON, July 11--President Truman today nominated John E. Peurifoy, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Administration, to be Ambassador to Greece.
WASHINGTON, July 11--A second year of military assistance to nations resisting communism was approved by a 22-to-0 vote of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs today.
TRENTON, July 11--The New Jersey Supreme Court reaffirmed today its decision voiding the 7cent zone fare of the two largest bus operating companies in the state.
Domestic steel mills made production history in the second quarter and the first six months of 1950 and, in addition, achieved the highest June output of raw steel ever recorded.

Bare Foot Boy, the Cain Hoy Stable's top-weighted colt with a superior mud rating, found Jamaica's off track decidedly to his liking yesterday and sped home an easy winner of the mile and an eighth feature on the Empire City program.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)-- The first broadcast of a statement attributed to an American war prisoner of the North Korean Communists was reported today by Government monitors.
Makers of branded lines of men's shirts will hold prices unchanged as long as possible, Harry S. Jacobson, president of F. Jacobson Sons, Inc., maker of Jayson shirts, said here yesterday.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 11 --The annual Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament for the Clifford Hemphill Trophy opened today at the Bathing and Tennis Club, but only a few matches had got under way when a short but heavy downpour of rain drove the players from the court.

CHICAGO, July 11--Baseball's mid-summer classic, the All-Star game, conceived in 1933, began its second turn of the wheel today and after seventeen long years it finally looks as if something new is about to be added.

The violent sell-off in the stock market shortly before the close did not stem the advance in railroad obligations on the bond market although it succeeded in pushing some carriers under their extreme highs of the session. The Immigration and Naturalization Service began a test yesterday of the proposition that membership in the International Workers Order is equivalent to membership in the Communist party.

The fact-finding board appointed to settle the four-day strike of 12,000 Manhattan apartment-house workers last April recommended yesterday that the workers receive a pay increase of $2.75 a week and one additional paid holiday each year.

New York's first work relief program since the depression of the Thirties will begin actual operations this morning when 320 recipients of public assistance, the vanguard of a projected "special labor force" of 5,000, report for work with five municipal departments.

PARIS, Wednesday, July 12-- Endorsed as Premier by the almost unprecedented vote of 373 to 185 by the French National Assembly, Rend Pleven, former Minister of Defense, was expected to form a reconstructed Ministry with a wide majority of all republican forces within several hours. It had taken five different candidates three weeks, since the Bidault Cabinet fell, to achieve this result.

ROME, July 11--Premier Alcide de Gasperi threatened tonight to invoke strong measures against the Communist "fifth column" if it persisted in undermining Italian unity and solidarity at a time when all citizens should join to face mounting international dangers.

HALIFAX, Va., July 11 (AP)-- Lawrence Morris Markey, 51 years old, author and former newspaper man, was found dead of a gunshot wound at his home here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11-- Local 10 of Harry Bridges' longshore union next week is to make a third attempt to establish policy on the Korean situation, following unsuccessful efforts last night at a meeting that ended in fist fights and brought police.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 12 (AP) --Ray Richards, correspondent of International News Service, and Cpl. Ernie Peeler of Stars and Stripes were reported killed in action Monday on the Korean front.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 11 (AP)--Anti-Leopoldists won another day's respite today in their lastditch battle to delay the return of exiled King Leopold III to his throne.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 11--A "relatively small investment" in a technical assistance program to build up under-developed countries like Korea will help to avert the loss of American lives in economically weak places where the Communists may decide to attack in...
WASHINGTON, July 11--The House Public Lands Committee today reported out the Bosone bill that aims at the eventual end of the Indians' status as Government wards.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 11--The free world has better than an even chance for success in the fight against communism in Southeast Asia, William S.B. Lacy, director of the office of Southeast Asian and Philippine Affairs in the State Department said today at the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

Strictly speaking, what the Senate will vote on today is not the bill at all, but a petition to limit debate on a motion to bring up the bill. Despite these complications of parliamentary procedure, however, the basic issue is clear...

Sales of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., rose 19 per cent, or $12,448,000 to $75,859,000 for the quarter ended on June 30, last, from the $63,411,000 volume for the same period a year ago, O. Parker McComas, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Richmond, Va.
CASPER, Wyo., July 11--The development of more crop land irrigation in the face of agricultural surpluses is a live subject in the Great Plains today.

It took thirty-eight minutes yesterday afternoon for a Federal court jury of three women and nine men to convict four men of being members of a gang that planned to steal $3,000,000 from the Cuban national treasury and...

WASHINGTON, July 11--Appearance in the Korean fighting of Russian-built jet fighter aircraft was guardedly viewed by military leaders here today as an indication that the Soviet Union might be ready to make an overt show in the Korean battle.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)-- An official forecast of a 3,175,000,000 bushel corn crop, the fifth largest on record, gave assurance today that the United States can step up its meat, dairy and poultry output if the military situation should demand.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Wednesday, July 12--James F. Byrnes, 71-yearold former Secretary of State, was assured early today of election as Governor of South Carolina, and Senator Olin D. Johnston appeared headed for a second term in the Senate, defeating his Dixiecrat opponent, Gov. J. Strom Thurmond.
WASHINGTON, July 11--President Truman today ended his long quest for a chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission by promoting Gordon E. Dean, a member, to that office.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 11--A grandmother who teaches the third grade in Mississippi, a business woman from New England and a wife and mother from Brooklyn are among the thirty women past the age of 40 who went back to school here this week.

BINGHARMTON, N.Y., July 11 (AP)--Larry Murphy of the Yahnundassis Country Club. Utica, came in just before dusk with a 70 to tie Lloyd Ribner of the Fenway Golf Club, White Plains, for the medal in the qualifying round of the twenty-eighth New York State amateur golf championship.
Master of an American passenger liner and a Danish freighter that collided in the harbor on June 27 blamed each other yesterday at an official inquiry before a board of the United States Coast Guard.

A comprehensive preview of fall millinery was presented last night in the Millinery Fashion Bureau and Millinery Stabilization Commission showing at the Astor Hotel by custom designers, volume manufacturers and members of the Creators Guild. It was a combination of trends, all aimed toward the creation of a more importantlooking hat.

On the authority of General Bradley, Chairman Tydings of the Armed Services Committee warned yesterday that the United Nations forces face a long and difficult campaign in Korea. No chance for an all-out counter-attack is likely for some weeks to come.
WASHINGTON, July 11--The National Labor Relations Board and its General Counsel, Robert N. Denham, collided head-on today in an issue of internal administration.

LONDON, July 11--The stock markets looked a little brighter today under the lead of British Government securities. Industrials followed, with many small rises, while South African goldmines generally closed with prices at their best levels.

PITTSBURGH, July 11--Longdiscussed plans to form a permanent organization to represent the soft coal industry in collective bargaining with the United Mine Workers were brought to completion today with organization of the Bituminous Coal Operators Association.

The announcement that Egypt is with us in condemning the North Korean aggression is a victory for the West. The statement that Foreign Minister Mohammed Saleh el Din Bey made yesterday, lining up Egypt on our side in the struggle against world communism, should have a notable effect throughout the Middle East.
Appointment of Joseph Kaitz as acting deputy director for planning of the State Civil Defense Commission was announced yesterday by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour cities shows, the Federal Reserve System announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended July 5: A decrease of $486,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities.
Are relief rolls rising? The latest figures are bound to be confusing to the public. This newspaper recently published what appeared on the surface to be conflicting reports.

Strike-free elevator service in Manhattan apartment houses until next April 20 was assured yesterday when union and employer representatives agreed to a wage increase of $2.75 a week and one additional paid holiday for 12,000 building service workers.

WASHINGTON, July 12--In memory of the thirteen American correspondents who were killed in an airplane crash near Bombay on July 12, 1949, an annual prize for journalistic achievement, to be known as the William The Silent Award was established today.

WASHINGTON, July 12--Proceedings on the proposed merger of Pan American Airways and American Overseas Air lines went into an odd spin today when the Federal District Court here bared the Civil Aeronautics Board from issuing President Truman's decision in the controversial case.

WASHINGTON, July 12--When the State of Texas, on July 20, files with the Supreme Court its motion for a rehearing of the case involving ownership of that state's submerged coastal lands, the principal argument will be that the recent decision awarding this ownership to the United States was founded on a historical error and therefore should be reversed.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The Senate committee investigating organized crime in interstate commerce announced today that the facilities and files of the Police Department of New York City had been placed at its disposal by Mayor William O'Dwyer.

The Pressed Steel Car Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it was selling its McKees Rocks, Pa., plant to a syndicate that "plans to dispose of the machinery and equipment and create a mufti-industry settlement in the 100-acre area."

WASHINGTON, July 12--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in an open letter to President Truman asserted today that he had evidence that the State Department in 1946 had destroyed files bearing on the loyalty of its employer.
QUEBEC, July 12 (Canadian Press)--Tugs and launches tonight evacuated passengers from the 20,000-ton liner Franconia, stuck fast on a reef in the St. Lawrence River a mile from Quebec.

SCHEVENINGEN, the Netherlands, July 12--The Holland Festival audience at the Kurhaus Audi-- torium was intrigued tonight by Leonard Bernstein's second symphony, "The Age of Anxiety," performed by The Hague Residence Orchestra under William Van Otterloo, with the composer at the piano.
COLUMBIA, S.C., July 12-- James F. Byrnes, 71 years old, former Secretary of State and onetime "assistant President," won the Governorship of South Carolina today.

SAN CRISTOBAL, Dominican Republic, July 3--The light-machine-gun manufacturing plant set up here two years ago with the aid of European refugees from communism has just started to turn out its first quantity of a new-type automatic weapon for the Dominican Army.

The Carpet Institute, Inc., yesterday sent a telegram to the Indian Ambassador in Washington and the Indian Consul General in New York protesting refusal of the Indian Government to permit shipments of firm orders for carpet wool placed prior to July 8 by American carpet manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, July 12--C. Tyler Wood, one-time senior partner of Gilbert Eliott Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, was nominated today by President Truman to be Deputy United States Special Representative for the Marshall Plan in Europe. Mr. Wood, whose nomination is subject to Senate approval, would have the rank of Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary.

PARIS, July 12--A new French Cabinet reviving the once-strong majority of Radicals, Socialist and Popular Republicans, under the leadership of Premier Rene Pleven, was announced early this evening. It followed a night and day of bargaining and disputing.
The cotton futures market closed irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange, with final prices 9 points higher to 47 points lower.

TOKYO, July 12--Apparently in anticipation of future reverses and prolonged guerrilla warfare, the North Koreans are hastening the distribution of land to the poor peasants in their newly won territory.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 13--The commanders of the United States Army and Air Force arrived here this morning for a series of critical conferences on the reinforcement of American strength in the Korean war.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 13-- North Korean tank columns today concentrated their attacks against outnumbered United States rear guards north of the Kum River, the last important natural barrier between the defenders of the Korean Republic and its emergency capital of Taejon.

CHICAGO, July 12--The Railroad Yardmasters of America, A.F.L., today telegraphed President Truman that it would forego for the present its right to strike against sixty-six railroads on or after Saturday and would seek to settle its dispute by further negotiations. These are expected to begin Friday with the return here of the National (Railway) Mediation Board.
Peter the Great--all hands decreed yesterday at the Bronx Zoo --henceforth will be called Peter, the Wondrous Ancient.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 12--The Israeli Government clarified its position today on the proposed establishment of a new oil refinery in Haifa and the allocation of exploratory oil rights to independent American oil companies as recently reported.

LONDON, July 12--The exploratory talks on ending the Korean war that were held in Moscow yesterday between the Soviet Acting Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, and the British Ambassador, Sir David Kelly, have not produced any concrete plan for mediation or settlement in the immediate future.
With a few reductions and no substantial price rises yesterday on major food products, olive oil was the only item to evidence any "scare buying."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 12-- Billy Dear Jr. of Montclair, N.J., who has a summer home at West Hampton, L.I., captured the medal with a one-under-par 72 in the Long Island amateur golf championsship over the Garden City Golf Club course today.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., July 12--Westchester County studies of ways to provide adequate water supplies for its communities were advocated today by the water resources committee of the Westchester Waterworks Conference.

Fear of shortages in consumer goods has boosted the sale of nylon hosiery at the retail level and has resulted in rising prices of unbranded lines at wholesale. Hosiery distributors reported yesterday that several unbranded lines have been withdrawn from sale while others have gone up from 25 cents to 50 cents a dozen.
Under the sponsorship of the League of Composers, a program devoted to the music of the late Kurt Weill was given last night at Lewisohn Stadium.
Howard E. Babcock of Ithaca, N.Y., who was one of the nation's most important agricultural leaders, died yesterday in the New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 61 years old.

LIEGE, Belgium, July 12 (AP)-- Sex hormones are making old persons feel younger and healthier. Hormones have brought startling results in about fifty men and women, all over 65 years old and some as old as 90, Dr. William B. Kountz of St. Louis, reported before the first International Conference on Gerontology today.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP)-- Jan Kyjovsky, acting Czechoslovak Consul General in New York, has asked the United States for asylum from communism. State Department officials said today the appeal, received June 19, was being consideed.

BERLIN, July 12--West German police reports that East German border officials had broken today their pledge not to interfere with the mails, within twenty-four hours after it had been given, prompted an investigation by the three Western commandants into the situation at Marienborn, Soviet zone border checkpoint.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The National Federation of American Shipping joined today with the Army and the Department of Commerce in opposing a bill to exempt intercoastal vessels from payment of Panama Canal tolls. The bill was introduced Feb. 8, 1949, by Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat of Mississippi.
BONN, Germany, July 12--A delayed reaction of nervousness appears to be setting in in Western Germany as the war in Korea continues without the Communist advance being checked.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12--Dr. Henry Cuthbert Bazett, Professor of Physiology at the University of Pennsylvania, died at sea, according to a radio report received today from the liner Queen Mary. He was 65 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 12--Secretary of State Dean Acheson today branded as "war criminals" the people who sanction, in defiance of the United Nations, the North Korean armed invasion of the Republic of Korea.
Must a bread knife have a serrated edge? This question, put to THE NEW YORK TIMES' food news department by a Pittsburgh housewife, brought different answers from different authorities.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)-- Provisional census returns show that 104 United States cities now have a population above 100,000. That's a dozen more than in 1940, with a few more still to be heard from.

Industrial circles have been buzzing with reports that the Government is readying an allocation plan for steel and other key commodities to assure proper availability of the necessary products for military orders.

LOS ANGELES, July 12--A formidable array of engineering problems must be solved before jetpropelled transport airplanes can come into general use, an official of the Civil Aeronautics Administration warned the nation's leading aviation engineers tonight.

If ever there was a man to be saying: "God save me from my friends; I can take care of my enemies," it should be Clement Attlee. The British Prime Minister has been plagued by a succession of wild statements and faux pas from his own Ministers, who have...

Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, declared yesterday that the Communist invasion of Southern Korea was definitely in accordance with Moscow's plan --"a step in a pleat that is still to unfold."
Customs authorities believe they are on the track of a concerted smuggling movement among refugees coming here under the displaced persons program.
IN SOUTH KOREA, July 12-- Chinese Communist troops in division strength now have been tentatively identified for the first time during the Korean war as taking action on the combat front.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 13 (AP)-- Communique No. 70 issued by Gen. Douglas MacArthur at 1:05 P.M. Tokyo time (11:05 P.M. Wednesday, Eastern daylight time) read:

Frequent meetings are being held by the Women's Division of the Travelers Aid Society to perfect plans for the dinner dance under its auspices to be held Sept. 28 at the Plaza. The event will open for the winter season the newly redecorated Persian Room. Mrs. W. Mahlon Dickerson is chairman of the division and has as her aides for the benefit Mrs. Dee Bredin and Mrs. Kelley Keresey.
A former Communist testified yesterday at a deportation hearing that the International Workers Order, a left-wing fraternal organization, was a Communist party adjunct.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP)-- George (Sugar) Costner scored the fistic upset of the year tonight by thrashing lightweight champion Ike Williams to gain a unauimous i 10-round decision before 9,809 spectators at Shibe Park. Costner weighed 148 pounds and Williams 143 for the non-title scrap.

Simon Kutner, builder, has sold the new one-story taxpayer containing seven stores at 118-23 to 118-33 Metropolitan Avenue in Kew Gardens, Queens, to Maxwell L. Low. The building, 100 by 60 feet, was completed April 1. The property, in the block between Eighty-third and Lefferts Avenues, was held at $125,000. Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., was the broker.
The main body of United States troops withdrew to the south bank of the Kum River as rearguards held back the North Koreans in a costly delaying action. [1:8; map P.2.] The Americans,...

The rubber futures market on the Commodity Exchange was under some pressure yesterday and prices declined 25 to 50 points. The lower market here reflected easiness in London, where near-by deliveries closed at 28 pence a pound.

BOSTON, July 12--The best way to make clothes look better and last longer is to give them a few days' rest between wearings, Prof. Edward R. Schwarz of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology told members of the American Home Economics Association today.

WASHINGTON, July 12--In a big step toward implementing President Truman's Point Four program, the House of Representatives approved today, 195 to 151, limited guarantees for American capital investment abroad.
We do not have to anticipate an extension of the Korean fighting in order to see value in the meeting in Washington between twenty-two top labor leaders and Chairman W. Stuart

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN KOREA, July 12 (AP)-- A bitter, beaten little band of G.L's sprawled in exhaustion on a sunny Korean hillside this afternoon--weary survivors of one of the most savage battles fought by Americans in the Korean war.

The rental status of the vast majority of residential tenants remained unchanged yesterday, but some faced attempts by their landlords to get the benefits of Tuesday's decision of the State Court of Appeals.

BASEBALL folks were still buzzing yesterday over the subtle strategy used by Burt Shotton to win the All-Star game for the National League at Comiskey Park on Tuesday. Only the craftiest sort of planning could have been behind the fiendishly clever move which culminated in Red. Schoendienst's fourteenthinning home run. The omniscient and occult Mr. Shotton sneaked the redhead into the fray by the back door and caught the American Leaguers off guard.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The International Typographical Union, A.F.L., asked the National Labor Relations Board today to withdraw its instructions to the board's General Counsel, Robert N. Denham, to seek court enforcement of board orders against the union.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 12--The United Nations appealed today to both sides in the Korean war to put an end to atrocities.

The state executive committee of the Liberal party approved last night a report by Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman, calling for extension of the Voice of America and President Truman's Point Four program for aid to backward world areas as made increasingly necessary by the invasion of South Korea.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)--Following is the roll call vote by which the House of Representtatives passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to guarantee United States private investments in economically retarded foreign countries, commonly called the Point Four bill:
Police Inspector Nicholas A. Pisarra made a belated reappearance yesterday before Brooklyn's racket-investigating grand jury.
WASHINGTON, July 12--Members of Congress responded with chagrin and anxiety today to the bad news from Korea and influential voices were raised for far greater American exertions.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 13 (AP) --Lieut. Gen. Walton H. Walker, who has assumed command of the United States ground forces in Korea, is a veteran of World Wars I and II.
BOSTON, July 12 (AP)--The Red Sox' pennant chances, already shackled with an eight-game deficit, suffered a bruising jolt today as X-rays disclosed Ted Williams had a fracture in the left elbow.

Entitling his fall collection "It's a Man's World," Walter Florell frankly took men's fashions for the inspiration of his presentation yesterday at 29 East Fifty-third Street. He translated fedoras, snap brims and even collapsible top hats into dramatic styles for women.

LONDON, July 12--Britain's military weakness, in view of growing world tension, was the highlight of a long and acrid debate in the Houss of Commons today. Replying to Opposition members who had sharply questioned the state of British preparedness,

The National "Cigar Enjoyment Parade" campaign, sponsored by manufacturers and distributors, will open next month with two months of heavy use of radio and television spots in forty-two major markets. While newspaper schedules for the main drive are not yet set, it was announced that...

If the aircraft manufacturing industry of the United States were called upon now to start an allout production effort, it would take ten months longer to reach an annual output rate of 50,000 planes than it did in World War II.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 13--The hard--pressed advanced United States forces in Korea face a foe whose successes have shaken deeply the confidence in American superiority in arms on the part of men assigned to the job of stemming the tankled Red tide that is still slowly engulfing Korea.

CHICAGO, July 12--Grain markets were irregular on the Board of Trade today, fluctuating in a nervous manner, influenced in part by uneasiness regarding the situation in the Far East with hedging sales appearing in wheat, corn and

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12--A syndicate of Eastern investors, headed by Paul V. McNutt, former Governor of Indiana and chairman of the War Manpower Commission, has acquired control of the United Artists Distributing Corporation, from Mary Pickford and Charles Chaplin.

NEWARK, July 12--The Public Service bus lines in New Jersey restored the 5-cent bus fare shortly before 1 P.M. today after being threatened with contempt and other legal proceedings for failing to act promptly on a Supreme Court decision yesterday which voided the 7-cent zone fare.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 12--Making his first appearance since his return from Wimbledon, where he led the Australian champion, Frank Sedgeman, by 2 sets to none, Arthur Larsen of San Francisco gained the quarter final round of the annual Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament today at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

Prices of lead, lead products and tin rose here yesterday. Customs smelters advanced lead cent a pound to 11 cents, New York basis, with market reports indicating that the Government may stockpile lead for the second half of this year. Spot "grade A" tin increased 2 cents a pound to 84 cents here, reflecting continued price strength in Singapore and London.
Freshly returned from Paris, Florence Reichman was enthusiastic as she talked of the fall and winter millinery fashions at a showing yesterday afternoon in her salon at 1 West Fifty-seventh Street.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 12--Chile is willing to give Bolivia an outlet to the sea between Arica and the Peruvian border and President Truman has given "enthusiastic" approval of the plan, President Mamerto Urriolagoitia said in an interview here today.
WASHINGTON, July 12--Senate leaders decided today to shelve the House-approved tax bill at the request of John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury.
WASHINGTON, July 12--The bill to establish a permanent Fair Employment Practices Commission again was barred from consideration by the Senate today.

Directors of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation declared yesterday a 40 per cent common stock dividend, payable Oct. 16, and also increased the semi-annual common stock cash dividend from 80 cents previously distributed to $1 a share, payable Aug. 15.

The stock market, still reeling from Tuesday's assault, was rocked yesterday by two distinct and savage waves of selling. The liquidation plunged the list to new lows for the year, completed the elimination of approximately one-half of the gains scored in the year-long bull movement and reduced values further by 1 to 4 points.

Following a nation-wide trend, the number of marriage licenses issued here in the first six months of 1950 was 1,667 less than in the same period last year. The total here has declined every year since 1946.
