Who can deny that there are certain advantages in having school over for the year? Perhaps cynics and pessio, ... mists can do so, shouting the denial until they are purple in the face.

TORONTO, July 12--The Korean war was described here today by a leading German churchman as the "first example" of what may happen in a nation that has been too long divided either by an "iron curtain" or by "unnatural frontiers."

WASHINGTON, July 12--Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat of Oklahoma, chairman of a Senate military spending subcommittee, said tonight that the Administration would ask "a billion or more" in new funds to finance the Korean fighting.

In warning the interstate bus companies serving New York that they will have to use the Port Authority's new union terminal now under construction, Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday was simply applying a little public pressure in a good cause. Clearly he cannot force the companies into the new terminal, but he can--and apparently ...

BOSTON, July 12--In a sweeping order adjudging the Waltham (Mass.) Watch Company "solvent," Judge George C. Sweeney, of the Boston District Federal Court, today authorized reopening of the 100-year-old plant, which had been closed since February for lack of working capital. Employment of Teviah Sachs, a stockholder, as president at $25,000 annually also was authorized.
GENEVA, July 12--A representative of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and one of the world's lead ing economists held out new hope today to the underdeveloped regions.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 12--Wartime use of television as a vital factor in communication on land, sea and in the air was predicted by David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, at a gathering of United States educators and high military officers here this afternoon.

The Duquesne Light Company, an affiliate of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application contemplating refunding of its outstanding 5 per cent preferred stock, the financing of its 1950 construction program and sale of new preferred stock to the Philadelphia Company.

The Maritime Administration of the Department of Commerce announced yesterday that fifteen Victory-type cargo vessels and a refrigerated cargo ship had been ordered removed from the nation's 2,200-ship reserve fleet.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP)-- John J. Edmiston, a former F.B.I. undercover agent, testified today that Communists led a 1941 strike against the Powell Valve Company of Cincinnati as part of their campaign to tie up the national defense program during the HitlerStalin pact.
Michael Todd began booking negotiations yesterday for a local Shubert house in which he plans to present Garson Kanin's new comedy, "The Live Wire," in midAugust.

Four hundred United Nations flags will soon be flying over General MacArthur's headquarters in Japan and at points on the mainland of Korea where the conditions of battle make it possible to give the colors to the wind. Sometimes these conditions do exist:...

WASHINGTON, July 12--The Michigan-Wisconsin Pipe Line of Detroit applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to make bank loans aggregating $20,000,000 in the period up to June 30, next.

The five-story store and apartment building on lot 41 by 80 feet at 737-39 Ninth Avenue, northwest corner of Fiftieth Street, was sold by the Dornbusch family, represented by Louis C. Dornbusch, to Nathan Wilson, the operator, in a deal negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company. The sale was the first involving the property...
The ten-story and penthouse apartment building at 67 South Munn Avenue in East Orange, N.J., has been sold by the Sixtyseven Holding Company to the Sixty-one Realty Corporation, of...
Jake La Motta defended the middleweight championship of the world with unqualified success at Madison Square Garden last night.
PEARL HARBOR, July 12--Pacific Fleet Admiral Arthur W. Radford is en route to Tokyo to confer with Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the admiral's headquarters announced here today

CLEVELAND, July 12--It was a bit different for Manager Barney Shotton here tonight than it was in Chicago yesterday. For the Indians racked up his Dodgers by an 8-5 score in the first meeting of their home--and--home exhibition series for the benefit of sandlot baseball.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 12 (UP)--The Western Powers have at least 170,000 top-grade fighting men in Western Germany, most of them armed with the latest American and British equipment, a United Press survey showed today.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 12 (AP)-- The former "Poughkeepsie Regatta" will go again in 1951 to Marietta, Ohio, the board of stewards of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association decided today after considering invitations from six cities.

WASHINGTON, July 12--Organized labor today promptly turned over to W. Stuart Symington, chairman of the National Security Resources Board, the names of nine labor leaders who will be the voice of labor in the Korea crisis.
The New York Public Library's outdoor story hours, which began this week, are being held at 220 parks and playgrounds in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island.

The City Planning Commission adopted yesterday an amendment to the Zoning Resolution permitting it to approve applications for the construction of garages or parking facilities accommodating only 150 cars. The previous minimum was 200.

The marriage of Mrs. Ruth Power-O'Malley, daughter of Mrs. Yeaton Stuart of Alexandria, Va., and the late Michael Power-O'Malley of Dublin and County Waterford, Ireland, to Granville Whittlesey Jr. of New York, took place yesterday afternoon at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 12 (AP)--Yeung Johnny Cwik blazed around the par-70 layout at the Binghamton Country Club today in 69 to eliminate the favorite, John Ward, 1 up, in the first round of the New York State Amateur golf championship. Cwik is club champion of the I.B.M., Poughkeepsie. Ward hails from the Syracuse Yacht and Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The Navy issued today to its district commanders a guide for the release of information on ship and troop movements. Army officials drafted a similar code and sent it to commands throughout the United States.

A seven-man team will represent the United States in the annual International Tuna Cup matches against six other combinations in the tournament to be held at wedgeport, N.S., Sept. 13 through 16. S. Kip Farrington Jr., chairman of the board of directors' executive committee for the matches, announced the makeup of the team yesterday.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 12--Upsets marked the second round of the forty-seventh annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today over the hilly Sleepy Hollow Country Club course.

A Coast Guard board of inquiry was told yesterday that the steering apparatus of the Danish freighter Colombia was in perfect working order when the vessel collided with the American Export liner Excalibur on June 27 in the Upper Bay.

VERSAILLES, France, July 12 (AP)--Lady Mendl, the former Elsie de Wolfe, renowned for successive careers as a Broadway stage star, interior decorator, and international hostess, died today in her Versailles chateau at the age of 84. She had suffered recently from rheumatism.
Sales of leading chain stores and mail order companies showed an increase of 7 per cent in June, according to the compilation covering forty companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

We are tempted today into a poor pun, currants are current. Very much so, market authorities report. Commercial preservers who up till last year took virtually the whole crop, are buying little because of a large carryover of the frozen berries and juice, which they can readily convert into jelly.

Prodded by fear that the events in Korea might prove to be merely a dress rehearsal for similar developments in Europe, French political leaders have at last composed their domestic differences and formed a new Government which commands a wider backing than any Government since the first days following liberation.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 12 (UP)--Motorized Bulgarian Army units in battle array are proceeding toward the Yugoslav frontier, the official news agency Tanyug said today.

Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham's Main Chance Farm apparently has a new formula for winning stakes races. It goes this way: "Ship a horse from Long Island to Chicago. Ship him back again. Then go after the money."

WASHINGTON, July 12--By a vote of 327 to 14, the House gave complete authority today to the heads of eleven departments and agencies closely associated with national defense to suspend or discharge any employe considered a bad security risk.

Some indications appear in Soviet statistics that Russia stepped up her war preparations recently, Dr. Naum Jasny of the Soviet Economics Study Group, Food Research Institute, Stanford University, reported yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 12--The effect of Communist aggression in Korea can be accurately measured by the difference in the reaction today to former President Hoover's revived proposal for the reorganization of the United Nations to exclude Communist countries.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 12-- Within three weeks, if Chinese Nationalist observers are correct, world communism will strike on a new front, probably in the Far East.

Increases were made in stocks of all major oil products last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline supplies were up 139,000 barrels to 114,278,000 at the week-end. A year earlier they amounted to 113,763,000 barrels.

Representatives of the city's 30,000 policemen and firemen, who are Seeking general pay rises and lower pension costs, were assured yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer that their requests would receive "very serious consideration."

The newspaper world must lament today the first of their fallen in the Korean war. Ray Richards of the International News Service and Corporal Ernie Peeler of Stars and Stripes join the honored list of those who died in the Second World War getting the news where the danger was greatest.
The Army said yesterday that it did not plan to send any of its new draftees to Korea in the near future, and that "not many" of them would be shipped there at all.

If the Free Milk Fund for Babies, of which Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is chairman, did not share in the proceeds, it might be reported that the wrestling program at the Yankee Stadium last night was just for laughs. However, there were 11,328 men and women who could find no humor in an infant's need for milk and a portion of the $33,746.90 they paid to watch the show will go to the fund.

AMSTERDAM, July 12 (Reuters)--Representatives of the American, Dutch, Belgium, British, Israeli and South African diamond cutting industries have decided to boycott the German diamond industry on the ground of its alleged dumping policy.

After a post-war slump productivity (output per man-hour) has risen and is now substantially above pre-war levels in most of the 133 companies studied by the National Industrial Conference Board in its latest survey of business practices. Offering of a new issue of $19,189,000 of Nassau County, N.Y., 2.10 per cent improvement bonds, maturing Aug. 15, 1951 to 1979, inclusive, will be made today by the Chase National Bank and associates.

LONDON, July 12--A few Americans mingled today with Britons, citizens of the British Commonwealth and others, as the first of the two royal garden parties took place on the rolling lawns of Buckingham Palace.

The World-Telegram and The Sun appealed yesterday to eight craft unions to "permit and direct" their members, made idle by a strike of the C.I.O. Newspaper Guild of New York, to return to work Monday.

Faced with uncertainties concerning raw material pricing, several large rayon mills have withdrawn from the market following sales which covered production through the third quarter, it was learned yesterday. Leaders of the Democratic party in this state said yesterday that they did not expect Mayor O'Dwyer to be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor despite reports that he was a candidate for the nomination.

Bodman of Hill House, Glen Head, have anpounced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Violet Bodman Price, to Edmund Coffin, son of Mrs. William Sloane Coffin of New Haven, Conn., formerly of New York, and the late Mr. Coffin. THE particular anxiety of Western visitors to India, as they specu late about the ultimate fate of that sprawling, untidy, mystertous and newly freed subcontinent, is whether it will turn to communism. Preparations for the general adoption of "open-end" mortgage contracts are now under way among savings banks in New York State. Such mortgages, previously adopted by some savings and loan associations, apparently have proved their suitability for the lender as well as the borrower.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., July 15 (UP)--Anne Mather of Boston, a descendant of the Puritan preacher Cotton Mather, was married today to a prominent Negro social worker whom she had met while working to combat racial discrimination.

General MacArthur's headquarters said that North Korean attacks had driven back the Americans six miles on the Kum River front. South Korean forces gave the invaders two of their worst setbacks since the war's outbreak.

PITTSBURGH, July 16--The steel ingot rate recovered somewhat last week from the holiday setback but not enough to meet the onrush of fresh steel orders. Ingot production was 96.5 per cent of rated capacity, up 3 points from the week before but 5 points less than the level of three weeks ago. It was believed that output this week would be stepped up some because vacations would be over at some plants.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 16--The South Jersey veteran regatta driver from Ventnor, C. Mulford Scull, who started years ago on the outboard circuit but has long since moved upward into the faster daredeviltry of inboards, played a major part toay on Pleasure Bay in the first race meet ever attempted by the Long Branch Ice Boat and Yacht Club.

The storm created by the temporary suspension of two American correspondents who had been reporting from Korea has blown over. General MacArthur has reversed his over-zealous public information officer, Col. Marion P. Echols. Tom Lambert of The Associated Press and Peter Kalischer of The United Press, who risked their hides getting action stories at the front, have "gone back to the war."
BASTOGNE, Belgium, July 16-- A monument commemorating the Battle of the Bulge was inaugurated here today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 16-- In the murk after the cessation of rain, but with an increasing breeze, the second session of race week at the Larchmont Yacht Club turned from a gloomy prospect into fine competition today.

DUNELLEN, N.J., July 16-- Miss Gail Fenbert of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Miss Carol Jean Kruse of Elizabeth, N.J., shared the honors today as the two-day Plainfield Horse Show on the Inglehurst Estate in Greenbrook Township came to an end.

WASHINGTON, July 16--President Truman is expected to ask Congress this week for the funds and home-front controls he believes are needed to prosecute the fighting in Korea. He worked at his White House office for several hours today, walking over from his near-by Blair House residence.

LENOX, Mass., July 16.--For the second week-end in succession Serge Koussevitsky and a contingent from the Boston Symphony Orchestra played two concerts devoted to Johann Sebastian Bach in the Theater-Concert Hall here at Tanglewood.

Michael Todd wasn't building castles in the air when he said he'd bring "The Live Wire" to Broadway as quickly as possible. Two factors prompted him to take this sudden step: Close examination of rehearsals and advice from kibitzers.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP)--The Cubs flattened the Phillies, 8 to 0, with a six-run seventh inning in the first game of a double-header before they walloped them again, 10 to 3, with a seven-run fifth inning.
WASHINGTON, July 16--Plans are being shaped for voluntary cooperation by radio and television manufacturers in expediting a speeded-up military procurement program.

Soviet Premier Stalin in a note received in New Delhi, India, yesterday, told Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, in apparent agreement with Pandit Nehru's views, that "reactivation of the Security Council should be the first step in ending the Korean dispute and all other problems."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 16--The Soviet Union is enjoying increasing success in extending its influence by assuming the old role of Czarist Russia as a friend of the Greek Orthodox religious community in the Levant states.

Francis S. Harmon, vice-president of the Motion Picture Association of America and head of the war activities committee of the Motion Picture Industry in World War II, was named yesterday to provide liaison between the association and the Voice of America film program.
WASHINGTON, July 16--Defense headquarters characterized reports of the past two days on the battle along the Kum River line as "more encouraging than anything we have had for a long time."

If you are among the fortunate with your vacation yet to come, or if your beach wardrobe needs replenishing, you will be interested in Patterns of The Times this week. From the two patterns a number of functional adaptations can be made of denim, terry cloth, gingham, other cottons and even bath towels.
NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., July 16 (U.P.)--Major Lloyd Hill tried to go over Niagara Falls in a 725pound iron barrel today but police and friends stopped him a mile from the brink.

ALBANY, July 16--The State Banking Department announced today that the Brooklyn Trust Company, 177 Montague Street, Brooklyn, had been issued an authorization to open branch offices at 221-44, 221-46, 221-48 and 221-50 Horace Harding Boulevard and 72-67, 72-69 and 72-71 Main Street, Queens.

LONDON, July 16--Displaying quite remarkable resistance to increasingly unfavorable news from Korea, the market's fortitude broke rather badly toward the last weekend. The military situation in Korea was by no means entirely responsible for the fresh, although moderate, wave of selling.
Maude E. Warwick Fund scholarships have been awarded to nineteen college students and high school graduates from seven states and the District of Columbia for the academic year 1950-51.
PARIS, July 17--The fifth International Cancer Congress was formally opened today in the presence of Vincent Auriol, President of France.
NEW DELHI, India, July 16-- Premier Stalin's reply to Prime Minister Nehru's note on the Korean conflict has been transmitted to Washington and London the Foreign Office said tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP)-- The Korean war and resulting heavy sugar buying have torpedoed chances for early signing of a new international sugar agreement, industry sources said today.

AMSTERDAM, July l6--After a listless but quiet tone early in the week a setback occurred on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange Thursday with share losses up to 17 points on the week though the turnover remained small. MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 16 (AP)--The fast yawl Escapade beat her forty-seven rivals to the finish line in the Port Huronto-Mackinac yacht race today in a record-breaking performance.

OTTAWA, July 16--A single world-wide teachers' organization, to consist of 2,500,000 teachers from every country except those behind the Iron Curtain, is expected to be founded within the next few months. Heads of the three leading world school groups have agreed on a tentative constitution for the united teachers group.

Appointments of seven additional members of the technical staff of the Department of City Planning were announced yesterday by Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the City Planning Commission. Five initial appointments were announced last week.
TOKYO, Monday, July 17 (AP)-- North Korean Army headquarters denied again today that North Korean Communist forces had murdered American prisoners of war.

BOISE, Idaho, July 16--The fight being waged by Senator Glen H. Taylor of Idaho for renomination as a Democrat, despite his excursion into third party politics as Henry A. Wallace's running mate in 1948, is only one phase of a primary campaign that is leaving Idahoans groggy.

ZURICH, July 16--The Swiss will join the European Payments Union, but they see many grave snags. Neither competent authorities in Berne nor leaders of Swiss business life in Zurich and Basle any longer doubt that Switzerland will adhere to the new union, but they expect it to come at a later date than the other countries of. the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
TOKYO, July 16--Gen. Douglas MacArthur promised today that United Nations force would drive the Communist North Korean invaders back behind the Thirty-eighth Parallel border.

The American Labor party will run no nominee against Assemblyman Harold A. Stevens, Democratic candidate for judge of the Court of General Sessions, Representative Vito Marcantonio, state and county chairman, announced yesterday. He urged full support of Mr. Stevens.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., July 16--A petition by a group of college student war veterans here calling for a cease-fire order by the United States in the Korean war was branded today as "just one more step in the Communist campaign to undermine and destroy America."

The United States reverses in Korea and the atrocities committed by North Korean troops and Communist execution squads already have evoked demands--still fortunately few--that we should use the atomic bomb against Northern Korea.

The Associate Alumni of City College, in a report to be issued today by its board of directors, declared: "It cannot be said with any degree of certainty that Prof. William E. Knickerbocker was anti-Semitic. By the same token, it likewise cannot be said with any degree of certainty that he was not."
MONTREAL, July 16 (UP)--Australia's netmen completed a 5-0 sweep over Canada today to gain the final round of the North American Zone eliminations against Mexico in the Davis Cup tennis competition.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 16-- Capt. Logan Cresap, U.S.N., retired, and his wife, Nancy Nash Cresap, were found dead today of illuminating gas poisoning in their home at 1 Walbrook Circle, Greenburgh. Captain Cresap until recently was marine superintendent of the Isthmian Steamship Lines.
Walk down a country road these bright summer days and you will see a page of rural history turning before your eyes.

An erratic movement of the Australian pound spotlighted the trading in the foreign exchanges last week. Liquidation of speculative positions built up in anticipation of an upward revaluation of the pound which did not materialize produced heavy offerings and depressed the rate from $2.22 on Monday, to $2.18 on Thursday.

The treacherous turf conditions caused by yesterday's rain resulted in the postponement or cancellation of all the near-by polo games, including the high-goal contest at Bostwick Field, Old Westbury, L.I., where a quartet headed by Pete Bostwick was scheduled to engage Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes.

CINCINNATI, July 16--The Giants and the Cincinnati Reds battled for 5 hours 58 minutes in a doubleheader on Crosley Field this afternoon and evening, carrying their campaign over six and one-half hours of elapsed time. When the firing ended shortly after 8 o'clock, the New Yorkers had been repulsed twice.

So far as the entire American League is concerned, Sunday, July 16, 1950, was an utter waste of time, toil and talent. With doubleheaders on all fronts, everyone won and everyone lost. Consequently, nothing at all was accomplished.
QUEBEC, July 16 (Canadian Press)--The 20,000-ton liner Franconia was freed today from Pointe au Taureau, rocky island off Orleans Point, where she ran aground last Wednesday night.
New and improved "stop" signs will appear tomorrow on fifteen streets intersecting Franklin Avenue in Brooklyn from Empire Boulevard to Atlantic Avenue.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 16 (AP)--"I feel a kindred spirit for our men in Korea today," said Jonathan M. Wainwright.

Independent stores are gaining over the chains in the race for the consumer's food dollar. This trend, developing for the first time since the end of World War II, is discerned in an analysis just completed by the National Industrial Conference Board.

PITTSBURGH, July 16.--A flurry of home runs--including two by Gus Bell and a ninth-inning four-master by Earl Turner--gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 6-5 victory over Boston in the second game of a double-header before 29,363 fans today. The Braves took the first game, 9-5, with a 14-hit attack.
TOKYO, Monday, July 17--North Korean artillery shells began falling in Taejon this morning, according to a front-line report reaching here.
The little Canadian coaster Velvet Lady, a 147-foot Diesel-powered craft, is about to complete a month-long voyage to the West Indian port of Matthew Town on Great Inagua Island.

Many couches and chairs available now may be converted, with some pushing and pulling, into comfortable bedding units. A new group just put on the floor at Macy's, however, shifts from sitting to reclining positions with a minimum of trouble and energy.

MOSCOW, July 16 (AP)--The Soviet press told the Russian people today that there was a rising wave of discontent in the United States and throughout the Western world over United States intervention in Korea.

Current world events and the present status of this country's merchant fleet demand a reawakening of public interest in American shipping, and toward this end the Propeller Club of the United States has developed a plan for the expansion of its promotional activities, Louis B. Pate, national president, said yesterday.

The Western Union Telegraph Company is planning an advertising campaign built around the theme: "A telegram commands attention--gets results." Newspapers, consumer magazines, trade publications and radio will be used, together with an expanded point-of-sale...

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP)-- American troops face "six to nine months" of fighting in Korea and even longer if Russia sends reinforcements to the North Korean Communists, Millard E. Tydings, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said today.
In accordance with the dictates of its last convention, the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., will initiate a new policy on aliens, starting at the end of this month.

An attempt to instruct New York's delegates to the International Typographical Union's convention to call for the filing of non-Communist affidavits by the union's officers finder the TaftHartley Law was defeated yesterday.
Two policemen in a helicopter and a lifeguard in a catamaran performed a minor feat in navigation at dusk yesterday in a heavy sea off Rockaway Beach.

CHICAGO, July 16--War talk is regarded as having lost its effect as a price-making influence in the grain markets, temporarily at least. The result last week was that prices reacted from the top levels on the Board of Trade, but not until July corn, all deliveries of soybeans and lard had sold at new seasonal high prices.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 16--Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett declined to commit himself today on Israel's answer to the request of United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie for aid in the Korean war. He said that the matter would be considered by the Cabinet this week, but implied that Israel's defense needs must be considered.
Plans for the erection of an apartment house in the Sutton Place section have been announced in connection with the purchase by the Florence Realty Company, Benjamin...

Death dazzle on the highways is a fearsome night peril that is increasing throughout the country. Although many measures have been suggested and tested to rid the roads of glare from motor headlights the results have been negligible.

Despite threatening skies and occasional rain, thousands waited in line for hours yesterday for the first public showing of eighteen new RCA-Victor television receivers at the Radio Corporation of America exhibition hall, 40 West Forty-ninth Street. The showing was attended by 20,000 persons.

Although the tonnage of the company's goods reached an alltime high in the fiscal year ended May 3, 1950, the dollar volume of business and net earnings of the H.J. Heinz Company declined during the period from the levels of the preceding year, H.J. Heinz 2d, president, discloses in the annual report to stockholders and employes, issued for publication today.

The Rev. Dr. Martin Niemoeller, militant Lutheran pastor who resisted the Nazis without compromise and suffered long imprisonment in concentration camps in Germany, emphasized in a sermon here yesterday morning that "faith is stronger than violence and fear" in meeting a world crisis.

Influenced by the unexpectedly low official planted acreage estimate of the crop, issued last Monday by the Department of Agriculture, buying pushed cotton prices in the domestic market sharply higher last week and into new upper levels for the season. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net gains of 158 to 304 points during the week.

BOSTON, July 16 (AP)--Walt Dropo lashed three homers for the Red Sox, boosting his season's total to twenty-two, as Boston forces split a double-header with the Indians today. The Sox won a first game slugfest, 13--10, and then bowed, 8--4, in the nightcap.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16-- Stanley Kramer's next production for United Artists, after he completes the current "Cyrano de Bergerac," will be "The Children," a photoplay which Carl Foreman is writing about "the impact of the world's insecurity on a child in Chicago."
ALBANY, July 16 (AP)--Governor Dewey, today appointed Allen S. Hubbard Jr. of Roslyn Heights, L.I., chairman of a three-member personnel relations board set up to handle grievances of state employes.
Record-breaking sales and earnings for the June quarter and the first six months of 1950 were reported yesterday for Motorola, Inc. by Paul V. Galvin, president.

CANTON, N.Y., July 16--A study of 10,000 elementary school children in New York State to find out with what accuracy those vulnerable to delinquency can be identified at an early age will be undertaken soon by the New York State Youth Commission.

Brazil is welcoming United States capital and knowledge as keys to increased mass production of essential goods, according to Mariano J.M. Ferraz, head of the Industrial Federation of the State of Sao Paulo and of "Soma," leading Brazilian railway equipment manufacturers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP)-- Home runs by George Kell and Hoot Evers, each with a man on base, featured a six-run fourth-inning rally as the Tigers gained a 7-6 second-game victory today over the Athletics. Philadelphia had put on a three-run eighth-inning uprising to annex the first game, 5--2.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 16-- Murray Vernon Jr., the new Eastern interscholastic golf champion from Hotchkiss, and his guest from Cherry Valley, Ernie Lundell, captured the title in Greenwich Country Club's eleventh annual member-guest tournament today, winning both semi-final and finalround matches by 5 and 4.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 16 (AP)-- Slamming Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., and Jim Ferrier of San Francisco, today captured the thirteenth Inverness invitational four-ball championship and pocketed the first prize of $4,000.
Times change, and whether or not we change we are confronted with a new face of things which re

WASHINGTON, July 16--William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared today that the world situation called for "all-out preparedness," and he included the mobilization of labor.

Two of the prize fish of East Coast waters are in season--salmon from Canada's Maritime Provinces and Quebec and tuna from off the shores of New Jersey, Long Island and Cape Cod. They are delicious enough to be con
The Board of Smoke Control has come up with a third set of rules and regulations to enforce smoke abatement in the city, but this time the surrounding circumstances are different.

NORFOLK, Va., July 16 (AP)-- Admiral Frank Hardeman Brumby, U.S.N., retired, one of the three four-star officers in the Navy in 1934, the time of his last promotion, died today at the Norfolk Naval Hospital at near-by Portsmouth after an illness of two weeks. His age was 75.

Twice within the last twelve hours deadly American fighter support and aggressive hard-hitting South Korean Army units have teamed up to hurl back advancing North Korean units in two of the most conclusive setbacks administered to the Reds since they crossed the Thirtyeighth Parallel.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 16 --Word has been received here from Boothbay Harbor, Me., of the death yesterday of George W. McRae of 120 Washington Street, this city, former general manager and vice president of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company. Mr. McRae, who was 65 years old, died at his summer home.
There is little basic difference between pastoral service here and in England, an Anglican clergyman has decided after a few weeks of ministering to a church here.

WASHINGTON, July 16--Misrepresentation in the sale of women's coats, suits and dresses was charged yesterday in a Federal Trade Commission complaint against Edward Goldstein Enterprises, Inc., and its subsidiary, Brentley's, Inc., both of 315 Seventh Ave., New York.

Use of newsprint last month by daily newspapers reporting to the American Newspaper Publishers Association was 7.6 per cent more than the same month of 1949 and 15.1 per cent above the 1948 month. There were four Sundays in each of the three months.

WHITE PLAINS, July 16--Carding 39, 39--78 over a selecteddrive alternate-stroke route, for the par 71 test, Herman Freydberg of the host club and Mrs. Jerome Herbert of Old Oaks won the annual Metropolis Country Club member-guest mixed two-ball tournament today.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 16 --Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., finally won the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament today for the first time after combating Arthur Larsen of San Francisco and the rain for close to four hours at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

Suggestions of any war-time scarcity or likelihood of controls in preparations by some paper mills to set up allocations were decried last week by industry executives. It is feared misinterpretation of the move will cause "war scare" speculative buying.

SAN LORENZO, Paraguay, July 16--An unfinished church in this suburb of Asuncion furnished a symbolically tranquil background for Paraguay's third one-man Presidential election in twenty-nine months here today.
Police Capt. John G. Flynn shot himself yesterday morning in his Brooklyn quarters after leaving a note declaring that his act was not connected with the gambling inquiry.

ST. LOUIS, July 17--Blasting the Cardinals twice today before a combined day-and-night crowd of 48,140 paying and saddened customers, the Dodgers suddenly found themselves only one game out of the National League lead, held by the Phils. The Brooks remained in fourth place, only half a game back of the Cards and Braves, who were tied for second.

The New York State highway system was described yesterday as at least twelve years behind requirements and a major factor in congestion. Serious results attending the inadequacy of many main arteries were emphasized in data presented by the American Road Builders Association and Automobile Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 17--President Truman will propose to meet the Korean crisis by placing the home front on a system of compulsory economic controls, limited in scope, and reinforcing the defense system by more than 200,000 additional fighting men and more than $5,000,000,000 in new funds.
UTICA, N.Y,, July 17 (AP)--Mrs. Ann Winslow Cantwell of Saranac Lake won medal honors today in the qualifying round for the New York State women's amateur golf championship.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)--A proposal by Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation and the New York State Natural Gas Corporation to develop a $37,750,000 underground gas storage project...

Retirement applications of a deputy police inspector and seventy other members of the department, including three captains, were approved yesterday by the Pension Board of the Police Department. At the same time the board, retired ten other patrolmen for physical disabilities.

TRENTON, July 17--The Vincent Astor Foundation of New York announced today through the State Institutions Department that a two-year study would be made of a new youth guidance program at the former Lindbergh estate near Hopewell.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 17 (AP)--A Pennsylvania Railroad official said today motor transportation had taken over much of the railroad's business in south Jersey.

CINCINNATI, July 17--To the accompaniment of three home runs and sundry other base hits, Jim Hearn, a refugee from the Cardinal chain gang, made his debut as a Giant pitcher tonight with highly satisfactory results.
CHICAGO, July 17--All deliveries of soybeans and lard, and July and September wheat sold at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade here today, soybeans leading the upturn, with the July...

The threat of economic controls, dictated by the international situation, dominated yesterday's stock market thinking. Last Friday's rally proved to be a short interlude as the list again headed downward. Only limited selling was necessary to depress prices from fractions to about 2 points, with the composite rate lowered 1.24 points.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)-- Following is the text of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's statement on the majority report of a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee which investigated charges of Communists in the Federal Government:

Hedley Woodhouse left them laughing as he bade local racing fans a temporary adieu yesterday. Riding in the Catskill, the feature race on the opening day's card of the meeting of the Saratoga Association at Jamaica, the able jockey from Vancouver, British Columbia, brought home the winner in Vera S. Bragg's 3-year-old gelding Monte.
WASHINGTON, July 17--Government officials felt encouraged today in their efforts to settle the hour and wage disputes affecting railroad yard service employes, trainmen and conductors.

MERIDEN, Conn., July 17--Five and a half weeks after his composing room force walked out in a contract dispute, Wayne C. Smith, publisher of two newspapers here, said today that he had completed installation of new typesetting devices, including Vari-type, and would operate an open shop henceforth.

WASHINGTON, July 17--When the President on Wednesday tells Congress and the public the added costs of his new program to meet the international situation, and what legislative and policy steps he proposes, the report will be a multi-governmental product.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)-- Michigan Consolidated Gas Company has asked the Federal Power Commission to refuse Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company permission to cancel a rate schedule covering sale of gas to Michigan on an interruptible (industrial) basis.

President Juan Jose Arevalo of Guatemala, in a statement released here yesterday, affirmed the "complete solidarity" of his country with the United States on the Korean issue and declared no political tie whatsoever existed with the Soviet Union.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 18-- Under heavy pressure of worth Korean forces, the main United States defense units at Taejon abandoned the city late last night, according to front-line dispatches reaching here this morning.
MANHASSET, L,I., July 17-- Mr. and Mrs. Russell Wilks have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marilyn Louise, to Earl E. Hoellen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Hoellen of Chicago.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 18 (UP)-- Marguerite Higgins, a correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune, has been ordered out of the Korean battle area as part of a plan to remove all American women from Korea except nurses, an Army spokesman said today.

BOISE, Idaho, July 16--Not for many years has there been such a wide divergence of opinion among Idaho political and business leaders on the outcome of a Senatorial election as there is this summer when they view the possible fate of Senator Glen H. Taylor at the Aug. 8 primary.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Allan of 1100 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Yvonne, to A. Richard Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius J. Goodman of Troy, N.Y. The wedding will take place late next month.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 17--The prevailing sentiment among United Nations delegates is strong opposition to the Soviet proposal that Communist China be admitted to the Security Council as a first step toward halting the war in Korea, and India's demarche is correspondingly regretted.

By a margin of nearly three to one, members of the city's biggest truck union voted yesterday to accept a two-year wage agreement intended to give their employers a "breather" and thus help revive trade in the Port of New York.

A corporation to raise funds toward creating a United States team in the equestrian competition at the 1952 Olympic Games and to train and maintain a pool of the nation's leading riders and horses has been formed. It's called the International Equestrian Competitions Corp., it was announced yesterday by Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman, who has become the corporation's executive vice president.

Brayton Eddy, curator of reptiles and insects for the New York Zoological Society for the last five years and one of the country's best-known entomologists, died unexpectedly yesterday of a pulmonary embolism in Fordham Hospital. He was 51 years old.

The First National Bank of Boston reported as of June 30 total deposits of $1,368,950,409 and total assets of $1,529,117,688, compared, respectively, with $1,376,694,768 and $1,527,894,718 on Dec. 31, 1949.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)--The District of Columbia Court of Appeals ruled in effect today that the Government must restore ownership of the Dollar Steamship Lines, Inc., Ltd. (Delaware), also known as the American President Lines, Ltd., to former stockholders.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)-- The Defense Department's Korean war casualty lists Nos. 25 and 26 today listed the following:

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 17-- Gen. Evangeline Cory Booth, daughter of the founder of the Salvation Army and herself a former international commander of the movement, died here at 4:05 o'clock this afternoon in her home on Washington Avenue, near Central Avenue. She was 84 years old.

If things keep on, food columnists will have no reason to write. The tin can has done much to take over the function of the home cook; home cookery, at least in Manhattan, threatens to move out of the home. Chicken-in-theBox, 309 East Seventy-fifth Street, which began with door deliveries

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 17-- The season of summer antiques shows got its start here today for Long Island vacationers with the opening of the Fifth Annual Hempstead Antiques Fair, housed as in former years in the Elks' Club at Fulton and Bennett Avenues.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 18 (UP)-- Gen. Douglas MacArthur told the press today to take upon itself the task of censoring war news and leave the Army free to fight.

NEW DELHI, India, July 17-- An Indian civil aircraft crashed in the low Himalayan foothills near Kashmir today, killing all twenty-two persons aboard, including five Americans and the Canadian chief of the United Nations military observers team in Kashmir.

WASHINGTON, July 17--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's charges of communism in the State Department were denounced today as false and "contemptible" by the three Democratic members of a Senate investigating subcommittee.

LONDON, July 17--A request from Secretary General Trygve Lie for ground troops to assist the United States in the defense of Southern Korea received the most serious consideration from the British Cabinet today, but no immediate decision was reached.

WASHINGTON, July 17--Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat of South Carolina, announced today that the Senate Banking and Currency Committee would start as investigation Thursday of price increases on foodstuffs and other commodities now sweeeping the country.
GENEVA, July 17--The British Government will support, the establishment of a vast international monetary pool to operate as an automatic guarantor of full employment in the Western world.

Buying at the China, Glass and Pottery Show in the New Yorker Hotel yesterday ranged from good to very brisk. Although it was only the second day of the show, which opened on Sunday, little "shopping around" was done, and some heavy orders were placed immediately by large buying groups.

The second price advance on spring worsteds was announced yesterday by American Woolen Company. Worsteds for both the men's and women's trade were raised 12 to 17 cents a yard, bringing prices 25 cents to 30 cents over the opening fall prices. The new price schedules will hold for November delivery and later.
Rumblings of discontent over the city's low census total have sent a few statisticians back to some yellowing old records. And they, have made a discovery.

WASHINGTON, July 17--The United States Court of Appeals today directed John J. Lewis and the United Mine Workers, of which he is president, to abandon the union shop agreement affecting the "captive" soft coal mines.

The following dispatch was written by Tom Lambert, Associated Press correspondent whom the Army barred from Korea on the ground that his dispatches gave "aid and comfort to the enemy." The ban was later lifted.

Members of mechanical unions refused again yesterday to cross picket lines established by the New York Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., outside the plant of The New York World-Telegram and Sun at 125 Barclay Street.

PARIS, July 17--The findings of an international panel of experts on race problems under the auspices of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization have provided evidence that there was no scientific justification for race discrimination.

The Board of Estimate authorized Corporation Counsel John P. McGrath yesterday to acquire Sydenham Hospital by condemnation. The action was taken to prevent the Harlem Savings Bank from foreclosing a $600,000 mortgage on the property, which is at Manhattan Avenue and 123rd Street.
Representatives of advertisers and major radio networks will meet on July 26 to consider problems arising from effects of television in reducing radio time values.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)-- Following are textual excerpts from, the findings and recommendations of the Democratic majority of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee set up to investigate charges by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, that Communists have infiltrated the State Department:

ITHACA, N.Y., July 17--Improved methods whereby families may plan for better home life were considered by thirty specialists from all parts of the country at a three-day conference that closed today at the College of Home Economics, Cornell University.
A strike of 2,600 steamfitters delayed progress yesterday on hundreds of major construction jobs in this city and on Long Island.
A Brooklyn attorney appeared yesterday as a witness before the special grand jury investigating organized gambling in the borough.
The will of Dr. Albert A. Berg, noted surgeon who died in Mount Sinai Hospital on July 1, has given his $4,000,000 estate to charitable, educational and religious institutions.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)-- Stirred by reports of a shortage of war-needed copper, the House voted overwhelmingly today to suspend for another year the two cents a pound import tax on the metal.
The repaving of Times Square, where 60,000 vehicles and hundreds of thousands of pedestrians become involved each day in one of the world's most famous traffic congestions, began yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 17--The House Rules Committee voted unanimously today to give prompt floor right of way to the bill providing $1,222,500,000 in arms for countries resisting communism, Leaders at once scheduled a start of debate tomorrow. The measure is expected to pass by Thursday, perhaps Wednesday. The Senate has approved it unanimously.

OTTAWA, July 17--Moscow-led teacher organizations are making a desperate attempt to block international unity among teachers in the non-Communist world, key educators warned here today. In some instances officials behind the Iron Curtain are fomenting unrest among democratic teacher groups and spreading "brazen lies" about them.

LYNBROOK, L.I., July 17-- Miss Jacqueline Christie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Christie, will be married to Edmund Paul Hennelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Hennelly of Fresh Meadows, Queens, on Aug. 19, in St. Raymond's Roman Catholic Church, East Rockaway. A reception will be given in the Garden City Hotel.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 17 (AP)--Wendell W. Anderson's seventy-two-foot yawl Escapade, a scratch boat, withstood the challenge of all handicaps today to take down the two main prizes in the 235-mile Port Huron-to-Mackinac--ailing race.

ALBANY, July 17 (AP)--State Controller Frank C. Moore was appointed by Governor Dewey today as chairman of the Temporary Commission on School Construction. Also named by the Chief Executive were fourteen members of the commission.
The Shell Oil Company yesterday began operating from here four new pumping stations on its oil product pipeline running from Wood River, Ill., to Columbus, Ohio. By using an ordinary tele-...

The nation's larger banks will be required to pay out $112,654,000 under the terms of a call issued yesterday by the United States Treasury. The call on the Treasury's tax and loan accounts, as of July 15, demands payment of 4 per cent of such balances on July 24. Banks in this district will provide $30,447,000 of the national total.

ASTRETCH ON THE RIVER,"* by Richard Bissell, is a fine barber-shop ballad of towboat life on the Upper Mississippi. It is in the great tradition of the American river yarn. It walks with a rather carefully planned swagger and it talks out of the corner of its mouth, but, like the hero of it, Bill Joyce, you can see that the point of view has filtered through...
A World War II mobilization index of the city's industrial plant capacity available for immediate production of materiel and munitions is being brought up to date.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)-- Third Baseman Eddie Yost of the Senators made a game-ending diving lunge over a rolled tarpaulin to snare pinch-hitter Jim Delsing's foul with the bases loaded tonight and give Washington a 3-1 victory over the Browns.

WASHINGTON, July 17--The United States drafted a note to Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, today assuring him that it wanted peace in Korea, but adding that it was not prepared to bring Communist China into the United Nations to discuss the question at Lake Success.

PARIS, July 17--If a man has been smoking cigarettes for twenty years it makes little difference if he stops as far as his developing lung cancer is concerned, accoriding to Dr. Alton Ochsner of New Orleans, La.

T. Edward Murtaugh, retired publicity man and a former manufacturer of elevators and dumbwaiters, died in Bellevue Hospital on Friday after a three-week illness. His age was 73. He lived at 205 East Forty-fourth Street.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed strong 119 to 195 points net higher yesterday.

CANTON, N.Y., July 17--The cities of the nation, where the greatest amount of delinquency and crime occurs, are not fitted to help young people mature, Dr. Ralph Spence, a leading authority in the fields of education and delinquency, charged toay.
BOSTON, July 17 (AP)--The Red Sox overcame a seventh-inning tie for a 7-5 victory under lights after being outslugged, 11-6, by the Indians in a day-night double-header today.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)-- Justice Harold H. Burton of the Supreme Court refused today to stay the civil contempt conviction of Bank of America and Transamerica, Inc., and their presidents.

HOBOKEN, N.J., July 17--The week-old work stoppage among Hoboken longshoremen was halted temporarily this morning but broke out anew in the afternoon amid disputes over the use of public address systems.

Nearly 300 years ago Daniel Denton, a settler here, wrote the city's first guide book. Charmed by his new surroundings, he wanted to help others who might be considering a trip to this town. A copy of his book is one of the items that go on display today, to remain until Sept. 30, at the New York Publiu Library, Fifth Avenue at Forty--first Street.

Atomic energy aspects of the city's civilian defense program were discussed yesterday at a City Hall conference attended by Mayor O'Dwyer, Arthur W. Wallander, Director of Civilian Defense, and Atomic Energy Commission officials.

WHITBY, Ont., July 17--A "roving ambassador" whose full-time assignment will be to strengthen Protestantism in "critical" areas of East Asia was named here today at a joint meeting of thirty topranking churchmen representing both the World Council of Churches and the International Missionary Council.

WASHINGTON, July 17--Seeking to override a situation in which more than 3,000 criminal and subversive aliens could not be deported under existing law, the House of Representatives voted 326 to 15 today to enable the Attorney General of the United States, at his discretion, to lock them in jail.
WASHINGTON, July 17--The Senate Appropriations Committee today voted, 13 to 3, to restore the $16,500,000 cut it made two weeks ago in President Truman's Point Four program.

Yogi Berra, Hank Bauer and Tommy Henrich deserted Joe Di Maggio last night, leaving the Clipper alone on the ailing list of the Yankees. Not that the Yankees could not have made use of Joltin' Joe--even a sub-par Di Maggio is ever a threat--but the returning trio collaborated most handsomely as the home side fashioned a 4-3 victory over the White Sox before 24.218 at the Stadium.
PITTSBURGH, July 17 (AP)--The Boston Braves exploded five runs in the ninth inning to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8--6, tonight before a crowd of 21,450.

Knitted gloves from Japan have begun to arrive and all indications point to normal shipments despite the Korean war, according to New York importers. A total of about 400,000 dozen wool knits are expected for the fall and winter season, they said, with the bulk of shipments due to arrive before the end of August.

Leaving no doubt that Italy proved a fertile source of inspiration, Chanda's fall millinery collection fairly glowed with the influences of his recent trip to that country. Viewed last night at 55 East Eighty-sixth Street, the presentation mirrored with rich imagination scores of themes from both past and present.

The Democratic majority of the subcommittee that has been investigating Senator McCarthy's charges against the State Department filed its report last evening. At the same time Senator Lodge of Massachusetts filed a separate minority report. Thus the long and at times tempestuous inquiry ends in, as it so often followed, a division along party lines.

Mr. and Mrs. Everett Horgan of 149 East Seventy-third Street have announced the marriage of their daughter, Mrs. Elizabeth Horgan Phipps, to Richard Wallace Murrie of New York and Hershey, Pa., which took place on Saturday in Arlington. Va.

Pinto, who was selected last week by the executive committee of the Kings County Republican Committee as the party's choice for Surrogate, announced last night that he would decline the nomination because of the pressure of his duties as a member of the State Commission Against Discrimination.

WASHINGTON, July 17--The Federal Bureau of Investigation today arrested Julius Rosenberg, 32 years old, a New Yorker, on charges of spying for Russia. He was the fourth American held within the past few months in connection with the passing of United States atomic secrets to the Soviet Union.

Those of us who do not care to go over Niagara Falls in a barrel or any other sort of container must always be puzzled by those who do. The experiment might have a gruesome charm if it had never been attempted before, but this is not the case.

Jean Berthoin of Paris. The wedding will take place the latter part of next month at Guran, Haute Garonne, France, in the summer home of the prospective bridegroom's parents.

Housewives in many parts of the metropolitan area were found yesterday to be hoarding sugar, coffee, canned meats, nylons and some other "scare" items, despite trade assurances of ample supplies of most commodities.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP)-- The Detroit Tigers picked up ground in the American League pennant race by taking both ends of a twi-night bill from the Athletics tonight. FRANKFORT, Germany, July 17 --Hundreds of thousands of German refugees and persons expelled tom Eastern Europe held meetings throughout West Germany over the last week-end, taking oaths of unity and pledging militant activity for their return to their former homelands.

WASHINGTON, July 17--President Truman's approval of the sale of American Overseas Airlines to Pan American World Airways for $17,450,000 will be challenged in the Federal courts, opponents of the merger said today.

Hide futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday continued their rise establishing new highs for the life of all active contracts. At the close all positions had advanced the day's permissible limit of 200 points.

The best recovery since the collapse of prices induced by the United States entrance into the Korean fighting was scored yesterday by the stock market.
Shipping through the Port of New York during June increased 881,576 tons over a year ago, with a consequent $4,500,000 rise in customs collections.
WASHINGTON, July 18--The designation of Castle Clinton, in Battery Park, New York, as a national monument was announced today by Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior.

"711 Ocean Drive," a melodrama presented by Columbia with Edmond O'Brien and Joanne Dru heading the cast, will have its local premiere today at the Paramount. Joseph H. Newman di

As the Government was tightening its case against Julius Rosenberg, the 32-year-old former Army electrical engineer accused of espionage and membership in the ring that gave atomic information to Russia, his lawyer said yesterday he was considering applications for lower bail, a prompt hearing and an early trial.
Sentences aggregating eighty years in prison were imposed by Federal Judge T. Whitfield Davidson yesterday on four men convicted of conspiracy, possession and sale of $50,000 in counterfeit money.
FRANKFORT, Germany, July 18 --High Commissioner John J. McCloy told West German youth representatives today that he was prepared to augment aid to youth organizations.

Brookmeade Stable's 4-year-old Blue Hills, making his second start of the season, romped to a sevenlength decision as the 4to-5 favorite in the $5,000 added handicap that headed the Jamaica racing program yesterday. A crowd of 15,483 checked in for the second session of the Saratoga-on-theL.I.R.R. proceedings.

ST. LOUIS, July 18--The Senate Crime Investigating Committee learned today that river crossings by enemies of law and order are not confined to Korea. In local battles by law enforcement officials, they were told the Mississippi plays the role of the Kum River, with the police officials on either side often fighting rearguard actions until reinforcements can arrive.
PARIS, July 18 (AP)--Five French mountain climbers have returned from the Himalayas with claims to a record in mastering the Anapurna Peak, 26,496 feet high. But the glacial cold almost got them.
The city of Minneapolis, Minn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Aug. 10 on issues of bonds amounting to $2,575,000.

Faced with a chronic shortage of trained nurses, hospital administrators and heads of nursing schools here are striving to attract more young women to the profession by removing the more onerous features of the training period.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., July 19--Miss Mignon Talbot, Professor Emeritus of Geology and Geography at Mount Holyoke College, died last evening in the Holyoke Hospital at the age of 80 after a lone illness.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19-- Testimony opposing applications of the Pacific Far East Line and the Pacific Transport Lines for Government aid in the operation of their trans-Pacific trade routes to Japan, China and the Philippines was offered today by the American President Lines, which is subsidized in the Pacific business.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 19-- The reversal of the tennis season in the East came today on the turf of the Merion Cricket Club as Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., was beaten by Tony Vincent of Elmhurst, L.I., in the Pennsylvania state championship, 4--6, 6--4, 6--4.

DETROIT, July 19--With twothirds of the United States open championship completed, there was a quadruple tie for first place following play in the eighth round today at the Detroit Edison Company's administration building.

A felonious assault charge against Martin Conway, 39 years old, of 48 West Seventy-third Street, was dismissed yesterday when his son, Donald, 8, denied in Felony Court that his father had thrown him out of a window of their room.

Hard-hitting carriers of the United States Seventh Fleet conducted heavy strikes on North Korean lines of communication and supply during the last fortyeight hours, it was announced today by Vice Admiral Charles T. Joy, commander of naval forces in the Far East.

ST. LOUIS, July 19--Under a veritable landslide of 28 runs, the Cardinals swamped the Giants in one of those day-night double features at Sportsmans Park today, and took undisputed possession of first place.

A hint of possible rises in housing costs was given by the Veterans Administration yesterday in an announcement of moves to comply with a request from President Truman. Beginning at once, the agency said, it will guarantee home loans to veterans only when the veterans make down payments of 5 per cent or more. They also must pay in cash any fees for closing title.
Gracious living is the theme of three model rooms opened yesterday at the summer furniture show at A. Bamberger's in Newark. Victorian, Empire and eighteenth century ...
There are two ways of looking at the moles which creep along under the grass, raising meandering bumps in the sod.
Under the present limited emergency, there is little likelihood of any serious reduction in the volume of advertising, ad sources said yesterday.

Emphasis on the jacket of thirty-four to thirty-six inches in length, contrast trim and a midnight blue shade in Persian lamb provided highlights in the Arnold Constable showing of fall furs yesterday.

LONDON, July 19-- "Mister Roberts" made its London debut tonight on a stage that was nearly as big as a ship's deck and really looked like one. It was an instantaneous success.

In the face of a storm of civic opposition and unfavorable reports by city officials, the Clearview Housing Company, Inc., yesterday withdrew its application to the Board of Estimate for tax exemption for its proposed $18,568,000 housing project south of Whitestone, Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 19--President Truman declared today that the free world was determined to fight against armed aggression anywhere, and he called on Congress to enact promptly a $10,000,000,000 rearmament program, discard the limits on miitary manpower, and impose extensive controls on the economy.
Efforts to effect a settlement of the Jersey dock tie-up failed again yesterday and a meeting of the principals involved ended with Jersey City authorities threatening to seek a court injunction.

Large tuna have made their appearance at the Mud Hole off the New Jersey coast. At least they were there Tuesday. One that weighed 558 pounds was boated. A few others, exact number not definitely established but reported from three to five, were hooked and lost.
Following is the text of President Truman's radio report to the nation last night on Korea, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Ben Grauer, the radio and television commentator, has joined Norman Rose, formerly a managing director of New Stages, to form a professional theatre group that will offer plays, beginning this fall at the Bleecker Street Theatre, 151 Bleecker Street.

An artist of the loom, John Walther has made fall tweeds and worsteds with the splendor of tapestry. This was evident in a handsome show of designer coats and suits presented yesterday at a luncheon in the Cottage Room of Hampshire House.

Alfred Dunhill of London, Inc., which occupies two floors in 11-13 East Twenty-sixth Street for warehouse and shipping purposes, has leased the store and basement in the same building. The lease, negotiated by Adams Co., brokers, covers 22,000 square feet of space.

WHITBY, Ont., July 19--A comprehensive, ten-month study of the effectiveness of American Protestantism in a modern industrial society will be conducted in three representative cities beginning next September.
The Fruit Growers Express Company, owned by railroads operating in the South and East, is scheduled to receive on Aug. 1,
PITTSBURGH, July 19 (AP)-- Frank E. McKinney, Indianapolis banker turned diamond magnate, sold his share of one of baseball's richest gold mines today to two partners.
UTICA, N.Y., July 19 (AP)--Favorites continued to dominate the play today in second-round matches of the state women's amateur golf tournament.
BOSTON, July 19 (AP)--The topplace Tigers nipped two rallies in the bud today while pulling out a 9-5 victory over the Red Sox for right-hander Dizzy Trout.

Underwriter's headed by White, Weld Co., and Glore, Forgan Co., will place on the market today an issue of $6,000,000 of two-year 5 per cent interim notes of the Texas Illinois Natural Gas Pipeline Company at par.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 19 --The fighting in Korea was giving impetus today to the development here of an air raid filter center that is to serve the five counties of New York City and seventeen other counties of this ...

WASHINGTON; July 19--Naval carrier planes, released from "cover duty" during the Korean east coast amphibious landing yesterday, made several strikes yesterday and today against Korean objectives and accounted for fortytwo enemy planes damaged or destroyed on the ground and direct hits on Korea's largest oil refinery.

LEBANON, July 19--The United States and the West are rapidly losing prestige in the Arab East as a result of the news from Korea. The strong attachment of public opinion to neutrality, which was evident before the Korean war broke out, is turning into passionate isolationism.

Suez Canal transit dues, which at present are thirty-nine Egyptian piastres a ton, have remained unchanged since Jan. 1, 1941, when they were increased 40 per cent over their pre-war level, the Compagnie Universelle du Canal Maritime de Suez said yesterday in a defense of its rate system.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 19-- Five builders today submitted bids for building homes under this city's plan to provide low-cost housing and slum clearance through private enterprise. The bids indicate that houses of at least four rooms can be built under city specifications to sell for less than $9,000 and with carrying charges of less than $59 a month.
Television output has increased "even faster than indicated or expected six months ago," according to an analysis issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, July 19--The Presi-- dent's message to Congress and his radio address to the international community were grim confirmations that the Communist attack on the Republic of Korea ended the "cold war" and that the free nations must at once complete the work of those in the Soviet orbit by turning the rest of the world into an armed camp.
A "flag" resulting from the enthusiastic cooperation of Sea Scouts and Boy Scouts here and in many other countries was dedicated last night.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Summarizing on the radio and television tonight his global defense program against Communist aggression, President Truman read a message from Gen. Douglas MacArthur giving the most optimistic report that has yet been made on the Korean conflict.

GENEVA, July 19--It would have cost the United States a little more than $20,000,000,000 over a ten-year period to have stabilized the world economy during the thirties, the United Nations Economic and Social Council was told today.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., July 19-- Protesting against recent endorsements of a proposed regional shopping center on a seventy-five-acre tract north of the traffic circle here on the Taconic and Saw Mill River Parkways, objectors called the project today an "atom bomb" attack on merchants and taxpayers of established communities.
LONDON, Thursday. July 20 (AP) --The Soviet Union insisted again today that the place to settle the Korean war was in the United Nations Security Council with Communist China as a member.
Patch, a gray colt by Dogpatch, took first money of $9,025 in the Albany Handicap for 2-year-olds at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday. He was the $11.80-for $2 third choice in a nine-horse line-up.

Except for the $10,000,000,000 figure that President Truman mentioned for the expansion of national defense, banking spokesmen said yesterday that his proposals to Congress were approximately what was expected. Most bankers said that they had anticipated a request for a defense appropriation of not more than $5,000,000,000.

A water tour around Manhattan, one of several trips scheduled this year to observe park conditions in the city's boroughs, was made yesterday by 100 members of the Park Association of New York City and their guests.
WASHINGTON, July 19--Rear Admiral Olton R. Bennehoff, retired, died Monday of a heart ailment at the home of Maj. Eric Bark, United States Army, at nearby Arundel-on-the-Bay, Md. He was 54 years old.

Inflationary and war-like psychology dominated in the stock market yesterday as prices continued to recover. Immediate response to President Trumans message was given in a lifting of prices which ranged to 3 points in the aircrafts--a typical war-boom section--while the composite rate rose 2.03 points.

MEXICO CITY, July 19--With Edward G. Miller, Assistant Secretary of State for Latin-American Affairs, still here, while negotiations for a Washington loan to develop Mexico's nationalized oil industry may be reopened momentarily,...

As American as the great Middle West from which he sprang Carl Van Doren held a notable place in the field of contemporary letters. Teacher, critic, editor, biographer, historian, his name had been familiar to the literate public for a generation; and his death takes from the scene a writer and scholar of great authority and broad influence.

Boys' wear retailers are well prepared for the late summer and back-to-school season, according to William R. Matthews, president of the Boys' Apparel Buyers Association. There is no prospect for depreciation in values, he said yesterday, nor is it likely that prices will show any drastic increases in the near future.

WASHINGTON, July 19--The Department of Agriculture announced today the annual grain export figures, showing a drop of two-fifths in wheat and flour exports in the crop year which ended on June 30, 1950.
Wide swings in cotton futures prices were experienced on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final quotations were 37 to 100 points net higher.

WASHINGTON, July 19-- Labor's League for Political Education, the political branch of the American Federation of Labor, planned today for all-out mobilization to raise funds for the primaries and November elections.
MUNICH. Between 8,000,000 and 10,000,000, refugees in Central Europe are facing a new period of uncertainty as to their fate.

Fresh oranges and grapefruit, favorite and rich sources of Vitamin C (ascorbic acid), are now in seasonal short supply and relatively expensive. But housewives seeking nutritive substitutes will find an appetizing variety of fruits and vegetables that cheaply fill the requirement for this essential to dental and general health. For an adult, the Vitamin C need is set by the National Research Council at 75 milligrams a day.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended Tuesday totaled 2,006, compared with 1,997 last week and 1,892 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 918 arrivals on Tuesday against 1,222 on the same day last week.

Since June 14 eight Belgian trade union leaders have been absorbing American industrial lore and observing the lot of the American worker. Yesterday they were willing to let him keep the higher standard of living, the television sets and the general din. They wanted a good home-cooked Belgian dinner.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 19--The United States was asked today by the American Association for the United Nations to take the initiative toward the creation of an international army.
The temporary flashboards rushed into place late Tuesday to hold back the water of Croton Lake were erected just in time to prevent the lake, largest of the Croton system, from spilling over.
The Arena, which up to now has concerned itself with the legitimate theatre, last night turned its attention to music, with a performance of Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Telephone" and "The Medium."
More than sixty air transport planes used on scheduled and nonscheduled airlines are now in service with the United States Air Force on the airlift to Korea, a check made yesterday revealed.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 19-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has called off its plans to make two more pictures with Betty Hutton, following the recent "Annie Get Your Gun," the studio disclosed today.
The arrest records of the six police divisions in Brooklyn have been subpoenaed by District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County in his investigation into organized gambling.
MONTREAL, July 19 (AP)--Laurent Dauthuille, 158 , France, knocked out Tuzo Portuguez, 162 , Costa Rica, in the third round of their scheduled ten-round middleweight fight tonight.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York announced yesterday that it had passed the $30,000,000 mark in the campaign for funds that began last February.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 19 (AP) --Bento Dias Pereira, president of the Rio de Janeiro coffee exchange, said today the price of green coffee is going up because coffee is in short supply.

BERLIN, July 19--The Soviet sponsored press of East Germany today hailed a Communist propagandist invasion of West Berlin yesterday--in which 1,56 Easterners were arrested by the police of the United States. British and French sector's--as a tremendous triumph for "the forces of peace."
Special restrictions to prevent parked vehicles from hampering street cleaning will be tested on the lower East Side for an indefinite period starting Aug. 1.
Gnats and not so much the Browns harassed the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium, where Casey Stengel's men took two, 16--1 and 4--3.

The purpose behind President Truman's message to Congress yesterday was to present his recommendations for adapting the national defense and the national economy to the new de-- mands, actual and potential, placed upon it by the armed attack in Korea.

One major domestic producer of aluminum yesterday wised prices 1 cent to 2 cents a pound on key products, and another large company reinstituted an allocations system on pig and ingot aluminum to assure equitable distribution of tight supplies.

A strike of 1,100 truck drivers hauling sand, gravel and other building materials threatened last night to force a full shutdown of construction activity in the metropolitan area. Construction officials predicted that the tie-up would make 50,000 workers in other crafts idle by next week.
Mrs. Elizabeth C. Taylor of New York and Florence, Italy, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Clare Elizabeth, to John Harmon Noble Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Noble of Pelham Manor, N.Y.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 19--Dr. Evla A. Wright, nationaly known for her efforts against tuberculosis, died here last night at the age of 83. Death came to the founder and longtime president of the Houston Anti--Tuberculosis League after she returned home from a league meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Two hours after Congress received President Truman's preparedness message, the House of Representatives today approved by a vote of 361 to 1 the authorization of $1,222,500,000 of new appropriations for a second year of military ...

LONDON, July 19--A growing divergence in the legal systems of the United States and Britain, despite their common basis, was cited here today by a United States judge. He was Judge Louis Goldstein or Kings County Court, who was addressing the International Bar Association.

The Magnet Realty Corporation, of which Jacob Glass is president, has purchased the sixteen-story and penthouse building containing eighty-one apartments at 785 West End Avenue from the 785 West End Avenue Corporation. The property occupies' a plot 91 by 80 feet at the northwest corner of Ninetyeighth Street. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The Government is preparing additional information before submitting to a Federal grand jury the case of Julius Rosenberg, 32year-old former Army engineer who is the fourth American charged with conspiracy to transmit atomic secrets to Russia.
HAMILTON, N.Y., July 19 (AP) --The chairman of a "super sales force" seeking to save the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railroad today announced appointment of three more county chairmen.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP)--The election of five directors of the Carr Consolidated Biscuit Company May 12 was challenged in two suits on file in Cook County Superior Court today.
