The decision of the British Government to cut off shipments of oil to China is welcome. It had previously been argued, in explanation and defense of such shipments, that they included no aviation gasoline and were limited strictly to oil for domestic Chinese consumption.
With Tuesday as the most successful day yet in Army and Air Force recruiting, the pace kept up at about the same rate for volunteers yesterday.

LONDON, July 19--A unified air defense organization covering northwest Europe has been built up, Defense Minister Emanuel Shinwell told the House of Commons today. It consists of fighter forces and a control and reporting system of the Royal Air Force, plus French, Belgian and Netherland air forces, all equipped with British-type jet aircraft and radar equipment.

Business and industry here moved quickly yesterday to support the program announced by President Truman in his message to Congress. Revival of credit controls was strongly endorsed but difficulties were seen in allocations of metals, according to comments by business executives.
In interviews which your Ambassador has had with officials of the Ministry of External Affairs we have explained India's position in the Korean dispute.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP)-- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan and Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing were called by the House lobby investigating committee today to tell how they promote legislative proposals.

M.E. Fields has been appointed director of personnel and public relations of the Cadillac Motor Car division of General Motors Corporation. He succeeds J.M. Roche, who recently was appointed Cadillac general sales manager.

Americans have reached "a grim day" and "must finally face the fact that we have failed to gain the promised peace purchased half a decade ago by the heroic sacrifices of America's youth," Cardinal Spellman declared yesterday at the opening celebration of the 100th anniversary of the establishment of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.
The touring horse-drawn Wagon Theatre of Sarah Lawrence College will stage its production of "The Emperor's New Clothes" at 4 P.M. today in Law Memorial Park, Briarcliff.

The first new settlement offer since the strike on The New York World-Telegram ad Sun began June 13 was made by the newspaper management yesterday, but the New York Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., said the offer represented "very little or no advance" toward ending the strike.

A move that makes way for potential volume increase through retail grocery channels of about $45,000,000 was disclosed yesterday by officials of General Foods Corporation. After Sept. 1 all of its dog foods will be sold in grocery stores.

Pricewise, the market for Government securities showed little reaction yesterday to President Truman's message calling for adjustments in the national economy to fit war stand-by needs. Only in the partially tax-exempt part of the list of Treasury obligations, Check Activity

PARIS, July 19--President Truman's message to Congress today was regarded here as placing the United States to some extent on a war footing and as compelling Western Europe to follow more or less rapidly.
Preliminary reports from a special Department of Markets survey show there are "ample supplies" of sugar on hand in most retail stores, Markets Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 19--Republicans today considered asking the Senate to repudiate the findings of a Democratic-controlled subcommittee that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's charges of communism in the State Department were "a fraud."

KANSAS CITY, July 19--The Senate Crime Investigating Committee heard today some details of the murder here last spring of Charles Binaggio and Charles Gargotta, active in local Democratic politics and associated with the underworld.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 19-- Allen B. Kline, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, said today that if Western Europe could shift its economic emphasis from production to trade it would "stand on the threshold of a great fifty years of progress."

WASHINGTON, July 19--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve System announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended on July 12:...

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)-- Rear Admiral Edward C. Ewen has assumed command of Carrier Division 1 in the Pacific Fleet, the Navy announced today. He has been serving as commander of naval forces in the Marianas and of the Fleet Air Station at Guam.

A committee representing various segments of the garment industry was designated at a City Hall meeting yesterday to make another attempt to solve the problem of traffic congestion in the garment district.

The amphibious landing in Korea was launched and carried through with speed and dash. This is in our tradition, the tradition of Washington, of Sherman, of Patton. Mobility, ingenuity, surprise and daring, the effort to fight an open battle, to strike hard and to keep on the offensive--these are the tactics that we like, and if we feel proud today it is partly because this action has touched deep chords.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture estimates the peach crop this year will be 55,512,000 bushels, 26 per cent less than last year's crop. It also would be 21 per cent below average.

WASHINGTON, July 19--A Women's Bureau analysis of 730 women in top-level Federal jobs, those who receive more than $3,000 a year, showed that more than half were 45 years of age or older when they reached their highest reported salary. One fourth had served the Government more than twenty years.

A survey to determine how much aid can be given increased war preparedness by plants of the nearly $800,000,000 toiletries manufacturing industry was started yesterday by the Toilet Goods Association. The information, to be gathered with questionnaires going to 1,800 concerns, relates the activities during World War II and will serve as a guide for fullest cooperation of the industry.

Adolphe Kramer has sold the one-story taxpayer containing six stores at 1431-1441 Queen Anna Road in Teaneck, N.J., to Robert Ulshofer. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $41,362. Reuben R. Rulbinstein was attorney for the seller and D. James Orlando acted for the buyer.

Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing visited the old folks in the Home for Dependents on Welfare Island yesterday afternoon to gather at first hand material for his forthcoming national conference on problems of the aged.

Queen Mary's famous needlepoint carpet, wrapped in fine linen and encased in a metal cylinder, was flown yesterday from this city to Toronto, in charge of the Imperial Order of the Daughters of the Empire, which had paid $100,000 for the fabric.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19-- More than 500 teen age sailors manning 171 racing craft were out on Long Island Sound today in the annual regatta for them during race week at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

OTTAWA, July 19--Unless financial assistance is increased immediately, the school crisis in the United States, as well as in the rest of the world, will worsen during the next ten years, teachers from twenty-six countries were told here today. Because of an increased school population, the demands placed on schools every where have become greater than ever before.

PARIS, July 19--Over and over again during the fifth International Cancer Congress the familiar question has been asked, What is the cause of cancer? Today it was answered by Dr. F. Duran-Raynals of Yale University's bacteriological laboratories in reasoning that plausibly accounted for the appearance of cancer in chickens.

NEW DELHI, India, July 19-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's, reaction to the State Department's rejection of his proposals on the Korean crisis was described by his associates today as one of "keen disappointment."

ALBANY, July 19--The State Tax Commission reported that cigarette tax receipts have increased more than $1,000,000 since the first of the year, indicating greater compliance and the stifling of mail-order tax evasion.

LONDON, July 19--British official circles promptly and warmly welcomed President Truman's rearmament message to Congress today, but this country was not ready to follow the United States example--at least, not to go so far and so fast in reactivating its war machine.

Corn comes to town from New Jersey, and in another week or two, when the season there is over, Long Island and the Hudson Valley will start shipments. Excellent supplies of this vegetable, as much a part of the American summer as ice cubes and sunning, are assured for weeks to come, not only here but generally throughout the country.

American Airlines, Inc., and its consolidated subsidiary increased operating revenues by $2,013,000 and earnings before taxes by $980,635 in the first six months of this year. As a result of substantially larger tax charges in the 1950 period, however, the net profit was $1,109,365 below the net for the 1949 half-year.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 19 --Flying Republic F-84 Thunderjets, Air Force pilots have just completed the most rapid accelerated test program on record for any aircraft, it was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, July 19--Industry considered itself headed for a full wartime footing today following President Truman's message to Congress.

Before a crowd of 15,000 yelling fans, a team of young veterans, each of whom had lost a leg or an arm in World War II, demonstrated last night in the Polo Grounds that they could move with agility by winning a baseball game.

A sharp rise in pleas against hoarding was evident yesterday. There is no need for hoarding because ample supplies are available for a considerable time to come in such fields as television, soap and detergents, hosiery and coffee, it was emphasized.

The Civil Rights Congress will participate in a motorcade next week to Jackson, Miss., which has been arranged in an effort to bring about a stay of the execution of Willie McGee, a Negro, who has been convicted on a charge of raping a white woman in 1945.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 20-- Gen. Douglas MacArthur, in a ringing communique at noon today, declared the Communist invaders of the South Korean Republic had lost their chance for victory and that United States forces had established a secure grasp on the remaining territories of South Korea.
WASHINGTON, July 19--The Army, Navy and Air Force will begin immediate recall of some of their Reserve personnel to active duty, the Defense Department announced today.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP)--Two tornadoes struck in western Ohio today, injuring at least twenty persons in the city of Lima, and causing untold property damage.
The appointment of Lawrence Wilkinson, veteran Army staff organizer and expert on European economies, as civil defense director of New York State was announced yesterday.
Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, yesterday urged a change in zoning regulations to encourage the construction of "well designed, landscaped, light industrial plants" within the city.

ON THE TAEJON FRONT in South Korea, July 19--In preparation for a new battle for Taejon, North Koreans threw light air, ground and artillery attacks today against the units of the United States Twenty-fourth Infantry division that are holding the western anchor of the United Nations defense line.

ONE of the things that has mystified this observer no end has been why baseball's two major leagues, operating jointly a vast gold mine extending from the Atlantic seaboard to the Mississippi, should reveal such a reluctance toward adopting a bright idea simply because the other fellow happened to think of it first.

Sharply higher margin requirements for all major commodities traded on the Commodity Exchange were posted late yesterday following a special meeting of the exchange's board of governors.

The Reynolds Metals Company and its wholly-owned subsidiaries had a consolidated net profit in the quarter ended on June 30 of $2,453,840, equal to $1.92 a share. This contrasted with only $14,749 earned in the second quarter a year ago. Sales for these periods were $37,800,000 and $27,800,000, respectively.

Sec. 101 (a) authorizes the President to require that tracts which he deems necessary or appropriate to promote the national defense shall be accepted and performed by any person found to be capable of performance and be given preference over all other contracts.
ALBANY, July 19 (AP)--Governor Dewey today appointed seven members to a temporary state commission to study the city of Buffalo's harbor, airport and parking facilities.
LONG-RANGE PROVING GROUND, COCOA, Fla., July 19-- The Army's first attempt to launch a guided missile from this new proving ground and range to seaward fizzled completely late this afternoon.

ARCOLA, N.J., July 19--A golfing team that proved superior in both foursome and singles play recaptured the Stoddard Trophy for New Jersey today in the annual triangular matches against Westchester and Long Island representatives at the Arcola Country Club course.
WASHINGTON, July 19--Willful violators of the draft law will be prosecuted, Attorney General J. Howard McGrath warned today.
WASHINGTON, July 19--Organized labor today favored the special appropriation sought by President Truman today to rearm the nation.

WASHINGTON, July 20--All organized Marine Reserve ground forces have been called to active duty, with ten days to report to one of four Marine camps. The order, issued late today, followed notification last night to the reserves to be alerted for such a call.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 20 --A severe food shortage in Budapest and other Hungarian cities was reported today by reliable diplomatic observers from the Hungarian capital.
WASHINGTON, July 20--President Truman warned again today that there may be new aggressions outside Korea, and at the same time began putting into effect his program against aggression everywhere.

Pvt. Arthur I. Levine of Brooklyn got back into the Army yesterday with quite a bang.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., July 20-- Miss Letitia Ann Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Robinson, has chosen Aug. 5 for her marriage to Robert D. Failor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Newton C. Failor of Upper Montclair.

TAEJON, South Korea, July 20--The battle for this western anchor of the United States defense line in Korea opened early today with the entry into the city of an estimated twenty North ... Korean tanks. By noon parts of the city were aflame and its defenders partly isolated.

Manufacturers using nylon yarn; either for hosiery or fabric, should preserve their allotted supply for their own requirements, according to Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 20 --Parliament authorized King Leopold III to return to his throne today but only after the Socialist, Communist and Liberal members of both houses had walked out of a joint session.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 20-- Echoes of the stolen ballots of 1947 and of the murder of Charles Binaggio, last April 5 were heard at the Senate crime investigating committee's hearing today.

Polio is showing its customary early summer increase here but the incidence rate of the disease is "markedly below" that of the 1949 epidemic.

WASHINGTON, July 20--The Pittsburgh Railways Company has $17,000,000 "and no more" to distribute to public security holders under its plan of reorganization, the Securities and Exchange Commission was told at a hearing today.

The music of thirteen leading European orchestras, each of a different Marshall Plan country, has been assembled in the form of thirteen hour-long recorded programs by the Economic Cooperation Administration for presentation to American listeners over independent radio stations.

WEST CALDWELL, N.J., July 20--Mrs. Gordon Park of Glen Ridge won low gross honors with a one-over-par 37, 41--78 in the New Jersey Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class A and B one-day tournament at the Mountain Ridge Country Club today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 20--B.D. Tallamy, chairman of the State Thruway Authority, revealed today that a study is now being made to determine whether the work on the $450,000,000 project can be hastened in view of the world crisis.

SAIGON, Indo-China, July 20-- The United States mission now here studying problems of military aid to the French Union states of Indo-China is not contemplating the use of United States combat units of any kind in the IndoChina area.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday an appropriation of $190,000 for a survey of the administration of the city's educational system, and one of $240,000 for the development and installation of a career and salary plan for about 100,000 municipal employes.

The cotton futures market closed steady 7 to 31 points net higher on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

OTTAWA, July 20--Educational leaders representing the democratic countries of the world today pledged "total mobilization" of the teaching profession, if necessary, to help the United States and the United Nations stop the Communist aggression in Korea.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 20--The United States insisted today that long-range disarmament talks must go on against the day when "aggression may at last have been halted."
No sharp changes in the homebuilding situation in this area were foreseen yesterday by bankers, builders and others.

A war-flavored stock market recovered further yesterday to show gains of 1 to 3 points. Railroad issues were the most prominent in the fresh rally.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 20 --By abandoning conventional designs and construction techniques the New York Diocese of the Protestant Episcopal Church is getting $300,000 worth of mission churches for the $100,000 assembled in last year's "cornerstone campaign."

Ruby-and-topaz hummingbirds with amber tails widespread flash through the orange trees in the Valley of Arima in Trinidad. Vanilla vines and night-blooming cereus form hanging gardens in the giant mahoganies, sunshade for stingless bees, tailless butterflies and flesh-eating army ants.

ALBERTO MORAVIA'S novel, "The Woman of Rome," was presented to the American critical fraternity last fall with a burst of brass and a cadenza of martinis, and, though its acceptance on a literary level was far from unanimous, no one was surprised at its eventual place on best-seller lists.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20-- Carrying heavy, wet sails, 234 craft wind-jammed today through the fourth point-scoring session of Race Week at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Bank loans to business rose $12,000,000 last week. Registering their seventh successive weekly advance for a total gain of $200,000,000, these borrowings from the New York City reporting member banks are now nearly $300,000,000 above the total outstanding a year ago.

The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest producer of steel, reported yesterday record earnings and sales for the first half of 1950.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 20--United States sources said today that several members of the United Nations had made confidential offers to send ground troops to aid the Republic of Korea.
ST. LOUIS, July 20--Leo Durocher took the wraps off his players last night and tonight the Giants took the wraps off their war clubs.

McDonald and his staff in the Brooklyn gambling investigation, 6,000 policemen--one-third of the department--turned out yesterday morning for the funeral of Capt. John G. Flynn, who shot himself Sunday after he had appeared as a witness in the inquiry.
The Army, the Air Force, the Navy and the Marine Corps are going to have a streamlined recruiting booth on the Times Square island at Forty-third Street within the next thirty days.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21-- Forty faculty members, including several full professors, of the University of California who had refused to sign a special non-communist loyalty oath or a non-Communist letter of contract acceptance were retained in their positions today by a 10-to-9 vote of the Board of Regents.

CINCINNATI, July 21--Elwin (Preacher) Roe, who has added luster to the town of Hardy, Ark., by just living there, spread a little brightness throughout Flatbush today by stopping the tough Cincinnati Reds and pitching the Dodgers to a 7-1 victory.
Great Britain will make no mass attempt to invade the United States textile market, according to Col. James Hutchinson, president of the Incorporated Sales Managers Association.

With the purchase of a plot from M.J. Martin Sons, on the west side of Henry Hudson Parkway, south of West 239th Street, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, Henry Richmond and Charles Tenebaum have assembled a site for a new apartment development.

CLEVELAND, July 21--A resolution protesting "loyalty programs that inquire into a library employe's thoughts, reading matter, associates, or membership in organizations, unless a particular person's definite actions warrant such investigations" was adopted unanimously today by the American Library Association.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)-- The American Newspaper Publishers Association has started another country-wide Taft-Hartley Act case against the International Typographical Union, A.F.L.

Mayor O'Dwyer may be called by the Brooklyn grand jury investigating tie-ups between the police and gamblers to explain his criticism of the conduct of the inquiry.

In a purchase for personal investment, Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner, president and treasurer, respectively, of the Sterling Investing Corporation, have acquired the Ferguson estate on Gold Lane in Halesite, L.I., which they plan to subdivide into one-acre plots.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 24 (AP)--Escapade led an advance guard of five boats across the finish line here today in the 335-mile Chicago to Mackinac yacht race.

Many of the nation's leading life insurance companies have filed applications with state insurance departments for authority to insert war risk clauses in new life insurance policies as a result of developments in the Far East.
WASHINGTON, July 24--President Truman today nominated Paul M. Herzog, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, for another five-year term to end Aug. 27, 1955.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)-- The Federal Reserve Board said tonight strong inflationary forces were building up in the economy even before the Korean crisis arose to make them worse.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 24-- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century opened her defense of the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy over the difficult Quaker Ridge course today by setting a new record of 37, 38--75 for the event.
Total grants of $2,143,633 in aid of a variety of projects were announced yesterday by the Rockefeller Foundation.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed strong, 22 to 40 points net higher.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 24-- Grand Knight, the juvenile Pacific star who won his tune-up outing over the same strip last week, scored the most important victory of his young career tonight when he captured the $10,000 Knight Dream test for 2-year-olds before ...
WASHINGTON, July 24--Democrats were accused today by Senator Homer Ferguson of using "the techniques of Goebbels and Vishinsky" to silence assailants of the State Department's integrity.

WASHINGTON, July 24--Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Trowbridge of Washington, formerly of Glen Cove, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy, to George Burgwin Holmes, son of Mrs. Joseph Horne Holmes of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Holmes. The wedding will take place in the early autumn.

WITH THE FIRST CAVALRY, in South Korea, Tuesday, July 25 --North Korean Communist forces concentrated their artillery and armor in this sector yesterday in an effort to split the newly formed United States line, but the defending general promised an attack soon.

"Mystery Street," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer romantic melodrama with Ricardo Montalban, Sally Forrest, Bruce Bennett, Elsa Lanchester and Marshall Thompson heading the cast, will open at the Palace on Thursday instead of "The Great Jewel Robber," announced previously by the management for that day. John Sturges directed and Frank E. Taylor produced "Mystery Street."

WASHINGTON, July 24--Army spokesmen at High Command Headquarters in the Pentagon this afternoon minimized some of the North Koreans' spectacular appearing gains. In particular, an Army general said there was nothing to be alarmed about in the Communists' wide "end run" down the western part of the peninsula.

MANILA, July 24--The position of the Philippines on assistance to the United Nations in the Korean war effort remained negative and confused, with an extended exposition of the Administration viewpoint by President Elpidio Quirino in response to questioning by the press.
A cross section of traditional and modern fabrics is on view in the exhibition at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fiftyfifth Street, which opened yesterday.

Crude rubber futures, adjusted to war developments in the Far East, again advanced into new high territory on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Prices of all active deliveries, reflecting a spectacular week-end jump of 2 d a pound in the London market, were ...

JACKSON, Miss., July 24--The police force in this city went on a twenty-four-hour alert at midnight tonight in preparation for any disturbances that might develop from the scheduled visit tomorrow of members of the Civil Rights Congress seeking executive clemency for a Negro convicted of raping a white woman.

WASHINGTON, July 24--Congressional leaders prepared today to take two tax-rise steps, the first a "stop-gap" step to meet immediate needs growing out of the Korean situation and the second to put the nation on a permanent ready-for-war basis.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 24 (AP)--Ford Frick, pinch hitting for Commissioner A.B. Chandler, dedicated the new $175,000 west wing of the Baseball Hall of Fame today "on behalf of the boys and girls and men and women of the United States."

Major league baseball attendance is off about 12 per cent, or almost 1,500,000, from last season. Only three teams--the Philadelphia Phillies, Detroit Tigers and Chicago Cubs--are ahead of last year's figures, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, July 24--Representatives of the overwhelming majority of members of the maritime unions in Atlantic, Pacific, Gulf and Great Lakes ports met with their employers here today and adopted a voluntary plan to weed out Communists and other subversives during the Korean emergency.

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Tuesday, July 25--Sitting cross legged in precise rows on floors of a church near United States Advanced Headquarters, several hundred North Korean prisoners under guard of Korean military police gnawed hunggrily at huge riceballs. Ranging in age from 13 to 26 the ragged "People's Army" troops were experiencing something unexpected.

The Glenn L. Martin Company yesterday reported net income of $872,901, equal to 77 cents a capital share, in the first six months of 1950. This compares with a net profit of $976,974, or 86 cents a share, in the first half of last year before a special adjustment converted ...
POMPTON LAKES, N.J., July 24 (AP)--If Joe Louis can untangle his income tax problems he'll probably train here for a September title bout with Ezzard Charles.
BALTIMORE, Tuesday, July 25 (AP)--William G. Helis, oil developer and horseman, died early today at Johns Hopkins Hospital. His age was 63.

VIENNA, July 24--The first concrete steps toward forming a schismatic Catholic church have been taken in Czechoslovakia, Roman Catholic sources said here today after studying the regulations for training and ordaining priests at two new Government theological faculties in Prague and Bratislava.

With production of cotton cloth at near capacity expected for the rest of this year, there is no reason for current fears of textile shortages. This was asserted yesterday by W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.

CLINTON, N.Y., July 24--Senator Wayne L. Morse made a plea today to the young votes of America and to Governor Dewey, asking them not to abandon the Republican party in a critical time of its history and the nation's international affairs.

Leading Home, owned by William Zeigler Jr., made her bid in the stretch and the bid stood up well enough for her to win the Piquet Handicap, the feature test on the racing program of the Saratoga Association at Jamaica yesterday. George Hettinger guided ...

Thirty-five thousand New York hotel workers will receive wage increases averaging 9 per cent under an arbitration award made public last night by Edward P. Mulrooney, impartial chairman of the hotel industry. The increases range from $.80 to $4 a week.

WASHINGTON, July 24-- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, urged the House Agriculture Committee today to approve a bill allotting $50,000,000 to his Department to help it dispose of spoilable surpluses now piling up under the price support system.
War-tinged psychology again dominated trading on the stock market yesterday as traders bid for railroad and aircraft issues but sold the motors.
The problem posed for United States policy by the millions of refugees now stranded in Central Europe is many sided, but its most critical aspect at this stage of the "cold war" is political.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)-- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the current hiring-hall contract between the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, C.I.O., and West Coast dock employers was illegal, on the ground that it gives hiring preference to union members.

ALBANY, July 24--Immediate activation of a New York State Guard that will be prepared to replace units of the National Guard as they are called to Federal service was ordered today by Governor Dewey. The Governor directed Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commanding general of the New York National Guard, to assume command also of the state force.

Lemons are more apt to be found in the refrigerator in summer than any other time of year, Miss Cay Hillegas said yesterday. Warm weather thirst "peaks" consumption of the satiny-skinned fruit. But lemons also do well in things other than drinks. Salad dressings and frozen desserts, for instance.

BERLIN, July 24--A listless crowd of several thousand workers, drenched by rain and including a sizable proportion of the "people's police," obediently thronged the Lustgarten in the Soviet sector of Berlin this afternoon for a "demonstration" concluding the third congress of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party.

HONG KONG, July 24--Swollen by torrential rains that followed a two-month drought, rivers of East and Central China have overflowed their banks and broken through dikes in new floods that have already brought widespread devastation to large parts of the Huai River valley.

Charles J. Fay, a senior partner in the law firm of White Case, 14 Wall Street, died on Sunday in Staten Island Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Fay, who was 78 years old, resided on Romer Road, Dongan Hills, S.I.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP)--Calumet Farm's Citation, world's money-winning champion with earnings of $938,639, may have run his last race.

Top aluminum officials believe steps should be taken immediately to increase the primary aluminum production facilities of the United States by at least 1,000,000,000 pounds--approximately 55 per cent--in the interest of national security.

WASHINGTON, July 24--Senate-House conferees, driving to complete a compromise social security bill, cleared a major hurdle today in deciding to care for the nation's permanently and totally disabled through public assistance rather than insurance.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 24 (AP)--The Boston Red Sox rallied in the eight inning on home runs by John Pesky and Vern Stephens to defeat the New York Giants, 8 to 5, today in the annual Hall of Fame game on ancient Doubleday Field where baseball was born.

Since 1900 the United States has added to its population very nearly the equivalent of the present population of the United Kingdom. Since 1940 it has added approximately the equivalent of the population of Turkey or the Philippines. Such is the evidence produced by the Census Bureau, which says that we have more than 150,000,000 men, women and children in the continental United States.

Supreme Court Justice Charles D. Breitel denied yesterday an application for examination of the designating petitions of Assemblyman Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn, the minority leader in the lower house of the State Legislature.
One of the first voluntary allocation plans in the home appliance field was announced yesterday by Landers, Frary Clark, New Britain, Conn., a leading manufacturer.

The city of San Antonio, Tex., received bids yesterday on school bond issues for $3,500,000, $4,750,000 and $9,500,000, and maturing from 1951 to 1970. The bids ranged in interest cost from 2.1228 per cent to 2.28 per cent. Award will be made later in the week.
There was swimming in the rain yesterday at the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street. The pool, however, was indoors.

LONDON, July 24 (AP)--Britain and Ireland have decided to raise their official representatives in Dublin and London to the rank of Ambassador, the Foreign Office said tonight. The changeover will be made Wednesday.

"Let him smell his way to Dover," wrote Shakespeare. But "Smelly" Kelly sniffs his way only as far as the Bronx. "Follow thy nose and thou wilt be there presently," wrote Thomas Hey wood. "Smelly" Kelly has taken that advice five or six times daily for the last twenty years.

Construction has been started on the first group of thirtyone dwellings in the 200-family development planned by Suburban Homes, Inc., on Banta Road and May, Putnam and Park Avenues in South Plain field, N.J. The ranch-style buildings are in the $9,500 price range.

A better understanding of New York and its problems is expected to be conveyed to other cities as one of the results of the formation of a twenty-nine-station radio "network" under the auspices of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters.

An audience of 1,400 disregarded the drizzle last night and assembled at the Lewisohn Stadium anyway. As a reward for their intrepidity, the rain-bravers not only heard a whole concert but were told they could all come back tonight and hear the same concert free.
Men's wear rayon suiting and slacks fabrics for next spring are priced at the same general level as last spring.

The Commercial National Bank and Trust Company, as trustees, has sold the seven-story office and store building at 13 East Fortysecond Street to the National City Bank and has purchased the sixstory building at 9 East Fortysecond Street from the Schulte Real Estate Company, Inc., in a three-cornered transaction.

RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 24 (AP)--In only fifty minutes, the nation's top-ranked amateur, Davis Cup veteran Ted Schroeder was soundly trounced by Herb Flam, national collegiate champion, 6--1, 6--2, 6--2, in the final of the national clay court tennis tourney today.

PUSAN, Korea, July 24--In the advance of arrival of North Korean tank and infantry teams at the suburbs of Mokpo, seaport at the southwest corner of Korea, local guerrillas emerged from hiding in the countryside and urban underground and became active.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 24 (AP) --Oklahoma's bitter Democratic Senate and governorship primary campaigns reached the finish line tonight with liquor, in legally dry Oklahoma, suddenly becoming the liveliest issue.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 24-- Thailand sent formal notification today to Secretary General Trygve Lie that it was placing a combat team of 4,000 officers and men at the disposal of the United Nations to fight with United States troops against the North Koreans.

WASHINGTON, July 24--When Chairman Symington of the National Security Resources Board today discussed with a Senate committee the economic controls essential to conduct the new quasi-war program, and when the Council of Economic Advisers this afternoon proposed them to the President in specific outline, they were operating on these general principles:
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)-- The Department of Interior declined today to order a hearing on allocation of natural gas to be handled in a proposed new 451mile Texas-to-California pipeline.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 24-- The proposed Connecticut Democratic party platform, another section of which was released late today, pledges the party "to rid Connecticut of the sales tax at the earliest possible opportunity."

Nearly 1,500 shipyard workers remained idle yesterday as operations were suspended at the Brooklyn and Hoboken plants of the Todd Shipyards Corporation following the strike that began at midnight Sunday.

CHICAGO, July 24--Scattered liquidation developed in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here today, and, with hedging pressure, resulted in a net decline of 1 to 2 5/8 cents a bushel in futures, while cash wheat in the Minneapolis market lost 2 cents, compared with the September positions.
WASHINGTON, July 24--President Truman today called on all citizens and police officers to be watchful of spies, sabotage and other subversive activities.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 25--The United States First Cavalry and Twenty-fifth Divisions fought off a series of North Korean tank and infantry attacks today all along the line running from behind Taejon into the hilly country eastward, where Communist forces were ...

GENEVA, July 24--The United States Government has decided to go a long way in international economic cooperation in an effort to strengthen the confidence of the rest of the free world in American economic stability.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 (UP) --A rank and file revolt against Harry Bridges' sixteen years of left-wing domination of West Coast port labor was in the making today because of his failure to take a solid stand in support of United Nations intervention in Korea.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., July 24--The first of the major horse mackerel derbies will get under way tomorrow morning with the opening of the Maine Tuna Tournament, a four-day event in which individuals rather than teams will compete for the trophy.

Federal and city mediators began yesterday a joint effort to end the strike of 1,100 building supply truck drivers that threatens a virtually complete shutdown of all construction in New York and Long Island by tomorrow night.
Mayor O'Dwyer greeted fifty Japanese men and women yesterday as individuals, emphasizing that he could not welcome them as a delegation representing "moral rearmament."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24-- Lewis Milestone has been signed by Twentieth Century-Fox to direct "Kangaroo," a film about Australia at the turn of the century, on which the company will spend its funds frozen in that dominion. Milestone will leave for the Antipodes about, Aug. 15, and the rest of the company will follow him late in September, although the cast is not yet determined.

The passports of foreign members of the Jehovah's Witnesses sect, suspected of harboring sentiments of "extreme pacifism" on their arrival here to attend a convention, were restored yesterday by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

PITTSBURGH, July 24 (AP)-- Rain wiped out Eddie Waitkus' two-run homer in the top of the seventh tonight and gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2-1 six-inning triumph over the Philadelphia Phils. The loss knocked the Phillies out of the National League lead.

Net income of the American Car and Foundry Company for the fiscal year ended April 30 was $436,193, equal to $1.51 a share on the 289,450 shares of preferred stock outstanding, according to the 51st annual report issued yesterday.

European buyers are bidding for scarce American metals at prices higher than levels prevailing in this country. As a result, industrial purchasing executives said yesterday, large industries essential to war production may ask Government officials to restrict exports ...

To a gourmet, it may be the quality of the food that makes for a truly happy meal, but the exhibition opening this morning at Katzenbach and Warren credit's a room's wallpaper with contributing to the enjoyment of good food.

Design suggestions ranging from primitive stone carvings to Roman coins, modern city parks and even that favorite standby, the rose, characterize the latest group of prints by Goodall Fabrics, which are now available through decorators from the showroom at 525 Madison Avenue.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 25--For the first time in a week the weather cleared Monday over the Korean battlefield permitting pinpoint bombing of tactical targets by B-29's.

LONG-RANGE PROVING GROUND, COCOA, Fla., July 24 (AP)--A huge German V-2 rocket carrying a smaller missile piggyback made a thunderous climbing turn over the Atlantic today for what was described as the first successful horizontal flight of a guided long-range missile.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 24--Col. James Wainwright Flanagan, internationally known mining engineer, died here today in St. Joseph's Infirmary at the age of 77.

It is particularly gratifying when awards made for conspicuous service in any field go to the front-line worker rather than merely to the titular head of a specific undertaking. This has occurred in the case of two of the awards of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences made in connection with its annual summer meeting on the Pacific Coast.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 24 (AP)--King Leopold and the Social Christian (Catholic) Government supporting him faced mounting opposition today.

WASHINGTON, July 24--The Korean situation was reviewed today by Secretary of State Dean Acheson at an executive session of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Afterward, Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, its chairman, expressed himself as more optimistic and confident about the progress of events in Korea.

Directors of the Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of $1 a common share, payable on Sept. 1. The company said this would raise the annual rate to $4 from $3 previously paid since August, 1947.

WASHINGTON, July 24--United States armed forces will not intervene in any attempt by Chinese Communist forces to take the island of Quemoy, off the harbor of Amoy. The State Department today said that no request for such intervention had been received from the Chinese Nationalists

Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company reported yesterday for the six months ended June 30, net income of $5,467,127, an increase of 124 per cent over the $2,443,879 net income reported for the similar period of 1949.

One pocketbook especially sensitive to food price changes is that of the family living on a relief allowance. We recall that in late 1948, after a period of rising prices, it was felt necessary or desirable to increase the food allowance to relief families here 25 per cent.

Fulton Oursler's "The Greatest Story Ever Told" will be presented by Guthrie McClintic and Victor Young as a dramatic musical this season. The elaborate production, capitalized at $150,000, is scheduled to play auditoriums, arenas and large theatres across the country. Although no Broadway presentation is scheduled at this time, the offering may eventually be seen here.

Buyers seeking to place fill-in orders on linens, domestics and curtains for August white sales have found prices raised 5 to 20 per cent in the last two weeks. The increases have been no deterrent, however, and business yesterday as the combined domestics and ...
GUATEMALA, July 24--President Juan Jose Arevalo, following an emergency Cabinet meeting, has declared a state of siege, that suspends constitutional guarantees.

Since the theory of repertory seems to be that classics are its meat, the latest group on Broadway, called the Festival Theatre, has dug up "Parisienne" with which to lead off its season. "Parisienne" was written by Henri Becque and, as adapter by Ashley Dukes, it was given at the Fulton ...

WASHINGTON, July 24--W. Stuart Symington, chairman of the National Security Resources Board, told Congress today that it must promptly approve President Truman's new mobilization program "if this nation is to survive."

ABOARD HOSPITAL TRAIN, in South Korea, July 24--Twenty-four wounded, several of whom stumbled into the American lines yesterday after a thirty-mile walk from encircled Taejon, lie on litters in this car.

CLEVELAND, July 24--Preservation of the Charter of the United Nations is primarily a responsibility of the Christian churches of the world, Justice J.W. Estey of the Supreme Court of Canada said here tonight at the eighth World Baptist Congress. At the conference are 20,000 delegates from forty-eight countries.

WASHINGTON, July 24--The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a company that refused to make any reasonable effort to prove to a union why it was unable to increase wages violated the Taft-Hartley Act by refusing to bargain in good faith.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 24 (AP)--A second amphibious landing on the rebel island of Ceram in the Moluccas has been made by Indonesian Federal troops, the insurgent-controlled radio at Amboina said today.

Mrs. Whiting Audibert of 320 East Seventy-second Street and Xavier M. Audibert, also of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marie, to Richard Francis Upton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Upton of Concord, N.H.

WASHINGTON, July 24--A rapid 60 per cent increase in the fighting strength of the United States Marine Corps is about to get under way, members of Congress said today. Also, perhaps three big aircraft carriers are due for withdrawal from the "mothball fleet." One, it was asserted ...

These times of crisis, with demands on the Federal Treasury unprecedented except in the course of a general war, call for every possible economy. That is to say, they demand the true economy which saves dollars without impairing essential services.

PARIS, July 24--The first pronouncement by the French Government on the international crisis is expected to be made tomorrow by Premier Rene Pleven, who is to address the Finance Committee of the Assembly in the morning and probably will speak in the Assembly in the afternoon.

A Center of Israeli Studies will be opened at Columbia University this fall to promote understanding of the new republic, its presentday relation to the Near East and its historical ties with Judaism.

WASHINGTON, July 24--President Truman today asked Congress to appropriate $10,516,976,000 to increase the armed forces by 600,000 men and to provide vast new quantities of tanks, aircraft, guns, ships and munitions to meet the challenges of Communist aggression. Almost half of the total would go to the Air Force.

Representatives of Latin-American republics and inter-American societies celebrated yesterday the 167th birthday anniversary of Simon Bolivar, South American liberator. Two hundred attended the ceremony at Bolivar's equestrian statue in Central Park.
LONDON, July 24--A supreme and urgent effort to arm Western European democracies against the possibility of aggression from the east was started here today.

NEW DELHI, India, July 24-- Five days of conferences on the Kashmir problem among Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan of Pakistan and Sir Owen Dixon, United Nations mediator, in this long-standing dispute, ended inconclusively tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24--Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Speigel of Highland Park, Ill., of the engagement of Mrs. Speigel's daughter, Miss Suzanne Hirsch, to Frank G. Binswanger Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Binswanger of Elkins Park. The wedding will take place in the autumn.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 24 --The annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament will start tomorrow on the Meadow Club turf, with an unusually large field of sixty-four players.

The Security Council meets at Lake Success today in expectation of the first report to be made to it through the American Government by General MacArthur, as commander of all United Nations forces fighting in Korea, on the progress of the first United Nations action to meet armed aggression with armed force.

Draft delinquents are in for trouble. With a higher percentage failing to report to their "greetings" than was ever evident during World War II, Col. Candler Cobb, director of New York City Selective Service, yesterday threatened them with the penalty for desertion.

The reconstructed transatlantic liner Liberty, formerly the German express steamer Europa, will reenter service next month completely transformed in specific departments in which she had been criticited by American marine architects.

When top Communists get together one suspects that they are hatching mischief. Some of the most important Communists of the world--Togliatti, Duclos, Pollitt, Suslov, Berman, Revai --met last week in Berlin, ostensibly as guests at the third annual convention of the German Socialist Unity [Communist] party.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., July 24 --The cornerstone repository of the new $10,000,000 addition to Nassau County's Meadowbrook Hospital was sealed and put in place here today. It contains two unusual items along with the customary cornerstone contents.

There is a school of thought which contends that major league baseball clubs should play no exhibition games once the regular campaign starts. Too often a player is incapacitated in extracurricular diamond activities, and last night at Ebbets Field, where the Dodgers defeated the Indians, 6--4, proponents of the idea pointed to the accidental beaning of Cleveland's Larry Doby as concrete evidence.

Pressure has continued on the First Cavalry and Twenty-fifth Infantry Divisions, most of which has been small detachments attacking with tanks. This has also been followed with some light artillery fire by Communists.
The normal decline that might have been expected in Mediterranean passenger traffic after the Holy Year will probably not materialize until the late summer or early fall of 1951.
The Voice of America is still probably getting its story through to Koreans from at least four Korean broadcasting stations, State Department officials said here yesterday.

Total assets of the Ford Motor Company reached a new high of $1,343,349,000 at the close of 1949, according to the annual report filed yesterday with the Massachusetts State Tax Commissioner in Boston. The figure shows a rise of more than $194,109,000 from the $1,149,240,000 total at the close of 1948.

WHEN Ray Robinson signed his latest contract, his act caused no little turmoil among the boys very close to the boxing picture. Eyes stared in disbelief, lips and tongues moved but sound came out rather unintelligibly, and shrugs of doubt, if harnessed by a football coach possessing the formula to do so, could have provided enough offensive strength to brush away all opposition for an entire season.

Plans for an apartment house at East End Avenue and East Eightysecond Street to accommodate 187 families were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The cost is estimated at $1,879,339.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 24--Secretary General Trygve Lie today sent the following message to Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister of External Affairs, concerning the death of former Prime Minister Mackenzie King:
SAIGON, Indo-China, July 24-- A new appeal for intensification of terrorism and sabotage in Saigon has been issued by the Vietminh Committee for Saigon.

Burglars who were unimpressed by stacks of painting by such artists as "Grandma" Moses, Adolf Dehn, Thomas Hart Benton and Charles E. Burchfield, left the British Book Center, Inc., 122 East Fifty-fifth Street, which they had broken into some time in the weekend, with a mere a $250 in cash for booty.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 25--Nassau County's 1949 record crop of babies has resulted in a 1950 shortage of baby-sitters.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 25-- The Huguenot Yacht Club of New Rochelle took a 2-point lead in the twenty-second annual junior sailing series for the Commodore Robert Law Trophy today as the first two races were sailed off Great Captain's Island under the auspices of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

Carded cotton sales yarn spinners started the second half of this year with the biggest backlog of unfilled orders on their books since December, 1949, it was reported yesterday in Charlotte, N.C., by the Textile Information Service.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25 (AP) --The Government protested to the United Nations today that an Israeli fighter plane had attacked a Lebanese airliner, killing two of the twenty-eight persons aboard and endangering nine Americans. Seven Arab passengers were wounded.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 25 (AP)--The Netherlands today disbanded her 120-year-old colonial Army and wound up the affairs of her regular Army command in Indonesia.

ROME, July 25--If Italy were attacked the Government would immediately deliver a knockout blow on the Communist fifth column, Defense Minister Randolfo Pacciardi said today in a speech to officers and men who participated in the Italian Army maneuvers in the Appennines.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 25-- Senhor Christiano Machado, Presidential candidate of the Social Democratic party, affirmed in his first major speech that, if elected, he would carry out the Dutra fiveyear plan known as Salte.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 25-- Mrs. Edward Bishop of Glen Oaks, 31-year-old mother of four children, scored her greatest competitive golf triumph by capturing the annual Joseph J. Windle Challenge Cup today at the Fresh Meadow Country Club course.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 26 (AP) --Text of Communique No. 1, issued Tuesday by General Headquarters, United Nations Command:

The Korean crisis is tending to develop shortages in the plastics field. The Society of the Plastics Industry, in a survey, pointed out yesterday that prior to the outbreak in Korea the industry was approaching a balance between supply and demand.

Two thousand children from religioius daily vacation schools in the five boroughs heard an announcement yesterday that Dutch children were sending thousands of assorted tulip bulbs to New York in a gesture of friendship, gratitude and good will.

The resumption of selective service and calling up of National Guard and Organized Reserve units are expected to have little or no immediate effect on college enrollment this year, even though most students are eligible for service.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 25 --Returning to competition after his collapse at the Merion Cricket Club last week, Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., survived two rounds of competition today in the sixtieth annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 25--The United Nations is negotiating with the Sperry Gyroscope Company next door to turn back part of this world peace headquarters within three or four weeks to provide additional space that Sperry needs to step up war production.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 25 (AP)--Withholding of dues to the national lodge was proposed today by a committee of the Knights of Pythias' Grand Lodge of New York State in a move to eliminate the "white" clause from the order's membership application blanks.
SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., July 25--Student veterans who have finished courses in New York colleges may not have to vacate their homes here.

There was surprise--and disappointment--in some Wall Street quarters when directors of the United States Steel Corporation failed to raise the dividend on the common stock yesterday. The 65cent rate paid in previous quarters this year was maintained.
Officials of the Parks Department began work yesterday on planning nineteen playground and building projects for which the Housing and Home Finance Agency lent $139,000 last Monday.

WHEN the United States Army dropped its horse show team after the 1948 Olympics, a grey void was left in the international military sport of jumping horses. The event closest to home that suffered was the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, Faded, too, were the contests for military men held at Harrisburg, Pa., and Toronto.
WASHINGTON, July 25--Senate-House conferees on the compromise Social Security Bill ruled out today any increase in taxes for old age and survivors insurance until Jan. 1, 1954.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 25(AP)--Nineteen rivals crossed the finish line ahead of her, but a handicap of nearly twelve hours gave the little ketch Fleetwood the top prize today in the forty-third Chicago-to-Mackinac yacht race.

CLINTON, N.Y., July 25--Three hundred politically ambitious high school and college students, many of them from New York's smaller communities, heard Controller Frank C. Moore stress today the importance of their local government units and the key roles that ...

President Truman has asked Congress for $10,486,976,000 in new military funds for the fiscal year 1950-51 and for an immediate increase of $5,000,000,000 in taxes. These requests are based on a general revision of manpower estimates for the armed services calling for an increase of approximately 600,000 men.
LONDON, July 25--The stock markets were again dull today prices drifting downward in extremely quiet business. Even "armament" shares lost their recent buoyancy.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 25--The Congress of the International Transport Workers Federation, meeting in Stuttgart, has decided to attempt to persuade the Argentine Government to recognize the grievances of the striking Argentine Seamen's Union.

The first of seventy Civil Air Patrol cadets who will tour six foreign countries on an exchange basis this summer to study the work of their counterparts abroad will start their trip from Mitchel Air Force Base today.
New bond issues totaling $27,000,000 were sold yesterday by the State of Texas and by the city of Dallas at interest costs ranging from 1.7148 per cent to 1.685 per cent.

Mrs. Hertha May Miller of 953 Fifth Avenue, Palm Beach, Fla., and Southampton, L.I., widow of Harold Bourne Miller, was married yesterday morning to Christian Marcel Lamarche of Liege, Belgium, and New York in Christ Methodists Church.

LONDON, July 23--Opinion is divided in London on the subject of waistlines. At the opening of the autumn fashion collections showing here, Digby Morton was emphatic on a change in the trend toward a straight line that tapers toward the hem.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 25-- Paul Leo Masson, a retired banker, died yesterday at his home here, 10 Overlook Terrace, after a brief illness. He was 61 years old.

DELMAR, Calif., July 25-- Arthur Ungar, editor of Daily Variety, published in Hollywood, and for many years a leader in the entertainment business, died here last night of a heart attack, at the home of a friend. His age was 64.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 25 (AP)--The South Korean Government at Pusan announced today it would execute all civilians found "making enemy-like action" in the war zone.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 25--The United States, in a somber appraisal of the Korean situation, today emphasized the "excellent Soviet materiel" and the numerical superiority of North Korean forces and warned that the enemy "cannot be overcome until the United Nations forces achieve the effect of superiority in weapons and manpower."

The crude rubber futures market on the Commodity Exchange continued strong yesterday, with final prices up 200 to 325 points. Sensitive to Korean developments, all active deliveries were up the permissible limit of 200 points.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 25--A message from former Secretary of State Cordell Hull, presented today to the United Nations Security Council, paid tribute to the world peace organization for having made a "solid contribution" to international peace and stability.
The best of the Saratoga-atJamaica races yesterday was a sprint for 3-year-olds that never had won twice. That's the kind of program it was. The other seven races all were claimers.

ST. LOUIS, July 25--The Yankees' gay dash into the west stepped into something like a gopher hole tonight as the sturdy left arm of chubby Frank Overmire tripped the Bombers and sent them sprawling amid the tantalizing jeers of 7,715 chortling onlookers.

WASHINGTON, July 25--The response of the United States to the two resolutions of the United Nations on the aggression of the North Korean forces has created both liabilities and assets for this country and its associates in the international effort to restrain militant world communism.

The picture of the refugee situation in western Europe that has been painted by our Geneva correspondent in his recent series is not a pretty one. There might have been justification for thinking, at the close of the war, that within five years the refugee question would have ceased to be a major European problem.

An independent union representing powerhouse workers and others non-operating employes of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad (Hudson Tubes) threatened yesterday to cut off service for 200,000 commuters if dismissal notices for three railroad patrolmen were not canceled by midnight Sunday.
WASHINGTON, July 25--The Department of Defense called Congressional leaders to a secret meeting at the Pentagon today to deliver a statement on the Korean fighting and its world-wide implications.

WASHINGTON, July 25--The House of Representatives by voice vote today completed Congressional action on an authorization to President Truman to hold 295,000 members of the Armed Forces on active duty for a year beyond the normal expiration of their enlistments.

Preparation of a plan to mobilize the state's medical resources in a war emergency has been urged by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman of the State Civil Defense Commission, in a letter to Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Commissioner of Health.
TOKYO, July 25--The Communist invaders of South Korea are successfully following the tactics of the Chinese Communists and are living off the country.

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, July 25--Hard-pressed South Korean Government officials, and United Nations and United States representatives here are faced with a growing problem of care, housing and feeding of refugees pouring in from the area between the Thirtyeighth Parallel and the present battle lines at the rate of 25,000 daily.

The Union News Company has sold the two-story building at 9120 146th Street, Jamaica, Queens, to the Jamaica Law Printing Company, Inc. The buyer paid cash for the property, which had been held at $50,000. John J. Reynolds, Inc., was the broker.

CLEVELAND, July 25--A universal call for abolition of religious discrimination was issued today by the World Baptist Congress. In a mid-century manifesto the organiization expressed deepest concern for the survival of free churches.

"Be yourself and please yourself in planning your home" was the advice given to brides yesterday afternoon at a home fashion show conducted by Abraham Straus and Bride's Magazine in the store auditorium.

BOSTON, July 25 (AP)--Frederick Lewis Collins, author and former magazine editor, died at Massachusetts General Hospital today a few hours after he was stricken at his West Falmouth home. His age was 68.
WASHINGTON, July 25--An invisible dust of radioactive "death sand" could spread over a city and kill its population by radioactivity without the noisy warning of an atomic bomb.

The Manhattan Republican organization chose Henry V. Poor, 36-year-old attorney, yesterday as its candidate to oppose the reelection of Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. in the Twentieth Congressional District.

Col. Candler Cobb, director of New York City Selective Service, backed his threat of prosecution against those who fail to report for the draft by conferring yesterday with the two United States Attorneys here.

DETROIT, July 25 (AP)--The Red Sox nipped the pace-setting Tigers, 7 to 6, tonight to tighten the American League race as secondplace New York lost, too. Eight pitchers saw action in the nip-andtuck battle with Chuck Stobbs, the winner, and Hal White, the loser.

After seizing the lead with a stirring five-run rally in the eighth inning and being overtaken in the ninth, the Giants scored an unearned tally in their last turn to squeeze out a 7-6 victory over the Reds before a Polo Grounds gathering of 8,838 last night. It was the sixth straight triumph for Leo Durocher's resurgent forces.

Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, criticized sharply yesterday the proposed new Defense Production Act now before Congress on the grounds that drastic government controls over industry are not only unjustified but would also pave the way for conversion of the nation into a permanent socialistic state.
TORONTO, July 25--The Board of Control today authorized the sale in the United States of $15,000,000 of debentures to provide funds for construction of Toronto's subway.

GUATEMALA, July 25--The university students' strike, which began last Thursday following the slaying of a medical student, Edgar Lemke, during a clash the day before, was extended yesterday to professional and commercial establishments.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 25 (AP) --Representative A.S. Mike Monroney defeated Senator Elmer Thomas today in Oklahoma's Democratic primary run-off election.

LONDON, July 25--Steamships and motorships under construction in the world total 4,549,921 gross tons, according to Lloyd's Register of Shipping for the three months ended June 30 and published here today. This represents a decrease of 134,753 tons from the previous quarter.

ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, in South Korea, Wednesday, July 26--United States jet fighters, flying a night mission for the first time in history Tuesday night, hit at North Korean communications behind the Communist front southeast of Yongdong.

"Mad Money," a musical about a gold rush in the Bronx, has been scheduled for Broadway production this fall by Morton Gottlieb, a 29year-old former company manager, who will be making his debut as a sponsor.

Mr. and Mrs. James C. Mackenzie of 570 Park Avenue and Gladstone, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elaine Toulmin, to John Benjamin Hill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice C. Hill of Westport, Conn.
WASHINGTON, July 25--As the Korean fighting approaches a crisis, Washington observers are studying closely the world's "soft spots" for possible clues to Premier Stalin's intentions.

President Truman's tax increase proposals sent a chill yesterday through the stock market. Although the nation had been well prepared for a shift to a war economy, the levies suggested to the Congress proved a bit steeper than anticipated.

Post-graduate education in many fields of medicine will be carried to doctors by an FM broadcast series beginning tomorrow night through cooperation between the New York Academy of Medicine and the Municipal Broadcasting System.
City officials, led by Mayor O'Dwyer, and 5,000 policemen attended the funeral yesterday of patrolman Alfred Loreto, slain Friday in a heroic off-duty battle with thugs.

Mortgage loans amounting to about $2,300,000 have been obtained by the Wantagh Developing Corporation on 200 dwellings under construction off Jerusalem Avenue in Wantagh, L.I. Known as Wantagh Crest, the project contains six and one-half room houses priced at $13,900.

Empty of cargo, and stripped of virtually every movable fixture, the Queens Victory rode high in the water alongside her Hoboken pier yesterday. Across the dock from her was the almost identical Belgium Victory.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 25-- Mr. and Mrs. Hubert J. McCusker have made known the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Dore, to Harry Frederick Weyher, son of Mrs. Harry Frederick Weyher of Kinston, N.C., and the late Mr. Weyher.

Employers engaged in hauling sand and gravel informed Federal and city mediators yesterday that they would not meet with the union representing 1,100 striking truck drivers unless the union would promise to put any new wage offer up to a closed ballot by the strikers.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 25--Two skulls found in cave deposits in the Transvaal by Dr. Robert Broom, a noted South African scientist, and his assistant I.T. Robinson, are regarded by Dr. Broom as among the most important discoveries yet made toward solving the problem of human evolution.

Louis E. Fairchild, chairman of the board of Fairchild Publications, publishers of trade newspapers, directories and business books, died early yesterday morning at the John T. Malthers Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I., after a week's illness. He was 81 years old.
BERLIN, July 25--As expected, Walter Ulbricht emerged today as Secretary General of the newly Bolshevised Socialist Unity party, by a vote of the revised Central Committee of fifty-two members.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 25--The Dutchess County Surrogate, Frederick S. Quinterro, held today that President Franklin D. Roosevelt did not die "while in active service as a member of the the military or naval forces of the United States."

Now that the hammock season is in full swing (and now that so many readers are putting aside "War and Peace," pro tem., and looking about for something more appropriate to the dog days) the present reader is happy to mention two novels that kept his own hammock rocking briskly through several siesta afternoons.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 25-- The interesting thing happening in Yugoslavia today is the evolution of the revolution. What is going on here is a rather painful readjustment of policy and perspective to world events.

PARIS, July 25--On the basis of a preliminary agreement in the negotiations here, Foreign Minister Robert Schuman gave the National Assembly today more details about the proposed coal and steel merger than he ever had revealed.
WASHINGTON, July 25--The unity committees of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations made progress today in developing plans and agenda for future meetings.

Industrial leaders in the machinery and factory supply industries are urging that production, priority and allocations plans be set up by a civilian board, rather than the military, after the armed services have prepared lists of their production requirements.

BRUSSELS, July 25--The people of Belgium were in a state of expectancy today wondering what the Social Christian (Catholic) Government would do next with the King it recalled from exile. If the Government has any plans for Leopold's future, it has not revealed them so far.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP)-- Richie Ashburn's single with two out in the ninth scored Ralph Caballero from second and gave the Phillies a 1-0 decision over the Cubs in the second game of tonight's doubleheader after they had won the twilight opener, 7--0, behind the three-hit pitching of Emory (Bubba) Church.

JERSEY CITY, July 25--Joseph V. (Newsboy) Moriarity, whose arrest in a gambling raid four years ago was said to have been a factor in the break between former Mayor Frank Hague and Mayor John V. Kenny, was taken into custody again today. The charge was possession of lottery slips.

DETROIT, Mich., July 25--American farmers have gone on a buying spree since the outbreak of fighting in Korea that has stripped most dealers of tractors and other farm implement inventories, a survey of local manufacturers of agriculture equipment disclosed today.
For the first time in their history, New York banks are preparing detailed plans to safeguard their operations in the event of an enemy attack from the air.
TOKYO, July 26 (AP)--The North Koreans are backing their military action with a well-oiled propaganda machine.
According to a dispatch from Vienna published in this newspaper yesterday there are clear signs that the Czechoslovak Communist Government is forming a schismatic Catholic national church.

India's favorable trade balance with the United States will compel some liberalization in her import licensing system on goods from dollar areas, according to Paul Geren, recently appointed United States consul in India.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 25--Following is the text of the first report to the United Nations Security Council by the United States on operations of the Unified Command for the defense of South Korea, together with a covering letter from Warren R. Austin, the United States representative:
At least three sales of Manhattan properties by estates were among the realty transactions reported yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 22 to 61 points higher than on Monday.
Each city hospital being built or planned will have "a large and active rehabilitation unit" connected with it, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday.
As the Catskill reservoirs continued yesterday to show a more marked drop than the Croton system, engineers prepared to force more Croton water into city conduits.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) --Following is the text of President Truman's letter today asking an increase in taxes:
WASHINGTON, July 25--Little more than half of the strategic materials that this country needs to fight an all-out war have been stockpiled or are on order, the Munitions Board told Congress today.

LONDON, July 25--A Permanent Steering Committee for the Atlantic pact defense organization came into being here today. It will immediately undertake the task of fortifying the Atlantic community against aggression.

In the face of recent home buying that has surpassed even the brisk business of the early postwar period, builders in the metropolitan area have started "rationing" sales in many of their developments.

The mobilization of national resources that is now just beginning cannot fail to have its effect on New York's public works programs. Shortages of manpower and construction materials will play their part in curtailing or reshaping these programs.

WASHINGTON, July 25--President Truman asked Congress today for a $5,000,000,000 increase in taxes on individuals and corporations to stem inflation and help finance military costs pending development of a more comprehensive tax program.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months to June 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges of $39,837,309. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.53 a share on the outstanding common stock.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 25 (AP)-- A brown half-brother to the stakes winners Navy Chief and Fond Embrace brought $20,500 today to top the second day bidding at the Keeneland summer thoroughbred yearling sales.

WITH THE FIRST CAVALRY, in South Korea, July 25--Forward elements of the First Cavalry Division, fighting gamely against wave after wave of enemy infantry assaulting frontally and on the left flank, were forced to fall back to new defense positions behind Yongdong late Tuesday.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., July 25--A long, 227-pound tuna was the only one boated during the first day of the state of Maine tuna tournament, which opened this morning at Boothbay Harbor, although several large tuna were hooked and lost during the day.
MILWAUKEE, July 25 (AP)--A worker at the Seaman automobile body plant who signed a Communist-sponsored "Stockholm peace petition" was carried from the factory today and dropped into the street.

CHICAGO, July 25--Grain and lard futures soared on the Board of Trade here today, with all deliveries of corn, rye, soybeans and lard at new seasonal highs. Soybeans led the advance and finished 10 cents a bushel higher, the maximum rise permitted for one day.

TOKYO, July 25--While the military crisis in Korea holds the center of the stage, the influence of the United States forces on the political situation within that country may prove a more serious problem in the long run.
