To avoid a factional fight in a state election year, John Cashmore, Brooklyn Borough President, made known yesterday his willingness to resign as Kings County Democratic leader, provided that County Clerk Francis J. Sinnott was elected to succeed him.

WARSAW, July 25--The American defeats in Korea are teaching the Poles that "people's armies" defending just causes are "invincible," Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky, Polish Minister of Defense, told a conference of the ...

TOKYO, July 25 (AP)--The United States Eighth Army announced today that correspondents covering the Korean war no longer had to submit their stories for a security check, but warned that "criticism of command decisions or of the conduct of allied soldiers on the battlefield will not be tolerated."

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., has been returned to office by a majority of more than five to one after one of the most bitter election campaigns in the union's history.

Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $60,805,199 for the first six months of 1950, equal to $2.11 a share, on the 28,806,344 shares of capital stock outstanding.

Advertising in newspapers in fifty-two cities during the first six months of this year totaled 1,198,205,123 lines, a gain of 5.2 per cent over the corresponding period of last year, according to Media Records. All classifications were up as follows: automotive, 17.1 per cent; ...

JACKSON, Miss., July 25--The Governor and the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Mississippi spent two hours today parrying questions in a public hearing with six "visitors" seeking a stay of execution for a Negro convicted of raping a white woman.

PARIS, July 25--Premier Rene Pleven told the Finance Committee of the Assembly today that the North Atlantic defense system should be financed by a "common fund" to which each country would contribute according to its national income.

WASHINGTON, July 25--The Federal Reserve Board informed Congress today that prompt approval of President Truman's recommendations for mortgage and consumer-credit controls was "imperative" to avert "serious problems of gray markets and spiraling prices."

Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, announced yesterday that the city's ferry service between Whitehall Street and Staten Island would be fully equipped with radar equipment by the first of next year.

E. Coster Wilmerding, a retired stockbroker, who had long been well known in New York society, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 103 East Seventy-fifth Street, from the effects of a cerebral hemorrhage suffered early in the morning. He was 72 years old on May 1.

CENTRE ISLAND, L.I., July 25--Three races were held in the Syce Cup Series for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today, with the Larchmont Yacht Club winning the first and the American Y.C. capturing the second and third in the Sound off the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club.

CHICAGO, July 25--Final details covering about $120,000,000 of financing for the Texas Illinois Natural Gas Pipeline Company, an affiliate of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company, Chicago, were completed today at a meeting at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank.

WASHINGTON, July 25--Dr. V.K. Wellington Koo, Ambassador of China, spent two hours at the State Department today for a full delineation of United States policy toward Formosa prior to his departure Friday for a two-week consultation with his Government at Taipei.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25-- "Aladdin's Luck," a screen comedy by Ben Roberts and Liam O'Brien which Columbia bought last fall as a vehicle for Larry Parks, has been switched to the schedule of Robert Cummings, the studio announced today.

Broadway's Great White Way is to get a new spectacle--a 150-foot tower, topped by a colored star visible for five miles in all directions, on the roof of the twentyfive story Mutual Life Building at Fifty-fifth Street.

Without any apparent decision having been reached on calling Mayor O'Dwyer, the holdover Brooklyn grand jury is to meet again today to hear District Attorney Miles F. McDonald. The jurors had questioned the Kings County prosecutor on Monday about the Mayor's criticism of his investigation into police-gambling tie-ups.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP)--Two men whose automobile the police said contained briefcases filled with "peace campaign" pamphlets and other propaganda were held in $20,000 bail today for a further hearing.

WASHINGTON, July 25--New peacetime peaks in both production and construction were reached during June, the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System reported today. The board's production index reached 199 for June, a gain of four points, compared with the preceding month.

Liberally spiced with such college favorites as plaids, gray flannel, jumpers, separates outfits, reversible coats and jackets, and fake furs, a lively presentation at Bloomingdale's yesterday led off the forthcoming series of back-tocollege showings.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25--Voluntary security measures, designed to bar Communists from American merchant vessels, are expected to go into effect in all West Coast ports "in a few days," Coast Guard spokesmen said here today.

WASHINGTON, July 25--A statement by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan that he approved an anti-inflationary device that would permit selling of government-owned food surpluses back into the market at current wholesale prices brought bitter ...
CANTON, Ohio, July 25 (AP)-- An anti-strike act which forbids strikes of public employes in Ohio was put to a new test today. About 240 city workers "resigned" to back demands for pay raises.

WASHINGTON, July 25--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy attacked a "Mr. X" today as a Communist in the State Department and the accused person was otherwise identified as Edward G. Posniak.
STOCKHOLM, July 25--Sweden and Denmark have formally challenged the right of the Soviet Union to declare arbitrarily a twelve-mile territorial limit in Baltic waters.

LONDON, July 25--Certain European air experts who have been studying the Communists' use of massed tanks and artillery in Korea think the way to defend Western Europe from similar onslaughts is by fleets of mass-produced light rocket bombers acting in close support of infantry.

The no-increase pattern that has prevailed in most branches of the textile industry for the last two years was broken yesterday. Fifteen thousand members of the Textile Workers Union, C.I.O., employed in seven plants of the American Viscose Corporation, won wage increases averaging 11 cents an hour.
WASHINGTON, July 25--The Michigan-Wisconsin Pipe Line Company of Detroit today received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission to borrow up to $20,000,000 from three banks.

WASHINGTON, July 25--A complaint charging five Standard Oil companies and the Atlas Supply Company of Newark, N.J., with monopolistic practices in the purchase and resale of tires, batteries and other automobile accessories has been issued by the Federal Trade Commission.
When it comes to choosing the home accessory that is most used, the ashtray seems to take top honors. It must give constant service and always be a decorative asset.

The brief work stoppage by 1,500 employes of the Brooklyn and Hoboken yards of the Todd Shipyards Corporation appeared to be near an end last night as members of one of the two union locals involved agreed to return to work this morning.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 26-- Hard-fighting American defenders behind Yongdong again pulled back their lines today as the North Korean Communist invaders resumed their tank, infantry and infiltration attacks.

LONDON, July 25--Should the Government decide on a rearmament program, British industry would be in a much better condition to take up the strain than it was in the Nineteen Thirties. In deciding each year since the end of the war how the national income was to be spent, the Government has allocated a substantial share to industrial expansion and re-equipment.

WASHINGTON, July, 25--The impending $10,000,000,000 to $20,000,000,000 rearmament program will not solve the Atlantic community's dollar crisis, but it will probably minimize, postpone and obscure it for a while.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 5-- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century, adding an 83 to her tournament record first-round score of 75 for a total of 158, took a fourteen-stroke lead in the Elizabeth Wheeler 54-hole medal-play golf competition over the Quaker Ridge course today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (U.P.)-- About ninety of the 290 war veterans in the House of Representatives and the Senate are members of military reserve units, but defense officials said today they would not go into uniform unless they volunteered.

The announcement yesterday that Australia has offered ground troops for the United Nations forces in Korea gives, added reason to welcome the Australian Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies to the United States. He arrives today and is going straight to Washington to see President Truman.

Orders for machine tools have risen more rapidly in the last two weeks than in any similar period in the last three years. Some plants in the industry are able to fill orders only on a twelve-month delivery basis, it was disclosed yesterday.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., July 26--Although tons of herring and whiting chum were fed to the ebb and flood tides by anglers on a score of boats, the second day of the State of Maine tuna tournament was concluded with nothing more substantial than would have been produced by a regatta.

BILOXI, Miss., July 26--The execution of Willie McGee, 37-yearold Mississippi Negro convicted of raping a white woman, was stayed temporarily today after a series of dramatic court actions on three fronts.
WASHINGTON, July 26--Bernard M. Baruch called today for immediate all-out national mobilization that would include blanket price, wage and rent controls as well as rationing.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 27-- United States and South Korean troops took up the offensive yesterday against North Korean invaders who swept down the west coast of Korea and were moving eastward against the defenders' supply lines running north from the landing port of Pusan.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 26--Pakist n came out strongly in the United Nations Little Assembly today against an apparent growing conviction among delegates here for some kind of unification between Ethiopia and Eritrea Italy's former colony in Africa.

Hope rose last night that the strike of 1,100 truck drivers that has brought construction in the metropolitan area to a virtual standstill would be over in time to permit resumption of deliveries by Monday.

DURHAM, N.H., July 26--Mrs. Dorothy S. Towle, writer, editor and radio speaker and wife of Prof. Carroll S. Towle of the University of New Hampshire, died yesterday afternoon at the Wentworth Hospital in Dover after an illness of several weeks. She was 43 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP) --Security measures designed to guard Pacific Coast ports against "Trojan horse" ships that might be carrying atomic bombs were reported to be in effect today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 26 --Mrs. Helen Pastall Perez of Encino Park, Calif., defeated Miss Dorothy Watman today as the Women's Invitation Tennis. Tournament opened at the Maidstone Club. Mrs Perez, the top-seeded star, was carried to a deuce second set, winning by 6--1, 7--5.

PARIS, July 26--Paulette calls her fall millinery collection a parade of the Middle Ages. The heart-shaped hennin, a Flemish headdress of the period, but in a flattened version is the inspiration for her large evening hats of panne velvet that spread into a gracious, undulating point at either side.

On July 1, 1949--more than a year ago--Mayor O'Dwyer approved a test of parking meters, although admittedly skeptical of their benefits. It was December before a Council committee got around to a public hearing on a law to establish an experimental program.

Brooklyn's racket-investigating grand jury and District Attorney Miles F. McDonald declared yesterday that they would not be "intimidated" by outside pressure in conducting their inquiry into tieups between the police and gamblers.
FRANKFORT, Germany, July 26 (AP)--American companies are placing large orders for steel from West Germany as a result of the Korean war, it was learned today.

Streets of Ottawa Are Filled as Funeral Service Is Held for Former Prime Minister. OTTAWA, July 26 (Canadian Press)--William Lyon Mackenzie King, confrere of the great and friend of the humble, made his last journey today from Parliament Hill.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 40 to 65 points yesterday in a heavy volume of business.

Charles Bunda has sold the twenty-eight-family apartment house at 40-69 Ninety-fourth Street, Elmhurst, Queens, to Hugo Jansen and Alfred Tomson. The property, on a plot 60 by 100 feet, is assessed at $80,000. Title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

A number of additional rentals were reported by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States in its Fordham Hill project at University Heights. The development consists of nine sixteen-story buildings at Webb and Sedgwick Avenues near West Fordham Road.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26-- Eddie Albert was signed today by Paramount to play Drouet, the second male character, in the screen version of Theodore Dreiser's novel, "Sister Carrie," which William Wyler will produce and direct next month. Ruth and Augustus Goetz have completed the screen ...

WASHINGTON, July 26--President Truman reported to Congress today that the country was enjoying record-breaking prosperity, with national output at $267,000,000,000. He added, however, that a mighty expansion of United States production was necessary to cope ...

Members of the Kings County Democratic executive committee will receive this morning telegrams, signed by Borough President John Cashmore, calling a meeting of the committee at noon tomorrow at the Democratic county headquarters; 4-5 Court Square.

GUATEMALA, July 26--The three-day general, strike caused by election campaign violence ended this afternoon after a conference among the head of the Army, a group of merchants and representatives of the university.
NEWARK, July 26 (AP)--The New Jersey State Federation of Labor--the state arm of the A.F.L.--today ordered its members to be on the alert for any evidence of subversive activity in defense plants.

Complete revision of the American Standard Safety Code for Mechanical Refrigeration has resulted from intensive investigation of the safety of refrigeration equipment, covering both its design and installation.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- Following is the text of President Truman's Mid-year Economic Report to Congress: To the Congress of the United States:

Actors Equity Association and Chorus Equity Association announced yesterday that they would "enter into independent contracts with individual producers, embodying the terms to which the League of New York Theatres refused to agree."

CHICAGO, July 26--Hotpoint, Inc., which has more than tripled the number of its plants, employes, and dealers since 1947, made and sold more electric appliances in the first six months of 1950 than in any previous half year.

Despite insistence by liquor suppliers that no shortages exist in domestic whisky supplies, operators of large package stores reported yesterday that a surge of Christmas buying by commercial organizations developed here this week.
LONDON, July 26--Britain's immediate additional contributions to the defense of Southern Korea and reinforcements of Western Europe were announced today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The battle for Korea has led to a great deal of talk about our "failure to balance commitments with capabilities," but this old bromide is dangerously misleading. Our real need is not so much a greater arsenal as a new approach in using the military capabilities we now have.

LONDON, July 26--Color contrasts and the use of handsome metallic fabrics for cocktails and evening were two interesting features in fall collections shown yesterday. The battle of waistlines also continues.

WASHINGTON, July 26--Joseph B. Lehmann of the American Council of Voluntary Agencies told the Agriculture Committee of the House of Representatives today that the Govermnent could channel all its spoilable egg and dairy surpluses into foreign relief by paying the transportation to shipside.

By a careless oversight, "The Voice of America" is carrying summaries of Communist radio and newspaper attacks on the United states. To add to the irony, it is theoretically a criminal offense for an American citizen to mention the broadcast, even though they can be heard by the whole world.

Felix E. Kahn, retired banker, former director of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, and a younger brother of the late Otto H. Kahn, former senior member of Kuhh, Loeb Co., bankers, this city, died Tuesday at his summer home, Kneisel Hall, in Blue Hill, Me. He was 75 years old.

Election of two new members to the public policy committee of the Advertising Council was announced yesterday by Samuel C. Gale, council chairman. They are Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the department of trusteeship and information from non-self-governing territories ...

CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP)--The Indians climbed to within a game and a half of the first-place Tigers tonight by trouncing the Athletics 6 to 2. It was Cleveland's ninth straight victory over Philadelphia.

PARIS, July 26--The French National Assembly approved today, 390 to 182, a budget for a Commissariat on Germany and thereby indirectly gave endorsement to negotiations for the Schuman plan. The 193 negative votes represented solid Communist opposition to the budget.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Jul. 26 (AP) --George D. Widener's Battlefield won the fifth running of the Sapling Stakes at Monmouth Park today as Mrs. Sara Chait's previously unbeaten Lord Putnam finished third. Dividing the pair was J.J. Colando's Uncle Miltie.

BERLIN, July 26--One of the most infamous "courts" in history is operating in Waldheim in Saxony under the supervision of the Soviet secret police, according to Frau Gertrud Mielke, who recently arrived in West Berlin after having been a court stenographer there for three months.

Since the beginning of the cold war Bernard M. Baruch has campaigned unremittingly for the enactment of comprehensive stand-by laws which could transform the entire economy from a peace basis to a war basis overnight in response to a simple joint proclamation of the President and Congress.

An issue of $2,500,000 of school bonds of Pulaski County, Va., was placed on the market yesterday by a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at prices to yield from 1.05 per cent to 2.20 per cent. The issue, which will come due Jan. 1, 1952 to l970, was ..

Sal Maglie, the Mexican League returnee who has risen from bull pen obscurity to a position of prominence on Leo Durocher's staff, yesterday pitched and batted the Giants to their second straight one-run triumph over the Reds at the Polo Grounds.
The crude rubber futures market on the Commodity Exchange yesterday failed to follow the spectacular price rises of 3 d a pound in London and 3 23/32 d a pound in the Singapore primary market.

PARIS, July 26--Premier Rene Pleven wound up a two-day foreign affairs debate in the National Assembly today by a brief statement in general terms that was found disappointing by those who had expected him to make an important declaration.

WITH THE FIRST CAVALRY, in South Korea, July 26--Under an assault by seemingly endless waves of Communist infantry, determined G.I.'s of this division slowly yielded ground here today to take up new positions along ,the perimeter southwest and north of Hwanggan, fifty miles north of Taegu.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined a further 2,824,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 108,915,000 barrels, compared with 1ll,739,000 a week earlier and 110,569,000 a year ago.

LONDON, July 26--In simple terms the job facing the Atlantic pact Council of Deputies, which held its second session in secret here today, is to decide how a Western Allied force of thirty-six divisions can be raised, trained and equipped to defend Western ...
NEW MARKET, N.J., July 26-- On a ninety-acre tract sprawling over the farming country of Middlesex County here, a small city has risen virtually over night.

TRENTON, July 26--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll issued orders today for special elections to fill vacancies in Assembly places in Essex and Gloucester counties. The balloting will take place simultaneously with the general election Nov. 7.
Democratic primary voters defeated the veteran Senator Elmer Thomas in Oklahoma and two first term House members in South Carolina in Tuesday's balloting, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

The electric power industry is ready to meet any immediate demands that industrial mobilization may place on it, providing the electric companies receive the necessary help from the Government in obtaining manpower and materials for their current construction program.

A strong protest against the present method of bareboat chartering Government-owned vessels to private operators, for time charter by them to the Military Sea Transportation Service, has been sent to John T. Koehler, acting head of the Maritime Administration, by Hans J. Isbrandtsen, veteran shipowner.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS in South Korea, July 28--There are reasons for believing the decisive battles of the Korean campaign are being fought now or are close at hand.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 26--Lebanon told the United Nations today that an Israeli fighter plane had made an "unwarranted and premeditated attack" on a Lebanese transport plane last Monday.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One shouldn't expect too much from census takers who were recruited from a political organization, in the instances below from the Democratic party.

William F. Smith, an assistant district attorney of Bronx County since 1933, and previously an Assemblyman for eight terms from the Second District, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital, Manhattan, after a long illness at the age of 49. His home was at 314 East 140th Street.
City water storage fell to an even 91 per cent of capacity in the twenty-four hours ended 8 A.M, yesterday, losing 615,000,000 gallons in that period.
BRUSSELS, July 26--With strikes spreading and more news of railway sabotage in Wallonia, King Leopold summoned Roger Motz, chairman of the Liberal party, to the Paiace of Laeken today.
GENEVA, July 26--It as virtually certain that the life of the International Refugee Organization will be extended beyond the theoretical deadline of March 31, 1951.

BONN, Germany, July 26--The German Bundestag, in a show of wholehearted identification with the Western unity program, approved virtually unanimously today a resolution in favor of a Furo. pean--federation with legislative and executive authority to bring about peace and social justice on the Continent.

A cold soup on a warm day has two roles--either as the center of attraction at lunch or supper, buttressed with a salad and dessert, or as the frosty prelude to dinner. Today recipes for several such chillers are offered, attractive not only because of their general appetite appeal, but because they are so exceedingly easy to turn out. Some rely on canned soups.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 26-- A Turkish Army combat unit, roughly equivalent to an American regimental combat team, placed at the disposal of the United Nations last night, will be ready to embark for Korea as soon as the United Nations provides the necessary shipping.

Warnings to motorists to exercise the utmost caution to avoid causing forest fires were issued yesterday by the New York State division of safety, United States Forest Service, and the Automobile Club of New York.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 27--(UP) Release No. 150 issued by Gen. Douglas MacArthur at 1:25 P.M., Thursday (11:25 P.M., Wednesday, Eastern daylight time):

Cigarette smokers by the end of the week will be paying up to 1 cent more a package for most popular brands, tobacco trade executives predicted yesterday.

Pierre Monteux, conductor of the San Francisco Symphony, had his regular concertmaster as soloist in Lewisohn Stadium last night. The violinist, Naoum Blinder, in his Stadium debut; the conductor and the Philharmonic-Symphony had a meeting of the minds and the result was one of the most felicitous occasions in recent memory.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 27-- American soldiers in Korea have had to contend with new and unfamiliar weapons especially developed for warfare in that country.

DETROIT, July 26 (AP)--Lefthander Mel Parnell of the Red Sox, troubled with a sore shoulder in recent days, knocked off the American League-leading-Detroit Tigers, 1 to 0, with a nifty five-hitter today.

WASHINGTON, July 26--The British, Australian and New Zealand offers of badly needed ground forces for Gen. Douglas MacArthur's United Nations campaign in defense of Korea were warmly received by several spokesmen for the Administration today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: When announcement first was made that New York City planned rain-making experiments over the Catskills area, residents of that area were slightly apprehensive, but today they are gravely concerned.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)-- United States members of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization have called on that organization to take "vigorous action" in support of the United Nations efforts to defend South Korea against the Communist invasion.

Seven units of the New York National Guard here have been alerted for active duty, to begin about Aug. 14. Five are antiaircraft artillery and two are radar units. Meanwhile tire Marines called up three more units of the corps' Organized Reserve.

Deposits in the nation's mutual savings banks rose $652,000,000, or 3.3 per cent, in the first six months of this year. Total deposits on June 30, according to a report issued yesterday by A. Livingston Kelley, president of the National Association yof Mutual Savings Banks, amounted to $19,939,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Judy 26--The unity committees of the American Federation of Labor and of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today authorized a subcommittee to draft the program for "next steps" in a possible laborpeace plan.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 26 (UP)--The Yugoslav Government soon will announce a change in attitude toward the Korean war by denouncing the North Korean attack as "aggression," well-informed source said today.

The Bowery Savings Bank made a construction loan of $1,591,700 to Saxony Apartments, Inc., sponsor of five six-story elevator apartment buildings going up on Thirtyfourth Avenue and Eighty-sixth, Eighty-seventh and Eighty-eighth Streets in Jackson Heights, Queens.

HONG KONG, July 26--Thousands of Chinese who fled to British Hong Kong from the civil war are returning to the Communistcontrolled mainland. It is estimated that almost 3,000 are leaving daily, while others are pulling wires in an attempt to get Nationalist clearance for travel to Formosa.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 26--Britain, Australia and New Zealand announced today that they would put ground troops under United Nations command to fight alongside United States soldiers in Korea.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn, July 26--A powerful new turbojet aircraft engine, completely American in design, has been built and suc cessfully flown by Pratt Whitney Aircraft, a division of United Aircraft Corporation.

No significant change is visible in the market atmosphere which has surrounded the market for United States Government obligations since the Korean outbreak. Buoyancy in the bank-ineligible bonds continues to be held in check by offerings from the Federal Reserve System.

Mahon of Texas, chairman of, the Appropriations subcommittee in charge of the bill, well described the American dilemma which was at last resolved by the Communist attack on South Korea. Said Mr. Mahon:
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 26 (AP)--Capt. Austin E. Lathrop, 84year-old northern Alaska capitalist and publisher, was killed today when he slipped off a coal car and was crushed by its wheels.

WASHINGTON, July 26--The Army disclosed today that its call for critically needed doctors on a voluntary basis had met with very poor response. There were indications that a mandatory call for Reserve medical officers would become necessary.
WASHINGTON, July 26--Presi dent Truman today signed the bil authorizing $1,222,500,000 for the second year of military assistance to nations opposing the spread of Communism.

CLINTON, N.Y., July 26--Governor Dewey called today for the creation of a vast international army, manned by troops from all free countries and led by the United Nations, to meet the world threw of Communist aggression and forestall a catastrophic global conflict.

WYTHEVILLE, Va., July 26 (U.P.) --Basil O'Connor, president of the National Infantile paralysis Foundation, said today that the outbreak of polio here in which ten persons had died was the most serious epidemic in the history of the foundation.
Edward B. Nitchie has been named director of manufacturing of the Durkee Famous Foods division of the Glidden Company. He formerly was an executive assistant in the Durkee headquarters office.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 26-- The marriage of Miss Rita Dorothea Purdy, daughter of Mrs. Theron Charles Purdy of Stamford and the late Mr. Purdy, to David Mahany Mittendorf, son of Mrs. Ella M. Mittendorf of Greenwich and Dr. Alfred D. Mittendorf...

Funds to buy the 22,000-acre Phipps estate on Barnegat Peninsula must be found quickly if that ten-mile stretch of ocean front is to be preserved as a recreation area and wildlife sanctuary. This was disclosed yesterday by Richard H. Pough, chairman of a committee ...

Key city officials attended aclassroom session on disaster yesterday. Invited to study the implications of atomic attack on New York, they met under auspices of the New York operations office of the Atomic Energy Commission at 70 Columbus Avenue.
WASHINGTON, July 26--Forty-eight additional fighting ships have been ordered back into active service to meet American commitments in the Far East and elsewhere, if necessary.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26--The probable effect of the Korean conflict on their colleges in this country was considered today by delegates to the twelfth annual convention here of the Christian Brothers' Education Association at La Salle College.

Some large Eastern electronics parts makers have canceled their peacetime orders voluntarily to cooperate with war production contractors in emergency output for national defense. No official priority steps from Washington were taken, ton executives in electronics plants said yesterday.

With earnings for the second quarter and the first half of 1950 sharply higher than the same periods of last year, directors of the Inland Steel Company yesterday voted an extra dividend of 50 cents a share on the capital stock in addition to the usual quarterly payment of the same amount.

The city was informed yesterday that the state was prepared to lend it $83,000,000 for seven new housing projects and to provide an additional $145,250,000 in outright grants to keep rents low during a fifty-year period.

The city opened bids for the proposed new stonework job on City Hall yesterday and found the lowest bid on the cheapest specifications about $500,000 above the engineers' advance estimate and the budget for the improvement.

PARIS, July 26--A quick review of the millinery mode made by this writer in these first two days in Paris has given her an all-over impression of the fall and winter hat picture. First of all, this city does not visualize big hats save for dressy occasions. Hats remain small though well poised on the head.

WASHINGTON, July 26--Hans Christian Sonne of New York, chairman of the board of trustees 'of the National Planning Association, was named today head of an eight-man group of experts to advise the German Government on how to deal with its refugee problem.

WASHINGTON, July 26--The Republican leaders of Congress drew together today in determination to modify the economic controls asked by President Truman but to support powers they believed adequate to meet the crisis.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 26 --The tennis season's outstanding winning streak was brought to an end today as Herbert Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., was beaten by Dr. Arnold Beisser of San Francisco in the Southampton Invitation Tournament at the Meadow Club.
WASHINGTON, July 26--Strong bipartisan support for tax increases based on President Truman's recommendations appeared certain today as Republican leaders conceded the need for more revenues.

Frederick Browr has resold to an investing client of Pearce Mayer, brokers, the business property at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Eightyfourth Street, known was 1241-9 Lexington Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP)-- Walt Dubiel faltered in the sixth inning tonight, walking six men and allowing two hits, as the Phillies scored all of their runs for a 6-4 victory over the Cubs. The victory increased the Phils' National League lead to one and onehalf games.

Now men's tennis has its glamour boy to give Gussle some real competition as a magnet of the first magnitude for those who ...

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 26 (AP)--Dick McIntyre of Seattle and Toronto's Jack Guest Jr. shared the limelight today in opening sculling events of the four-day Royal Canadian Henley Regatta. Both were double-heat winners.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 26-- With fine rounds of 75, 83, 79--237, Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century retained the Elizabeth Wheeler 54-hole medal play trophy emblematic of the women's open championship of Westchester and Fairfield counties as the tourney was completed over the Quaker Ridge course today.

RYE, N.Y., July 26--The distinction of being the only golfer in the field to break par also-carried medal honors for Mal Galletta of North Hills, who scored a 71 over the Apawamis Club course in the qualifying round of the metropoliton amateur championship today.

The dispute within the International Longshoremen's Association; A.F.L., over control of pierto-truck loading work still kept the Jersey City piers idle yesterday, with no settlement in sight. The fight is now in its fourth week, but is localized after having spread to other New Jersey docks about ten days ago.

AN ADVANCED AIRBASE in South Korea, July 26(AP)--A grim young corporal said today he and three other American prisoners were bound by North Koreans, forced to lie face down under a tree, and then machine-gunned.

CHICAGO, July 26--A large blooming mill, produced in the East Chicago (Ind.) and Wheeling (W. Va.) plants of the Continental Foundry and Machine Company, is being dismantled and prepared for shipment via the port of New York to Zenica, Yugoslavia, next month, company spokesmen said today.
There was a touch of Scarborough Downs to the Saratoga Association's racing program at Jamaica yesterday. All eight races were minimum-purse affairs and seven were claimers.
TOKYO, July 26--Spokesmen for Gen. Dougles MacArthur's headquarters expressed today a degree of cautious confidence in the defenders' ability to hold key positions in South Korea.
ROME, July 26 (AP)--Following is the text of an unofficial translation of the Pope's new encyclical:
NORRISTOWN, Pa., July 26 (AP) --Machinery needed by a concern making apparatus for the Atomic Energy Commission was removed today from a strike-bound factory.
Mediation conferences intended to bring about settlement of the six-week-old strike on The New York World-Telegram and Sun were recessed indefinitely yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, July 26--The Yankees, it seems, are about to develop a new mound duo that may become as successful as last year's Allie Reynolds-Joe Page tandem.

CLEVELAND, July 26--The Rev. D.F. Townley Lord, pastor of the Bloomsbury Baptist Church of London, was elected today to serve as president of the World Baptist Alliance until the Golden Anniversary Congress to be held in London in 1955.

ROME, July 27--The Soviet Union and other Communist states have either killed or imprisoned more than 13,000 priests and members or religious orders since the end of the war, the Vatican radio said today.

WASHINGTON, July 27--The Senate Crime Investigating Committee warned racketeers today that it intended to keep a sharp eye on any attempted entry into black market activities during the economic dislocations that might result from the Korean campaign.
DETROIT, July 27 (AP)--The veteran Paul (Dizzy) Trout turned back the Boston Red Sox, 5-1, on a neat nine-hitter today to protect the Detroit Tigers' slender American League lead.
Manufacturers of skirts and blouses in New York will again import Parisian styles directly through their trade associations. This was made known yesterday after a telephone talk between B.

WASHINGTON, July 27--In a direct blow at sugar hoarders, the United States has arranged to buy Cuba's entire reserve stock of sugar of 600,000 short tons, the Department of Agriculture announced tonight.

Anthony B. Farrell and Eddie bowling have acquired the rights to "Angel in the Pawnshop" and are making plans to produce the play on Broadway this fall. Mr. Farrell and Mr. Dowling joined in obtaining the rights to the drama after the Theatre Guild dropped its option.

Alternately smirking and cursing, 17-year-old Stanley Openshaw, accused of the fatal shooting of his father, Martin, 70, an importer, was committed yesterday to Matteawan State Hospital at Beacon, N. Y. He appeared in Bronx County Court in a straitjacket.

The Crusade for Freedom, which is headed by Gen. Lucius D. Clay and sponsored by the National Committee for a Free Europe, offers American men and women, as private citizens, the opportunity to participate in a campaign "to demonstrate before all the world our true aims of freedom and friendship for all peoples."
George F. Dewey, president of H. T. Dewey Sons, well-known wine merchants at 138 Fulton Street, has died at Feura Bush, near Albany, N.Y., according to word received here yesterday. His age was 73.

An epochal advance in the educational use of radio was made last night at 9 o'clock with the opening of the New York Academy of Medicine's series, "For Doctors Only," over the city's frequency modulation station, WNYC-FM.

A sharp exchange of opinion between Judge Nathan R. Sobel and the prosecution on the merits of the state's case against Acting Lieut. James F. Reilly marked the closing phases of the trial of the police official yesterday in Kings County Court.
TOKYO, Friday, July 28 (AP)-- Japanese fishermen today found the wreckage of a transport plane that plunged into the sea eighty miles south of Tokyo yesterday with twenty-six persons aboard.

The Hoover Commission estimated that if the President gave even as hour a week to each of the departments, agencies and other non-regulatory bodies of the Federal Government he would thereby lay himself out a sixtyfive-hour work week. This would be in addition to the vital policy-forming duties of the Presidency.

Heavy attacks were made along the fronts of the Twenty-fifth Infantry and First Cavalry Divisions in recent action reported. The Communist invaders have employed heavy artillery and their attacks have been supported with some tanks.
Sales of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company in the first half of 1950 rose to a new high record while earnings were $3,788,037 above the net for the previous year.

The people in charge of the Stadium Concerts can guarantee many things: an orchestra of high caliber, virtuoso soloists, internationally known conductors and a wide-ranging program to please a variety of tastes.
PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 22 (AP)--The host St. Catharines Club piled up 71 points today to take a wide lead in the sixtyeighth annual Royal Canadian Henley Regatta.

WASHINGTON, July 27--The United States Air Force has set out to build up from forty-eight to sixty-nine groups. The goal is one short of the seventy-group Air Force plan that has caused controversy between the Executive Branch and the Congress for almost two years.
John E. Raasch, president of Wanamaker's, said yesterday that its "Million Dollar Sale" was one of the most successful ever held by the store.
Prices of cotton futures rose 3 to 25 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, with a moderate volume of business.
WASHINGTON, July 27-- President Truman said today he would send his second request to Congress for additional taxes after the members of Congress came back from the election next fall.
BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., July 27--A 541-pound tuna boated this afternoon put Ogden W. Headington in first place in the State of Maine tuna tournament, which will end tomorrow.

The Brooklyn grand jury and the District Attorney have taken the only possible position in response to Mayor O'Dwyer's criticisms. They will proceed, with their investigation of any connections between police and gamblers.

BONN, Germany, July 27--A long brewing conflict between capital and labor in West Germany came to the forefront in the Bundestag today on a debate over a law that would give workers the right to codetermine with management the economic as well as welfare policies in industry.
Large orders for European machine tools are now being placed by American plants, with prompt deliveries sought of equipment needed for national defense production.
WASHINGTON, July 27--Organized labor appears to be on the road toward fulfillment of its desire to be represented on all Government boards and agencies handling war mobilization policy.

TOKYO, Friday, July 28--A "planned interdiction campaign" has been under way for five days in an endeavor to sever the North Koreans' supply lines to the front, a United States Air Force spokesman announced here yesterday. It is carried out primarily by Japanbased B-29's.

The tanker committee of the American Merchant Marine Institute has taken action to induce the Cairo Government to repeal a new Egyptian customs ruling that it believes to be "impracticable, unworkable, objectionable" and beyond the authority of that country.

RYE, N.Y., July 27--Although a number of favorites advanced through the two opening matchplay rounds in the Metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Apawamis Club course today, the defending titleholder, Joe McBride of Arcola, was not among them.

Anyone furnishing a home on a budget may find some encouragement, as well as inspiration, in the model apartment at McCreery's Summer Furniture Show, which opens today. A living room, dining room and two bedrooms are furnished with a new group of sensibly priced furniture designed by Manuel Martin of California.

WASHINGTON, July 27--A financing proposal involving upwards of $50,000,000 made today by the Duquesne Light Company and the Philadelphia Company, both of Pittsburgh, will be heard by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Aug. 8.

Willie Pep, veteran boxer from Hartford, Conn., signed yesterday to defend his world featherweight championship against Sandy Saddler of Harlem. The pair will meet in a fifteen-round bout at the Yankee Stadium on Sept. 6. Promoter...

SAN JOSE, Calif., July 27-- James Augustus Bacigalupi, former president of the Transamerica Corporation and the Bank of Italy, predecessor of the Bank of America, died of heart attack today at O'Connor Hospital. He was 67 years old.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27-- A deal is in negotiation for Humphrey Bogart to play the male lead in "The African Queen," a photoplay which John Huston and John Collier are writing from a novel by C.S. Forester, and which Huston's company, Horizon Pictures, expects to produce next spring.

Pakistan is likely to devalue its currency in the near future and thus eliminate the trade block with neighboring India, Sir Chunilal B. Mehta, Bombay industrialist and banker, now visiting the United States, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 27--A seven-point program aimed at cutting the estimated $555,000,000 Post Office Department deficit more than in half, "without reducing postal services by one iota" was presented to Congress by the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report today.
WASHINGTON, July 27--The Federal Government moved further today to tighten protection against subversive elements in the emergency.
LONDON, July 27--Several scientists, most of them American, reported here today that supervoltage X-ray machines were causing otherwise untreatable and hopeless cancers to shrink up and disappear.
LONDON, July 27--In somber phrases Winston Churchill, the Jeremiah of 1939, warned this nation today of a military threat from the Soviet Union more menacing than that of Nazi Germany.

Dr. Fred Wise, former president of the American Dermatological Association, died Wednesday in Memorial Hospital after a long illness. His age was 68. He resided at 55 Central Park West and had his office at 870 Fifth Avenue.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 27 (AP) --Skip Alexander, the former Duke University star, smashed out a record 63 today to take the lead at the end of eighteen holes in the Sioux City open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 27--The Federal Reserve Board today reported a record rise in department store sales. For the week ended July 22 the dollar value of sales was 46 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year.
The four-week tie-up of Jersey City piers took on additional legal complications yesterday.

A new colony of 120 ranch style houses is planned by Moss Sons, builders, on a tract in Garden City, L.I., which they purchased from Realty Associates of Brooklyn. The property fronts the Garden City Country Club and is bounded on the east by New Hyde Park Road.

Before a brilliant gathering that packed his garden, Jacques Fath presented his fall and winter collection tonight. It was evident that the Fath theme of the season, the "Lily" flared skirt, brings grace of movement to the wearer.

There should be "no concern whatsoever" over steel supply and the industry's productive capacity in the present national emergency, E.G. Grace, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, declared yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 27 --Miss Maureen Connolly, 15-yearold national girls' champion from San Diego, Calif., had a real fight on her hands today in defeating Miss J.S.V. Partridge of England in the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club.

Assurance that war production would go forward without strikes at the Lake Success plant of the Sperry Gyroscope Company was contained in a three-year agreement reached last night by the company and the new International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C.I.O.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP)-- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, told the Senate today that Owen Lattimore, Far Eastern expert, had sold his summer home in Vermont to "avowed" Communists for an apparent profit of $3,000. He suggested the transaction might be a Communist "pay-off."
The semi-annual report of Standard Oil Company of California disclosed yesterday net income of $60,407,463 for the first half of 1950.

A 61-year-old man from Dorchester, Mass., shot and killed himself at 8:15 A.M. yesterday in a bus at the Greyhound Bus Terminal, 242 West Thirty-fourth Street. Although hundreds of persons were in the area, no one heard the shot.
TAIPEI, Formosa, July 27-- Contradictory communiques tonight reported unsuccessful Chinese Communist attempts to take Nationalist-held Taitan Island early today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 27 --Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., and Earl Cochell of San Francisco gained the semi-final round and Arthur Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., and Dr. Arnold Beisser of Santa Ana, Calif.,...
Eleven hundred sand and gravel truck drivers, whose nine-day-old strike has made 75,000 construction workers idle in the metropolitan area, voted yesterday to return to their jobs Monday morning.
LONDON, July, 27--The stock markets here were quietly dull today, having scarcely reacted yet to defense debates in the House of Commons.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 27 (AP) --James C. O'Hara's West Milton took the feature at Monmouth Park today, running six furlongs in 1:11 1/5 under Jockey Robert J. Martin.

New York City Housing Authority officials were inclined yesterday to take a long-range view of the state's offer on Wednesday of $83,000,000 in loan funds for seven projects. The offer was made by Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman, who also suggested sites for the seven developments.

CLINTON, N.Y., July 27--The New York State Republican Committee staged a full dress rehearsal of its fall election campaign today on the Hamilton College campus for the benefit of 300 politically enthusiastic high school and college students.

A new advance yesterday by the stock market was sustained and widespread. Under the leadership of the steels and oils, which set up sizable gains during the morning, the list faltered only slightly near the close.

CHICAGO, July 27--The Crusade for Freedom, a nation-wide campaign to mobilize the American people for getting the truth behind the Iron Curtain, will begin Sept. 4 and run for six weeks, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, national chairman of the crusade, announced here today.

Rodman Wanamaker, the department store executive, is an honorary Deputy Police Commissioner. In that role he became involved yesterday with a police helicopter, a drifting barge with a lone castaway, a police launch, a fireboat, an

AN AIR BASE in South Korea, July 27--Gen. Douglas MacArthur, United Nations commander, conferred with his top Army and Air Force commanders in Korea today and told reporters later that while "new heartaches and setbacks" were inevitable, he never felt more confident of ultimate victory in his life.

BONN, Germany, July 27--The West German Bundestag lifted the parliamentary immunity of Communist leader Max Reimann today. This paves the way for his projected indictment on charges of having kidnapped his former deputy, Kurt Mueller, who is now in a Soviet zone jail.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27--The marriage of Miss Barbara Littman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Littman of Woodberry House, London, to Albert M. Greenfield Jr., son of Albert M. Greenfield of Overbrook, and Mrs. Edna K. Paine of New York, took place at noon today in the home of the bridegroom's father.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27(AP)-- The Philadelphia Phillies held to their one-and-one-half-game lead in the National League race today as southpaw Curt Simmons racked up his fourteenth pitching victory with a 13-3 decision over the Chicago Cubs.
Mayor O'Dwyer signed a bill yesterday creating a Board of Hospitals to act as the top policymaking body for the Department of Hospitals.

WASHINGTON, July 27--Diplomats-in-exile of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania appealed to the United States today to support a United Nations investigation of "genocidal mass deportations" they said were being carried out in their countries by the Soviet Union.

The State Guard is to be activated as soon as possible to take the place of National Guard units called into Federal service. Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, commanding the National Guard, made this announcement yesterday after a meeting of his staff with State Guard commanders at headquarters, 270 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, July 27--The Banking and Currency Committee of the House of Representatives reported out President Truman's Economic Mobilization Bill today by a vote of 20 to 1. Only a few changes were made in the measure and none was basic.

CHICAGO, July 27--Grains showed a heavy undertone here today on the Board of Trade except for a brief early period. Final sales of wheat futures were well toward the bottom with losses of 2 1/8 to 2 cents; corn was cent higher to cent lower, the former on September; oats were unchanged

The plan of Lawrence T. Beck, engineer, backed by the Citizens Budget Commission, to tap the Hudson River for a virtually inexhaustible supply of water was rejected yesterday by the Board of Water Supply.

TOKYO, Friday, July 28--Gen. Douglas MacArthur's latest communique on the fighting in the central sector of South Korea said this afternoon that the left flank of the United States First Cavalry Division had been driven back slightly by tank-led North Korean onslaughts.
More normal convertibility of Western European currencies is nearer realization than generally thought, members of the Export Advertising Association were told yesterday at the Shelton Hotel.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 27-- Dr. John B. Hopper, veterinary surgeon and former Mayor of Ridgewood, died here today in his home at 329 Prospect Street. His age was 78.

AN ADVANCE UNITED STATES COMMAND POST, IN SOUTH KOREA, July 27--This is the story of a fighting preacher. He is not a chaplain. He couldn't qualify for the chaplain's corps but he can qualify as a fighting man in anybody's league.

The National Emergency Medical Service of the American Medical Association has urged young physicians in Greater New York who received medical training at Government expense during the last war to volunteer for the armed services.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)-- Dissension within the Republican National Committee came to light today with the resignation of Arthur Summerfield of Michigan as chairman of the party's Strategy Committee.

CATHARINE WHITCOMB'S last novel, "Door to the Garden," a grade-A study of a young girl overburdened with relatives, was a crit ical success last year-though it failed to win the audience it deserved. Based on a Freudian foundation, it never lost the human touch.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 27-- Rioting broke out tonight on the approaches to King Leopold's residence at Laeken, on the outskirts of Brussels. A body of 4,000 Socialist militants attacked a procession of automobiles and buses filled with the King's Social Christian (Catholic) supporters.

WASHINGTON, July 27--Blame for the Korean war became a top political campaign issue today as the Democratic National Congressional Committee advised candidates for the House of Representatives to put the burden on "isolationist" Republican opponents.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 27 (AP) --Australia's contribution to the United Nations ground forces in Korea probably will total a division, Army and Navy Minister Josiah Francis said today.

Mayor O'Dwyer climbed up to a shaky wooden construction platform on top of the Empire State Building yesterday noon to place a 14 carat gold-plated rivet in the first steel beam of a new television tower that will, when completed, add 217 feet to the height of the world's highest building.

Research alone can reduce the number of chronic-disease patients, three medical experts agreed last night in a discussion of programs now in operation at city hospitals to alleviate overcrowding while supplying first-rate medical service.

Plaids this fall offer fashion's single strongest theme. No longer the property solely of the college girl, with whom they have long been a favorite, they crop up in the most sophisticated fashions and accessories and in all types of fabrics. Night and day, the tartan...

RHINELANDER, Wis., July 27 --Edson P. Lichty of Wilmette, Ill., a veteran of the hospital insurance movement, died last night after suffering a heart attack at Sugar Beach, a resort near here. His age was 49.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 27 (AP) --William O. Coe charged today that the Democratic nomination for Governor had been stolen from him and said he would demand a complete recount of the Tuesday run-off primary.
GENEVA, July 27--The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund has set aside $500,000 for immediate emergency aid to children in war-torn Korea.

Robert Gordon Menzies, Prime Minister of Australia, arrived here yesterday afternoon en route to Washington to confer with President Truman and other Government officials on the matter of increasing Australian aid to United Nations forces in Korea.

BOSTON, July 27 (AP)--Lefty Warren Spahn hurled the Boston Braves back into the National League's third spot by notching his twelfth victory of the season with a 5-3 decision over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight before 8,302 fans.
A new system of color television, said to have important technical and economic advantages over previously proposed systems, has been announced in Syracuse by the General Electric Company.

Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman reserved decision yesterday on a motion by counsel for the Chinese Communist Government to remove from the New York State Supreme Court to the Federal Court a $791,123 suit between the present Peking Government and the Chinese Nationalist Government.

HOLLYWOOD, July 27--The Motion Picture Association, along with the entire film industry in Hollywood, was astonished today at the revelation that a group known as the Committee to Free the Hollywood Ten is preparing to

WASHINGTON, July 27--The Administration's ten-and-a-halfbillion-dollar arms program is predicated upon the assumption, or more properly the hope, that there will be no general war for the next two years.

LARAMIE, Wyo., July 27--The Great Plains Council recognized today the implications for the country's "bread basket" in the Korean conflict and appeared ready to abandon long-delayed conservation work and turn to allout food and fiber production.

Heeding the lessons of the fighting in Korea, the Atlantic Council of Depu ties (now meeting in London) has begun to revise the previous defense plans of the Atlantic community with two new aims in mind.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 27--Jacob A. Malik, Soviet representative on the United Nations Security Council, notified Secretary General Trygve Lie this afternoon that he would assume his duties as president of the Security Council for August, thus ending his walkout in protest against the Council's refusal to expel Nationalist China.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 27--Turkey is eager to join the North Atlantic security pact or a similar collective defense arrangement centered on the Mediterranean area, Ankara's representative at the United Nations said today.
Replies to Secretary General Lie's appeal for ground troops for use in Korea are now coming in and they are gratifying. East and West Asia are represented by the offers of Thailand and Turkey.
Fresh fish is in such good variety, according to the Fishery Council, that week-end shoppers should be able to find one or two species to their taste to substitute for meats and poultry.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., July 27--In at least one category--the piston-engine field--the United States still holds a considerable lead over the Russians, according to Frederick B. Rentschler, chairman of United Aircraft Corporation.
Mayor O'Dwyer cleared the way yesterday for the installation of parking meters and the indications were that the first of the devices would start collecting dimes by early fall.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP)-- Perry E. Moore, president of the New York Cotton Exchange, said today the controls President Truman seeks over commodity market speculation would force cotton prices up instead of down.
VIENNA, July 27--Szabad Nep, organ of the Communist Hungarian Workers' party, angrily denounced three Hungarian Bishops today as saboteurs of all efforts to reach a church-state agreement.

Mayor O'Dwyer termed as "ridiulous" yesterday a charge made on Wednesday by the Citizens Union that the Mayor had used the suicide of Police Capt. John G. Flynn for a "theatreal demonstration" of his disapproval of the Brooklyn investigation into organized gambling.

WASHINGTON, July 27--The Senate rejected by 47 to 28 today a bipartisan attempt to cut $365,000,000 from the allocation for rivers, harbors and flood control projects carried in the pending allpurpose appropriations bill.

WASHINGTON, July 27--There are many differences between this period and that of 1940-41, but since an expanded program for national security is common to both certain comparisons are in order. Viewed from the administrative and substantive standpoints, the present activity is being better managed.

WASHINGTON, July 27--President Truman said today that he was still hoping fervently for world peace and would do his best to attain it. His head was inclined downward, and he was staring at the top of his desk as he spoke.

GREAT NECK, L. I., July 27-- Two teams were tied for honors today after thirty-six holes of the Women's Long Island Golf Association's four-ball best-ball tournament were completed at the Deepdale Club course.

ST. LOUIS, July 27--The Yankees' high hopes of making appreciable gains in the American League flag race at the expense of the lowly Browns ended in complete disaster tonight as a couple of Bomber castoffs turned on their former team-mates.

Ships from ports beyond the Iron Curtain will be thoroughly searched before they are permitted to enter the Upper Bay and proceed to their docks. This is part of a drive to keep "Trojan" ships from our harbors.

LENOX, Mass., July 27--Serge Koussevitzky cut a cake for his seventy-sixth birthday yesterday; and tonight he waved a baton for the first of the Berkshire Festival's concerts here by the full Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood. Since life for many con-....

IN SOUTH KOREA, July 27-- Meeting in a small theatre in this emergency capital, the National Assembly of the Korean Republic today held its fourth temporary session and heard both President Syngman Rhee and Assembly Chairman Shin Ik Hi voice the...

PARIS, July 27--Three battles must be fought in any possible war of the United States with the Soviet Union and one would be the battle for Europe, Gen. Pierre Billotte said today in addressing the American Club of Paris. The army for this battle must be centered around France but with powerful United States support, General Billotte added.

With Jockey George Hettinger whipping away at him fourteen to the dozen in the stretch, George D. Widener's 4-year-old Marabout pulled away from the opposition to take the money in the $4,500 added handicap that headed the Saratogaon-the-L.I.R.R. racing program yesterday.

CLEVELAND, July 27--The World Baptist Congress called today upon all of its associated organizations, comprising 18,000,000 members, to remove from their worship and fellowship all forms of segregation and discrimination "based on race, color or culture."
WASHINGTON, July 27--The angry political debate here over Formosa has subsided, but that island is still a source of considerable worry to the White House and the State and Defense Departments.
Maintaining their upward movement for the eighth successive week, bank loans to business rose $53,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. The latest expan

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP)--Randy Gumpert pitched the Chicago White Sox to a 6-3 victory over the Washington Senators in the second game of a double-header before 5,174 fans today after the Senators had used just three hits to capture the opener, 3-2.

WASHINGTON, July 27--The Army stepped up its demands for manpower sharply late today with a call for 100,000 men through Selective Service. Simultaneously President Truman, by executive order, extended for one year all enlistments of persons now in the armed services.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 27-- Miss Dorothy Bonbright Long, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Long Jr., has completed plans for her marriage to John H. Hale of Canton, N.Y., and Nancy, Alaska, son of Mrs. Horace C. Hale of Canton and the late Mr. Hale,...
The dairy farmers who supply this city with milk have won a quiet struggle against strict Federal supervision of their industry.

Prices of natural crude rubber in the sensitive futures market on the Commodity Exchange moved over a wide range yesterday and closed with all deliveries beyond September off sharply from Wednesday's levels.

The woeful ineptitude of Brooklyn's bullpen corps was re-emphasized yesterday when the Cardinals assaulted four of Burt Shotton's second-line hurlers for ten runs in the last two innings to convert a close contest into a 13-3 massacre.

Although there are reports from many sources that the nurse shortage is critical, most of the training schools for nurses in this city say they are unable to accept any more students for September admission.

WASHINGTON, July 27--The Army stepped up its demands for manpower sharply late today with a call for 100,000 men through Selective Service. Simultaneously President Truman, by executive order, extended for one year all enlistments of persons now in the armed services.
Two hundred years ago today the cantor at the St. Thomas' Church in Leipzig died and was buried in an unmarked grave.

The Senate did a good thing on Wednesday in adopting, by unanimous vote, an organic act for Guam. The measure has already passed the House and the amendments are minor. Quick agreement and Presidential signature should therefore be relatively easy.

This particular house belonged to the time when a proper family house had to have a tower--a relic of the not distant Gothic re-... vival--which gave dignity to a "residence" the way a porch used to give
Michael Goldenberg has been elected president of Century Shoe Manufacturing Company. He was formerly a director.
PITTSBURGH, July 27--Business in the Pittsburgh district last week rose to record levels, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

A record net profit of $272,889,624, equal to $6.14 a common share, was achieved in the second quarter of 1950 by the General Motors Corporation as the tempo of its operations rose to a new peak, C.E. Wilson, president, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, reported yesterday.

A first grade detective, apparently overwrought because the members of his family were separated as a result of a fire in their home at 756 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, last week, committed suicide at 2:10 A.M. yesterday in a Queens parking lot.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, said yesterday that the Democrats had an excellent chance of winning control of the State Senate at the November election and a fair chance of gaining control of the Assembly.

Capt. Fritz Braun of the Royal Swedish Army Service Corps arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 10:30 A.M. yesterday. He left immediately for Washington to discuss Sweden's announcement that it would send a complete Red Cross unit to Korea.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 27 (AP)--The Air Force today asked twenty-three plants to cancel vacation plans so their employes could concentrate on producing equipment needed to aid the Korean fighting.

WASHINGTON, July 27-- John, T. Koehler, acting head of the Martime Administration, announced today the withdrawal of thirty more Victory cargo vessels from reserve for use of the Military Sea Transportation Service.

TOKYO, July 27--United States forces in Korea have five major divisions and one weapon to beat, United States intelligence officers here have decided after the month's fighting, in which the Communisttrained North Korean Army has...

ST. LOUIS, July 27--It is always something of an inspiring sight to see a couple of real old champs thundering up the backstretch, forgetting their years and giving that final bid to the wire another terrific go.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)-- The Veterans Administration extended educational benefits of the G.I. Bill indefinitely today for World War II veterans who go back into active military service.

The election of County Clerk Francis J. Sinnott as Brooklyn Democratic leader is expected at today's meeting of the Kings County executive committee, and the only question that seemed to remain was whether the election would be unanimous.

The Edgecombe Development Corporation, a syndicate headed by Irwin B. Levitt, has purchased the three five-story buildings at 145-155 Edgecombe Avenue, containing sixty apartments, from the Ro-Will Realty Corporation. The property, assessed at $123,000, was acquired for cash above a mortgage of $43,350.

PARIS, July 27--Christian Dior has hit another high. His winter and fall collection brings freshness to the mode, particularly in his daytime and late afternoon creations. The full silhouette, which...

"THE SATURDAY BOOK,"* edited by Leonard Russell, is a fine bouillabaise of week end reading. In fact, a reasonably tolerant browser can find almost any sort of bedside manna here, ranging from articles on the newfangled sciences to oldfangled art.

SETAUKET, L.I., July 28--Dr. Joseph Edward Golding, who retired last December after many years as an ophthalmologist in Brooklyn, died here last night at his home after a long illness. Dr. Golding, who was 72 years old, had practiced at 1 Nevins Street.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 28--The marriage of Miss Margaret Hoitt Harvey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward William Harvey of Highland Park, to Fremont Jones McKenrick, son of Judge and Mrs. Ivan Joseph McKenrick of Ebensburg, Pa., took place this afternoon in the Highland Park Reformed Church.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 28 --Mrs. Annalisa Bossi of Italy scored a surprise victory over Mrs. Magda Rurac, formerly of Rumania, in the women's invitation tennis tourney at the Maidstone Club today.

Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, U.S.N., retired, was named by President Truman yesterday as the first permanent member of the new Federal Maritime Board. His nomination was sent to the Senate for confirmation.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 28-- The Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association retained its superiority over the Women's Connecticut State Golf Association in winning their annual inter-association team match, 26 to 19, at Brooklawn Country Club course today.
The stock market completed yesterday its second recovery cycle since the collapse induced by America's entrance into the Korean fighting. In effect, prices returned to the level of July 7.

Paul Kelly and Uta Hagen are definitely set for the starring roles in Clifford Odets' latest work, "The Country Girl." Dwight Deere Wiman, producer of the play, signed the performers on Thursday before leaving for a month's vacation in Bermuda.

WITH THE FIRST CAVALRY DIVISION, on the Korean Front, July 28--Men from two companies of the First Cavalry Division told today an amazing story of how they survived for three days completely cut off from United States forces, escaped enemy ambush and walked thirty miles over rugged mountains and through the mud and water of the rice paddies with only two meals in the entire period.
WASHINGTON, July 28--The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the reinstatement of Lloyd H. Sidener, president of a Canton, Ill., local of the United Mine Workers.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., July 28--Ogden W. Headington of Mantoloking, N.J., reeled in first prize in the State of Maine Tuna Tournament with a score of 1,157 points, a lead of 299 points over the nearest contender.
CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP)--Al Rosen smacked out his twentyeighth and twenty-ninth home runs tonight as the Cleveland Indians belted the Boston Red Sox, 13 to 1.

DETROIT, July 28--A field larger than the eight starters in last week's, Gold Cup regatta has been assembled in the pits for the second half of the double-barreled speed boat program tomorrow afternoon when the main event prize will be, the Henry Ford Memorial Trophy for craft of unlimited power.

WASHINGTON, July 28--A five-member interim committee charged with making an immediate start to gearing the schools of the nation to the defense effort with less wasted motion than during the last war was setup here today.
One of a pair of gunmen, whose accomplice robbed a West Fortyseventh Street jeweler of $2,000 after shooting him twice in the left arm, was arrested yesterday as he fled the scene.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 28--Six members of the United Nations Security Council paid tribute to the United States troops in Korea today for their valor and stubbornness in battle against the North Korean Communist Army.
Pakistan is not preparing to make any change in its currency, L. Shaffi, Consul General of Pakistan in New York, asserted yesterday.

The Bendix Home Appliance Company has begun limiting dealer orders to "normal" quantities, an official said yesterday at the first showing here of the company's new line of washers, ironers and driers.

An early return of waterfront activity in Jersey City was considered a possibility yesterday afternoon after longshoremen agreed to vote "as quickly as possible" on whether or not to return to work and end a four-week tie-up of the docks.

President Truman's decision to make drastic reductions in Federal housing outlays is certain to curtail work on six large Governmentfinanced public housing projects in New York City, John A. Kervick, director of the Public Housing Administration's local field office, reported yesterday.

The Navy and the Air Force ended yesterday their reliance on volunteers to fill the increasing need for trained men, and began issuing mandatory calls to indivividual officer and enlisted Reservists to report for active duty.

Natural crude rubber futures sold off sharply in early trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday but rallied strongly later and closed 185 to 195 points above Thursday's levels, at the highs of the day.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP)-- Defense Secretary Louis Johnson warned the public today to regard "with the gravest suspicion" any radio broadcast or other communications originating in North Korea and claiming to involve United States prisoners of war.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 28 (AP) --Sammy Snead stroked a sixunder-par 66 today to take the lead at the halfway point in the 72-hole Sioux City Open golf tournament.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 28 --A half volley made off the wood of the racquet saved Arthur Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., from defeat in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today as he gained the semi-final round with Richard Savitt of Orange, N.J., at the Meadow Club.

About the end of July, when mid-season doldrums are likely to hit home in full force, seems to be a good time to add a few lively serving accessories to luncheon and dinner tables. They may be just the tonic needed to give new spirit and gaiety to family get-togethers.

The Government was ordered yesterday to reveal some of its evidence against William Remington, former Department of Commerce economist who was indicted for perjury in denying to a Federal grand jury that he ever had been a member of the Communist party.
