NEWARK, July 28--A charge that three out-of-state milk producers paid a Newark lawyer $25,000 after their permits had been suspended by the Newark Health Department was made today by Prosecutor Duane E, Minard Jr., who said that the results of his investigation would be presented to ...
LONDON, July 28--An acceleration of arms production was the first recommendation made today by the North Atlantic Council of Deputies for improving the defenses of the Western world.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 29-- Counter-attacks by the United States Twenty-fifth Infantry Division have regained ground lost on the central Korean front, and have re-established its battle positions, a communique from Eighth Army headquarters said today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 28-- With protest strikes, sabotage, acts of violence and demonstrations of hostility to King Leopold spreading like fire through dry grass in the great industrial centers of Belgium today, the Social Christian [Catholic] Government began for the first time to talk of compromise.

PARIS, July 28--European and United States officials are discussing the future of the European Marshall Plan council in light of the drastic economic changes expected to result from rearmament in the United States and Europe.

Mounting interest in Bible reading has been found among transient guests in the city's hotels and clubs since the beginning of the conflict in Korea. The New York Bible Society, which will complete today its 104th annual distribution of Bibles in 378 hotels and clubs here, has been informed by hotel managers that they have more requests for Bibles than in any previous year.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 28--Dr. Ernest William Bertner, head of the $100,000,000 Texas Medical Center here since its establishment in 1945, died today of cancer, which he had devoted most of his professional career fighting. His age was 60.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 28-- It is worth coming to Yugoslavia to see a 100 per cent Communist Government bent on going in exactly the opposite direction from the road Moscow took in developing a socialist state. The chief impression left by interviews with various members of the Government ...

A national campaign to promote an American-made English-style bread will be started next week by Hovis, Inc. About twelve American bakery concerns have been granted franchises to make the bread according to the process used by Hovis, Ltd., a leading English bakery company, and to market it under the Hovis label.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP)-- The league-leading Phillies made three hits good for three runs in the third inning tonight and went on to defeat the Pirates, 4--1, for their fifth straight victory. Rookie Bob Miller chalked up his ninth pitching triumph against two setbacks ...

At a time when the American people are naturally--and properly--on the alert for evidence of espionage or sabotage, President Truman and the director of the F.B.I. have both given some advice that is as temperate as it is sound.
Large soft-coal consuming industries have been closing contracts for fuel with a rush as a result of the Korean war after having put off ordering during the spring and early summer.

GENEVA, July 26--A new approach to the problem of protection of civilians in time of war has been developed by a private organization in Geneva. This plan, which bears the name Geneva Zones, has already attracted favorable comment from several European ...
First Whirl, a $7,000 claim on Tuesday, was a feature-race winner at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday. The 6-year-old horse, ridden by Bobby Permane, was the 12-to-1 outsider in a five-horse line-up.

City Markets Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli announced yesterday that he had suspended the permit of a tenant in one of the city's public markets for three weeks because he had charged too much for sugar.

Joe Louis will return to ring competition in September. This not unexpected development in the career of the Brown Bomber who held the heavyweight championship of the world from June, 1937, to March, 1949, when he formally gave it up, was made known yesterday by Jim Norris, president of the International Boxing Club.

STORRS, Conn., July 28--White gladiolus blossoms, white carnations and ferns formed a garden background this afternoon in the Storrs Congregational Church for the marriage of Miss Dorothea Maria Jorgensen, daughter of Dr. Albert Nels Jorgensen, president ...

RYE, N.Y., July 28--Murray Vernon Jr. of Greenwich, a youth of eighteen who recently had taken the Eastern interscholastic championship, stole the show from golfers of more established reputations today as he entered the semifinals of the Metropolitan amateur tournament at the Apawamis Club.
CHICAGO, July 28--Increased hedging pressure made its appearance in wheat futures on the Board of Trade here today and closing trades were at the bottom, with losses of 1 to 2 1/8 cents a bushel.

ALBANY, July 28--State Health Department authorities said today that although the incidence of infantile paralysis was somewhat higher than it was a year ago, they did not believe 1950 would be an epidemic year.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 28--The United Nations is planning a new appeal through the Security Council for relief aid to South Korea.

From the young usher to the husky fellow who sounds the chimes to signal the start of the concert and on to the musicians themselves, there is an easy and universal informality at the Lewisohn Stadium where New York's Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra projects harmonious messages these nights.

MANILA, July 28--Filipinos were heartened today with what they interpreted as the probability of further aid grants from the United States Government to assist their staggering economy. They hope the assistance will come through recommendations of President Truman's Economic Survey ...
WASHINGTON, July 28--Dr. George W. Hoover, who helped write the Food and Drug Act of 1906, died here yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 75.

The dudes were dancing in Cunningham Park yesterday. Steps were called by the "Mountaineers," a two-a-day troupe that stopped at the day camp site of the Child Service League of Queensborough in Jamaica, Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 28--Mrs. Mary MacCracken Jones, wellknown Washington news feature writer, died here today in Emergency Hospital. She was the widow of H. Williams Jones, for many years Dean of Bexley, Kenyon College, Ohio.
ALBANY, July 28 (AP)--The State Bureau of Motor Vehicles has ordered used car dealers not to use the word "new" without qualification in advertising automobiles for sale.

Edward P. Frost of 908 Edgewood Avenue, Pelham Manor, N.Y., for many years a member of the New York Curb Exchange, died yesterday at Fort Hamilton Veteran's Hospital after a long illness. His age was 60.

PARIS, July 28--France must quadruple her internal defense forces against a fifth column and saboteurs, Jules Moch, new Minister of Defense, told the National Assembly today, in his first important speech, outlining energetic action that he plans for French rearming.
WASHINGTON, July 28--Orders that would have put the operation of the New York milk marketing area under Federal control will not go into effect.

John T. Koehler, acting chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, Department of Commerce, made public yesterday the names of thirteen shipping concerns that will operate twenty cargo carriers, withdrawn from the reserve fleet a week ago.

William A. Hauck, who as a Government official in World War II was a leader in the steel expansion program, died on Thursday in Doctors Hospital, Washington, after a brief illness. His age was 64. At his death he was a steel consultant to both the Government and private industry.

BOSTON, July 28 (AP)--The Cincinnati Reds supported Ewell (The Whip) Blackwell with an elevenhit attack tonight as he gained his first 1950 pitching victory over the Boston, Braves, 8--5, before 13,505 fans.
WASHINGTON, July 28--Powerful moves were proposed by the White House today to advance the country's mobilization for the Korean war and to ward off other threats of international communism.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 28-- With Gov. Chester Bowles and United States Senators Brien McMahon and William Benton scheduled for renomination by the Democratic State Convention tomorrow, it became evident today that the Connecticut Democrats intended to stress national and international issues in the campaign for their re-election.
Another attempt to settle the second part of the ten-day-old strike by union teamsters who haul building materials was made yesterday when building supply dealers made a new wage offer.
Mayor O'Dwyer paid tribute yesterday to the Army Chaplains' Corps, which is 175 years old today, by proclaiming tomorrow "Military Chaplains Day."

PITTSBURGH, July 30--The most serious problem encountered by steel sales executives here is making a decision on what is and what is not a military order.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 30 --Floyd Rose, Pittsburgh engineer, industrialist and civic leader, died here at his summer home last night. He was 73 years old.
Cancellations of overseas travel space on transatlantic shipping lines attributable to the crisis in Korea have been surprisingly low in the opinion of local travel officials.

PUSAN, South Korea, July 31-- Heavily equipped and trained to peak efficiency, fresh combat troops of the United States Army poured from transports here today to add strength to hard-pressed American and South Korean forces against the battleline of North Korean Communist invaders.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in July was slightly smaller than in the previous month but was the heaviest turnover of any corresponding month in seventeen years or since 1933. Sales crossed the 3,000,000-share mark in three sessions, the largest of which was 3,246,270 on July 11.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- The number of employed persons in the United States, outside of on farm work, reached a record high mark of 52,774,000 in the first week of July. The previous peak was 52,452,000 in July, 1948.

Government officials in Washington have been assured that the current supply of raw wool in the hands of traders and manufacturers was sufficient to meet civilian and military requirements for the time being.

BALTIMORE, July 31 (AP)-- Baltimore, the nation's leading ore importing center, has handled 17,100 tons of manganese ore and 25,290 tons of chrome ore from Russian ports since the first of the year, customs and shipping records disclosed today.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 31 --Three incumbent Democratic United States Representatives in Connecticut are expected to be renominated Saturday in conventions throughout the state.

Brand Names Foundation will expand and intensify its educational program this fall and winter to keep the public aware of the essential importance of brand-name competition despite probable Government controls over the economy.
JERSEY CITY, July 31--Completing a career in nursing dating back to 1899, Miss Jessie McGavin Murdock retired today as director...
WASHINGTON, July 31--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that consumer credit soared $550,000,000 during June to reach a new record volume of $19,627,000,000 at the end of the month.

Administration leader's were reported yesterday to be swinging to the idea of expanding the provisions of the Defense Production Act of 1950 so as to give the President stand-by powers to freeze prices and wages.
Carson McCullers' drama, "The Member of the Wedding," received Donaldson Awards here last night as the best play of last season and as the best first play by an author to be produced on Broadway.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31-- "You Belong to Me," a comedy by Robert Riskin about an American newspaper man who adopts two European war orphans and brings them to the United States, which Paramount bought last year, has been scheduled as Bing Crosby's next vehicle and will go before the cameras in October.

LONDON, July 31 (AP)--An official British commonwealth source said today that the Communist government in China had proposed a settlement of the Korean conflict through mediation by Asian nations.

CHICAGO, July 31--Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, supply and demand considerations plus the favorable outlook for the spring wheat, corn and soybean crops resulting in good selling at times, and there also was hedging pressure in wheat...

HELSINKI, July 31--In a large, modern building on the edge of this city are an even dozen artists' studios. The rooms are large and airy. Sunlight streaming in through the broad glass windows encourages the many plants into luxuriant greenery. Wide shelves overflow with bowls, figurines, plaques and platters, some of which are glazed, others halfbaked, still others raw clay.
CLEVELAND, July 31 (AP)--Embarrassed executives of the Cleveland Indians humbly apologized today for the public "humiliation" of Boston Red Sox manager, Steve O'Neill.

With the receipt of the first consignment of an improved "stop" sign, a good step has been taken toward mots effective control of automobile traffic in New York City.

WASHINGTON, July 31--The House Rules Committee left the door open today for passage of sweeping price, wage and rationing controls as it cleared the Administration's economic mobilization bill to the floor.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 31--Officials of the Nassau County Health Department, listing thirtyfive cases of poliomyelitis so far this year, expressed the opinion here today that a county-wide epidemic was unlikely.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, July 131--A new ocean terminal that makes the tedious business of debarkation as much a pleasure as it can be was opened here today by Prime Minister Attlee.
WASHINGTON, July 31--The Reconstruction Finance Corporation served notice today that it is going on a full defense footing, so far as loans to American business are concerned.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 (UP) --John Foster Dulles said today he did not believe Soviet leaders had decided to start a third world war.

Mrs. Francis E. Storer of 791 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Adelaide Storer Lusk, to Edward Davis Rowley of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Rowley of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The wedding will take place in the autumn.

CAIRO, July 31 (AP)--The Egyptian Royal Council officially placed the assets of Queen Mother Nazli under custody tonight and removed her as custodian of her daughter, former Princess Fathiya. [Both the Queen Mother and the Princess are in the United States.]

Hot and humid, it started out as a rough night at Ebbets Field, where the Dodgers made three consecutive errors on the first three plays in their finale with the Cubs. It got lots rougher, too, and the Brooks, forfeiting an earlier 5-1 lead, wound up on the wrong end of an 8-5 count last night.

Do you have lazy lips, a stiff jaw or a sleepy tongue? Do you answer the telephone with "Hello," or "For whom does the bell toll?" Do you speak more than 126 words a minute? If you do, say the Customer Service Consultants, you have bad telephone manners.

The Lewisohn Stadium concerts are being cut short by a week, but the curtailed season has had its high moments, and Zino Francescatti's performance of Beethoven's Violin Concerto last night was certainly one of them. It was an auspicious beginning for the seventh and final week of the annual summer concerts by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.

YARMOUTH, N.S., July 31 (AP) --Frank Parker Day, known in Canada and the United States as a scholar, soldier and writer, died at his home near here last night after a long illness. He was 68 years old.
BOSTON, July 31 (AP)--Backed down to 7--5 by the 9,633 crowd, J.M. Grieve's Red Ring sped to a three-length victory in today's featured six-furlong sprint at Suffolk Downs.

WASHINGTON, July 31--President Truman told Congressional key men today that he wanted to throw, as quickly as possible, an additional $4,000,000,000 into the arming of nations resisting communism. This would be on top of the $1,222,500,000 recently authorized by Congress to carry the Mutual Defense Assistance Program through its second year.

Owen Lattimore, who was characterized by Senator Joseph McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, as a Communist within the State Department, but who was cleared by a Senate subcommittee, again yesterday defended American steps in Korea.

The New York Dock Company has sold the loft building at 62 to 114 Imlay Street in Brooklyn to a subsidiary of the Brooklyn Standard Bag Corporation, of which William Salzman is president. The building, containing nearly 25,000 square feet of floor..

Surfcasters seem to be getting some old-fashioned bass fishing at Montauk these days, with plenty of stripers in the 20 to 40 pound class being taken at night, and blue fish ranging from 3 to 6 pounds taken by day.

The Port of Houston, Tex., has saved nearly $1,000,000 in the construction of two large wharves through adoption of a revolutionary design.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 31-- The last of seventy-five teams to report took honors today as Robert Maslow and Henry Ciuci of Fresh Meadow won the weekly amateur-pro best-ball golf tournament over the Glen Head Country Club course with a 6 under par 34, 31--65.
AMONG certain literate and articulate circles when the conversation isn't about Herman Melville it is about Henry James. But everyone who talks about Henry James isn't qualified to do so.

FORT MEADE, Md., July 31 (AP) --The Army said good-by today to Lieut. Gen. Leonard T. Gerow, a short, trim man who has been soldiering for thirty-nine of his sixtytwo years. To honor him, elements of the Second Army he had commanded since early in 1948 passed in review on the parade ground here.

Provision for the city's new traffic signal system, involving a stepped-up light interval, is included in a $4,213,000 allocation for traffic signals and devices that the Police Department, through Commissioner William P. O'Brien, has requested in its 1951 capital budget.
HONG KONG, July 31--The Chinese Communists have gone all out in an intensified propaganda campaign directed against "American imperialism" in Asia.

The railroads still are attempting to recover some of the passenger traffic volume lost to private passenger cars and buses by reducing fares. The Pennsylvania Railroad yesterday announced that for Sunday, Aug. 13, it would put into effect one-day round-trip excursion...

The story of how Jehovah' Witnesses have preached the Gos pel and won fine legal points if the high courts of a dozen land was told over and over again yesterday to an absorbed gathering of 55,000 members in the Yanke Stadium.

IN the winter of 1949 at the Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden, Clarence Ellis Harbison of Noroton, Conn., and Harry Brogan, chairman of the Buffalo Kennel Club show committee, were discussing dogs, an endless source of conversation for people like Harbison and Brogan. Harbison began on an idea he had held for years--that dog psychology wasn't different at all from human psychology.

SARATOGA SPRINGS. N.Y., July 31--The start of the Saratoga Association's eighty-second race meeting on the old home grounds lead as its highlight today the victory of Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's English-bred Northern Star in the Flash Stakes for 2-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill establishing rules for allotting cotton acreage during the next two years and virtually assuring quotas for those years. The vote was 160 to 85.

WASHINGTON, July 31--President Truman today ordered to active duty in thirty days four of the nation's twenty-seven National Guard divisions, two Guard regimental combat teams, and other supporting units.

The aircraft industry in this area was still operating at reduced capacity yesterday because of shutdowns for summer vacations despite requests from Washington for a threefold increase in plane production during the fiscal year that began July 1.
PARIS, July 31--The integration of the economies and the defenses of the North Atlantic region was the subject of discussions in Paris today between French and United States officials.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 31--The Security Council, holding its last meeting before the return of the Soviet Union, today adopted a resolution requesting Secretary General Trygve Lie, the Economic and Social Council and other United Nations agencies to cooperate in providing relief for Korean civilians.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP)-- Senate crime investigators soon will broaden their inquiry to include underworld operations in California and Pennsylvania, Senator Estes Kefauver announced today.

One of the gayest of all wild flowers is splashing rural fields these midsummer days with nature's own special shade of orange. This is the season of the butterfly weed, also known as orange milkweed or orange root. Some know it as pleurisy root, a producer of medicine prescribed especially for pulmonary afflictions.

DETROIT, July 31--A matter of two percentage points separating them from the league leaders. Casey Stengel and his Yankees were resting quietly today preparatory to engaging the Tigers in a momentous three-game series that opens at Briggs Stadium tomorrow...

One of the most interesting revivals to watch in the last year has been the return to favor of the floor lamp. Anyone who doubts that this important home accessory is again in good standing has only to look around at the variety now available.

A series of steps to improve postal service here was outlined yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York. The recommendations grew from a survey of 500 companies, which showed that recent curtailments in postal service have had a disruptive effect on business in the city, Thomas Jefferson Miley, executive vice president of the association, said.

Standardized advertising and sales promotion forms are now available to all retail stores and to manufacturers who create helps for dealers. The sponsor is the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 31 --The first apartments of this city's $5,500,000 Winbrook public housing, which eventually will accommodate 450 low-income families, were opened today.

The month of July was actually 1.1 degrees hotter than normal but because the humidity was below average it was pleasanter than most Julys, the Weather Bureau reported yesterday.

The Board of Elections, at hearings yesterday, ruled off the primary ballot a number of insurgent candidates opposing regular organization designees.
PARIS, July 31--Alwynn selects black, elephant grays and all the shades of blue violet for a collection that includes suits and coats essentially modern in their chic simplicity.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Tuesday, Aug. 1--King Leopold III announced today that he would delegate his powers to his 19-year-old son, Crown Prince Baudouin, and would abdicate when the youth reached 21 years of age.

The retirement today of Paul Revere Smith, veteran New York shipping man and Naval officer and assistant to the general manager of the United States Lines, was announced yesterday by John M. Franklin, president.

Six more small units of the New York National Guard in this area were alerted for duty yesterday. They will report to their armories on Aug. 19. According to information given to unit commanders, the men will have adequate time to settle their affairs before going on active duty.

WASHINGTON, July 31--Robert Gordon Menzies, Prime Minister of Australia, said today he would have an announcement within twenty-four hours concerning the participation of his country's ground forces in the Korean war. Australian Air Force and Naval units are already committed to the operation.

Defying a police ban, leaders of the New York Labor Conference for Peace anounced last night that they would hold a "peace rally" at Union Square at 5 P.M. tomorrow. They estimated that thousands of persons would attend.

Within ninety days sixty new forty-four-passenger. Diesel-powered buses will be put into service in the Bronx, James Hodes, operating trustee of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation, announced yesterday.
With a moderate business, futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 35 to 51 points net lower yesterday.

BOSTON, July 31 (AP)--Walker Cooper singled off Tommy Glaviano's glove in the last of the ninth to drive in Earl Torgeson with the winning run tonight as Boston's Braves whipped the Cardinals, 4--3, and replaced the Redbirds in second place in the feverish National League pennant fight.

The stock market rounded out yesterday, a month of erratic movements induced by the events in Korea. The last day of July found the list furthering its recovery and, on balance, the composite rate closed at a better figure than it registered on the first trading session of the month.

BERLIN, July 31--West Berlin's demand for incorporation into Western Germany as the twelfth land (state) in the Federal Republic "must be faced up to in the near future," Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor said today.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP)-- Senator Harry F. Byrd, urged Congress today to investigate the South Koreans "failure" to resist effectively the Communist invasion of their country.
LARAMIE, Wyo., July 31--A Government economist said today that the Korean conflict had not "blown the lid" off food prices.

Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retiring director of the Joint United States Military Advisory and Planning Group in Greece, does not believe there will be trouble in the Balkans soon.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 31-- Turkey's admission to the Atlantic Past is regarded by public opinion as "an acid test of United States interest in Turkey," according to Prof. Fuad Koprulu, Turkey's Foreign Minister, who is in Paris awaiting the session of the Council of Europe.

Michael Obermeier, president of Local 6, Hotel and Club Employes Union, A.F. of L., was fined $1,000 and sentenced to two years in prison yesterday by Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn. Obermeier was tried on a three-count perjury indictment before Judge Inch, without a jury, and was found guilty on July 18.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 1--Reinforcements from the United States landed in South Korea yesterday. Today the North Korean invaders drove against the whole western and southern section of the United States and South Korean defense line in a desperate effort to break through or at least smash the defending United States divisions.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 31-- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet representative on the United Nations Security Council, who is president of the Council for August, proposed today that it take up the admission of Communist China as the first item on its agenda when it convenes at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.
A strike by 700 marine painters that started yesterday morning in major shipyards of the port threatened to tie up work on reactivation of the "mothball' transport fleet.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 31-- Syria and Jordon protested to the United Nations today that Israel deliberately had violated the armistice agreements signed with the neighboring Arab Governments.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 31--The season's most representative gathering of ranking tennis players started out today in the turf court championships of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 31--The establishment of a United Nations military force on a full-time basis was backed here today by Sven Grafstrom, Sweden's representative to the United Nations.

The battered troops in the Korean lines and those who have been anxiously waiting at home will be immensely cheered and relieved by the knowledge that reinforcements from the United States have landed in Korea. The first dispatches stated that they were already being rushed into the threatened lines. Their arrival is dramatically timely.

District Attorney Miles F. McDonald promised yesterday afternoon that his investigation in Brooklyn into alleged police tie-ups with organized gambling would continue "whether or not it meets with the favor of those in high places."

CHICAGO, July 31--Early buyer arrivals at the Merchandise Mart building's bedcoverings, linens and domestics show were greeted by the announcement that leading lines of white sheetings had been withdrawn from the market.

CHICAGO, July 31--The National Safety Council reported today that traffic deaths in the first half of 1950 were 11 per cent higher than the total in the first six months of 1949. In the sixmonth period, 15,080 persons were killed on American streets and highways.

LONDON, July 31--When the fifth congress of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women was convened here today the delegates showed themselves to be just as womanly as they were businesslike and professional.

After a protracted period of delays and interventions, the proposed acquisition of American Overseas Airlines by Pan American World Airways has been approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board in a decision directed by the President of the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- Admiral Ben Moreell, retired, president of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, today urged "very strongly" that a voluntary steelrationing system be set up instead of compulsory allocations.

A New York syndicate headed by Samuel Silk, through a stock purchase transaction, has acquired the sixteen-story and penthouse commercial building at 75 West Street from the West-Carlisle Corporation, of which Irving Weisner is president.

Mayor O'Dwyer conferred yesterday with the heads of three city departments to discuss methods of combattin gwhat he termed "racketeering in price gouging and hoarding." He said he wanted to find out first if it was going on and who was doing it.

WASHINGTON, July 31--The Atomic Energy Commission reported to Congress today that it was continuing studies concerning the feasibility of using radiological substances as war weapons. Such weapons would contain radioactive poisons in concentrations great enough to kill large populations if dropped on big cities.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 31 --Fairing along to the finish in an eased-sail breeze, Vice Commodore John Nicholas Brown's yawl Bolero, Ray Hunt's sloop Shoaler and De Coursey Fales' schooner Nina were the group winners today on the initial run of the New York Yacht Club's cruise.

Invitations to bid on 150,000 pairs of field shoes for delivery at the rate of 25,000 pairs a month, beginning on Oct. 15, have been issued by the Marine Corps Quartermaster Purchasing Officer in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, July 31--The Senate voted $2,450,000,000 today to carry forward the Marshall Plan for the economic reconstruction of Western Europe.

One of the leading infantry schools in the country, Fort Benning provides many educational courses for both officers and enlisted men. In the last year 22,000 soldiers were "graduated" from the various specialized schools on the "campus." The courses run from five weeks to ten months.

Suspending his publishing activities the other afternoon for half an hour, that distinguished bookman, Alfred A. Knopf, talked about eating and drinking. He is off to France this week, home of good food and good wine, where, he said. "I can't help but enjoy myself." A large wine map of France was propped on the floor of his small, crowded office on Madison Avenue.

PARIS, July 31--At the close of the Balenciaga collection today, the audience was loathe to leave. In a storm of applause, all remained in the hope that Balenciaga would take his well-deserved curtain call. Too modest to show himself, he remained behind the scenes.
BOSTON, Aug.1 (AP)--The Cardinals regained the National League runner-up berth tonight when their rookie righthander, Cloyd Boyer, turned back the Braves, 6--1, with a six-hit pitching performance.

Morris Mite, owned by O.E. Carobeil of Montreal, won the first division at a mile.
PARIS, Aug. 3--Jacques Heim designs his luxurious coats and suits with a waistline slightly dropped, imperceptibly so in front but more apparent in the downward curve of the belt in back.
The State Department has asked Paul Robeson, a native American, a noted singer and a leader in leftwing movements, to surrender his passport. He refused to give it up.

The unmatched artistry of the late John Barrymore was heard again last night over N.B.C. in a recording of a reading of "Macbeth" which he originally did thirteen years ago. Let the soap opera queens, the mystery show villains run for cover; last night radio rediscovered acting.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 3-- State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman has agreed to a compromise of the ban on dogs at state housing developments, which will allow residents of the Santini and Lido projects to keep their pets and not be faced with eviction as violators of the Public Housing Law.
MONTREAL, Aug. 3 (AP)--United States tourists in Canada are getting a special but unofficial "peace" welcome--by the Communists.

The warm honey-toned walnut finish of John Scalia's latest group of furniture first introduced about six weeks ago, is shown to good advantage in two rooms opening this morning at Altman's. Stark white walls offer a striking background for the rich grains and subtly rounded lines.

BOSTON, Aug. 3--Seven New England communities that would not give up in face of depressions have aroused the region to a new appreciation of industrial foundations as the answer to the threat of competition elsewhere, the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston reported today.
The Alfred M. Best Company, Inc., announced yesterday publication of the fiftieth annual edition of Best's Fire and Marine Insurance Reports.
The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the first half of this year a consolidated net income of $28,641,355 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $2.37 a capital share.

There is special activity these soft summer mornings at yacht club floats and the town landing docks. City and suburban skippers are putting their extra gear and supplies aboard family sailing and power craft for the year's most momentous playtime event, the midsummer vacation cruise.
In listing the schools of nursing in this area that accept men students, an article on nursing published in this paper last week only gave those in Manhattan.

Preliminary successes in experiments that may lead to a considerable reduction in the cost and liabilities of treating rheumatoid arthritis with cortisone were reported yesterday by five doctors writing in The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology.

Last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium was postponed yesterday afternoon because of rain. Isaac Stern, violin soloist, and the Philharmonic-Symphony under Vladimir Golschmann will be heard tonight instead.
Greece has given the free world proof that communism can be stopped, Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet asserted yesterday.

The Prudential Steamship Corporation, one of the first United States-flag lines to accept a general agency agreement with the Government in World War II, is now preparing two Governmentowned vessels for Korean service.
Bank clearings for the twentyfive leading cities of the nation for the week ended on Wednesday totaled $15,257,039,000, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday.

The engagement of Miss Patricia May to Charles Schwartz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schwartz of New Orleans, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Sylvester May of 70 East Ninetysixth Street.
GENEVA, Aug. 3--The United States, acting jointly with four other Governments, formally proposed today the establishment of a permanent United Nations agency to aid children.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 3--The new Ocean Terminal at Southampton, opened by the Prime Minister on Monday, had its first big test today when the liner Queen Mary docked with almost 1,000 passengers from New York.

Gate keepers at the Polo Grounds can start cheering for the New York Giants again as the result of an arbitration decision by the New York State Mediation Board granting them the same pay scales in effect at other large ball parks.
Ninety Army wives, many with husbands now serving in Korea, pledged themselves yesterday to give up canasta for Red Cross canteen service "for the duration."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--President Truman disclosed today that he was now considering the possibility of sending a regular diplomatic Minister to the Vatican.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 3 (AP)--The Maryland State Racing Commission today refused to approve a night meeting for thoroughbred horses at Marlboro.

MONTREAL, Aug. 3 (AP)--Albert Molini, president of the Provincial Baseball League, announced today that the New York Yankees have paid $7,000 for the contract of Victor Pellot Power, infielder of the Drummondville, Que., club.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3--Oedipus, owned by Mrs. Ogden Phipps, trained by Pete Bostwick and ridden by Jim Smiley, provided a mild surprise at Saratoga today by scoring a record-cracking victory in the fortyseventh running of the Shillelah Steeplechase. The 4-year-old gelding was the $12,70-for-$2 third choice.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3--Heavy buying in retail channels at this time of the year coming on top of near-capacity production in many major industries boosted the level of business in the Pittsburgh district to a new record last week, ...
ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 3-- Brown Bigelow, specialty advertising house, set an all-time record sales volume for its fifty-four-year history in the seventh-monthperiod ended July 31.
Capt. David A. Jones, master of the Isbrandtsen Line freighter Flying Arrow, took the stand at a Coast Guard hearing yesterday to deny misconduct charges brought against him by members of his crew.
A total of 400,000 barracks bags is among the items listed in the latest bulletin of the Department of Commerce, City of New York, containing invitations to bid by various governmental agencies.

Sales of Maytag Company during the six months ended June 30 were 47 per cent greater than in the corresponding period of last year, and the net profit was up 129 per cent, according to the company's interim report issued today.

Negotiators for The New York World-Telegram and Sun and the New York Newspaper Guild, which has been on strike against the newspaper for fifty-two days, held another futile mediation session yesterday with Federal conciliators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Dr. Clifford E. Barbour of Knoxville, Tenn., former moderator of the Presbyterian Church, married yesterday Miss Alice Elizabeth Patton of Knoxville, daughter of S.M. Patton of Washington.

PARIS, Aug. 3--Paton showed fall and winter fashions this afternoon. In good taste, the collection avoided extremes. Outstanding was the quality and excellence of fabrics, which represented many of the famed houses of France.
HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 3 (AP)--The Brotherhood, an underground organization of German exofficers proposed today the rearmament of twenty German divisions as part of a new European army.
The election of O. Kelley Anderson as president of the $1,000,000,000 New England Mutual Life Insurance Company was announced yesterday. He suc ceeds George Willard Smith, who ...

Several famous American speedboats of the Gold Cup and Unlimited classes will top the long list of scores of smaller craft which will compete tomorrow and Sunday on the Navesink River at Red Bank, N.J., in the eighteenth annual National Sweepstakes regatta.

Hugh McGovern, operator, has purchased the new one-story taxpayer at the southwest corner of Northern Boulevard and Eightysecond Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, from the Queensboro Corporation for cash above mortgages of $150,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP)--Babe Didrickson Zaharias slammed a record-breaking 70 in the opening women's round and Jimmy Clark, a former United States marine, led the men qualifiers with a six-under-par 66 in the All-American golf tourney today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Federal Reserve Board today reported a third consecutive week of huge gains in department store sales. The increase is generally attributed to "scare" buying because of the Korean situation.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 3 --Unconfirmed reports today said that 100 persons had been killed in an earthquake at Tocuyo, in the state of Lara, 200 miles southwest of Caracas.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 3-- The Hamburg-American Line has announced the reappointment of Stuart Hosie, their former agent ...

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Rose Marie Elliott of 333 East Sixtyeighth Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Thomas Elliott of Suffolk, Va., to William Donald Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Brown of Riverdale.
MOSCOW, Aug. 3--All blitzkrieg theories of warfare were condemned today by the Soviet Army newspaper Red Star, which said a surprise attack gave only temporary advantages.
LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP)--The account of the Bank of England for the week ended Aug. 2 issued today follows (in thousands of pounds):

Thirty-three hundred Jehovah's Witnesses, drawn from almost every country in the world, solemnly dedicated themselves to the service of their God yesterday as they received mass baptism by immersion in a rain-swept public swimming pool.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 3 (AP)-- Deposits in New Jersey banks increased 5.3 per cent during the last year, the State Department of Banking and Insurance said today. Deposits as of June 30 totaled $2,835,362,000, an increase of $143,784,000 over the June 30, 1949 figure.

Once again that most hopeful of all organizations seeking European unity --the Council of Europe--is meeting at Strasbourg. The Committee of Ministers, with Foreign Ministers or their deputies from thirteen countries, began ...
William E. Reid has been advanced to the position of vice president in charge of sales of the Riegel Textile Corporation.
The battle of the Naktong River was opening yesterday in Korea, with the United States beachhead line strengthened by newly arrived reinforcements.

Michael Obermeier, president of the Hotel and Club Employes Union, Local 6, A.F.L., who was sentenced to two years in prison and fined $1,000 last Monday, was released yesterday in $5,000 bail pending an appeal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP)-- The International Refugee Organization announced today that 1,222 displaced persons from Europe would arrive in New York Saturday aboard the Navy transport General Blatchford.
BRIDGEPORT, Aug. 3--Vivien Kellems, Stonington manufacturer, today announced her acceptance of the nomination for United States Senator on the newly formed "Independence party" ticket.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 3 (UP)--The General Electric Company received today the award of a $250,000 Government contract to install a 100-kilowatt shortwave radio transmitter at the General Pacheco Government transmitting center.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 3 --A lull in the downpour that greeted most of the 101 teams in the annual John G. Anderson Memorial tourney at the Winged Foot Golf Club today helped Fred Mayer and Tommy Goodwin of the Westchester Country Club in collaborating on a 67 that brought them the medal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Railroads have been temporarily denuded of spare freight cars and of a large part of their regular supply by heavy demands of military freight movements, the Government was advised today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)-- The Eberhard Faber Pencil Company of Brooklyn agreed today to stop saying that its Mongol pencils stay sharper longer than other pencils in the same price class.

After having accepted an invitation to appear as a witness on Monday before the special grand jury in Brooklyn, Mayor O'Dwyer charged yesterday that District Attorney Miles F. McDonald's special staff of rookie patrolmen were being exposed to politicians.
MEADVILLE, Pa., Aug. 3 (AP)-- Talon, Inc., zipper manufacturer, today stopped accepting orders while it studies its backlog and works out production plans.

The Broadway premiere of "Out of This World" at the Century Theatre has been moved back from Nov. 16 to Nov. 30, it was announced yesterday by Saint Subber and Lemuel Ayers, producers of the new musical comedy. The delay was necessitated to accommodate an earlier ballet booking.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Utah Power Light Company, of Salt Lake City, applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to issue $8,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due in 1960.
MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L.I.--The first two nurses recruited within the First Air Force district for service in the Air Force Nurse Corps were sworn in as second lieutenants here today.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 3-- Assessed valuations on which Nassau County's school tax rates are based have increased $108,739,480 over last year's figure.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 3 --Police officers averted today a possible riot when they dispersed 300 men milling about the main entrance of the Douglas Aircraft Company plant and rescued one man from a mauling.

The eight-round bout between Joe Lindsay of Brooklyn and Omelio Agramonte of Cuba, which was to have featured the weekly program at Dexter Park last night, was postponed until next Thursday because of rain.

LONDON, Aug. 3--A 45 per cent increase in defense expenditure for the next three years was proposed by the British Cabinet tonight in a memorandum to the United States Government. The increase was, in part, conditional on American financial assistance.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 3 (AP)--A daughter was born today to George Brent, film actor, and Mrs. Brent, the former Janet Michael of San Francisco.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3--The Philadelphia Acceptance Corporation, which specialized for fourteen years in providing cash to whisky distillers and winemakers on warehouse stocks, filed a voluntary bankruptcy petition today in Federal court here.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 3 (AP)-- Emilio Huyke, vice president of the Puerto Rico Baseball League, left today for New York, where he will present to Frank Shaughnessy, president of the International League, a record book of the Caribbean series. The book ultimately will go to the baseball museum at Cooperstown, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)-- Leon Keyserling, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today it would be "ridiculous" to freeze all prices, wages and jobs now to support the arms program.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 3 --The Western Allied High Commission has suspended one of the major Communist newspapers in West Germany for ninety days and placed a police guard around the plant to make certain that the presses could not be carried out and used elsewhere.

Discontinued in 1940 on the eve of mobilization for World War II, the Army War College will reopen at Fort Leavenworth on Oct. 2 with an enrollment of 100 officers. It will become the highest academic institution in the Army's educational system.
RICHMOND, England, Aug. 3 (AP)--Art Clark of Huntington, W.Va., barely managed to qualify for the last two rounds by shooting a 75 today in the second round of the Daks Open golf tournament.
Rome, Aug. 3 (AP)--The dollar, which hit a 1950 high on Rome's free market two days ago, dropped 18 points in a wave of selling today to close at 660 lire to the dollar.

MONTREAL, Aug. 3 (AP)--Red Hardy pitched and helped bat the Jersey City Giants to a 5-4 victory over the Montreal Royals tonight. Hardy scattered nine Montreal hits in posting his tenth victory against nine defeats and drove out three hits and scored one run.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 3 (AP)--Premier Tage Erlander stated flatly again today that Sweden would not join the North Atlantic Pact. The Premier was commenting on a London report the North Atlantic Council of Deputies was considering inviting Sweden to join.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 4 (UP)-- The Tokyo Shimbun reported today that several North Korean army officers had sneaked into Kyushu and started organizing an underground army of terrorists in Japan's southernmost island.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)-- The nation's electric utility plants produced more energy and used more gas and fuel oil during June than in any previous June on record, the Federal Power Commission said today.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 3 (AP) --Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., seeded No. 1 in the national junior and boys tennis championships, reached the quarter-finals today by ousting Stafford Carson of Santa Paula, Calif., 6--4, 6--1.

Robert Peebles, 14 years old, who was accused of firing the shot that killed a spectator at the Polo Grounds on July 4, was committed yesterday to the State Training School for Boys at Warwick for an indeterminate term.
After three days of bitter wrangling in which the diplomatic niceties gave way to some of the plainest speaking ever heard within the United Nations or any other international assembly, ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Attempts by the House lobby investigating committee to obtain specific data on the direction and membership of the Civil Rights Congress failed today when William L. Patterson, its executive secretary, failed to produce subpoenaed records.

Jacob A. Malik, Soviet representative in the United Nations who is serving as president this month of the Security Council, was involved last night in a minor automobile accident while he was returning from Lake Success to the Soviet delegation headquarters at 680 Park Avenue. He was not hurt.
LONDON, Aug. 3 (Reuters)-- Roy Marshall and Clyde Walcott today enabled the West Indies cricket team to register an impressive total of 434.
This city's housing crisis is "pretty nearly over," although there are "still shortages among certain income groups," Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, declared yesterday.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Aug. 3 --The wife of the director of biological research at Creedmoor Hospital in Queens, New York, was severely hurt today when a car driven by her husband, Dr. Frank Cotui, crashed into a pole along Route 28, at Jugtown Mountain, ten miles east of here.

The first major break in the solid tie-up of Jersey City piers occurred yesterday morning when sixteen gangs of longshoremen, some 450 men, reported for work at Pier 9, which is used by vessels of the American President Lines.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 (UP)-- A trade and payment agreement was signed today by Argentina and Switzerland. It was understood that the agreement called for an exchange of Argentine foodstuffs and raw materials and Swiss manufactured goods totaling 236,000,000 Swiss francs, about $55,000,000.
LONDON, Aug. 3--For the first time in twenty years a Briton will succeed an American in the presidency of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women.
Miss Hilda Brown was held in $500 bail for felonious assault yesterday because of her part in Wednesday's Union Square demonstration to support the Communist "peace" offensive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)-- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommended today ratification of a treaty between the United States and Canada concerning use of more Niagara River water to generate power.
Charles F. Piedmonte has been appointed a vice president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, it was announced yesterday. He was formerly an assistant vice president.

UNITED STATES HEADQUARTERS, in Korea, Friday, Aug. 4 (UP)--Lieut.-Gen. Walton H. Walker, commander of ground forces in South Korea, ordered today a complete investigation of the loss of three Sherman tanks in battle because they did not have proper fan belts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)-- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development said today it was discussing a loan to Australia for economic development of that country. Officials indicated the loan negotiations probably would be finished in a few weeks.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 (UP)--A son was born today to Jeanne Crain, film actress. Her husband is Paul Brinkman, furniture manufacturer.

PANAMA, Aug. 3--President Arnulfo Arias called on the people of Panama in a radio broadcast tonight to support a declaration of the Cabinet to aid the United Nations in the war in Korea.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 3 (AP) --Gov. Gordon Browning held the lead tonight in his bid for renomination in the Democratic primary.
Nine persons who found lost articles for which no claimants have appeared will receive the items today at the police property clerk's office. The most valuable is a ring valued at $1,500.
The end of a sixteen-day-old strike by teamsters who cart building materials was indicated last night when it was announced that 550 drivers would vote today on a new employer offer.

Only three books are being published today. Dutton has at $2.75 a novel of suspense by Fredric Brown, entitled "Here Comes a Candle." Rand McNally is issuing a new edition of its "World Atlas" at $1. The large-sized book contains twenty-eight pages of maps in four colors.

The stock market evidenced considerable caution yesterday as the debate in the United Nations Security Council became another factor to retard trading. Although on balance the list leaned to the higher side at the close, the composite rate showed a loss of 0.12 point due to the weakness in two high-price issues.

Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Roth of 55 Central Park West, and West End, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan M., to James L. Marcus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Marcus of New York. The wedding is planned for Oct. 8.
In the hope of determining if racketeers have moved into the sugar market here the city started yesterday to make a complete survey of the situation.

OYSTER HARBORS, Mass., Aug. 3 (AP)--The theft of jewelry valued at more than $100,000 from her summer home here was reported today by Mrs. William H. Danforth of Wellesley, wife of a Boston broker. She told police she last wore the jewelry July 4 and had put it away in a small case.

Harold Green, Brooklyn middleweight, will oppose Bobby James of Jamaica in the main eight-round bout at the Long Beach (L.I.) Stadium tonight. The six-round semi-final will send Tony Allegro against Vince Murray.

Rain yesterday washed out the finale of the series between the Dodgers and the Pirates. The Brooklyn club announced that the contest had been rescheduled for Ebbets Field as part of a doubleheader on Tuesday, Sept. 19.

Shoppers this week-end will find that a dollar won't go far either at the butcher shop or the poultry counter. Meats and poultry, though they have advanced no further, except for a 4-cents-apound increase on frankfurters, are still expensive.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 3 --Representative Katharine St. George, Republican of New York, asserted today that Gen. Douglas MacArthur was being made the victim of a sly campaign to discredit him for this country's reverses in Korea.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. George C. Haas Jr. of 115 East Ninetieth Street on Tuesday at the LeRoy Sanitarium. Mrs. Haas is the former Miss Dorothy Marston, daughter of Mrs. Russell Marston of 1070 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Marston. The child will be named Susan Marston.

Ballet Theatre will fly a company of sixty dancers and technicians, with some twenty-five tons of scenery and costumes for twenty ballets, from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, Sunday, on a five-month tour of ten countries in Europe and Africa.
Fur coats, varied both as to styling and types of fur appeared at a showing last evening in the fur department of Gimbels.
Unless current scarcities in metals are eased, cutbacks in production in some plants in eastern states will start within thirty days because of inadequate supplies for present output schedules.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Aug. 3 (AP) --Miss Catherine Kleinschmidt of Hawaii, bettered last year's winning time as she led eight qualifiers into the final of the 1,500meter free-style event in the National A.A.U. senior women's swimming meet today.

A second decrease in the wage demands of Local 679, Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A.F.L., was reported last night by J.R. Mandelbaum, acting regional director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, who said the offer was under study by representatives of the Marine Painters Association.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 3-- Church leaders in thirty-three countries were urged today to give active support to a plan to set up a network of United Nations "watchdog" commission to serve wherever aggression was threatened or committed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The State Department reported today that the Government was studying a new request by Turkey for admission into the North Atlantic Pact but was not in a position to commit itself on the question at this time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)-- President Truman said today that he would support the winner in the Democratic Senatorial primary in Missouri where his choice, Emery Allison, apparently lost to former Representative Hennings of St. Louis. He always supported the ticket, he told a news conference.
Howard Reilly, Martin M. Reed, Elizabeth J. Rubino, Helen P. Taussig, John J. Harris, Andres Mata, in Sutton Terrace, 450 E 63d St--Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

HONG KONG, Aug. 3 (AP)--An unidentified British sloop was reported today to have been fired upon by shore batteries on Communist-held Lintin Island, between Hong Kong and Macao. Navy authorities here declined to confirm or deny the report. Four shells were said to have struck the water close to the vessel.

A 29-year-old former paratrooper, the manager of his father's securities office, was held in $50,000 bail yesterday in Felony Court on a charge that he had stolen $150,000 from fifty clients in an unsuccessful attempt to score a financial coup by speculating in Italian lire.

GRAVENHURST, Ont., Aug. 3 (AP)--Charlie Volker, chief mechanic for the speedboat Miss Canada IV, took his sleek charge over Muskoka Lake at about 140 miles per hour today and said her performance was "much improved."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Senate voted 55 to 31 late today to cut 10 per cent from the nonmilitary items in the $34,000,000,000 all-purpose appropriations bill.

Long Island University has purchased the Paramount Theatre and Office Building, DeKalb Avenue and Flatbush Avenue Extension, Brooklyn. Dr. Tristram W. Metcalfe, president of the university, and William Zeckendorf, president of the board of trustees, announced the purchase yesterday.
WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES, in South Korea, Aug. 3-- The United States Navy's three inseparable chief petty officers, ` Allen, Emsley and Coe, are taking this war in their stride.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 3--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Burt Lathrop of Rye, and The Hedges Farm, New Hope, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Joanne, to John Theodore Falconer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norwood B. Falconer of Baltimore.
VIENNA, Aug. 3 (UP)--Friedl Fuernberg, Secretary General of Austria's Communist party, announced today the beginning of a purge of Titoists and "imperialist agents" from party ranks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Legislation granting statehood to Alaska and Hawaii is essential for the public interest and national defense, President Truman said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP)-- The Department of Commerce today suspended export license privileges of Theodore E. Kedros of (204 Franklin Street) New York for illegally arranging transshipment of truck tires and tubes to Yugoslavia.
The National Tube Company, one of the main subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation, announces the election of William F. McConnor as executive vice president.
The first big tuna of the season was brought to the Montauk Yacht Club dock yesterday by Russ MacGrotty of Flushing, N.Y., who was fishing with Captain Carl Darenberg on the Fortenate.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 3 (AP)--The Indonesian Government's request for the extradition of Capt. R.P.P. (Turk) Westerling was denied today by the Supreme Court.
Fifty New Yorkers played chess yesterday while the roof of a three-story building in which the contests were being held burned.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 3 (AP)--The Foreign Ministers or their deputies from thirteen countries began discussions today on an agenda for the European Consultative Assembly's second session, which opens here Monday.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Stephen Craig of 422 East Fifty-eighth Street of the engagement of their daughter, Tod Dee, to Richard Wallace Sabin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Sabin of Portland, Ore.

Federal Judge T. Hoyt Davis will hear argument today on the legality of the detention of Abraham Brothman and Miss Miriam Moskowitz, both of whom have been indicted on a charge of conspiracy to obstruct justice during a grand jury investigation of espionage. The defendants are being held in $25,000 bail each.

Policies for occupational deferment of members of civilian components, including the Reserves and the National Guard, in the mobilization of the nation's armed forces were announced today by Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson.
MANILA, Aug. 3--The Philippines foreign trade balance showed a first favorable turn in the first quarter of 1950, figures presented today by the Government's Commerce Department showed.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 3 (AP)--Connie Wood's Gabe from the Eastern Yacht Club and Morton Bromfield's Challenge from South Boston each scored 36 points to tie for the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup today. A sail-off was scheduled for Aug. 11.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The State Department said today that "insurmountable difficulties" blocked any effort to hold free elections in all China to determine if the Chinese people support the Communist regime.

Contributions, in the form of assessments charged to visitors and friends of departing travelers boarding passenger liners at local piers and intended for seamen's charities totaled $147,567 last year and probably will amount to more than $200,000 this year.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 3-- Charles A. George, in charge of the Free Public Library here since its founding in 1909, died last night at his home, 52 North Avenut, after a brief illness. His age was 82.

Setting a new production record since the start of World War II, the "moonshine liquor" industry expanded by 25 per cent in the last fiscal year, it was declared yesterday by the Distilled Spirits Institute, national trade association of beverage distillers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3-- President Truman today vigorously defended his Secretaries of State and Defense, saying they would not resign as long as he was President.

Radio Free Europe will start daily broadcasts today to Poland and Hungary. Broadcasts to Czechoslovakia and Rumania began on July 14 as part of the station's program to carry undistorted news and the true story of democracy's struggle for world freedom to the people of Eastern Europe.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3--The grain markets fluctuated in an erratic manner on the Board of Trade here today, reacting after an early upturn, with wheat closing unchanged to cent a bushel lower; corn, 1 cent a bushel lower to cent higher, the former on September.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 3--Merchants resisting the rationing of textiles and leather goods, which was introduced Monday by Israel's Supply Minister, Dr. Bernard Joseph, proclaimed a strike to begin tomorrow in all branches of trade except groceries and pharmacies.

LONDON, Aug. 3--The stock markets were relatively strong today. A gentle rise in nearly all markets was accompanied by a slight increase in the volume of business. The best showing was made by South African gold mines, which were active and strong all day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP)-- The House of Representatives, in a parliamentary uproar today, approved and then quickly turned around and rejected a move to restore the excess profits tax of the second World War.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The House of Representatives approved on a tentative basis tonight an economic mobilization bill authorizing selective application of price and wage controls if retail prices go 5 per cent or more above the Government's Consumers' Price Index for June 15.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 3--The Soviet Union brought Maxim Litvinov's name back into the international political arena today in the hope of proving that the United States had started the Korean war, but the former Soviet Ambassador in Washington proved to be an unreliable witness.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP)--Patricia Lesser of Seattle, Wash., and Virginia Dennehy of Lake Forest, Ill., 16-year-old players, meet tomorrow in the final of the twenty-fourth annual junior invitation open golf tournament sponsored by the Women's Western Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--President Truman warmly welcomed the announcement of the British rearmament program today and he suggested that it was an example for the other allies of the United States to follow.

Frequent meetings have been held at the Ritz-Carlton to complete plans for the "Miss New York City" pageant to be held on Wednesday in the Crystal Room at the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of Irvington House in Irvingtonon-Hudson, N.Y.
One of the nicest things about taking a house in the country for the summer is the chance to have friends ...
HONG KONG, Aug. 3--Official Communist figures quoted here today by the left-wing newspaper Ta Kung Pao reported that 900,000 acres of farmland had been inundated by floods in Central and South China.

Operations of the New York Telephone Company in the twelve months to June 30 resulted in revenues of $467,567,513, a gain of $49,051,893 over the $418,515,620 reported for the preceding twelve months.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 3-- The Soviet delegate to the United Nations, Jacob A. Malik, started an argument over John Foster Dulles in the Security Council today, but the British delegate, Sir Gladwyn Jebb, finished it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--In the week ended on Aug. 2 member bank reserve balances decreased $20,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Reductions in member bank reserves resulted from increases of $85,000,000 in ...

GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 3 (UP) --The Washington Redskins and the Green Bay Packers traded tackles today. Paul Lipscomb, a five-year Packer veteran, went to the Redskins. The Packers will get Leonard Szafaryn of the Redskins in return. It was described as a straight deal, with no money involved.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 3 (AP)--Hugh McAteer, Chief of Staff of the outlawed Irish Republic Army, was released from Belfast prison tonight. He was convicted of treason in November, 1942, and was sentenced to twelve years. No reason was given for his release.
BUFFALO, Aug. 3 (AP)--Federal Judge John Knight extended today until Aug. 14 a temporary injunction restraining the Switchmen's Union of North America from striking against the Rock Island Railroad.

CHICAGO, Aug 3 (AP)--Pitcher Randy Gumpert needed only one run to put the Chicago White Sox in the victory column today with a 1-0 decision over the Philadelphia Athletics. The right-hander gained his fifth success with a four-hit performance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3-- Harry Lundeberg, secretary of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A.F.L., received reports today that the Navy had chartered foreign ships to carry cargoes to Korea, and at once registered a vigorous protest.
PORT ROYAL, Pa., Aug. 3 (UP) --A New York-to-Chicago freight train was derailed here today, blocking all four main tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad. No one was injured.

It "rained" hard yesterday both inside and outside Weisenberger's Loan Shop, at 781 Eigth Avenue. Before the downpour ended one man was arrested on a burglary charge, another was held by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for questioning and two 16-yearold girls from Dover, N.J., were in care of the Police Department Juvenile Aid Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The appointment of Capt. John A Waters Jr., of the Navy as director of the Division of Security for the Atomic Energy Commission was announced today. He succeeds Rear Admiral John E. Gingrich, who resigned May 3, 1949.

Orders for a complete housecleaning of Communists and their sympathizers from local unions were issued yesterday by the high command of the State Federation of Labor. Thomas A. Murray, federation president, directed 1,000 delegates to the group's annual convention at the Commodore Hotel to do the job.

The Ministry of Transport and Communications of the Government of Israel and El Al Israel National Airlines have leased a floor in the Aeolian Building, 27-29 West Fifty-seventh Street. Riker Co., Inc., were the brokers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--President Truman signed and made final today Congressional authority to raise the size of the armed forces to any level required to meet present and possible future emergencies.
BUFFALO, Aug. 3--Blueeyed Barry James Nixon, a year-old child born on the other side of the world, played unconcernedly today in the home of his new mother.

Trading desks in the financial district devoted to the exchange of municipal bonds are continuing to function profitably in a strong market. With the market supply of bonds substantially less than that of recent weeks, there has been a noticeable falling off in activity.
The war boom in natural crude rubber forced the prices in the foreign markets yesterday to the highest levels in twenty-five years.
Two new films arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the attraction is "Panic in the Streets," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama starring Richard ...
The taxpayer property at 102-04 Main Street in Hornell, N.Y., has been resold by Frederick Brown, operator, to an investor represented by Safir Kahn, attorneys. Ralph Sullivan was the broker.
Ruth Hammers Associates, Inc., has been named to handle the fashion coordination, production, staging and publicity of the spring, ...
LA GRANDE, Ore., Aug. 3 (AP)-- Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court is off on another globe-girdling jaunt.

The Jessop Steel Company of Washington, Pa., has elected Frank B. Rackley, formerly executive vice president, to the post of president. At the age of 33, he is one of the youngest heads of a steel producing company in the United States.

Loans to business by New York banks rose $72,000,000 last week. After registering nine successive weekly increases, as the normal seasonal expansion gets under way, the total of such loans outstanding is slightly higher than the seasonal peak of last fall.

Military mobilization of this country and its allies will tend to spur greater economic unity of the free world, it was concluded yesterday in round-table talks participated in by leading Belgian trade and business executives.

The heads of all city departments and agencies were urged yesterday by the City Planning Commission to revise downward their requests for allowances in the 1951 capital budget. These requests are already in the commission's files.
With a skirling of bagpipes and a lassie dancing to the tune, Arnold Constable came out yesterday in full favor of plaids for back-tocollege fashions.

BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP)--Righthander Vern Bickford's second straight four-hit pitching performance, a 5-1 decision over the St. Louis Cardinals, today boosted the Boston Braves to second place in the National League race over the rained-out Brooklyn Dodgers.
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 3 --The police here are investigating the cause of a fire that routed 250 guests from the North End Hotel and caused damage estimated at $40,000 last night.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) yesterday announced that it had put into effect a plan for the protection of employes entering military service.

Mrs. Reba Moness, the United States table tennis champion, will represent this country in the Third World Maccabiah Games in Israel, Sept. 27 to Oct. 18, it was announced yesterday by Charles L. Ornstein ...

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 3 --Village police were continuing their search here today for the person who stole a Confederate flag from a six-foot staff on the front porch of the home of Edmund T. Duval at 41 Prospect Street.

DETROIT, Aug. 3--The Yankees, striving desperately to salvage something from an almost untenable position in the American League flag race, ran smack dab into a one-round knockout today as Red Rolfe's rip-roaring Tigers ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 3--A committee of state insurance commissioners today recommended that state boards approve "result of war" riders submitted by life companies for use on policies newly issued to military service members.
ST. CATHARINES, Ont., Aug. 3 (Canadian Press)--Maj. Henry Bartlett Burgoyne, president and managing director of The St. Catharines Standard and managing director of radio station CKTB, ...
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 3-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru defended his support of the United Nations resolutions on Korea in a seventy-minute speech to Parliament today.
The Ohio Oil Company Yesterday reported for the first half of this year a consolidated net income of $17,541,017 after charges, taxes and reserves, compared with $17,512,007 a year ago.
MOSCOW, Aug. 3 (UP)--Gen. Douglas MacArthur's recent visit to Formosa means a "full American occupation" of the Chinese Nationalist island, the Soviet Literary Gazette said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Withdrawal of forty-five more Victory and one C-4 cargo-type vessels from the National Defense Reserve Fleet to meet military needs was announced today by John C. Koehler, acting head of the Maritime Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--President Truman announced today that he was sending W. Averell Harriman, his top-level policy coordinator, to Tokyo to brief Gen. Douglas MacArthur on the Far Eastern political situation.
BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 3 (AP) --Mrs. Alma Ace of Bennington today defeated Mrs. Dan Inman of Brattleboro, 5 and 3, to win the Vermont women's golf championship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Senate Armed Services Committee today approved President Truman's nomination of Robert J. Smith of Dallas, Tex., to be vice chairman of the National Security Resources Board.

Nesco, Inc., Milwaukee, has appointed Eugene G. Blumenschein sales manager of its electrical division. He was Chicago district manager in the housewares division for fourteen years. James D. Dodge has been named assistant sales manager of the electrical division.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 3-- Production of the transcript of the meeting of the United Nations Security Council moved at a slower pace today than yesterday.

McKEESPORT, Pa., Aug. 3--An ordinance requiring all Communists to register with police was passed by the McKeesport City Council today in a tumultuous session marked by the ouster of two district Communist leaders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)--The Senate Banking and Currency Committee today recommended confirmation of Oliver Powell as a member of the Federal Reserve Board.

ON NAKTONG RIVER LINE, South Korea, Aug. 3--North Korean patrols reached the west bank of the Naktong river Thursday and the enemy's long-range artillery was shelling United States supply trucks moving on the main northsouth road just a few miles southwest of Taegu.

LAUREL, Md., Aug. 3 (AP)-- H. Cuy Bodwell, one of the na tion's leading horsemen, announced today he will sell his breeding farm here and return to California, whence he came thirty-eight years ago. The 75-year-old trainer and owner is not quitting. He will continue to race a string on the West Coast.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 3-- The Belgian Government presented today the bill under which King Leopold would hand over his royal powers to Crown Prince Baudouin.

The Castleton Housing Corporation has sold the Taconic Gardens, a three-story garden apartment containing ninety-six suites, at 6225-6245 Broadway, the Bronx, to a client of Lawrence I. Gerber, attorney. Pearce Mayer were the brokers.
Continuing declining meat prices and improved prospects for meat supplies during the last quarter of this year were reported yesterday by the American Meat institute.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 3-- Maj. Gen. Ivan A. Skliarov, Soviet representative on the United Nations Military Staff Committee, did not appear at the committee meeting today despite the fact that he was chairman for August.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Department of Defense issued tonight, on the eve of an expected call to duty of a substantial number of Army Reservists, a strict policy governing deferments for Reserves of all armed services and the National Guard.
The Franklin Baker division of the General Foods Corporation has promoted Hugh R. Conklin to manager of grocery sales. Formerly associate sales manager for all grocery products in the division, ...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--President Truman denounced today the Senate's action in ordering the inclusion of Spain in the Marshall Plan with a $100,000,000 loan.

Federal Judge Matthew T. WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP)-- A special study to determine whether there are enough tankers, barges, tank cars and pipelines to handle the nation's oil and gas needs in the war emergency was undertaken today by the National Petroleum Council.

Bill Bossio, 121 , Pittsburgh, won a unanimous decision over Pat Marcune, 126, Coney Island, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Fort Hamilton Arena, Brooklyn, last night. In the six-round semifinal, Richie Howard, 134 , Nova Scotia, outpointed Gurney Van Hook, 132, Philadelphia.
