The Korean crisis has focused attention on Italy as a potential supplier of mechanical metal products for the rearmament program of Western Europe, Italian economists said yesterday.
Whether it's her first or her final college year; whether she's going north or south, the 1950 col lege girl will find a wide choice of clothes at the Abraham Straus College Shop.

SEATTLE, Aug. 3 (AP)--Refusal of marine cooks and stewards of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to have their sea papers checked by security officials was met by the Sailors' Union of the Pacific, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, today with a reply that its members would not sail with "unscreened donkies."

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 3--Victor De Sabata conducted the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood tonight. He was the first guest conductor not a member of Serge Koussevitzky's staff the Berkshire symphonic festival has had in the last thirteen years.

ADVANCED COMMAND POST, in South Korea, Aug. 3 (AP)--A United States tank-patrol has dashed 22 miles behind enemy lines, captured valuable documents, maps and Russian-made equipment and returned successfully to its own lines.
More than 800 girls in costume are expected to dance in the annual Brooklyn Children's Dance Festival of the Department of Parks Aug. 12 at 2:30 P.M.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 (AP)-- The International College of Surgeons today elected Dr. Hans Finsterer of Vienna president for 1951, at the seventh congress of the college here. Dr. Finsterer succeeds Dr. Herbert Acuff of Knoxville, ...

Advertising directors of newspapers are being urged to consider opportunities for tie-in advertising with the American Medical Association's advertising campaign to promote voluntary health insurance.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3--The boards of directors of the Baldwin Locomotive Works and the LimaHamilton Corporation have approved the terms of a merger plan, it was announced today.

SAYREVILLE, N.J., Aug. 3-- In protest against negotiations being carried on by the international union, 250 members of Local 269 of the Glass Bottle Blowers Association, A.F.L., walked out today on strike at the Sayreville plant of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP)--Lloyd H. Sidener, Canton, Ill., coal miner, will get $1,721 in back pay for wages lost while the United Mine Workers kept him out of work.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a company could not discharge employes for promoting a consumer boycott of the company's products.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 3 (UP) --The Socialist party withdrew its support today from Presidential candidate Eduardo Gomes of the National Democratic Union and announced that it would nominate its own candidate for the Oct. 3 election.
NEWARK, Aug. 3--Only 402 of New Jersey's September draft quota of 1,605 have been accepted for Army duty, while 601 have been rejected.
Consumer credit controls were endorsed yesterday by the emergency Government controls committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
A three-man arbitration board set up on Tuesday as a result of a threat of a strike, ruled yesterday that the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company had the right to lay off three railroad patrolmen.
BUFFALO, Aug. 3 (AP)--The University of Buffalo announced today it had acquired a large collection of manuscripts of the late Irish novelist James Joyce.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 3-- President Truman's policy of neutralizing Formosa may not have been abandoned in the last week by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's visit here, but it was "a move in that direction," Dr. V.K. Wellington Koo, China's Ambassador to Washington, said yesterday.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., yesterday urged Congress to provide defense funds through taxation rather than deficit financing, with consideration of how much can be raised without impairing defense measures and drying up sources of future revenue.
The Swedish Davis Cup team, winner in the European zone of the international tennis matches, will arrive in New York today.

In denying, before the event, an application of the New York Labor Conference for Peace to hold a "peace" demonstration on Wednesday in Union Square Park, Supreme Court Justice Eugene L. Brisach upheld the right of public assembly but defended the rights of the balance of the public.

PARIS, Aug. 3--Jules Moch, French Minister of Defense, told the French Advisory Council of the Republic today that if France exerted a maximum effort on defense she would expect that Britain and the United States would make a parallel effort in Europe.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 3 --A driving rain that fell from early in the morning forced cancellation of play in the Eastern grass court championships today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

Mrs. Mary Ellen Conaway Leslie daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Conaway of Great Neck, L.I. and New York, was married here yesterday morning to Walter Black of New York in the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. George G. Cameron.

SOUTH BUTLER, N.Y., Aug. 3 (AP)--Delmar C. Stell, 46 years old, an Auburn Prison guard, died of a heart attack today after a bee had stung him through the eyelet of a shoe. A physician pronounced Mr. Stell dead at his home here and ascribed the cause. The guard had begun his vacation early today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 3-- A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Ward on Monday in the Nassau Hospital, Mineola. Mrs. Ward is the former Miss Nan Ward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvanus D. Ward of 122 East Eighty-second Street, New York. The child will be named Katherine Delamere.

LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP)--Communist Czechoslovakia was reported today to have halted the work of the Salvation Army within her borders. Confiscation of the Army's property and imprisonment of at least two officers were also reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)-- President Truman declared at his news conference today he would back Martin A. Hutchinson for the Federal Trade Commission and Carroll O. Switzer for a Federal District Judgeship in Iowa just as long as they chose to fight.
WASHINGTON, Aug 3--The State Department today offered to sell a dismantled German aluminum plant to United States buyers.
The House voted "tentatively" yesterday to go far beyond providing the President with stand-by controls over prices and wages in case of serious rearmament inflation.

Federal Judge Robert Inch in Brooklyn has sustained a Department of Agriculture ruling requiring a Long Island milk dealer to make "differential" payments to the New York milk pool on account of cream purchased in Ohio in 1945 and 1946 for making ice cream.

The city of Boston, Mass., borrowed yesterday $5,000,000 on temporary loan notes due on Dec. 1. The notes were sold to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. at an interest rate of 1.07 per cent and a premium of $107.

ALBANY, Aug. 3 (UP)--The week of Aug. 6-12 was proclaimed Vegetable Week today by Governor Dewey. He called attention to the great supply of fresh vegetables available to the people of the state and stressed "the great importance of vegetables as a staple part of the family diet."
MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 3--Soaking wet but still not bedraggled, the New York Yacht Club fleet arrived here today on its cruise run from Newport, R.I.

Gwinn, general manager, said yesterday in response to Air Force and Navy orders for "substantial quantities" of high-power piston and turbojet engines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UP)-- Dr. Joseph M. Pisani today was named executive director of the Medical Sciences Committee of the Armed Services Research and Development Board.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 3 --Settlement of a wage dispute involving twenty striking pipe coverers today enabled construction of the $20,000,000 veterans hospital on the Bamberger estate to continue uninterrupted. A plumbing subcontract agreed to pay the strikers $3 an hour, an increase of $.37 , and the men went back to work.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Dr. Stevan Ruzicka, a pioneer in the use of rotary kilns in steel-making in this country, died last night in Doctors' Hospital of a heart ailment. His age was 61.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier again yesterday and closed 20 to 27 points net lower.

NEWARK, Aug. 3--The engagement has been announced of Miss Patricia Elizabeth Killoran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Killoran, to Cadet Paul Jennings Brown of the United States Military Academy, son of Judge and Mrs. Paul E. Brown of Fairfax, Va.

Doubt as to the availability of essential building material has halted temporarily the construction of a $5,500,000 passenger car assembly plant by the Studebaker Corporation at North Brunswick Township, N.J.

DETROIT, Aug. 3--True friendship, they say, transcends everything, including wars and even sizzling pennant races. Therefore, it is that we find the eminent Prof. Casey Stengel not the least bit disturbed as his Yankees lock themselves in a death grapple with the clawing Tigers while a band of Indians lurks just around the corner.

Botany Mills, Inc., manufacturer of woolen and worsted fabrics, reported yesterday for the first twenty-six weeks of 1950, a net profit of $20,202 before allowing for preferred dividend requirements of approximately $225,000.

BOGOTA, Columbia, Aug. 3 (AP) --Nineteen persons were killed and many wounded in clashes between bandit gangs and units of the Army and police in three sections of rural Colombia, the Conservative newspaper El Siglo said today.

Stockholders of Phillips-Jones Corporation approved yesterday a plan whereby forty-eight executives will be allowed to buy a total of 10,000 shares of no par value common stock at $15 a share.

Jack Weprin and associates have bought from a client of Scribner Miller the two nine-story and penthouse apartment buildings on a plot 125 feet by 100 feet at 15 and 19 West Fifty-fifth Street, adjoining the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)-- False marking of aircraft could bring fines and imprisonment under a bill signed today by President Truman. The new law provides penalties up to $1,000 and three years imprisonment.

David M. Lilly, president of the Toro Manufacturing Corporation, manufacturers of power lawn mowers, announced yesterday the purchase of the Coldwell-Philadelphia Lawn Mower business. Leo Greenbaum of 146 Central Park West, president of the Lion Match Company, died Wednesday night in Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. His age was 74.

PARIS, Aug. 4--"The critic met the critics" today on a Paris sightseeing boat. Sylvan Rich of Martini Frocks, New York, invited guests to take part in a discussion of French and American fashions and the influence of each upon the other.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--Average primary market prices advanced 0.9 per cent in the week ended Aug. 1, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index was 165.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 3.8 per cent above four weeks ago, and 7.9 per cent below the comparable week in 1949.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 (AP)--After losing seven straight to the Chicago Cubs, the Boston Braves humbled them, 10--2, tonight as Lefty Warren Spahn gained his fourteenth pitching victory with a four-hit performance. He had the Cubs blanked until the ninth, when they bunched two of their hits with as many bases on balls for their tallies.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday, and prices were 21 points lower to 7 points higher than on Thursday, with the near months displaying the most weakness.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--The Army today issued a mandatory call for 62,000 enlisted men on the rolls of its Reserve elements. They will be called in September and October for twenty-one months' active duty to round out the National Guard and Organized Reserve Corps units soon going on active duty.

The battleship Missouri, proud host to the Japanese surrender a month less than five years ago, was a long way from the shooting war yesterday. But at Pier 88 in the North River the Mighty Mo was filling the role of the ship behind the ship that does man its guns.

Animal-loving New Yorkers had their sentiments put to the monkey test yesterday. India's gift to America--two rambunctious, tenpound Macaca rhesus monkeys-- sent noon-hour throngs in Columbus Circle scurrying for cover and generally disrupted the section's normal activity.

Mr. and Mrs. Douglas M. Moffat of 43 East Seventy-fifth Street, and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia, to E. Farrar Bateson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bateson of 791 Park Avenue, and Cold Spring Harbor. The wedding will take place early in the autumn.
LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP)--A virtual freeze of British Government tin stocks sent prices of the metal soaring madly to the highest price in the history of the London market today.

In a garden setting of white gladioluses, stephanotis and greens in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon Miss Georgina Walton Green, daughter of Mrs. Horace Green of 439 East Fifty-first Street and Northeast Harbor, Me., and the late Mr. Green, was married to Lee Gwynne Martin, son of Mrs. Curtiss Martin of 145 East Fifty-second Street and the late Clarence Clark Martin.
ALBANY, Aug. 11--The State Banking Department announced today that the Bankers Trust Company, 16 Wall Street, had been authorized to open branch offices in six locations in New York City.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat quieter yesterday than in previous sessions of the week and final prices were 14 to 24 points net lower on the day.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP)--"A scarcity such as never seen before" in the Boston wool market, is here, according to the Commercial Bulletin. The situation, long forecast, has been intensified by the Korean war, according to the bulletin, which will say tomorrow:

The nation's steel mills turned out a record tonnage in the first seven months of this year. Last month's output of 8,087,610 net tons brought the industry to a record of 55,194,337 tons up to July 31. It was the fourth consecutive month in which production exceeded 8,000,000 tons.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11--Sam Hellman, humorist, author of many short stories and motion-picture scripts and one-time newspaper man, died today at his home in Beverly Hills of a coronary thrombosis. His age was 65.
Mandatory calls to active duty will go out to 896 Army Reserve officers--two-thirds of them combat lieutenants and captains--in New York State within a few weeks.

BOSTON, Aug. 11--Vernon Edgell Bickford, swarthy righthanded pitcher of the Boston Braves, gave the boys another "one for the books" tonight when he set the Dodgers down with no hits and sent 29,008 fans and all his teammates into a state of hysterical happiness.

LONDON, Aug. 11--The military task force that Britain is sending to Korea to join the United Nations units under Gen. Douglas MacArthur will be ready to embark in six to eight weeks. It will be sent from the United Kingdom via Japan and it will be three months before the Tommies are in action.
Back-to-school clothes for the kindergarten to high school set this season have many of the earmarks of fashions for older students.

ST.LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP)--Outfielder Ken Wood's throwing arm choked off two consecutive runners at home plate in the second game of a twi-night double-header to night, giving the Browns a 2-1 victory over Detroit after the St. Louisans had lost the opener, 4--3, in ten innings.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 31 --The American Dance Festival sponsored by Connecticut College opened the second of its three scheduled week-end series of performances last night in the Palmer Auditorium with a program by Jose Limon and his company, with Pauline Koner as guest artist.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 11-- To a Communist deputy's cry of "Vive la Republique," Prince Baudouin was sworn in today as the ruler of Belgium, ending the brief resumed reign of his father, which had brought the country to the verge of civil war.
Motorists in New Jersey found yesterday that the gasoline situation had returned pretty much to pre-price war normal.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 11--Denmark's emergency move this week to curtail imports by the transfer of fifty free-listed commodities back to the restricted list has been reported to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, ...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--The Senate Finance Committee voted for higher personal income taxes today. The bill would raise present taxes about 12 to 20 per cent.
Lee Pressman, left-wing labor lawyer, resigned from the American Labor party yesterday on the ground that its policies reflected those of the Communist party.

NEWTON, Mass., Aug. 11--The marriage of Miss Mary Stoddard Bigelow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Hardwick Bigelow of West Newton and Marshfield, to Douglas Danner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Frederick Danner of Waban and Duxbury, took place here tonight in the second Congregational Church. The Rev. R. Clyde Yarborough performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--The State Department opposed the Senate-approved amendment to the nation's immigration laws today on the ground that they would obstruct the Government's struggle against communism.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 11--Officers of the Eastern Air Defense Force arrived here this afternoon to take charge of the new air raid filter center that is to play a major role in protecting the New York metropolitan area from air attack.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 12--In the blazing harbor town of Pohang, on the Korean east coast, street fighting was in progress today, after United States reinforcements of tanks and infantry established a perimeter around the important airbase across Pohang Bay.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 11--Myram Picker of 101 Ellwood Avenue, who pioneered in the manufacture of five and ten cent store cosmetics and introduced women's leg make-up during the World War II hosiery shortage, died of a heart ailment in a London hospital on yesterday, according to word received by relatives here today. He was 70 years old.

ALBANY, Aug. 11--Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley called on the American press tonight to "force, through public opinion, whatever emergency measures are necessary to go all-out in the fight against Communist aggression."
UTICA, N.Y. Aug. 11 (AP)-- Major creditors of the bankrupt Schenectady Railway Company pressed today in Federal Court for foreclosure and liquidation of the bus concern.
MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 11 (AP)--Results ran to form as the doubles division of the Essex women's tennis tournament moved through the quarter-finals today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 11-- Senator Robert A. Taft in addressing a group of Republican newspaper editors tonight declared that pro-Communist policies followed by President Truman and the State Department with relation to Asia invited and encouraged the Communist attack on South Korea.
WITH A MARINE AIR GROUP, IN KOREA, Aug. 11 (UP)--All the weapons the Korean Communists abandoned as they retreated on the Chinju front were made in Russia, American Marines said today.

The Yankees found it necessary to bench Joe DiMaggio at the Stadium last night but the Bombers still retained enough of their only bounce to hurdle this startling development as they wrestled Connie Mack's Athletics to the ground, 7 to 6, before a gathering of 27,002.

Refugees in camps in the American and British zones of Germany are "frantic" with fear they will not be processed for entry into the United States before the expiration of the Displaced Persons Act in June, 1951.

Edward J. Brown, general merchandise manager of Saks-Thirtyfourth Street, has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. Elected with Mr. Brown were Frederick C. Strodel, vice president, The Fair, Chicago, and ...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11-- David Wayne, Broadway actor who has appeared in two films as yet unreleased, has been borrowed from Twentieth Century-Fox by Universal-International for the role of Joe, one of soldier-cartoonist Bill Mauldin's two seedy, warweary G.I. characters, in the projected comedy, "Up Front with Mauldin." Joe's buddy in the film, Willie, has not yet been cast.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 11 --After his medal-winning victory yesterday, Bill Kuntz Jr. of Bonnie Briar followed a three-under-par pattern to eliminate the defending champion, Lloyd Ribner of Fenway, in the second round of the Westchester amateur championship at the Winged Foot Golf Club's east course today.
Peter Freund Knitting Mills has appointed Joe Klein West Coast representative in charge of general sales, with headquarters at the company's showrooms, 846 South Broadway, Los Angeles.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 11-- Clinton C. White, executive vice president and treasurer of the Puritan Life Insurance Company, life trustee of Brown University and a past president of the Rhode Island Life Underwriters Association, died at his home here last night. He was 71 years old.
UNITED STATES AIRBASE, Near Pohang, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 12--A tight perimeter guard kept enemy infiltrators away from this vital United States airstrip during the darkness of early morning today.

Hearings on the application of the Yonkers Railroad Company to increase its present interim rates from 7 to 10 cents were ended yesterday before the Public Service Commission, with representatives of each side challenging the figures of the other.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11--An "urgent" request that Congress nullify the postal cutback issued by Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson April 17 and a denunciation of the so-called Stockholm peace petition as "a rank fraud," marked the closing session today of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 11--The Netherlands and Canada announced plans today for new aid to United Nations forces in Korea, and Israel joined the list of countries offering supplies.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 11 (AP)-- Brookfield Farms' Istan, 2-5 favorite, whirled to a new track record of 1:09 in the six-furlong Mt. Holly Purse before 10,592 at the Atlantic City race course today. The bay gelding clipped one-fifth of a second off the mark established by Polynesian in 1946.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP)-- Castleton Farm's Scottish Pence from Lexington, Ky., winner of the $50,000 Nassau two-mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway last week, took the $3,000 11-Class pace at Good Time Park today. It was the Grand Circuit's getaway card. Grand Circuit racing opens at Springfield, Ill., Monday.

Voting unanimously in favor of controls over prices and wages, the board of directors of the Boys' Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association has wired President Truman and Government officials that the controls should be imposed immediately.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Aug. 8, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The proposal to build a new "China Village" got off to a bad start, with an exchange of acrimony, puns and synthetic Confucian quotations between Commissioners Moses and Stichman, but this cannot alter the fact that there is a job of rebuilding to do in the Chinatown area. That area is a slum;

Fast movement of the initial deliveries of coats and suits in retail stores over the country has induced buyers to re-order in substantial quantities, it was learned yesterday from New York manufacturers.
The thirty-fifth annual congress of Esperantists has been meeting in Paris to discuss means of introducing Esperanto as the "inter-language among the peoples of the world."
Suspension of water restrictions, begun in some cases on June 15 and in others July 15, was continued to Sept. 15 yesterday.

A refrigeration system for perishable fruits and other produce, now being tried in Pier 27, North River, by the Pennsylvania Railroad, is proving highly successful, produce men reported here yesterday.
The Estate of Edwin Desvernine sold the one-story taxpayer, on plot 85 by 100 feet, at 3560 Jerome Avenue, corner of 212th Street, the Bronx, to a buyer for occunancy.
PARIS, Aug. 11--The 43,450-ton Ile de France, one of the largest luxury liners in North Atlantic service, went into dry dock today for minor repairs.
The immediate appointment and training of air raid wardens was ordered yesterday by Col. Lawrence Wilkinson, director of the New York State Civil Defense Commission.

LONDON, Aug. 11--After an extraordinarily long and unexpected meeting the British Cabinet announced tonight that Parliament, which is having its summer vacation, would be recalled Sept. 12 "to discuss the defense situation."

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 11--In a tournament that ended amid rain, lightning and thunder, Mrs. Harold Greenberg of the home club posted 95-24--71 to capture low net honors at the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Class B event today.
LONDON, Aug. 11--Strength in British Government securities was the feature of the stock markets here today. These gained up to 5/16 point.

TORRINGTON, Conn., Aug. 11 --John H. Brooks, president of the Brooks Bank and Trust Company, said today that Lieut, Gov. William T. Carroll, whose resignation several weeks ago as an assistant vice president of the bank had occasioned comment in state political circles, had agreed previously to quit if he stayed in public service.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Aug. 11-- Announcement has been made by Col. and Mrs. Charles Gibson Brown of the engagement of their daughter, Constance Marchand, to William Lewis Church, son of Mrs. Sheldon Lewis Church of Lancaster and the late Mr. Church.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 11--Australia took a jolting blow in the defeat of its champion in the opening match of the Davis Cup interzone final with Sweden today, then sent out the veteran John Bromwich to score a crushing victory over Torsten Johansson, 6--2, 6--3, 6--0, on the rain-swept turf of the Westchester Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Senate Republican policy leader, struck at the pending economic control bill today as a measure that would give to President ...
The American Export liner Independence, which is scheduled to enter Mediterranean service next Feb. 10, will be equipped with ten of the largest lifeboats ever built, the line announced yesterday.

Navy pilots from two Essex class carriers hung up their greatest kill over a territory ranging from Kaesong and Haeju on the north to the port of Yosu in South Korea in a series of strikes over a two-day period. The toll of damage was announced by Vice Adm. Arthur D. Struble, United States Navy, Commander, Seventh Fleet.

ALLONS! Vamonos! Tally ho! Nyet! Skoal! We shall today the United States of America visit in a new guidebook droll and unique and magnificent. Translated is "The United States"* from the French of Americans in Paris (than which there is nothing Frencher) for "The World in Color" series under the editorship muy distinguido of Dore Ogrizek.

LENOX, Mass. Aug. 11--Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt was the guest artist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, during a concert tonight highlighting the annual "Tanglewood on Parade."
WASHINGTON, Aug.11--Panic buying and the hoarding that accompanies it are on the decline, officials of this Wholesale Trade Advisory Committee advised officials of the Department of Commerce today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP)--An inspired aggregation of college football All-Stars tonight scored a stunning upset, defeating the Philadelphia Eagles, 17--7.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 (AP)-- Gardner Mulloy, 36-year-old veteran, outlasted young Dick Savitt of Orange, N.J., and Sam Match of San Francisco crushed Jim Brink of Seattle in the quarter-finals of the Newport invitation tennis tournament today.

Observers at Lake Success during the past few days have believed that at times an expression of contempt passed over the otherwise impassive countenance of Mr. Malik. Mr. Malik seemed to be thinking that there must be something feeble-minded about members of the Security Council who ventured to disagree with Russia.
The wildcat bus strike spread yesterday to six heavily traveled Manhattan lines of the Surface Transportation Corporation, stranding 450,000 regular passengers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11--Sal Maglie put the Giants back on the winning beam tonight. Pitching his way out of one jam after another with a spine-tingling display of craft and courage, the Mexican League returnee beat Curt Simmons, the southpaw ace of the league-leading Phillies, 3--1, in a duel that thrilled a gathering of 15,895 at Shibe Park.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 11--Following is the unofficial verbatim record of today's meeting of the United Nations Security Council:

It is natural that many persons should look, at this point, to every source of available manpower to throw into the battle for the freedom of Korea. Accordingly it has several times been suggested that General MacArthur might well recruit, equip and train a contingent of Japanese for military service on the peninsula.

WESTOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Mass., Aug, 11 (AP)--Two Air Force sergeants who lashed themselves to framework inside the belly of a huge cargo plane so that they could drop cargo out of a hatch were credited today with saving the plane from crashing into the Atlantic.
The Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America, which advocates sobriety, opened its seventy-eighth annual convention last night in the Shelton Hotel, at a meeting of 100 of its delegates.
STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 11 (AP)--The text of Winston Churchill's address to the Council of Europe:

We are interested in the report just filed with the City Planning Commission by a special committee headed by Robert W. Dowling which finds that in the main the proposal to rezone New York City would benefit land values.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--Secretary of State Dean Acheson reported today that first-year plans of the North Atlantic Treaty nations for stepping up their military preparedness would be laid before the Council of Deputies later this month.

The fifteen-story apartment house for fifty families at 315 West 106th Street, near Riverside Drive, has been sold by a syndicate to an investing client of Bedros G. Terzian, attorney, for cash over mortgages amounting to $304,000. Renting for $85,000 a year, the building contains 314 rooms laid out in suites of six, seven and eight rooms. It was built in the 1920's by Paterno Brothers.

Profit taking was directed yesterday against the televisions and motors, as the stock market suffered the worst reversal in almost three weeks. Losses ranged from fractions to 2 points and the composite rate sagged 1.13 points on the day. Gains were made by only a few sections, notably the oils, which, with the motor and video issues, were the most heavily traded.

VIENNA, Aug. 11--The Russian occupation authorities have capped a long series of interferences in Austrian political affairs with one that points to a definite policy of encroachment on Austria's remaining autonomy.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES, on the Southern Korean Front, Aug.11--United States Marines on foot pushed forward again today, advancing from two to three miles west of Kosong along the road parallel to the southern coast of Korea.

A warning that too much emphasis has been placed in recent years on flood control, irrigation and hydro power projects and too little stress on the dredging of our navigable waterways, deep-water channels and harbors has been issued by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)-- Home builders said today that recent Government curbs on mortgages would not check the recordbreaking housing boom until late fall. They said the eventual effect will be a cut of 25 to 30 per cent in home building next year.
LONE PINE, Calif., Aug. 11 (UP) --Searching parties combed the steep slopes of Mount Whitney, highest peak in the United States, today for two 17-year-old New York boys missing for five days.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Aug. 11-- Two thunder squalls raised havoc today with the craft participating in the annual regatta of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association off Timber Point, with more than 25 per cent of the starters failing to finish. The hardest hit class of all was the Narrasketuck, only twenty-eight of a fleet of fifty-two boats completing the race.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11--Arise, the Addison Stable's 1949 winner of the Travers, and Bobby Permane, the comeback kid, combined their talents today at Saratoga to score a two-length victory in the $9,525 American Legion Handicap.

A conference to be held at the Municipal Building Wednesday morning at 10:30 o'clock between Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. and East Harlem civic leader's will start what Mr. Wagner has announced as a new method for more comprehensive planning of the borough.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- Fifty-four persons who had refused to answer questions of its Committee on Un-American Activities were cited today by the House of Representatives for contempt of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--The Army, Navy and Air Force today repeated a request to the press and radio not to divulge large-scale "alerts" of armed forces or their movements within the country.

Although production of paper is held to be more than adequate, runaway price and panic-buying conditions building up in the market are making the industry ripe for swift and drastic controls, trade sources warned yesterday.
GENEVA, Aug. 11--The United Nations Economic and Social Council established today a basis for future action on problems of refugees and stateless persons.

LONDON, Aug. 11--British concern over the implications of United States policy on Formosa has been the subject of discussion between Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador in Washington and Dr. Philip C. Jessup of the State Department.

The 35-year-old mother of two small children, whose husband and brother stand accused of being atomic spies for Russia, was held in $100,000 bail yesterday on a charge of conspiracy to commit espionage.

LOS ANGELES, Aug, 11--A state of "chaos" in the seasonal farm labor field on the West Coast was described today to the President's Commission on Migratory Labor in a remarkably candid exposition by a farm labor contractor who did not exempt himself from blame.
CHICAGO, Aug, 11--The grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade here today with prices swinging rapidly within a fairly wide range.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 11--This vast military reservation is undergoing a conversion process, similar to the emergency period of 19401941, but without the growing pains and confusion that accompanied the sudden expansion of the Army prior to World War II.

A good many people in the country have learned to make it a habit to take most of their questions to the public library. It is no surprise that there are few questions the library is not equipped to handle directly or by giving the location of the agency which can handle it directly.
The problem of where to place "Peter Pan", which must vacate its present home, the Imperial, to make way for the incoming "Call Me Madam" in October, has been resolved, it was learned yesterday.

Stephen J. O'Brien, founder and president of S.J. O'Brien, Inc., electrical contractors, and of S.J. O'Brien Sales Corporation, Frigidaire refrigeration and air-conditioning dealers in Manhattan, died Thursday in Lenox Hill Hospital, after a brief illness. His age was 62.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--Secretary of State Dean Acheson assailed the "dilatory" and obstructive tactics of the Soviet Union's representative to the United Nations Security Council, and accused him of deliberately standing in the way of peace in Korea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--The Army issued today a compulsory call to active duty for, 7,862 reserve captains and lieutenants and for 1,582 medical, dental and veterinary officers, while the Air Force disclosed that its call-up of officers and enlisted men from the reserve would total 50,000 men by early fall.
BERLIN, Aug. 11--The lifting of the West German embargo on shipments of steel to Eastern Germany received official sanction today from the Western Allied High Commission.

Lightning and wind accompanying spotty rainfall caused damage in several sections of the metropolitan area yesterday. A man died in Great Neck, L.I., after lightning had struck near by. Radio Station WGBB in Freeport, L.I., went off the air for twenty minutes after being struck by lightning, and a house in Hicksville, L.I., was demolished by the wind. Telephone and electric service was reported interrupted momentarily on Long Island.

The flotation of new issues of securities has just about dried up and Wall Street expects that the underwriting tide will remain at ebb until after Labor Day. Exceptions seem likely to spring mostly from the wish of local governments to tap the current low-cost market for tax-exempt lending.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP)--Henry Ransom, a transplanted Texan who has won only two major titles in thirteen years of campaigning, shot to the front in the $49,000 Tam O'Shanter "world" golf meet today with a halfway total of 139, five under par.

A program has been started to encourage wider participation in the American Association of Advertising Agencies' monthly interchange of opinion on objectionable advertising, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)-- Exemption from provisions of the proposed Defense Contract Renegotiation Act was asked today by several industries producing raw materials.
TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 11-- Churchgoers who accept Christianity on the sole basis of its "success and decency," were sharply criticized here today by one of the world's leading Protestant churchmen.

Canada's Department of National Defense has canceled a proposed non-stop flight of the new Canadian jet fighter, the Avro CF-100, to the United Kingdom in view of plans to accelerate aircraft production in Canada. The allweather, day-night fighter was to be demonstrated at the Society of British Aircraft Constructors' show at Farnborough, England, next month.

To make cappelletti, the Gusto Ravioli Company, 643 Ninth Avenue, near Forty-fifth Street, employs a method as old as this Italian macaroni product itself. The "little hats" stuffed with meat are fashioned by hand. Its other specialty, ravioli, is turned out with the up-to-the-minute speed and efficiency of a Detroit assembly line.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 11-- A continuance until Aug. 22 was announced today by coroner Theodore E. Steiber in the second session of the inquest he is conducting into the death July 26 of Miss Elizabeth M. Ayres, 74-year-old wealthy Danbury spinster.

RETREATING from its recent gloomy pronouncement concerning the trend in waterfowl population, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service now reports that "the situation on waterfowl breeding grounds this year shows no noticeable improvement over last year at this time."
Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies rose 25.8 per cent in July, according to the compilation covering forty-three concerns made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 11--Sir Gladwyn Jebb of Britain, speaking in the United Nations Security Council today, warned India and the other new countries of Asia that the "dark forces of communism," having been repulsed in Europe, were "concentrating for the kill" against them.

BOSTON, Aug. 11--The Reconstruction Finance Corporation was fined $50,000 for contempt today by Judge George C. Sweeney in Federal District Court, for failure to surrender $500,000 in collateral cash to the Waltham Watch Company.

A REGIMENTAL COMMAND POST, on the Southern Korean Front, Aug. 11--North Koreans came down from the hills as the sun rose this morning and poured small arms fire into the headquarters of this regimental combat team, now on the attack.

Parents who "learned" music appreciation in the grammar grades by memorizing titles of phonograph records reacted with pleased surprise to the series of "musical parties" for children, concluded on Wednesday at Adelphi College, Garden City.

This fall will see the introduction of amateur drama to interpret the Scriptures on a semi-portable square stage in the lower social hall at the John Hall Memorial Presbyterian Church, 342 East Sixty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--President Truman let it be known today that he had decided not to ask Congress to enact a universal military training program at the present session.

Full data on present storage and production facilities are being gathered by the 18,000 members of the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association for the guidance of planning agencies of the Federal Government in their defense plans.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP)--Fred Corcoran, who guides the fortunes of women's golf in the United States, today proposed an open tourney for British women.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12--Labor union leaders who are blueprinting the campaign to retire Senator Robert A. Taft from public life are encountering difficulty in stirring up rank-and-file enthusiasm for Joseph T. Ferguson, his Democratic rival.

SYOSSET, L.I., Aug. 12--Miss Cornelia King Ames, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edgar Ames of Laurel Hollow, was married this afternoon to David Maxwell Abbot, son of Mr, and Mrs. John Radford Abbot of Andover, Mass., in St. John's Protestant Episcopal ...

DEEP in the heart of the Belgian Congo's Ituri Forest, separated by more than 200 miles from the nearest white settlement, stands one of the world's most unusual--and probably one of its most primitive --hotels. Called Camp Putnam, it is run by an American couple who say they prefer life in the jungle to the blessings of Western civilization.

Purchasers of the former P.T. Barnum estate at North Merrick, L.I., announced plans yesterday for construction of 400 mediumprice ranch-style dwellings on the property. In reports from other areas on Long Island, continued building and sales activity was indicated.

WITHIN the past two weeks two contemporary operas have been presented by the opera department of the Berkshire Music Center, at Tanglewood here. The department is under the direction of Jan Popper this summer.

BOONTON, N.J., Aug. 12--The First Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Alison Miller McCain, daughter of Mrs. G. Leonard McCain and the late Rev. Mr. McCain, to Ernest Remer Deming, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Renan Deming of Syracuse, N.Y.

Textile prices moved forward again last week as the result of bullish developments in raw commodities. Manufacturers of cotton and wool goods are generally withdrawn from the market, having sold the great bulk of their capacity for the year.

Building work estimated to cost $224,000,000 was started in New York during the first seven months of 1950, with new residential projects as the feature of current activity, according to preliminary figures compiled by Robert R. Behlow, regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--The Social Security system, on the eve of its fifteenth anniversary, has paid out more than $24,000,000,000 to individual beneficiaries, Oscar R. WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)-- Stiff opposition broke out today to a bill intended to prevent interruption in off-shore oil operations pending final settlement of ownership of the submerged lands.

Dallas County, Tex., announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on Sept. 6 an issue of $6,000,000 of bonds of Road District No. 11, Dated Sept. 10, 1950, the bonds will be due on April 10, 1951 to 1970.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14--The nosetip victory of Greentree Stable's Big Stretch over Phantom Farm's Nullify in the Sanford Stakes today wasn't made official till the stewards had called time-out to talk it over with the jockeys. There had been a squeeze play in the stretch and Nullify was the squeezee.

Rabbi Morris J. Jacobovits, assistant rabbi of Congregation K'Hall Adath Jeshurun, 90 Bennett Avenue, who did much in France under the German occupation to save the lives of Jewish refugees, died on Saturday at his home, 530 Audubon Avenue, after a brief illness. His age was 59.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday net income of $10,532,042 on sales of $76,246,411 in the twelve months ended May 31. In the preceding twelve months the corporation realized a net profit of $12,023,374 on sales of $73,669,182.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Tuesday, Aug. 15 (U.P.)--Marshal Tito put himself on record today as saying in effect Yugoslavia would not automatically fight on the side of the Soviet Union in the event of war between Russia and the United States.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14--The trends of population from rural to urban areas and, at the same time, from cities to their outlying suburbs were singled out as major sources of community, state and even Federal problems today as the National Planning Conference opened its four-day annual meeting here.

The New York World-Telegram and Sun and the Newspaper Guild of New York acceded yesterday to the urgent request of a panel of three Federal mediators that negotiations in the two-month-old strike against the newspaper continue without interruption until a settlement is effected.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug.14--Mrs. Woodbridge Riley of Chestnut Hill has announced the engagement of her daughter, Annette Troth, to Varian Mackey Fry of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Varian Fry of Ridgewood, N.J. The wedding has been planned for November.

PARIS, Aug. 14--The floating of a large-scale international loan, similar to those that financed the Dawes and Young plans after World War I, is expected to be proposed in a new French memorandum on the rearmament of Western Europe. The Paris Cabinet will approve the proposal tomorrow.

Tin futures on the Commodity Exchange here advanced yesterday 200 to 400 points, setting a high record in the local market. The nearby September delivery closed at $1.03 a pound, bid, with offerings at $1.04. In the spot market, dealers were asking $1.06 ...

The stock market adhered yesterday to narrow price movements in the dullest trading in almost two months. Final quotations leaned to the higher side by a small margin. Few exhibited alterations in excess of fractions. As measured by the composite rate, the list was ahead 0.35 point.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 14--Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis won the qualifying medal with a twoover-women's-par 38. 41--79, as the twenty-fifth annual women's Westchester and Fairfield championship got under way over the Wee Burn Country Club course here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--President Truman vetoed today three private bills which would have permitted non-immigrant aliens to remain in the United States. Different reasons led to each veto.
Two subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday plans to increase sheet and tin plate capacity by a total of 315,000 net tons annually in the West.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 (AP)--An 11-run third inning permitted Cincinnati to stand off piecemeal rallies by Pittsburgh today and breeze to a 13-8 victory before 4,306 grown-up fans and 5,547 kiddies.

Top executives of the steel industry, trying to allay the fears of their customers, have been stating in recent weeks that the industry will be able to furnish all the steel needed for military production and still be able to provide enough for high-level civilian production.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--President Truman, in a message to the National Conference on Aging, tonight declared against arbitrary age limits on retirement, especially "at a time like the present when we need increasing production to insure our national security."

Aviation's climb in five years from forty-second place among American industries to wartime first place is being carefully documented by the Baker Library of the Harvard Business School, Cambridge, Mass.

EVERY two years or so amateur tennis takes a haymaker on the chin in the loss of its top player and the viewers with alarm say it is the finish; there's no one left to defend the Davis Cup, and Forest Hills might as well close the stadium gates, except that there's still Gorgeous Gussie.

STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 14 (AP)--British Labor and Conservative members, in a rare show of unity in the European Consultative Assembly, made a strong attack today on the Schuman plan to pool Europe's coal and steel.

Loyalty screenings for the 22,000 civilian volunteers who will constitute the state's aircraft warning service were ordered yesterday by Col. Lawrence Wilkinson, state civil defense director.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., Aug. 14 --Mayor John Leonard of this city today characterized the Coast Guard's report of its investigation into last May's munitions explosion here as the "expected whitewash."
CLEVELAND, Aug. 14 (AP)-- Dale Mitchell grounded to Neil Berry in the bottom of the tenth tonight, sending in Roberto Avila with the winning run as the Indians beat the Tigers, 3--2.

Government need for industrial alcohol will not create a demand for the output of alcoholic beverage industries, distilling executives held here yesterday. Conditions that preceded the last war no longer exist, and industrial alcohol produced from grain now accounts for an extremely small percentage of total output, it was explained.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 14--The Western Big Three Foreign Ministers "undoubtedly" will discuss the question of German rearmament at their meeting next month in New York, according to authoritative United States, British and French sources.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 14-- The national doubles tennis championship started today on the fine turf courts of the Longwood Cricket Club with the best teams of this country and a number of strong foreign combinations in the field.
TOKYO, Aug. 14--Tomorrow marks the fifth anniversary of the surrender of Japan in World War II and the second anniversary of the founding of the Korean Republic under United Nations auspices.

The jewelry industry faces excellent prospects for the fall and Christmas selling period, despite, possible shortages.

Efforts of the packaging industry to prepare for mobilization requirements are meeting little official guidance beyond indications that long-term needs will be on a large scale, trade sources said yesterday.

A new round of wool carpet price increases will be put into effect by major mills on or about Sept. 1, a leading retail source predicted yesterday. The latest industry-wide advance would be the sixth since last November.

LONDON, Aug. 14--Arrangements were made today for Winston Churchill, leader of the Conservative party, and Anthony Eden, his deputy, to see Prime Minister Attlee on Wednesday and explain their reasons for requesting the prompt recall of the British Parliament for a defense debate next week.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 15--Infantrymen of the Twenty-fourth Division slugged ahead today in a drive to wipe out the Communist bridgehead across the Naktong River defense line southwest of Changnyong, most serious threat all along the front to the United Nations 140-mile perimeter in Korea.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 14-- Corbin Wheeler, head of an insurance and real estate business he had conducted here for fifty years, died this morning at the North Country Community Hospital. He would have been 73 on Sept, 12.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 14-- The last pair to finish, Mike Turnesa and Fred Fiore of Knollwood caused a tie for the Westchester pro-amateur golf championship as they turned in a best-ball gross score of 63 at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14--The country's output of goods and services, running at an annual rate of $270,000,000,000 in the second quarter of 1950, reached a new all-time high level, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Velvet is the fabric key to fashion this fall. Its touch is almost everywhere, used as an enriching accent or in its entirety. Jake La Motta agreed yesterday to defend his middleweight title against Laurent Dauthuille of France, the No. 2 challenger, in Detroit's Olympia Stadium Sept. 13. The fighters signed at the offices of the International Boxing Club here.
KELLOGG, Iowa, Aug. 14 (U.P.)-- A couple identified as Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wynes of Dubuque, Iowa, and three children were killed today when a private plane crashed in a cornfield west of here.

On Aug. 15, 1947, the Commonwealths of India and Pakistan assumed their independent--and divided--existence. They celebrate today, the third anniversary of that event, in an atmosphere somewhat more hopeful than at any time previously. There are still difficult problems to be solved, but notable progress has been made during the past year.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Z. Sherman of 300 Central Park West, of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Joan, to Milton L. Albert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Albert of Brooklyn and Amityville, L.I. The wedding is planned for December.

NASHUA, N.H., Aug. 14 (AP)-- Samuel Arthur Williams, who rose through the ranks from a laborer at 15 cents per hour to be vice president of the Johns-Manville Corporation, died in Nashua Hospital last night. His age was 67. He lived in Scarsdale, N.Y., until his retirement a few years ago.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 14--George Nichols, a former Commodore of the New York Yacht Club, who was one of the greatest yachtsmen in the history of the sport in the United States, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

HONG KONG, Aug. 15--An increasing number of laborers are being inducted into the Chinese Communist party as part of a multiphased drive designed to increase the party's proletarian element, correct "authoritarian methods of work" and strentghen relations between the party and Chinese masses on a united front basis.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 15-- Jack Bromwich, Frank Sedgman, Kenneth McGregor and George Worthington were named today as the team that will represent Australia in the Davis Cup challenge round against the United States at Forest Hills on Aug. 25, 26 and 27.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 15--Pending further clarification, the United States and other members of the Security Council are reserving their position on an Indian suggestion for the establish ment of a committee of six to submit recommendations for a peaceful settlement in Korea.
A lone mariner set sail yesterday in a thirty-four-foot yawl, supplied with nothing more than courage and a few provisions, on his second crossing of the Atlantic Ocean.

The supreme convention of the Knights of Columbus opened yesterday on the deeply religious note of the Roman Catholic Feast of the Assumption, marked by a parade and a solemn pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 15-- With the arrival today of thirty recruits from six countries to take up police and security training, the United Nations announced that its plans to set up a permanent service of 300 guards to protect its peace missions in the field were shaping up on schedule.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--Bowled over, 10 to 5, in the afternoon encounter of their day and night program with Bucky Harris' rambunctious Senators, the Yankees appeared to be facing their darkest hour on the banks of the Potomac tonight, when their young lefty, Eddie Ford, turned them sharply about and put them on a winning course again.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP)--Walt Dropo, flashy rookie Red Sox first baseman suffered a cerebral concussion tonight when "beaned" by Athletics' Pitcher Hank Wyse in the first game of a twilight-night doubleheader which Boston won by scores of 8--3 and 9--4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--Negotiations between the major railroads of the country and two of the railroad brotherhoods to settle a wage dispute that has lasted nearly a year and a half were broken off here today in a hopeless deadlock. The most recent negotiations have taken place under White House auspices.

There is a sound reason why the official handbook on the effects of atomic weapons, issued by the Department of Defense and the Atomic Energy Commission as a guide in planning and executing effective civilian defense measures against possible attacks by atomic bombs, describes in detail the various spectacular phenomena accompanying an atomic explosion.

Shipments of Youngstown kitchen sink and cabinet units to the metropolitan area have dropped one-third in the last two weeks. This was revealed yesterday by Samuel A. Weirs, president of Weiss Besserman Co., Inc., metropolitan area distributor for the Mullins Manufacturing Corporation, producers of Youngstown appliances.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--The Senate voted unanimously today to halt one-year enlistments in the armed services of 18-year-old youths.

The stock market remained bogged down yesterday in its midsummer rut with only minor price changes except in certain issues. Despite the cautious slow trading, the list again edged irregularly higher. While a few stocks responded to favorable earnings reports and dividend actions, the composite rate rose only 0.12 point.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 15--The marriage of Miss Edith Le Witt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Le Witt of New Britain, Conn., to Leonard Ryder Myers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Myers of West Hartford, took place here this afternoon in Temple Beth Israel. The Rev. Dr. Abraham J. Feldman performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Tumble Brook Country Club in Bloomfield.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and prices declined 2 to 17 points.

LONDON, Aug. 15--Prime Minister Attlee said in a statement published today that there were "dangerous possibilities" in the situation caused by the decision of the United States to defend Formosa against a possible Chinese Communist assault.

A water storage loss of 834,000,000 gallons in the twenty-four hours ended 8 A.M. yesterday brought the total decline of supplies in thirty-two consecutive days of such losses to 18,369,000,000 gallons.

Thousands of volunteer workers and a full mobilization of trained medical and nursing personnel will be needed to cope with an outbreak of atomic warfare in which New York is a target, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday.

Meetings of stockholders of the Bankers Trust Company and the Lawyers Trust Company are to be held on Sept. 14 to vote on merging these institutions into an enlarged Bankers Trust Company, according to a joint announcement...

SOME anglers not only want big fish, but a lot of them, and there seems to be something of a weight-hauling marathon cropping up in big-game angling circles these days, which the skippers insist is nothing more than another aspect of the ailment known as tuna-mania.

The task of the European Recovery Program will not be achieved by 1952, when it is scheduled to end, but "a splendid start will have been made," Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower writes in a report on the progress and prospects of American aid to Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--At least 50,000 men will be called by Selective Service in November besides the 100,000-man induction call set for September and October, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national director of Selective Service, said today.

Homemakers returning from summer vacations to apartments and houses laden with city dust and soot may find some consolation in the accumulation of available aide to make their cleaning chores lighter. New gadgets and appliances falling into this group range from a small sponge to a low-cost electric floor polisher.

The Glidden-Buick Company, after twenty-six years ownership and occupancy, has sold the fourstory and basement automobile building at 3261-75 Broadway to William Solomon for cash, according to Arthur S. Thomases, broker who negotiated the deal and will manage the property for the new owner. The assessed valuation is $475,000.

TAEGU, Korea, Aug. 16--This is a handy compendium of useful information for travelers in this country, called the Switzerland of the Orient by some but not by any of the many Americans who have flocked here this season. They refer to it strictly in unprintable terms.
The Propeller Club of the United States announced yesterday award of nine prizes to newspaper men for the best coverage of American merchant marine developments during the year ended June 30, 1950.

Smoking a curved-stem pipe in Drawing Room A of car 540 on the Embassy, Pennsylvania Railroad express from Washington, Ambassador-Designate William O'Dwyer returned to the city last night from the capital.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 15--One match that went extra holes, one that finished on the eighteenth green and a disqualification marked the first round of match play in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship at the Wee Burn Country Club course today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--American invention in fields related to armed conflict is far ahead of its position at the outbreak of World War II, Dr. Charles F. Kettering said today.

Eddie Stanky probably was ready to hang himself from the highest hook in his locker last night. The Brat made a serious error in the second inning of the series opener between the Dodgers and Giants which gave the Brooks an unearned run.
NECEDAH, Wis., Aug. 15 (UP)-- While an estimated 100,000 persons looked on a 40-year-old farm wife raised her eyes to the heavens today and said that the Virgin Mary had appeared and spoken to her.
The desirability of the "released time" system for religious instruction in school hours came in for frank discussion yesterday by representatives of leading religious groups and teachers.

WHO was Perkin Warbech? If you know, you know more English history than 99 out of 100 American college graduates. Yet 455 years ago a young man with that unlikely name (an English manhandling of Pierre de Werbecque) was exciting much of Western Europe and giving that wily Welsh monarch, Henry VII, many an uneasy moment.

TORONTO, Aug. 15--Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, told the World Convention on Christian Education today that the "moral foundations" of the free nations of the world would assume more importance during the next fifty years than "at any other time since the Dark Ages."

LONDON, Aug. 15--Princess Elizabeth's second child was born today. It was a girl and the nation was delighted. The baby Princess, sister of Prince Charles, who was born twenty-one months ago, weighed six pounds.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 (AP)--Art Houtteman pitched Detroit into a more comfortable spot atop the American League today, defeating Cleveland by 4 to 1 before a crowd of 40,299.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 15 (AP)--The United States Army in Germany is starting a "get friendly" campaign with the German populace."

WASHINGTON, Aug, 15--A zipsleeve raincoat for women and a shower-shelter poncho for children --functional designs worked out by the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics--were modeled today at the Department of Agriculture.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 15 (AP)-- Premier Ali Razmara announced that the Russians had today released one Iranian officer and three soldiers captured seven months ago in a border clash east of the Caspian Sea.
GENEVA, Aug, 15--The United Nations Economic and Social Council adopted today an elaborate long-range program for combating economic depression and unemployment.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 15 --Personnel consultants retained last spring by the Westchester Board of Supervisors reported today that county employes receiving less than $4,000 a year are overpaid and those in higher brackets are underpaid. Salaries in similar jobs elsewhere were used for comparative purposes in the survey.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 15-- Miss Bernice Mittlacher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Mittlacher, was married to Walter Emerson Rosenberger, son of Mrs. Walter E. Rosenberger and the late Mr. Rosenberger, here tonight in the West Side Presbyterian Church. The Rev. John Reid performed the ceremony.

The possibility of making automobile insurance compulsory was raised tentatively yesterday as a State Joint Legislative Committee studied the insurance problems of people living in such congested areas as Harlem and Coney Island. The committee, headed by State Senator William F. Condon of Westchester, heard seventeen witnesses testify at the Bar Association building, 42 West Fortyfourth Street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15--The grain markets staged a strong rally in the late trading on the Board of Trade here today after being sharply lower early, led by soybeans which were off more than 4 cents a bushel at one time.

First Gallon, Mrs. Ruth Emmett's 5-year-old bay, registered an incredible 9-length victory in the featured Hastings Pace as harness racing returned to Yonkers Raceway for a 12-night meeting last night. Covering the mile in 2:06, a clocking that tied the track record, First Gallon made only one move and that was perfectly timed by Joe O'Brien, who was in the sulky.

TOKYO, Aug. 15 (AP)--The shock divisions of the North Korean army--more than 60,000 foreigntrained officers and men--have been cut nearly in two by Casualties, United States intelligence officers estimated today. They put the figure at "40 per cent and up."

Crude rubber futures in the nearby September delivery again declined the permissible limit of 200 points, or 2 cents a pound, on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday. The December contract sold off 98 points, but the more active distant deliveries finished 50 to 70 points above Monday's final figures.
In drab green dungarees and field packs, with rifles slung over their shoulders, the First Infantry Battalion, Marine Corps Reserve, marched off yesterday to probable war.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (AP)-- The Phillies increased their National League lead to six games over the runner-up Braves tonight, by winning, 9 to 1, before 32,215. Army-bound Curt Simmons received credit for his fifteenth pitching victory but needed help from the ever reliable fireman, Jim Konstanty, who made his fiftythird appearance of the year.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Aug. 15--West German economic leaders are expecting a "war boom," and have undertaken to prepare for it. The first signs of a sharp upward trend in production and other prosperity indexes already are apparent.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 15-- Gov. Chester Bowles called today for the institution of price controls on building materials as a vital aid to civil defense planning.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Aug. 15-- New Political developments are expected within the sphere of authority of the new French Union state of Vietnam after the conclusion of the Pau conference in France. The grant of power to the city commissioners to regulate goats in the District of Columbia may be of immediate concern to a good many inhabitants of the District of Columbia; but it isn't of much interest to the remaining 150,000,000 people of the United States.
Organized gambling in war plants, which went on in full fever during World War II, is getting special attention from Federal investigators now that arms production is again of major importance.

Net income of Eastman Kodak Company for the twenty--four weeks ended on last June 11 was 21 per cent above that for the corresponding period of 1949. Sales were less than 1 per cent greater than in 1949, Perley S. Wilcox, chairman, and Thomas J. Hargrave, president, reported yesterday.

The News Syndicate Company, publishers of the New York Daily News, has completed the assembly of a site for its new radio station by purchasing the property at the southwest corned of Forty-second Street and Second Avenue. It previously had acquired adjoining properties.

ALBANY. Aug. 15 (AP)--New York politics, which has been bubbling quietly in advance of next month's state conventions, will boil over in scattered sectors next Tuesday, when five United States representatives fight at the polls for their political lives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--A tremendous increase in electric power production at Niagara Falls was urged today by Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat-Liberal of New York, when he appeared before the House Public Works Committee to press his bill for greater use of the Niagara River water near the falls.
Through tighter control of expenditures and further extension of mechanization plans, the West ern Union Telegraph Company has reversed a trend that had losses as its feature.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 15-- Australia's two teams advanced without the loss of a set in the national doubles tennis championship at the Longwood Cricket Club today and William Talbert and Gardnar Mulloy, winners of the title four times, moved ahead by default.

When it comes to clothes, some of us love wool, others cotton--so why not combine the two? This is the thinking behind some of the smartest fall fabrics. Unique qualities of the two fabrics are combined, thereby creating an entirely new and exciting material.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--Never take anything for granted, baseball's outstanding academic minds have long told us, anything can happen.

LYNDHURST, Ont., Aug. 15-- Dr. William T. Ellis, a newspaper writer whose work has been continuously syndicated for the last fifty-three years, died in his summer home near here today at the age of 76.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--The first National Conference on Aging, closing here today, was credited by Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing with starting a crusade similar in importance to those against child labor and for women's suffrage.
GENEVA, Aug. 15--Evidence on the working of the forced-labor system in the Communist world was submitted to the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations today by the British Government.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15--Russia has been trying for a year to exchange petroleum products for Spanish quicksilver, Jose Barcelo, Madrid, said today at a news conference at the Navy pier office of the First United States International Trade Fair. Mr. Barcelo, economic adviser to the Spanish Government, is here to report on the fair.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 16 (AP)--North Korean officials made their first mention today of the "friendly support of the Soviet Army" in their battle for South Korea.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15-- Jerry Wald and Norman Krasna, newly established producing team at R.K.O., today announced the titles of eight screen stories which they have conceived or written themselves and expect to use in their twelve-picture-a-year program for R.K.O.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 15-- Charles Metcalf Allen, professor emeritus, noted for his work in hydraulic engineering while on the faculty of Worcester Polytechnic Institute, died today at his home in near-by Holden. He was 78 years old.

Representatives of the Newspaper Guild of New York, C.I.O., and The World-Telegram and Sun met yesterday for five and a half hours in an attempt to settle the strike that has prevented publication of the newspaper since June 13.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 15-- Joseph Pholien, Belgian Senator, became Premier today of a new Government dedicated to the promotion of unity and harmony around Prince Baudouin.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 15 (AP) --Mrs. Dave Hennen Morrris of New York, widow of the former United States Ambassador to Belgium and Minister to Luxembourg, died at her summer cottage, Bogue Chitto, today. Her age was 75.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 15--William Bradford Greeley, retired New York patent attorney and a leader in Wildlife preservation, died here last night in his home at 230 Drake Avenue. His age was 90.

Extra compensation to employes who leave for war or defense service will be paid by 107 out of 119 New York business concerns that have definite military leave policies, according to a survey made public yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

Maintaining that complete enforcement of Interstate Commerce Commission and Coast Guard regulations has not always been possible because of limited personnel, the National Board of Fire Underwriters urged yesterday establishment of state or local safeguards th prevent disasters such as the munitions explosion in South Amboy, N.J., last May.
The first recruiting station in this area for the joint use of all the armed services is to be opened Sept. 1 in Times Square, between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--Harold E. Stassen called tonight for a Congressional declaration that a further Communist military assault anywhere in the world would mean that "war will come to Moscow, to the Urals and to the Ukraine."

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP)--Miss Marjorie Lindsay, a veteran campaigner, today outlasted a former national amateur champion, Miss Grace Lenczyk,in a marathon 23hole battle featuring the opening match-play round of the Women's Western amateur golf tourney.

CAIRO, Aug. 15--Neither Iraqi Premier Tawfik Suwaidi nor his Deputy Premier, both of whom had attended the previous meeting of the Arab League, came to Egypt for the session of the League's Political Committee, which opened tonight in Alexandria.

A cooperative agreement, expected to result in color television for industrial, business, hospital, governmental and military use, was concluded yesterday by Remington Rand, Inc., and the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Plans for new garden apartments in Rutherford, Hillside and Springfield, N.J., have just been announced by builders.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 15--Democratic leaders in Congress decided today to proceed with all speed toward passage of President Truman's recommendations for control of subversive activities in this country. These were contained in a message he sent to the Capitol on Aug. 8.
The Government of Canada has decided to refund only half of the issue of $100,000,000 of bonds which it has called for payment on Oct. 1.
A tall young woman from San Diego discovered yesterday that times have changed--but not very much. In short, people still make a fuss over someone who swims the English Channel.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15--Express highways, while doing much to relieve the traffic congestion with which most large cities are afflicted, may create more problems than they solve if not planned carefully, the American Society of Planning Officials was warned today.

City Stores Company will offer today 149,317 shares of its $5 par value common stock in exchange for outstanding preferred and common stocks of its subsidiaries, Oppenheim, Collins Co., Inc., and Franklin Simon Co., Inc.

The Kings County grand jury investigating Mayor O'Dwyer's accusation that the Brooklyn gambling inquiry was "a witch hunt" handed its written reply to this charge to Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz yesterday. But he refused to accept it.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 15-- From Kashmir to Cape Comorin and from the Arabian Sea to the Bengal Bay Indians celebrated today the third anniversary of their independence with renewed determination to surmount numerous difficulties, some new and others ages old.

Active sales of homes are continuing in many parts of Queens despite upset world conditions. Reports from brokers yesterday showed many purchases in Forest Hills; in new projects at Little Neck; in Kew Gardens Hills and Flushing.

John Galm, supervisor of menageries at the Central and Prospect Park Zoos, leaned back in a chair in his office yesterday and spoke of the Central Park's newest acquisition--a two-andone-half-ton unnamed bull hippopotamus.

Demand for American-made machinery and equipment in Pakistan is growing rapidly, J. Russell Andrus, first secretary and consul in Karachi, told members of the Com merce and Industry Association yesterday. Mr. Andrus recently returned from that country.

Cunard officials announced yesterday that a cargo of Russian crab meat that longshoremen had refused to unload here Monday from the liner Parthia would be returned to England. Reports that Mayor O'Dwyer would not serve out the full term of four years to which he was re-elected last November have been heard so often and over so long a period that the confirmation yesterday produces only mild surprise.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 15--The Rev. Arthur Johnston, pastor of Mt. Ida Memorial Presbyterian Church for 26 years, who retired on May 1 because of failing health, died last night in the Samaritan Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 64 years old.
